HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:
This has been the week of "Beauty and the Beast" in video stores. Disney reports that seven million copies of the tape were sold in its first six days on the shelves. While distributors and dealers can't confirm that figure, many say "Beauty and the Beast" is the fastest-selling title ever.
Now comes another animated film on tape, also associated with Disney, that is distinctive for another reason. Next week Lightyear Entertainment will release "The Snow Queen," the fairy tale by Hans Christian Andersen. The 30-minute tape, which is narrated by Sigourney Weaver, is part of the "Stories to Remember" series of children's animated films. On Nov. 14 it will be shown on the Disney Channel. 
 "The Snow Queen" was animated at the Klassika studio in Moscow. Joshua Greene, the producer of "Stories to Remember," said it was the first children's video to be made in Russia for distribution in the United States. Mr. Greene said he chose Klassika because of a distinguished tradition of Soviet animation that dates to the 30's when Russian animators were trained by Disney. He also said he had gone to Moscow to make the film as economically as possible.
At first, Mr. Greene said, there was friction. Klassika's animators were just starting out on their own, he said. "They were desperate to start a studio and we were their only channel to a source of dollars. They didn't know whether we'd try to exploit that."
The Russians had virtually no equipment, so Mr. Greene and his American associates donated crates of materials, from pencils and paints to an animation camera. "It helped to show that we were willing to put something back," Mr. Greene said.
But interpretation of "The Snow Queen," the subject of a famous Soviet animated film of the 40's, presented philosophical problems. The story involves a boy abducted and held prisoner in an icy land and the girl who survives many perils to free him. In the American way of storytelling, everything works out.
"The Russian perspective is starker than what Americans are accustomed to," Mr. Greene said. "They have a bleaker view of fairy tales. It's more reality than fantasy. I'm not sure they were comfortable with everything coming out happy."
With the film to appear on the Disney Channel, softer characterizations were agreed upon. "The Russians like their children earthy, not as prosperous or as innocent," Mr. Greene said. Again the American view prevailed and the characters remain robust and their attitudes steadfastly upbeat.
On other matters, however, the Russian view won out. For instance, pursuing wolves were fiercer than fuzzier American versions.
With results acceptable to both parties, a second collaboration -- "The Wild Swans" -- is under way. "The Snow Queen" is $12.98. Information: (800) 229-7867.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
Sister Act
1992. Touchstone. $19.99. 1:40. CC. PG.
In a none-too-original turn of events, a lounge singer (Whoopi Goldberg) crosses a vengeful gangster (Harvey Keitel) and hides out in a convent disguised as a nun. There, she takes charge of the choir, a sort of ecclesiastical dirty dozen. There's the plump, perky nun, the shy nun, the gruff but nice nun. As the black nun, Ms. Goldberg warms to her chores and soon the group is singing so well they charm the Pope, get on some magazine covers and look solid for a string of performance gigs in a film that, Janet Maslin wrote in The Times, is full of "cute, synthetic uplift."
 
Uranus
1992. HBO. $89.99. 1:40. French with English subtitles. R.
In Claude Berri's film, a French village copes with its behavior during the Nazi occupation. A collaborator on the run (Gerard Desarthe) takes refuge in the house of Archambaud (Jean-Pierre Marielle Gaigneux), a philosophical fellow who regards his actions with tolerance. Mr. Berri ("Jean de Florette" and "Manon of the Spring") takes a neutral stance to ask whether collaborators are worthy of forgiveness and how guilty are passive observers who ignore or rationalize whatever they witnessed. Gerard Depardieu, as a bombastic barkeeper, and Philippe Noiret, as a boarder with recurring nightmares involving the planet Uranus, are but two of many characters in a "bleak examination of human nature, which survives any way it can" (Caryn James).
 
Prospero's Books
1991. Fox. $89.98. 2:09. R.
John Gielgud portrays the old duke exiled with his books in Shakespeare's elegiacal last play, "The Tempest." From there Peter Greenaway's film takes apart the original to examine the worlds and creatures in the duke's prized volumes. While rich and fascinating to a point, the sheer range of Mr. Greenaway's imagination and enthusiasms overwhelms the confines of the film and inundates the viewer with a wild and confusing tangle of images that becomes "too much for mortal eye and ear" (Vincent Canby).
 
The Donner Party
1992. Direct Cinema, (800) 933-7991. $39.95. 1:26. No rating.
Trapped for months by 22 feet of snow in the Sierra Nevada during the winter of 1846-47, a group of settlers resorted to cannibalism to survive. Ric Burns's film, which was broadcast on "The American Experience" on PBS last week, uses archival material in the same way he and his brother Ken did in their acclaimed documentary "The Civil War." With old photographs and the effective use of music and scenic stills setting a chilling tone, a famous American story unfolds in a measured, unsparing account, deepened by "eloquent and well-delivered passages from diaries and the thoughtful observations of historians" (Walter Goodman).
 
FROM YEARS PAST
 
Films That Made the Leap From Stage to Screen.
This month MGM/UA will release "Two for the Seesaw," Robert Wise's film of the William Gibson play, and 10 other films adapted from notable stage works. Here are some other screen adaptations on tape.
 THE MEMBER OF THE WEDDING. Fred Zinneman directs Julie Harris in a film of Carson McCullers's novel and play about coming of age in the South. 1953. Columbia Tri-Star. $69.95. 1:29. No rating.
 LOOK BACK IN ANGER. Tony Richardson directs Richard Burton, Claire Bloom, Mary Ure and Edith Evans in the film of John Osborne's play about family alienation. 1959. United American Video. $19.95. 1:39. No rating.
 A RAISIN IN THE SUN. Sidney Poitier stars in the film of Lorraine Hansberry's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about domestic conflict in Chicago. 1961. Columbia Tri-Star. $19.95. 2:08. No rating.
 LONG DAY'S JOURNEY INTO NIGHT. Katharine Hepburn, Ralph Richardson and Jason Robards Jr. star in Sidney Lumet's film of the Eugene O'Neill play. 1962. Republic. $19.95. 2:16. No rating.
 A SOLDIER'S STORY. Howard E. Rollins Jr. stars in Norman Jewison's film of Charles Fuller's play about a murder in an all-black military unit. 1984. MGM/UA. $14.95. 1:41. PG.
 DEATH OF A SALESMAN. Dustin Hoffman reprises his Broadway performance as Willy Loman in Volker Schlondorff's film of the Arthur Miller play. 1985. Warner. $19.95. 2:14. CC. No rating.
 PLENTY. Fred Schepisi's film of David Hare's drama about the postwar problems of a resistance fighter stars Meryl Streep. 1985. HBO. $19.95. 2:04. R.
 THE GLASS MENAGERIE. Paul Newman directs Joanne Woodward as the aging belle Amanda Wingfield and John Malkovich as her son Tom in the Tennessee Williams play. 1987. MCA/Universal. $79.99. LD, $39.98. 2:10. PG.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Do Early Birds Catch a Pink Slip?

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
Bob Quinn struck early last year and see where it got him -- unemployed.
Quinn, general manager of the Cincinnati Reds at the time, didn't wait for the annual winter meetings to make deals that he saw as critical in shoring up the weaknesses that wrecked the team's chances of successfully defending their 1990 World Series championship. 
 In the latter half of November, the Reds acquired Greg Swindell from Cleveland and Tim Belcher from Los Angeles, giving them a solid starting pitching rotation. The Reds, however, encountered problems this year and did not win their division championship. Marge Schott, the owner, designated Quinn as the scapegoat and fired him.
Quinn's downfall does not mean that Al Harazin and Gene Michael have jeopardized their jobs. Actually, with George Steinbrenner on the way back, Michael doesn't have to do anything to lose his job; Steinbrenner doesn't need a reason to fire his employees.
Michael is the Yankees' general manager, Harazin the Mets' general manager. Conversation about the exciting last game of the World Series had hardly died down when they each made a trade.
Harazin took advantage of the San Diego Padres' fire sale and plucked Tony Fernandez to be the Mets' shortstop. Michael knew the Yankees needed a left-handed power hitter and took advantage of the bad season Paul O'Neill had with the Reds to bring him to Yankee Stadium.
The Mets' trade raised questions among the usual skeptics about Fernandez's physical condition. Something had to be wrong with him for the Padres to give him away for Wally Whitehurst and D. J. Dozier. Skeptics, though, are too busy finding fault to see the obvious.
Joe McIlvaine, the Padres' general manager, is under orders to reduce the Padres' payroll. Shedding Fernandez's $2.3 million salary was the easiest first step, though a painful one considering the shortstop's talent. McIlvaine actually did his old team a favor by letting them have Fernandez. Considering that he knew he wouldn't get much in return, McIlvaine could just as easily have traded him elsewhere.
The Yankees' acquisition of O'Neill has raised questions, too. Why, the skeptics ask, would the Yankees trade Roberto Kelly for a player who batted .246, hit 14 home runs and drove in 66 runs? The point is, if O'Neill had hit 28 home runs and driven in 91 runs, as he did the year before, the Reds never would have considered trading him.
The Yankees are counting on a strong comeback from O'Neill, who in a bizarre twist could wind up feeling less harassed with the Yankees than he was with the Reds. This, of course, is before he encounters Steinbrenner for the first time.
According to a friend of O'Neill's, the outfielder felt intimidated by his manager, Lou Piniella, who often worked with him on his hitting. Piniella is a fanatic on hitting and always has been. When he played for the Yankees, he once stood at home plate minutes before opening-day ceremonies, holding an imaginary bat and swinging at imaginary pitches.
Piniella, who left the Reds after this season, is a great believer in the mechanics of hitting, and he believes that the more a player works on his mechanics, the more natural his weight shift and swing become.
But Piniella apparently did not connect with O'Neill, and at least some of O'Neill's drop-off could be attributed to the pressure the player felt from the manager. Sometimes, his friend said, when O'Neill returned to the dugout after making an out, he went to the opposite end from where Piniella was because he didn't want to listen to the manager tell him what he had done wrong.
O'Neill could hear plenty of that from Steinbrenner, but at least it won't be in the dugout.
The Yankees, meanwhile, would like the O'Neill trade to be an omen reminiscent of 1979. Just days after Michael became the club's general manager the first time, the Yankees made two trades on Nov. 1.
To replace Thurman Munson, who was killed when his plane crashed the previous August, they got Rick Cerone from Toronto in a six-player trade in which Chris Chambliss went to the Blue Jays. They also acquired Tom Underwood in the deal. The same day they obtained center fielder Ruppert Jones from Seattle in another six-player trade.
A week later, they signed Bob Watson and Rudy May as free agents.
In 1980, Watson led the Yankees in hitting with a .307 average and was third in runs batted in with 68. Cerone batted .277 and knocked in 85 runs, second to Reggie Jackson's 111 r.b.i. May compiled a 15-5 record, Underwood 13-9, giving the Yankees four pitchers with 13 or more victories.
They did not do as well with Jones, who was limited to 83 games because of physical ailments. But they won 103 games and the division championship, the last full-season division championship they won.
The Yankees aren't in position to make that much out of the trade for O'Neill, but maybe it's a start.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Backer Spielvogel's Heir Apparent

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
After intense speculation, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide made clear who is most likely to succeed Carl Spielvogel as chairman and chief executive. The agency yesterday named Michael Bungey president and to the new post of chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.
Mr. Bungey, 52 years old, is currently chairman and chief executive of BSB Dorland and chairman of BSB Europe, based in London. He will succeed William M. Backer, 66, as president. Mr. Backer was named vice chairman and retains the position of worldwide executive creative director. Successors for both of Mr. Bungey's positions will be named by the end of the year. 
In an interview, Mr. Spielvogel put an end to the long guessing game. Mr. Bungey, he said, "is positioned in the line of succession," adding, "A final decision will be made in the latter part of 1993." Mr. Spielvogel, 63, said he would remain chairman and chief executive of the $5 billion agency until the end of 1993 and serve as chairman through 1994.
Mr. Bungey was one of three executives believed in the running to head the agency's 167 offices in 50 countries. The others were Kenneth R. Rogers, 46, chairman and chief executive of Backer Spielvogel Inc. and chairman of the Americas region based in New York, and Alex Hamill, 53, chairman and chief executive of George Patterson Pty., and chairman of the Asia-Pacific region, based in Sydney, Australia.
As has the the rest of the industry, Backer Spielvogel has been hit hard by the recession. Over the years the agency has lost $230 million from accounts like Dole, Fisher-Price and Miller Lite.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 920 words

HEADLINE: As for All That Lore About Foolproof Predictors, '92 Made It Look Foolish

 BODY:
Like shamanism and advanced medicine, election lore and modern polling have been matching their predictive powers against each other for decades. On Tuesday night, the competition ended. It was a rout.
The infallible New Hampshire primary rule failed. The prophetic Weekly Reader survey yielded an incorrect prophecy. And the voters of Crook County, Ore., who had picked the winning Presidential candidate for the last 27 elections, this time chose the loser. 
 "It's over," the Crook County deputy clerk, Evelyn Adams, said, declaring the county's winning streak finished with a low chuckle.
So eager are Americans to find out who the next President is going to be that hardly anyone wants to wait any more to see how the actual vote comes out. Indeed, there is almost no limit to the auguries used to determine the outcome of the election before it takes place. There are astrology charts, economic indicators and bellwether counties. There is the Beaujoulais harvest rule, the World Series rule and the left-handed incumbent rule.
When, on the basis of the public opinion polls, political analysts called 1992 an unpredictable year, they didn't know the half of it, it seems.
 
Stars Go Blank for Dixon
 Jeane Dixon, the syndicated astrologer, once could boast a flawless record prophecizing the next President. Then, over the summer, she said that the stars pointed definitively to George Bush.
Joyce Jillson, another well-known astrologer, also got her planets crossed. Starting Oct. 11, the date of the first Presidential debate, the heavens, she said, "almost cinch it for President Bush."
Closer to earth, Ray C. Fair, a professor of economics at Yale University, developed a formula that uses the inflation rate, the per capita growth rate and an assortment of constants to predict the Presidency. Before Tuesday, it had come up with the winner in 16 out of the last 19 elections. The only times it had missed--1960, 1968 and 1976--were in extremely close races.
This year, Mr. Fair's model predicted that President-elect Bill Clinton would be defeated in a landslide.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Fair said that perhaps the model could be adjusted in a way that would preserve its utility. Or perhaps, he conceded, "You just have to dump it."
Ever since the current primary system came into being in 1952, no President has been elected who did not first win the New Hampshire primary. No President, that is, except Mr. Clinton, who came in second in New Hampshire, behind former Senator Paul E. Tsongas.
Similarly, until Tuesday, no Democratic candidate had ever won the Presidency without carrying Texas. Mr. Clinton lost the state to President Bush, 40 percent to 37 percent, with 22 percent of the vote going to Ross Perot.
 
Best Lesson Is Failure
 "The big lesson here," said Tom Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, "may be don't use the old lessons."
Two decades ago, there were half a dozen counties across the country that, through some uncanny link to the national political psyche, had perfect Presidential voting records. By 1988, there was only one such county left, Crook County, which chose the winner in every Presidential election since it was founded. Now there are none.
"This blew it right out of the water, Ms. Adams, the county's deputy clerk, said. The final tally for the county was: 2,702 votes for Mr. Bush, 2,509 for Mr. Clinton and 2,001 for Mr. Perot.
Maybe it used to be the case that out of the mouth of babes came correct predictions. But in 1992, even this is no longer true.
Ever since 1956, the Weekly Reader, a magazine for children, has correctly predicted the President by polling its young audience. This year, the magazine's readers chose Mr. Bush over Mr. Clinton, 58 percent to 36 percent.
At one time, the outcome of World Series series also was a reliable indicator of who would win the White House: if the American League won, the Republican candidate would become President. But those days are definitely over. The American League rule proved a dud in 1980, 1988 and now again, less than a month after the Toronto Blue Jays won the series, in 1992.
Perhaps most disappointing of all is the collapse of the old rule: in vino veritas.
Michael Lewis-Beck, a professor of political science at the University of Iowa, noted that one of the lesser known rules of Presidential predicting is a poor Beaujoulais harvest augurs a Republican administration. Recently Mr. Lewis-Beck called some vintners in France to see whether the rule would survive. The grapes were calling the election for President Bush.
 
Settling for Near-Miss
 So what's left for 1996? According to Mr. Lewis-Beck, who wrote a book on forecasting elections, not much.
For those who are willing to settle for the near-miss, he offered Mexico, which has voted for the winning candidate in ever election except 1976. It did so again on Tuesday, giving Mr. Clinton 46 percent of its vote, to Mr. Bush's 38 percent.
Similarly, Palo Alto County, Iowa voted for the victorious candidate in every election from 1896 to 1980; it missed in 1984, but voted correctly in 1988 and again on Tuesday.
Mr. Lewis-Beck noted that there is one rule that has managed to survive completely intact, and that is that no left-handed President wins a second term. The rule worked for President James Garfield, President Gerald Ford and now President Bush.
It does not bode particularly well for President-elect Clinton, a southpaw.

LENGTH: 775 words

HEADLINE: Ten Reasons to Feel Good

 BODY:
Beyond all the political facts and figures -- what Adm. James Stockdale derides as "all of the little stinky numbers" -- Tuesday's election evoked a whole web of feelings, reasons for satisfaction, and not just for Democrats.
The Lines. All those people huddled under umbrellas outside Manhattan precincts gave a reliable clue to remarkable voter turnout everywhere. About 104 million people voted, 55 percent of those eligible. According to Curtis Gans, a voting scholar, that's the highest rate in 20 years. 
 The Tube. Bashing TV for sins real or imagined is traditional Election Night sport. This year the four networks deserve unstinting praise for threading a careful path between sensationalism and censorship. None pronounced a Clinton victory until nearly 11 P.M., even though the authoritative exit polls from Voter Research & Surveys had indicated a landslide for hours. Television thus demonstrated respect for Western voters whose polls were still open -- a respect the Senate denies them by failing to enact uniform poll closing hours.
The Language. What a joy it was early yesterday to listen to victory statements from two candidates who think and talk in complete sentences. At that hour, many viewers surely wished there had been fewer sentences; even so, Bill Clinton and Al Gore evince a respect for language often dramatically missing in the locutions of President Bush and Vice President Quayle.
The Bozos. Something odd happens to Mr. Bush when he vaults into "campaign mode." His good manners fall away and he stands revealed as Nastyman. In 1988, that brought harsh exploitation of race and crime fears. This time it went from Red-baiting to juvenile expostulations like, "My dog Millie knows more about foreign affairs than these two bozos." The bozos responded with dignity, pushing the dialogue back to national issues and facilitating conciliation now.
 The Demographics. In his last two years, Mr. Bush played politics with racial resentment. He used his plan for school choice, giving money to private and parochial schools, as a way to divide Catholics and blacks. He pushed and pulled his otherwise laudable North American Free Trade Agreement like a saw between labor and Mexican-Americans. Crafty tactics maybe, but poisonous leadership by President Slice-and-Dice. Governor Clinton promises to become President Unifier, a consummately welcome outcome for all Americans who have been made to feel excluded.
The Cities. It seems like a century ago that anyone in the White House understood or cared about the poorhouse burdens borne by the nation's cities. But now, listen to some of Bill Clinton's first words as President-elect: "This election is a clarion call for our country to face . . . problems too long ignored -- from AIDS to the environment to the conversion of our economy from a defense to a domestic economic giant."
 Women. Did it make sense for Vice President Quayle to pick a fight with a TV character about to become a single parent? Tuesday's exit polls offer a decisive answer. Voters generally favored Mr. Clinton by about 5 points; single parents -- mostly women -- favored him by 20 points. For many women, this was also an inspiring election for a long list of other reasons, starting with the names of four new women Senators.
Gridlock. In his first term, President Reagan could work with a Republican Senate and a House whose conservative "boll weevil" Democrats would occasionally tip big votes his way. But since Democrats regained the Senate in 1986, Washington has experienced divided government, often paralyzing needed legislation. Congress should remain a check on the executive branch; ours is not a parliamentary system. Nevertheless, the prospect of a President and Congress of the same party offers hope for accountable leadership.
Politics. The voters showed they want responsive government. President Bush has often provided prudent management and personal geniality but appears to like politics about as much as broccoli. That makes it all the more satisfying that the winners are men who know politics, like politics and are, demonstrably, good at politics.
Sportsmanship. After the campaign nastiness, President Bush Tuesday praised his opponent with straightforward good grace. Ross Perot did likewise, urging his surprisingly large legion to "Forget the election. . . . We must all work together." The most gracious of all was Vice President Quayle. He gave all Americans reason to feel good with his salute to Mr. Clinton: "If he runs the country as well as he ran his campaign, we'll be all right."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Who Gets What Jobs

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
While the world waits to hear who will be Bill Clinton's Secretary of State, the President-elect is thinking more about strategy than names.
His strategy will flow from two premises: 
 * For the first time since the 1930's, the appointment of the Secretary of the Treasury will be more important than the appointment of the Secretary of State, possibly even for foreign policy. Mr. Clinton knows his Presidency will effectively collapse in two years unless he quickly stimulates the economy and creates jobs without increasing the budget deficit.
* The chances of reaching this goal will be nil if he has to squander his days dodging inevitable Republican foreign policy bullets. Three seconds after Mr. Clinton's inauguration, George Bush will be attacking him for not getting rid of Saddam Hussein. Americans generally and world leaders particularly are anxious about Mr. Clinton's foreign policy inexperience. So he has to wall off the White House from such anxieties and Republican attacks.
All this argues powerfully for a national security team of moderates and conservatives, including Republicans.
It also calls for the most experienced hands. President Bush will leave his successor a world filled with time bombs ready to explode in the ex-Soviet Union, ex-Yugoslavia, the Persian Gulf and China. Any such calamity will drag Mr. Clinton into an international quagmire unless he can rely on his top advisers in a crisis.
Finding the right Secretary of State will be a problem. Five hundred Democrats fantasize about being the chief diplomat and believe they are already overqualified for the job. But Mr. Clinton will soon realize that no Democrat has the stature to fill that position and instantly reassure the world. The party has been out of power too long for world-class reputations to develop.
Some obvious and able candidates, for example, are Representative Lee Hamilton, former Vice President Walter Mondale and Warren Christopher, the number two at State under Jimmy Carter. But they may be seen as too liberal to provide sufficient conservative cover for the White House.
If so, Mr. Clinton will look next at moderate Democrats like Senator Bill Bradley. His standing is good with conservatives.
Or the President-elect could think even more widely and craftily and focus on Republicans -- like Senator Richard Lugar.
Defense should be easy. Representative Les Aspin and Senator Sam Nunn both have the necessary expertise and conservative backing.
The C.I.A. would be a natural home for someone like retired Adm. William Crowe, who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under Presidents Reagan and Bush. Admiral Crowe has an undeniable political claim to a top position. His campaign endorsement gave Mr. Clinton critical protection from the right. The two Daves, Representative McCurdy and Senator Boren, also fit the bill.
The post of national security adviser should go to a skilled, moderate pragmatist. The leading candidate continues to be Tony Lake. He ran the foreign policy side of the campaign with Samuel (Sandy) Berger, a Washington attorney, and was head of State Department policy planning for Cyrus Vance. The Lake-Berger duo engineered the Clinton campaign strategy of reaching out to Reagan Democrats and neoconservatives. If it's not Tony Lake, the field will be wide open.
Selecting such a moderate-conservative team raises the question of what to do with loyal liberals. Mr. Clinton's answer should be obvious: Give them the "new agenda" issues like environment, energy, drugs, refugees, foreign aid and development. And center these activities in a new Economic Security Council and staff -- paralleling the N.S.C. staff -- which he recently proposed to mesh foreign and domestic economics.
Liberals would be in no position to cry foul. These are the very issues they have rightly been fighting to place at the core of world politics for the last 15 years.
Mr. Clinton has little direct familiarity with national security personalities. He will therefore rely heavily on Al Gore, who knows them all, and well. By record and instinct, the Vice President-elect will reinforce the push for a moderate-conservative team.
May the force be with these two young knights of bright countenance on their journey. With anxieties high, the honeymoon is almost over.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 35; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
Losers, Not Weepers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With reporters on campaign beats covering the reception of returns in Houston and Little Rock; and with The New York Times's Washington editors up in New York putting together the election issue -- on Election Night the Times bureau here was like a morgue.
Seeking human political contact at a historic moment, I walked one block east to watch the returns in the office of Lane Kirkland of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. We differ on economics, agree on foreign affairs, but in this election we were curiously aligned: Lane was a Democrat supporting Clinton, I was a Republican opposing Bush. 
Labor's leader is an understanding soul. As the returns came in, neither he nor his other guests gave loud hoots of happiness at the Clinton victory. He tolerated my small whoop at the victories of Senators Al D'Amato and Arlen Specter. As one who had known 12 long years in the Presidential wilderness, he respected the feelings of a Republican watching his side lose -- and even more troubling, who had voted against his side.
I imagine a great many people on the right feel as I do today; not triumphant by any means, but not sorry to see the Bush people go. Twelve years is a long time for any group to be in power, and this bunch was beginning to turn Republicanism sour.
We do not buy the Democratic line about years of greed and jingoism; by and large, the 80's were years of prosperity and global success. But not lately.
The first term, with Reagan in charge, found greatness in stopping inflation and, yes, "winning the cold war." But the second Reagan-Bush term, with its dreamy morning-in-America theme, lost its fervor; the third term, with Bush presiding, lost its sense of direction.
We're not happy about the Clinton plurality (though Bob Dole, the new Republican top dog in Washington, must be secretly delighted). Instead, we have a sense that the White House had become occupied by occupants. They were not "exhausted volcanoes," in Disraeli's phrase about Gladstone, because they were never true volcanoes -- but they are exhausted.
The excuse for single-termhood is that the economy didn't recover in time. But that's just part of it.
Strategically, the Bush entourage missed history's boat in the Soviet Union and China, was engulfed by error in the gulf, and not until the last minute tried to make the case for a coherent conservative domestic policy.
Tactically, in the campaign, the tardy James Baker botched the convention by romancing the hard right. Then he blew the debate negotiations, preferring to appease Ross Perot and use him as a buffer -- rather than freeze the billionaire out and deal directly with the President's Democratic challenger.
That's why some of us crossed over and why the Reagan Democrats went home or waltzed off to gold-plated protest. And it explains the curious lack of a letdown in watching the President concede; our letdown had come months or years before.
With both the White House and Congress in the hands of the Democrats, what now for the ideological homeless? Conservatives have to do more than oppose, grumble, view with alarm and drag a foot.
We will lie down and bleed awhile. We will retreat to the think-tank mountains and op-ed marshes to cook up a new-old philosophy that exalts individual freedom and national strength and public rectitude. With the advantage of being in opposition, we will build a new movement that can stick together without the glue of anti-Communism.
If the Clintonians advance prosperity at home and human rights abroad, we'll learn from them; if they fall out over the spoils of office or revert to budget-busting, redistributive type, we'll hold them accountable.
But wait: Each new administration is entitled to a honeymoon period -- a time to plan a transition, appoint the new team, present detailed legislation, persuade the people to support their different approach. The Clinton Administration deserves no less.
(Pause.)
O.K., that's it -- the honeymoon is over. The Clinton and Gore "victory" speeches were long-winded and inappropriately contentious, and revealed a pair of stump-loving politicians unwilling or unable to shift from campaigning to governing.
If these bozos (good, irreverent figure of speech!) cannot get it together soon, the revivified right will be back before you know it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: With Help, New York High Tech Could Rival Silicon Valley

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "New York a Hard Town for High-Tech" (Business Day, Oct. 12), you describe the challenges faced by Willow Peripherals, a gutsy company that started its computer business in the South Bronx. Willow's struggle in attracting employees to one of New York's most notorious neighborhoods should not be surprising. 
 But it is misleading to engage in yet another criticism of New York's economic potential. New York has the elements to be a high-tech center.
(1) We have a huge pool of talent, educated in New York's world-class universities. The city's financial community, I.B.M. to our north and Long Island's military contractors have trained an army of engineers.
(2) The New York region is a huge market for high-tech, particularly computer software for financial services, brokers and lawyers.
(3) While not everyone would choose to pioneer in the South Bronx, there are innumerable lofts and older office buildings in the city that can provide new ventures a first home.
I have counseled software entre preneurs who have become millionaires from high-tech ventures started in this city. These entrepreneurs were tough, street smart and adept at managing the personalities attracted to computer technology. They wanted to be in New York.
Engineers and software designers want to be near other entrepreneurs. A single subsidized loft in downtown Brooklyn or one abandoned plant in Queens could serve the needs of a dozen start-up ventures.
Entrepreneurs are chronically short of capital, even while working in the financial center of the world. If New York's government can stimulate a modest flow of seed capital, it would reap long-term rewards.
New ventures require accounting, advertising and legal services, most of which serve New York's large banks and corporations. The city could coordinate a volunteer or reduced-fee program to help high-tech entrepreneurs get started.
If New York City's government, universities and business community joined in a common goal, the canyons of Manhattan would rival Silicon Valley.
 
PETER BROWN
New York, Oct. 14, 1992
 
The writer, a lawyer, specializes in computer law.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: REACTION -- VOICES;
The Subject Is Politics, and the Voices Are as Diverse as the Country

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Wherever Americans gathered yesterday, the subject was politics in general and Bill Clinton in particular. The young and the old, suburbanites and ghetto residents, political junkies and even the avowedly apathetic paused to contemplate the election results and what a Clinton Administration might be like. 
 Following are snapshots of an assortment of voters who shared their thoughts one day after the election.
 
Colorado
Coming Home, To the Suburbs
 ARVADA, Colo., Nov. 4 (Special to The New York Times) -- A huge number of suburban voters came back to the Democratic Party on Tuesday. Voters here say that is because the Democratic Party came back to the suburbs.
Here in the conservative Denver suburbs of Jefferson County, where minivans fill the parking lots of shopping malls, Bill Clinton ran neck-and-neck with President Bush. For a Democrat, that is success.
Voters here said they did not necessarily believe everything Mr. Clinton had to say. But they believed one important thing.
"He's not a liberal," said Geraldine Asay, a 52-year-old housewife, who voted for Ronald Reagan twice, then Mr. Bush, and now Mr. Clinton. "For a long time, the Democrats have been all for welfare. But Clinton's not like that. He wants to put people to work."
Like almost every other Clinton supporter interviewed here this morning, she cited one other motivation for her vote: "We need change."
Ray Williamson, a 47-year-old trucker, came back to the Democratic fold, too. As the economy faltered, he said he simply lost faith in President Bush. "All he could do was complain about Clinton," Mr. Williamson said.
Not everyone was celebrating on the streets of Arvada this morning. Republicans like Pat McMullin, a 49-year-old cosmetologist, said she expects higher taxes from the President-elect. "How else is he going to pay for his programs?" she asked.
Her husband, Perry, a former Marine who works as a photographer, said he could not vote for Mr. Clinton, a man who opposed the Vietnam war. "What if we have another situation like Kuwait?" he asked.
But Larry Teeple, a retired owner of a baking company, said the new Presidency offers hope. "I wasn't thrilled with any of the three," said Mr. Teeple, 70, who finally chose Mr. Clinton. "More than anything else, we needed a change. And Clinton's the only one with a chance of giving it to us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Teeple, A retired owner of a baking company in Arvada, Colo. -- "We needed a change. And Clinton's the only one with a chance of giving it to us." (Brian Brainerd for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: REACTION -- VOICES;
The Subject Is Politics, and the Voices Are as Diverse as the Country

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

 BODY:
Wherever Americans gathered yesterday, the subject was politics in general and Bill Clinton in particular. The young and the old, suburbanites and ghetto residents, political junkies and even the avowedly apathetic paused to contemplate the election results and what a Clinton Administration might be like. 
 Following are snapshots of an assortment of voters who shared their thoughts one day after the election.
 
Florida
In Autumn of Life, A Wish for Change
 PEMBROKE PINES, Fla., Nov. 4 (Special to The New York Times) -- During the campaign, they listened attentively when Marilyn Quayle came to visit them, and Ross Perot's fusillades kept them constantly entertained. But when it came time to go to the polls, most of the residents of the Century Village planned retirement community here, like other elderly voters around the country, turned to Bill Clinton.
"When I got up this morning, I was elated," said Esther Herman, 68, a retired medical technician originally from New Jersey, as she chatted with friends at the clubhouse of this complex southwest of Fort Lauderdale. "Bush had four years to do all the things he has been standing up there saying he wanted to do. This man is a young man with a lot of ideals, who stands for change, and I think he will do a lot better."
Century Village's residents, living on fixed incomes or investments, include many people who cast their first ballot for Franklin D. Roosevelt but turned to Ronald Reagan in the 1980's. Many went into this election, they said, convinced that a historical cycle was drawing to a close.
"Perot I thought of when he first came in, but when he talked to the blacks about 'you people,' that turned me off," Janet Brenner, 69, said. "As far as Bush was concerned, I didn't like the idea of him looking at his watch during the debate. I felt like he couldn't wait to get out of there."
Most retirees here said they paid little attention to campaign charges and countercharges that one party or another would tamper with Social Security or Medicare. What mattered most, they emphasized, was the same issue that concerned their children and grandchildren: the economy. "It just seems that our total system was eroding, and that the companies that were strong 20 years ago weren't here anymore," said Kitty Thibault, 58, a former audiologist.
Having promised much, Mr. Clinton is expected to act quickly. "I want him to get jobs for the young people, deal with this drug thing, and decrease the deficit," said David Montekio, 73, who voted for Mr. Perot.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kitty Thibault, a former audiologist in Pembroke Pines, Fla. -- "It just seems that our total system was eroding, and that the companies that were strong 20 years ago weren't here anymore." (Tom Salyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT-ELECT -- THE HOME STATE;
Emotional High for 'Lowly Arkansas'

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 4

 BODY:
"Highest of the High," ran the headline in the weekly Arkansas Times, and for Bill Clinton's home state the words were about right.
Playing off President Bush's description of Arkansas as "the lowest of the low" the headline reflected the extraordinary degree to which the Arkansas Governor's victory on Tuesday was seen as a triumph not just for him, but also for his often-derided home state. 
 "I want to thank the people of this wonderful small state," Mr. Clinton told admirers Tuesday night, once again paying off the Bush campaign's dismissal ofMr. Clinton as "the failed Governor of a small state."
Most Arkansans seemed to share the sentiment.
"Most of us don't consider Arkansas the bottom of the heap," said Bruce Schrader, an elementary school principal in Sheridan, Ark., who was part of a euphoric crowd that packed downtown Little Rock into the early morning hours today. "Maybe this will put the barefoot and backwards image to rest."
 
Fighting a Common Malady
 Arkansas isn't the only state that has battled an inferiority complex over the years. The maladay is common to many small states, particularly in the South.
But from its earliest days as forlorn frontier outpost to the Dogpatch image of Li'l Abner, Arkansas has always been a place that defined where it's not at. H.L. Mencken, who once derided the "miasmic jungles of Arkansas," said in his defense: "I didn't make Arkansas the butt of ridicule. God did."
Nor did it help that the state's only major moment on the national stage in recent decades was tghe bitter battle over the integration of Central High School Little Rick in in 1957.
Given all that, people here have had a stake in the Presidential race in a way residents of, say, Walter F. Mondale's Minnesota or Michael Dukakis's Massachusetts never did.
Many Arkansans believe the Clinton victory has put their state on the map in a positive sense, and in a way that has been unique in Arkansas history.
"Most people know how to spell 'potato', but they don't know where Arkansas is," said Roby Robertson of the University of Arkansas at Little Rock. "Now they will."
Economists say Arkansas is small enough, with a population of 2.4 million, and geographically isolated enough that Mr. Clinton's Presidency might not have as much of an economic impact on this state as Jimmy Carter's election had on Georgie.
But few doubt that in terms of influence in Washington and international and national visibility Mr. Clinton's election has the potential to provide an enormous lift to Arkansas.
"We're not suddenly going to become the center of the world, but this can't help but be good for Arkansas," said Mike Gauldin, Gov. Clinton's press secretary, who spent most of the last two days videotaping the festivities.
The election has already set off a predicatable round of hackneyed imagery that centers on hogs, hillbillies and chickens. Arkansas chic may still seem like a contradiction in terms, but the souvenir dealers are already hawking "Honorary Arky" coffee mugs.
The real significance for Arkansas, however, is the degree to which the election reflects the extent to which this state and the South have left most of the old stereotypes behind.
After Mr. Clinton and his running mate, Senator Al Gore, spoke to a crowd at the Excelsior Hotel early today, themusic of James Brown's "Living in America" came throbbing out of the speakers. And in a state that has been associated for years with racial unrest at Central High, a giddy, interracial group waving Arkansas and American flags boogfied euphorically under a shower of confetti.
But then, because this is still Arkansas, when the music ended the celebrators raised thir arms and hollered the Razorback hog call before drifting out into the night.

HEADLINE: With Help, New York High Tech Could Rival Silicon Valley;
Recycled Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
This is a word of appreciation for the Ageworks I.B.M. computer training program sponsored by the New York City Department for the Aging. 
 This program is geared toward unemployed New Yorkers 55 years and older, and trains them on I.B.M. computers, teaching the fundamentals of WordPerfect 5.1 and Lotus 1-2-3. The staff helps with resumes and job-search suggestions. Important also is the restoration of self-esteem, ambition and hope after a period of self-doubt due to difficulty finding a job.
Employers who have hired these mature, experienced and responsible workers have been very satisfied and consider them assets to their companies. Thanks also to Mayor David N. Dinkins for continued support for this program.
 
RITA L. GADOL
Ridgewood, Queens, Oct. 22, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
SOUTH

BYLINE: This report was written by James Bennet, John H. Cushman Jr., James Dao, Jason DeParle, Clifford Krauss, Stephen Labaton, Neil A. Lewis, David Margolick, Maria Newman, and Martin Tolchin.

 BODY:

ALABAMA - BUSH
Alabama remained loyal to the Republicans, putting its nine electoral votes in Mr. Bush's column. As usual, Republicans branded the Democrat as too liberal, especially on social issues. At a rally last week in Birmingham, for instance, parents said their children would encounter homosexual scoutmasters if Mr. Clinton won the election. 
 Senator Richard C. Shelby, a Democrat, easily won re-election over Richard Sellers, a businessman.
Running for the House in an open district, a Republican political novice, Terry Everett, a newspaper executive, defeated one of the state's most famous names, George Wallace Jr., the State Treasurer. Mr. Everett had attacked Mr. Wallace, son of the former Governor, has part of a politics-as-usual tradition.
Ben Erdreich, a five-term Democratic incumbent, became a victim of redistricting, losing to a Republican, Spencer Bachus, a former state party chairman, in a redrawn district. State Senator Earl F. Hilliard, a Democrat, became the first black Alabaman in Congress since Reconstruction.

ARKANSAS - CLINTON
Since Lincoln lost in Kentucky in 1864, every Presidential victor has won the state of his birth. The exception was 1988, when George Bush lost Massachusetts.
Mr. Clinton easily kept the tradition alive, becoming the first Democrat to win Arkansas's six electoral votes since 1976. Mr. Perot, who had mocked the state's chicken industry, drew only 11 percent.
Senator Dale Bumpers, the popular three-term incumbent, trounced his Republican challenger, Mike Huckabee, a 37-year-old minister and broadcast executive.
The House district in the state's northeast corner changed hands for only the third time in 53 years as Blanche Lambert, who had beat the incumbent, Bill Alexander, in the Democratic primary, won. The only Democratic incumbent running, Ray Thornton, also won easily.
But two other Democrats lost. John R. VanWinkle was defeated by State Representative Tim Hutchinson. Mr. Clinton's Secretary of State, Bill McCuen, lost to Jay Dickey, a businessman.
Voters also approved a measure limiting the terms of state and Federal officials.
PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush...333,909...36%
Clinton...498,548...54%
Perot...98,215...11%
SENATE

Bumpers (D)...545,325...60%
Huckabee (R)...362,203...40%

 FLORIDA - BUSH
Mr. Bush won the state's 25 electoral votes, but only with extreme effort. After winning by a margin of nearly a million votes in 1988, this year the President had to keep returning to Florida until late October, draining time and money from other states.
The economy was his main enemy, with September unemployment at 8.9 percent in a state used to being a job-seeker's mecca.
The national Democratic Party ran a series of advertisements charging that the Republicans would make cuts in the Medicare program. The advertisements drew criticism from independent experts, but polls of voters leaving the polls showed the Democrats running strongest among the elderly.
Mr. Perot's strong showing may also have siphoned votes from conservatives disaffected with the President.
Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat, won re-election easily, but Republicans took some solace in House races. The state's delegation expanded by four seats, to 23, and Republicans captured 13 of them. They also drew even with the Democrats in the state Senate.
Florida elected three new black Representatives, all Democrats: Carrie Meek, Corrine Brown, and Alcee L. Hastings. Mr. Hastings, a former Federal district judge who now joins the House that impeached him in 1989 on charges of bribery.
A referendum imposing an eight-year term limit on members of Congress passed with 77 percent of the vote.

Clinton...2,051,845...39%

GEORGIA - CLINTON
 The Southern-grown Democratic ticket of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore held on for a narrow victory in Georgia, a state that four years ago gave Mr. Bush a landslide victory.
But an odd set of circumstances has Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., the incumbent Democrat, facing a runoff even though he ran ahead of Mr. Clinton.
Georgia law provides that a statewide candidate cannot claim victory without winning 51 percent of the vote. Mr. Fowler received only 49 percent; his Republican challenger, Paul Coverdell, received 48 percent, and the remaining three percent went to Jim Hudson, a Libertarian.
Mr. Coverdell had boasted of his association with President Bush, whom he once pronounced "one of the strongest Presidential personalities in history." As Mr. Bush's popularity plummeted, Mr. Coverdell mentioned him less frequently. Democrats tried hard to insure Mr. Fowler's re-election, seeing that he campaigned with Georgia's senior Senator, Sam Nunn, an enormously popular figure.
Representative Newt Gingrich, a slashing Republican fighter in the House, won re-election.

KENTUCKY - CLINTON
Emphasizing his ticket's Southern roots, Mr. Clinton succeeded in wooing conservative Democrats who had supported President Bush on social issues in 1988 but abandoned him this year because of the weak economy.
Mr. Bush, who visited the state twice in the campaign's final week, ran well in traditional Republican strongholds in rural southeastern corner and in the suburbs of Cincinnati. But his attacks on Mr. Clinton's economic and environmental policies failed to dent the Democrats' core constituency or to prevent Reagan Democrats from turning to Mr. Perot.
In the Senate race, the Democratic incumbent, Wendell H. Ford, the majority whip, easily defeated David Williams, a Republican State Senator.

LOUISIANA - CLINTON
Capitalizing on his status as a Southerner and Governor of a neighboring state, Mr. Clinton broke the Republicans' grip on Louisiana's white voters and brought the state into the Democratic column for the first time since 1976.
He had the strong backing of Senator John B. Breaux, the power in the state party and a longtime ally from the Democratic Leadership Council. Representative William J. Jefferson of New Orleans, another early Clinton supporter, worked hard to turn out the city's sizable black vote.
Republican efforts were fractured when Billy Nungesser, the state party chairman, backed Pat Buchanan in the primaries and Representative Richard H. Baker, Mr. Bush's choice as chairman, became consumed by a tough, though successful, battle against a fellow Republican, Representative Clyde C. Holloway. Mr. Bush, struggling to keep the state's nine electoral votes, made seven trips to Louisiana, including an election-eve visit to Baton Rouge.
In another race between incumbents, Representative Jim McCrery, a Republican, won handily over Jerry Huckaby, a Democrat.
PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush...729,880...42%
Clinton...815,305...46%...
Perot...210,604...12%
 
 MISSISSIPPI - BUSH
Mr. Bush held on to this conservative bastion -- and its seven electoral votes -- even though Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore are both from neighboring states.
Mr. Bush won by 87,000 votes, less than half his margin four years ago. Even so, his 50 percent showing was better than he did in any other state this time.
Lisa Walker, state director for the Clinton campaign, said the result reflected a successful campaign by Christian fundamentalists to get out their vote.
Blacks make up 36 percent of the Mississippi electorate, but the Clinton campaign fell short of its target of increasing black turnout by more than 25 percent over 1988. Republicans barraged the state with advertising assailing Mr. Clinton's character and saying that he had done little for blacks in Arkansas.
Mississippi re-elected its five Democrats in Congress. Even Representative Jamie L. Whitten, 82 years old and in poor health, survived against the first opponent he has faced in the last 18 campaigns.

Bush...481,583...50%

Perot...84,496...9%
 
NORTH CAROLINA - BUSH
In North Carolina, the Democrats gained a governorship but lost a Senate seat. And Mr. Bush barely squeaked by Mr. Clinton, just as in the two biggest Southern states, Texas and Florida.
Both Mr. Bush and the Republican challenger for the Senate seat, Lauch Faircloth, succeeded by reminding the large number of voters who live on six military bases of their opponents' views on the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Faircloth, a former Democrat, upset Senator Terry Sanford by also making an issue of Mr. Sanford's age and recent heart operation. The operation hampered the 75-year-old Senator's campaigning.
Jim Hunt, the Democratic Governor from 1977 to 1985, was sent back to the governor's office for a third term, beating Jim Gardner, the Republican who had been Lieutenant Governor since 1989.
Two Democrats in House races, Eva Clayton and Mel Watt, won and became the first blacks to represent North Carolina in Washington since 1901. Democrats continued to control the House seats, by a margin of 8 to 4.

OKLAHOMA - BUSH
Mr. Bush won easily in Oklahoma, about as Republican as any state in Presidential politics. Democrats had hoped to make the race for the eight electoral votes closer, but much of the protest vote went to Mr. Perot, who won 23 percent. Though Mr. Gore visited several times, the real estate, banking and cattle industries have taken a turn for the better and Mr. Bush remained popular.
Steve Lewis, a Democrat and former Speaker of the State House, failed to do well against Senator Don Nickles, the Republican incumbent, in part because he was short of money. Mr. Lewis made an issue of Mr. Nickles's strong opposition to abortion rights, an approach that apparently failed in this Bible Belt state. Mr. Nickles had served as chairman of the Republican platform committee.
The Democrats held their 4-to-2 advantage in House seats. Representative James M. Inhofe, a Republican, once again beat off a tough challenge.

SOUTH CAROLINA - BUSH
South Carolinians split their votes, preferring a Republican for President and a Democrat for the Senate.
In taking the state's eight electoral votes, Mr. Bush had one of his strongest showings in the nation, largely unaffected by Mr. Perot, who had a particularly weak performance. Signs were that the religious right had stood firm with the Republican ticket, resisting the erosion to Mr. Perot that occurred elsewhere.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the veteran Democrat, won a narrow victory over former Representative Thomas F. Hartnett. Mr. Hartnett tried to make an issue of Mr. Hollings's vote against partipation in the Persian Gulf war, but the Republican's campaign failed to muster enough money to challenge the incumbent effectively.
James E. Clyburn won easily to become the state's first black Representative. Bob Inglis, a Republican, eked out a surprise victory over Representative Liz J. Patterson, a three-term Democratic incumbent.

TENNESSEE - CLINTON
Governor Clinton's choice of Senator Gore as his running mate put this state into the Democratic column for the first time since Jimmy Carter won its 11 electoral votes.
Despite polls showing a predictable Democratic lead, Mr. Bush, Mr. Quayle and their surrogates, including Lamar Alexander, the former Governor of Tennessee and now Education Secretary, all campaigned there in hopes of keeping the state Republican.
Mr. Quayle made Tennessee one of his last stops before Election Day. But Mr. Gore got the last word, returning to Tennessee on Tuesday for two rallies before casting his vote there.
The Democrats were also counting on Mr. Gore's coattails to draw votes for Democratic Representatives.
But the margin of the Gore-Clinton victory, 47 percent to 43 percent, with 10 percent for Mr. Perot, apparently was too small to have made much difference, and every one of the incumbents -- three Republicans and five Democrats -- was re-elected.
Most won by comfortable margins, although Marilyn Lloyd, of Chattanooga/Oak Ridge, squeaked by with a margin of a few thousand votes.
PRESIDENT
100% reporting
Bush...840,899...43%
Clinton...933,620...47%
Perot...199,787...10%
 
TEXAS - BUSH
With 32 electoral votes, Mr. Bush's adopted state of Texas was his biggest catch, although he won by a far smaller margin than the 12.7 percentage points of his 1988 victory.
It was a measure of the President's woes, as well as a reflection of Mr. Clinton's regional appeal, that Mr. Clinton came close to capturing the state even though he was outspent by the Republicans on direct media campaigns alone by more than $3 million.
Texas is also the home turf of Mr. Perot, who had a particularly strong showing in the state. Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that his maverick campaign hurt Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton virtually equally.
Democrats continued to control the House seats by winning in 21 of the 30 Congressional districts. Two Democrats who wrote many overdrafts on their House bank accounts beat back stiff challenges, although a third member was less fortunate.
Representative Charles Wilson, a 20-year member from East Texas known for his flamboyant lifestyle, defeated Donna Peterson, a Republican. Ronald D. Coleman of El Paso, who wrote 673 overdrafts, beat Chip Taberski, a popular sportscaster.
Representative Albert G. Bustamante of Laredo, who had held a once-secure seat, was defeated by Henry Bonilla, a Republican television executive. Mr. Bustamante wrote 30 House bank overdrafts and was also under investigation by a Federal grand jury for helping a friend win a bingo contract on an Indian reservation.
PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush...2,460,334...40%
Clinton...2,279,269...37%
Perot...1,349,947...22%
 
VIRGINIA - BUSH
Virginia, which has voted Republican in Presidential races since 1968, gave President Bush a comfortable victory in his battle for the state's 13 electoral votes. Still, the race was tighter than some had expected, especially after one debate, in Richmond, gave Mr. Clinton momentum.
Although the state's Congressional districts had been extensively redrawn, all eight incumbent House members, five Democrats and three Republicans, were re-elected. One Democrat and one Republican were elected to open House seats.
The creation of a district with a 64 percent black population guaranteed that the winner of the Democratic primary, State Senator Robert C. Scott, would become the first black House member from the state in this century. He won easily.
In another new district, the 11th, in the suburbs of Washington, Leslie L. Byrne, a Democrat, became the first woman elected by Virginians to the House.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
West

BYLINE: This report was written by James Bennet, John H. Cushman Jr., James Dao, Jason DeParle, Clifford Krauss, Stephen Labaton, Neil A. Lewis, David Margolick, Maria Newman, and Martin Tolchin.

 BODY:

ALASKA - BUSH
 Alaska, where Mr. Bush won handily, has not given its three electoral votes to the Democrats since 1964. Mr. Clinton's chances were hurt by his opposition to drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which Alaskans overwhelmingly favor. 
 Senator Frank H. Murkowski, a Republican, turned a notable financial advantage into an easy victory over the Democrat, Tony Smith. The Republican Representative, Don Young, held off a challenge from John S. Devens, a Democrat.

Bush...72,264...41%
Clinton...57,264...32%
Perot...50,634...28%

Smith (D)...69,862...38%
 
ARIZONA - BUSH
Devastated by the savings-and-loan scandal and plummeting commercial and residential real-estate market, this solidly Republican state gave George Bush the jitters. The President only narrowly won the eight electoral votes in Arizona, which has voted Republican in every Presidential race since 1952.
Although Senator John McCain, a war hero and first-term Republican, was tarnished as one of the five Senators who intervened on behalf of Charles Keating, the jailed savings-and-loan operator, he handily defeated Claire Sargent, a Democrat who has been active in civic affairs.
Mr. McCain also beat former Gov. Evan Meacham, a Republican best known for his opposition to a state holiday celebrating the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Voters also approved the King holiday in a referendum on Tuesday.
In a break with tradition, Barry Goldwater, the founding father of modern Republican conservatism, backed Karan English, a Democrat, and she defeated Doug Wead, a Republican minister, in a House race.

CALIFORNIA - CLINTON
Mr. Clinton's victory in California had been a foregone conclusion, and as it turned out the Democrat could have gained office even without the state's 54 electoral votes.
California's most notable decision was its unprecedented election of two women to fill the state's two seats in the United States Senate.
Dianne Feinstein, a former Mayor of San Francisco, won comfortably over the Republican incumbent, John Seymour, who was appointed two years ago to the Senate seat vacated by Pete Wilson when he was elected Governor. She will face election again in two years.
The other female Senate candidate, Representative Barbara Boxer, also a Democrat, staved off a stiff challenge by Bruce Herschensohn, a conservative Republican and television commentator.
Californians overwhelmingly endorsed a proposition limiting the terms of its members of Congress, then returned almost all of the state's incumbents to the House of Representatives. Opponents of the ballot measure have warned that if it takes effect, it will cost the state a score of committee and subcommittee chairmanships.
Representative Frank Riggs, a one-term Republican, was ousted, but Vic Fazio, the head of the national Democratic Congressional fund-raising effort, hung on to his seat. So did Duncan Hunter, an outspoken conservative Republican who was a special target of the Democrats for helping to call attention to Mr. Clinton's foreign activities as a student.
In a newly drawn district, the 41st, which includes some of Orange County, Jay C. Kim, a Republican, became the first Korean-American immigrant elected to Congress.
The voters rejected a proposition that would have allowed doctors to assist in the deaths of terminally ill patients.

COLORADO - CLINTON
After vigorous campaigns by all three Presidential candidates, Colorado broke a six-election tradition by giving its eight electoral votes to Mr. Clinton. But the state made history in the Senate race by electing an American Indian. With a pony tail.
President Bush pushed hard in Colorado, visiting the state twice and dispatching Barbara Bush to Denver at the 11th hour. Even Mr. Perot made an appearance in Colorado in the final days. But, although Mr. Perot retained a high-profile campaign headquarters in Denver after withdrawing from the race, he barely regained the level of support he had before dropping out.
In the campaign to replace Senator Tim Wirth, a Democrat who is retiring, Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell defeated State Senator Terry Considine, a Republican, to become the first American Indian to be senator. Mr. Campbell campaigned as a strong supporter of abortion rights.
Voters, as expected, approved a ballot measure that will erode civil rights protection for homosexuals.

HAWAII - CLINTON
 To no one's surprise, Hawaii's formidable Democratic machine not only delivered its four electoral votes to Mr. Clinton but produced an overwhelming victory for him in a state where he never campaigned.
Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the incumbent Democrat, easily won re-election. An advertisement that claimed he had molested his hairdresser 17 years ago backfired on his opponent, State Senator Rick Reed.

IDAHO - BUSH
President Bush swept to an easy victory after a bumpy start in his campaign for Idaho's four electoral votes.
The conservative oratory of the Republican convention initially soured many voters and opened the way for Mr. Clinton to make inroads in this bedrock Republican state. But the Democrat quickly faded, in part because of the re-entry into the race by Mr. Perot, who came in less than 10,000 votes behind the Arkansas Governor.
In the race for the seat left by retiring Senator Steve Symms, Mayor Dirk Kempthorne of Boise had a surprisingly easy time defeating Representative Richard Stallings, a conservative Democrat.
Michael D. Carpo, a Republican who is President of the State Senate, easily won the House seat that Mr. Stallings is leaving.

MONTANA - CLINTON
Mr. Clinton narrowly became the first Democrat in 28 years to win Montana's three electoral votes, while Mr. Perot enjoyed a strong third-place showing.
Montana Republicans also lost a popular Congressman, Ron Marlenee. Redistricting this year cost the state one of its two Congressional seats; this created the most populous district in the nation and forcing a face-off between Mr. Marlenee and another popular incumbent, Pat Williams.
Mr. Williams, a Democrat, had represented the western part of the state for 14 years; Mr. Marlenee had represented the east for 16 years.
In the race for governor, the State Attorney General, Marc Racicot, a Republican, defeated Dorothy Bradley, a state Representative.
Montanans approved a measure to limit the terms of state and Federal legislators.

NEVADA - CLINTON
The shadows of Paul Laxalt and Ronald Reagan were scarcely perceptible on Tuesday, as President Bush garnered only 35 percent of the vote.
Some observers had predicted a Perot victory, perhaps because protest votes are easier to cast in a state with only four electoral votes. But Mr. Clinton, backed by a Democratic Governor, prevailed.
Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat, won handily. His opponent, Demar Dahl, refused to accept interest-group financing, only to run out of money a week before the vote. Two incumbent members of Congress, James Bilbray and Barbara F. Vucanovich, won comfortably. Miriam Shearing became the first woman elected to the State Supreme Court.

NEW MEXICO - CLINTON
 Governor Clinton won New Mexico's five lectoral votes, but his performance had little effect on House races in the state: two incumbent Republicans won handily, as did an incumbent Democrat.
Mr. Clinton, sensing support among Hispanic voters and workers in high-technology industries, campaigned in Albuquerque before dawn on Election Day.
Even top Democrats were somewhat surprised by Mr. Clinton's showing. But perhaps they should not have been. Except for 1976, the state has gone with the winner in every election since it gained statehood in 1912. With many new residents, it may reflect the views of the whole nation fairly accurately.
PRESIDENT
99% reporting
Bush...212,393...38%
Clinton...259,500...46%
Perot...91,539...16%
 
OREGON - CLINTON
Two unsurprising bottom lines in Oregon -- Mr. Clinton's victory for the seven electoral votes and the defeat of a measure that would have permitted discrimination against homosexuals -- hid some surprising results.
In the Presidential race, Mr. Perot bucked projections by racking up one in four votes, apparently drawing support from fiscally conservative voters.
A second surprise came from the initiative. Although the measure failed, it received more support -- 43 percent -- than state polls had estimated, apparently because some backers were embarrassed to tell poll takers.
In the fierce Senate race, the Republican incumbent, Bob Packwood, managed to hang on for a fifth term, defeating Representative Les AuCoin, a nine-term Congressman. Mr. Packwood blasted Mr. AuCoin for leaving his influential House position to run for the Senate and being too solicitous of the spotted owl.
Voters also endorsed term limits for state and Federal officials.

UTAH - BUSH
Given a third option, Utah voters demonstrated that they are as suspicious of Democrats as they are loyal to Republicans. Not only did Mr. Bush win the five electoral votes, but Mr. Perot beat Mr. Clinton in the state, and an independent candidate for governor ran ahead of the Democratic contender.
In the race to replace Senator Jake Garn, a Republican who is retiring, Robert F. Bennett, a Republican management consultant, defeated Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat whom Mr. Bennett accused of being the most liberal of the Utah delegation.
In the Governor's race, Mike Leavitt, a Republican insurance executive, beat the Democrat, Stewart Hanson, a former state trial judge, and Merrill Cook, of the Independent Party.

WASHINGTON - CLINTON
Patty Murray, the self-described "mom in tennis shoes," used luck and pluck to beat a five-term Congressman for a Senate seat, helped along by Mr. Clinton's victory.
Mr. Perot attracted nearly a quarter of the voters in this state of independent voters troubled by the economy and by conflicts over natural resources.
Ms. Murray, a first-term State Senator, had decided to take on Senator Brock Adams even before he announced his retirement after allegations of sexual misconduct. She beat Representative Rod Chandler, a Republican. In an upset, Mike Lowry, a Democratic former Congressman, beat out State Attorney General Ken Eikenberry, a Republican, to replace the retiring Governor, Booth Gardner, a Democrat.
Voters also approved term limits.

WYOMING - BUSH
Voter discontent with the President's handling of the economy and with his early support for stronger measures to protect the environment forced Mr. Bush to fight for Wyoming's three electoral votes, even though the state has voted Republican in every Presidential election since 1968.
And although the President won, Wyoming also yielded Mr. Perot one of his strongest showings, with 26 percent of the vote.
The state's lone member of the House, Craig Thomas, a Republican seeking his second full term, easily defeated John L. Herschler, an eye surgeon.
The voters overwhelmingly approved term limits for senators and House members.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
Midwest

BYLINE: This report was written by James Bennet, John H. Cushman Jr., James Dao, Jason DeParle, Clifford Krauss, Stephen Labaton, Neil A. Lewis, David Margolick, Maria Newman, and Martin Tolchin.

 BODY:

ILLINOIS - CLINTON
In its votes for national offices, the Land of Lincoln repudiated the party of Lincoln. It gave its 22 electoral votes to Mr. Clinton and elected Carol Moseley Braun, who will be the first black woman in the United States Senate. 
 Ms. Braun invoked Lincoln in her victory speech. "Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith, that we dare to do our duty as we understand it," she told her jubilant supporters.
Ms. Braun, the 45-year-old Cook County Recorder of Deeds, won 55 percent of the vote to beat Rich Williamson, the 43-year-old lawyer offered up by state Republicans when they thought they had little chance of defeating Senator Alan J. Dixon, whom Ms. Braun later defeated in the primary.
Ms. Braun, who barely won among men and lost among whites, carried 95 percent of the black vote.
Democrats will hold a 12-to-8 edge in the state's new Congressional delegation, which will include a former Black Panther and the first Hispanic member of the House from Illinois.

INDIANA - BUSH
The voters of Indiana were generous to incumbents of both parties this year, with one exception: Representative Jim Jontz, a Democrat first elected in 1986, lost to Steve Buyer, a veteran of the Persian Gulf war who criticized Mr. Jontz for opposing the war and accused him of harboring environmental views that were too liberal for his rural district.
Mr. Bush walked away with the state's 12 electoral votes, although the margin of victory was slimmer than Republican officials had hoped. In this conservative state, which has voted for the Republican in every election but one since 1932, Mr. Perot pulled in about one in five votes, apparently from voters who were concerned about the economy but not comfortable with Mr. Clinton.
Senator Daniel R. Coats, a Republican, fended off a challenge from the Democratic Secretary of State, Joe Hogsett. Mr. Hogsett never recovered from a damaging radio advertising volley from Mr. Coats that portrayed him as a career politician.
Gov. Evan Bayh, a Democrat who at 36 is the nation's youngest governor, easily defeated his challenger, Linley E. Pearson, the Republican State Attorney General.

IOWA - CLINTON
Mr. Clinton won Iowa's seven electoral votes by a comfortable margin, but otherwise Democrats had little to cheer about, notwithstanding their numerical superiority. Neither, in this "Year of the Woman," did women.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, a folksy and plain-spoken Republican, crushed his Democratic challenger, State Senator Jean Lloyd-Jones. In southern Iowa, Jim Ross Lightfoot, a Republican member of the House Appropriations Committee tarnished by 105 overdrafts at the House bank, defeated Elaine Baxter, the Iowa Secretary of State. And a resolution to add an equal rights amendment to the state constitution suffered a narrow defeat.
In a race between two incumbents, Jim Nussle, a Republican who gained notice by wearing a bag over his head on the floor of the House to symbolize his disgust over the banking furor, defeated Dave Nagle. That leaves only one Democrat, Neal Smith, in the state's Congressional delegation.

KANSAS - BUSH
Mr. Bush carried Kansas, as has every Republican Presidential candidate since Richard M. Nixon in 1968.
Yet he still ran way behind Senator Robert Dole, the minority leader in the Senate and the man Mr. Bush beat for the Republican nomination four years ago. Mr. Dole defeated Gloria O'Dell, a state treasury official, and won re-election with 64 percent of the vote.
Kansas, with six electoral votes, was one of those states that expressed its dissatisfaction with both major-party Presidential candidates by giving Mr. Perot a strong showing, 27 percent of the vote.
Representative Dan Glickman, a Democrat, was re-elected despite intense opposition from the local cable system, which opposed his vote to re-regulate cable television.

MICHIGAN - CLINTON
Michigan was considered a swing state vital to Mr. Bush's re-election prospects. But the travails of the automobile industry hurt Mr. Bush and helped Mr. Clinton to win the state's 18 electoral votes.
Ross Perot, a former member of the General Motors board who barely campaigned, received a healthy 21 percent of the vote. Polls indicated that Mr. Perot drew more votes from Mr. Clinton than from Mr. Bush, and voters said they were most concerned about the economy and health care.
Reagan Democrats, blue-collar workers whose disenchantment with their party led them to support Ronald Reagan and Mr. Bush, apparently proved the key to Mr. Clinton's victory. Many who lost their jobs making cars in recent years returned to the Democratic fold, with 68 percent voting for Clinton and 18 percent for Mr. Perot.
Representative David E. Bonior, the Democratic whip who is his party's third-highest official in the House, won re-election despite his 76 overdrafts on the House bank, which were an issue in his campaign against State Senator Doug Carl, a Republican. Representative William D. Ford, a 14-term Democrat who is chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, handily won re-election.
Michigan voters also handily approved a referendum to limit House members to three terms in any 12-year period and senators to two terms in 24 years.
PRESIDENT 99% reporting
Bush...1,587,105...37%
Clinton...1,858,275...44%
Perot...820,855...20%
 
MINNESOTA - CLINTON
With Tuesday's vote, Minnesota is now the only state to have voted Democratic in the last five Presidential elections, giving its 10 electoral votes to Mr. Clinton.
Ethical problems finally caught up with Gerry Sikorski, the five-term Democratic Congressman from the northern suburbs of Minneapolis. Mr. Sikorski, who ranked among the top 10 Congressmen both in bank overdrafts and the use of franking privileges, was trounced by the Republican, Rod Grams.
Democrats did retain a 6-to-2 advantage in the House with the apparent victory of David Minge over Cal R. Ludeman, a former candidate for governor, for the seat being vacated by Representative Vin Weber. The race, for which there may be a recount, indicated the limited length of Mr. Clinton's coattails.
Alan Page will become the first black -- and the first former star for the Minnesota Vikings -- on the State Supreme Court.

MISSOURI - CLINTON
Although Mr. Bush made a point of visiting Missouri often, Mr. Clinton, Governor of neighboring Arkansas, easily won the state's 11 electoral votes.
Senator Christopher S. Bond, the Republican incumbent, did little to disguise the fact that he was running away from Mr. Bush, and wondered publicly whether the President's unpopularity would sink his re-election chances. But he prevailed easily over his Democratic opponent, Geri Rothman-Serot, a member of the St. Louis County Council who emphasized her support of abortion rights, a view that Mr. Bond does not share.
The contest for the Governor's mansion became a kind of referendum on abortion, with a different outcome: The Democratic contender, Lieut. Gov. Mel Carnahan, emphasized abortion rights and overwhelmed his opponent, William L. Webster, the state attorney general, who had argued the case for restricting abortion rights that led to the 1989 Supreme Court ruling Webster v. Reproductive Health Services. Mr. Webster seemed eager during the campaign to avoid the issue.
