NEBRASKA - BUSH
Nebraska defied the electoral landslide to give Mr. Bush an easy victory in the contest for its five electoral votes. Like other Great Plains states, Nebraska also gave Mr. Perot impressive backing. But, as in many states, he seemed to draw as much from Mr. Clinton as from Mr. Bush. The state has not embraced a Democrat since Lyndon B. Johnson.
With no races for the Senate or the governorship, the hottest contest was for the House in the Second District, anchored in Omaha. Peter Hoagland, a two-term Democrat, barely survived a spirited challenge from a flamboyant restaurant owner, Ron Staskiewicz. Trying to ride the anti-incumbent wave, Mr. Staskiewicz played the outsider by campaigning in a bus decorated like a Pullman car. Mr. Staskiewicz threw the book at his opponent: "House Rules," a volume by Robert Cwiklik painting Mr. Hoagland as the consummate insider and an opportunist to boot.

NORTH DAKOTA - BUSH
North Dakota gave its three electoral votes to President Bush, despite a late surge by Mr. Perot among farmers that hurt both parties. The barely contested campaign was waged largely over the airwaves; none of the candidates visted the state, which last voted for a Democrat in 1964.
In the race to succeed retiring Gov. George Sinner, Ed Schafer, a Republican businessman, defeated Nicholas Spaeth, a Democrat who is the State Attorney General. In the Senate race, Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat, defeated Steve Sydness, a Republican member of the Fargo City Council.
North Dakota also approved an initiative to limit Federal lawmakers to 12 years in office.

OHIO - CLINTON
Bill Clinton, the first Democrat to win Ohio since Jimmy Carter in 1976, achieved victory by fewer than 100,000 votes.
Mr. Bush fought hard for Ohio's 21 electoral votes with an exuberant tour in the final week of the campaign, and was scathing in his attacks on Mr. Clinton's character and environmental positions. Polling of voters indicates that Mr. Clinton won wide support among blue-collar and union workers, suggesting he attracted back many Reagan Democrats.
Mr. Perot, who won a respectable 21 percent, may have meant the difference in the race. Twenty percent of his voters told poll takers that Mr. Bush was their second choice, while only 16 percent said they would have otherwise voted for Mr. Clinton.
The late Bush surge helped Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine's run at Senator John Glenn, the three-term Senator who had never experienced a difficult race for re-election. But Mr. Glenn still won 55 percent of the vote, though his reputation as a squeaky clean astronaut was tarnished by slashing advertisements linking him to the Keating Five savings-and-loan scandal.
House races featured a mud-slinging match in Cleveland involving Representative Mary Rose Oakar, an eight-term Democratic incumbent weakened by her association with the House bank and post office scandals. The Republican, Martin R. Hoke, a lawyer and political newcomer, won by a landslide.
As in 13 other states, a term-limits referendum covering state and Federal officeholders passed easily.

SOUTH DAKOTA - BUSH
President Bush won South Dakota's three electoral votes after making the state a symbolic battleground for the nation's farm vote.
On a September visit, Mr. Bush announced a $1 billion subsidy program for wheat exports, after having criticized similar subsidies by European governments. On his one visit, Mr. Clinton offered his own programs for rural health care, ethanol production and farm development. Mr. Perot seemed to draw equally from both parties.
Senator Tom Daschle, a Democrat seeking his second term, defeated Charlene Haar, the only Republican woman running for the Senate.
South Dakotans also approved a measure to limit the terms of state and Federal legislators.

WISCONSIN - CLINTON
Although steady dairy prices have helped Wisconsin weather the recession, the state still gave Mr. Clinton a comfortable victory. Republicans had predicted that Wisconsin and its 11 electoral votes would be the only state lost by Mr. Bush in 1988 that he might win this year.
But in the end the Republicans could not resist a heavy Democratic turnout in Milwaukee and Madison. Mr. Perot took 22 percent of the vote, reflecting the efforts of his strong local organization.
The Presidential race was nearly overshadowed by the defeat of a two-term Senator, Bob Kasten, one of the few incumbents to lose, by State Senator Russ Feingold. Mr. Kasten, who in his two previous Senate campaigns had not received more than 51 percent of the vote, attempted to paint Mr. Feingold as a radical liberal. For his part, the 39-year-old Mr. Feingold staunchly opposed such popular measures as a balanced-budget amendment, term limits and a middle-class tax cut. In the end Mr. Kasten's promotion of supply-side economics was seen as too conservative.
Representative Les Aspin, head of the Armed Services Committee, won a surprisingly easy victory over Mark Neumann, a Republican businessman who had made a spirited challenge.
Representative Scott L. Klug, a Republican, easily defeated Ada E. Deer, who sought to be the first American Indian woman to serve in Congress.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: STATE BY STATE;
Northeast

BYLINE: This report was written by James Bennet, John H. Cushman Jr., James Dao, Jason DeParle, Clifford Krauss, Stephen Labaton, Neil A. Lewis, David Margolick, Maria Newman, and Martin Tolchin.

 BODY:

CONNECTICUT - CLINTON
 As in many other states, the anemic economy defeated President Bush in Connecticut. Gov. Bill Clinton was the first Democratic Presidential candidate to carry the state since 1968. 
 In this once-booming state now staggering from the loss of thousands of manufacturing and white-collar jobs, Ross Perot managed to attract more than a fifth of the voters looking for change.
In the race for the Senate, the two-term Democratic incumbent, Christopher J. Dodd, resoundingly beat back a challenge from a millionaire businessman, Brook Johnson.
With polls last year showing Mr. Dodd's popularity eroding, Mr. Johnson tried to paint him as a free-spending politician beholden to special interests. But Mr. Dodd spent millions on advertising to show his opponent as a political novice and tried to turn the debate back to the prime issue on most voters' minds: the economy.
He made no apology for his political career, asserting that his experience helped save the Seawolf submarine contract for Electric Boat, eastern Connecticut's largest employer. Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed most voters here bought his message, saying they believed Government experience was more important than business experience in this election.

DELAWARE - CLINTON
Despite a vigorous campaign by President Bush and a stronger-than-expected showing by Mr. Perot, Governor Clinton won Delaware's three electoral votes, the first Democrat to do so since 1976.
The state's governor and sole House member traded jobs. For Congress, Gov. Michael N. Castle, a Republican taking mandatory retirement after two terms, defeated former Lieut. Gov. S. B. Woo. And Representative Thomas R. Carper, a Democrat, defeated B. Gary Scott, a retired real-estate executive, for governor.

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA - CLINTON
As predicted, Mr. Clinton crushed his opponents. But the Presidential race in the nation's capital was overshadowed by a referendum on whether to adopt a tough death-penalty law. Voters defeated the measure by more than 2 to 1, not only because they opposed the death penalty but also because it was Congress that put it on the ballot.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat, won again as the city's non-voting House delegate, and former Mayor Marion Barry returned to politics, winning a seat on the City Council.

MAINE - CLINTON
As Kennebunkport went, so went neither Maine nor the nation.
It proved to be one of the few bright spots for the Republicans, with Mr. Bush carrying the town by a comfortable margin. But even here, Mr. Bush's problems were evident: four years ago, he won by nearly 3 to 1.
Turnout in the town was among the lowest in the county, suggesting that if they could not comfortably vote for Mr. Bush, his neighbors simply stayed home. His margin there helped spare him the ignominy of a third-place finish in the state, where Mr. Perot ran very close with 30 percent, the highest proportion he received in any state.
In two House races, Representative Olympia J. Snowe defeated the Democrat, Patrick K. McGowan, and Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat, crushed Linda Bean, a Republican and heiress to the L. L. Bean fortune. She spent over $900,000 of her own money on the race.

MARYLAND - CLINTON
The defection of Maryland's maverick Democratic Governor, William Donald Schaefer, to the ranks of President Bush's supporters made no difference. Both parties had long counted the state's 10 electoral votes in Mr. Clinton's column, and he cruised to an easy victory in a state where registered Democrats are a 2-to-1 majority.
Voters also reaffirmed a law that guarantees abortion rights, by a vote of 61 percent to 39 percent. The law was enacted last year, but an anti-abortion group collected enough signatures to keep it from taking effect until put to a popular vote.
Senator Barbara A. Mikulski shared in the Democrats' victory with a decisive defeat of Alan L. Keyes, a Republican and former diplomat.
In a face-off between two incumbents, freshman Representative Wayne T. Gil chrest, a Republican, defeated three-term incumbent Tom McMillen, a Democrat. Representative Steny H. Hoyer, chairman of the Democratic Caucus, held off an aggressive campaign from Lawrence J. Hogan, Jr.

MASSACHUSETTS - CLINTON
Massachusetts went to Mr. Clinton, who had failed to win a single delegate in the state's Democratic primary last spring, when he ran third to Paul E. Tsongas, a native son, and Edmund G. Brown Jr.
In this Democratic stronghold, anti-Bush feeling was so strong that the state that had twice supported Ronald Reagan before voting for Michael S. Dukakis, another native son, gave Mr. Clinton its 12 electoral votes. Nearly one in four voters chose Mr. Perot.
Neither the governorship nor a Senate seat was at stake, but reapportionment helped defeat two Congressional veterans who had severe political problems.
Representative Joseph D. Early, a nine-term Democrat who had written 140 overdrafts on his House bank account, was defeated by State Senator Peter I. Blute, a Repoublican, in a district in which half the voters were new. Representative Nicholas Mavroules, a seven-term Democrat indicted on charges of racketeering, bribery and tax evasion, was defeated by the Republican, State Representative Peter G. Torkildsen.

NEW HAMPSHIRE - CLINTON
 Rejecting a sitting Republican President for the first time in 80 years, New Hampshire gave Mr. Clinton its four electoral votes, but only by the slimmest of margins. As a mark of how hard it was for voters in this recession-mired state to support a Democrat, Mr. Perot won almost a quarter of the vote.
But New Hampshire showed its Republican roots by choosing Gov. Judd Gregg, a Republican, over John Rauh, a Democratic businessman, to replace Senator Warren B. Rudman, who is retiring.
For governor, a former state Attorney General, Steve Merrill, a protege of the former White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, defeated the Democrat, Deborah Arnie Arnesen, who defied tight-fisted tradition by proposing a state income tax.
The state's two House members, Bill Zeliff, a Republican, and Dick Swett, a Democrat, fought off strong challenges to keep their seats, as expected.

NEW JERSEY - CLINTON
In the end, it was as close in New Jersey as the candidates expected. Mr. Clinton beat Mr. Bush there by two percentage points, with Mr. Perot a distant, faded third. And though redistricting and the retirement of four incumbents led to a number of ferocious House races, the Democrats clung to a majority of the delegation's seats.
With 15 electoral votes and more independent voters than Democrats or Republicans, New Jersey was considered crucial for the Republicans, who sought to link Mr. Clinton to Gov. James J. Florio, a Democrat badly wounded by tax increases. Mr. Clinton visited the state six times after his party's convention and touted the low tax burden in Arkansas. He and Senator Gore repeatedly claimed that 218,000 residents of New Jersey had been thrown out of work under President Bush.
Support for Mr. Perot, which topped 20 percent in state polls after he re-entered the race, declined after his allegations of Republican dirty tricks.
Although it seemed possible that Republicans could outnumber Democrats in the House delegation for the first time since 1964, the Democrats held on to a seven-to-six majority. The retirement of Representative Robert A. Roe, the delegation's 12-term dean, led to a nasty race in Northern New Jersey. Herbert C. Klein, a former Democratic state legislator, defeated Joseph L. Bubba, a Republican State Senator.
In a district drawn to increase Hispanic representation, New Jersey elected its first Hispanic Congressman, Robert Menendez, a Cuban-American who is a Democratic State Senator and Mayor of Union City.

Perot...505,698...16%
NEW YORK - CLINTON
Despite a victory of landslide proportions at the top of the ticket, the Democrats suffered a stunning defeat for the Senate. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato defeated state Attorney General Robert Abrams by a little more than 100,000 votes to win a third term. His victory left New York Democrats too shocked to savor Mr. Clinton's showing.
With the Presidential outcome never in doubt, the contest between Mr. D'Amato and Mr. Abrams became the main show in the state. Mr. Abrams had won a primary that left the Democrats bitterly divided. He was never able to gain a sure footing against Mr. D'Amato in a blistering campaign that may have been the nation's nastiest.
Mr. Abrams's lack of appeal was clear: Mr. D'Amato fought him to a draw among women even though Mr. Abrams had emphasized his support for abortion rights and other women's issues. And Senator D'Amato received nearly 40 percent of the Jewish vote, a remarkably high figure for any Republican. The Senator won a majority of voters of other major religious faiths.
In the House races, two multi-term incumbents were turned out of office. Representative Bill Green, a Republican who represents what is left of Manhattan's Silk Stocking District, was beaten by Carolyn B. Maloney, a Democratic City Councilwoman who was aided by the Clinton landslide.
On Long Island, Thomas J. Downey, a Democrat, was defeated by Rick Lazio, a Suffolk County legislator who made an issue of the fact that the incumbent had several overdrafts at the House bank.
Nydia M. Velasquez, a Democrat from a new district covering parts of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, became the first woman of Puerto Rican heritage in Congress.

PENNSYLVANIA - CLINTON
Mr. Clinton won Pennsylvania's 23 electoral votes as the coalition of blue-collar Democrats and middle-class suburbanites that had voted for President Bush in 1988 splintered because of concern about the economy.
The President had sought to win rural votes by painting the Democrats as overzealous on gun control and the environment.
Mr. Clinton ran surprisingly well in the Philadelphia suburbs, echoing the 1991 campaign themes of Senator Harris Wofford, whose surprise victory last year over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had been orchestrated by James Carville, Mr. Clinton's chief strategist. Mr. Perot drew support from coal miners and steel workers in western Pennsylvania, but he may have hurt the President more than Mr. Clinton.
In a closely watched Senate race, Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican considered vulnerable after his questioning of Anita Hill at the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings last year, narrowly defeated Lynn Yeakel, the Democrat. Using an expensive, sharp-edged advertising campaing, Ms. Yeakel tried to link Mr. Specter to the President's economic policies and repeatedly attacked Mr. Specter for humiliating Ms. Hill.
Mr. Specter responded with advertisements calling Ms. Yeakel a one-issue candidate, emphasizing his support for women's issues and attacking her for having failed to pay her Philadelphia income tax until a day before announcing her candidacy.

RHODE ISLAND - CLINTON
As expected, Mr. Clinton did slightly better in Rhode Island than in the rest of the nation, Mr. Bush a bit worse. Mr. Perot attracted the same strong support that he did in other Northeastern states.
Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat, managed to beat back an anti-incumbency mood and handily defeat his challenger, Elizabeth Ann Leonard, a Republican car dealer, who had been called the "perfect outsider" by the Republican Governors Association.
Representative Ronald K. Machtley, a Republican who unseated a 28-year Democratic Congressman in 1988, overcame a tough re-election challenge from State Senator David R. Carlin Jr. Representative John F. Reed, a Democrat, handily beat his Republican challenger, James W. Bell, a building contractor.

VERMONT - CLINTON
Mr. Clinton became the first Democrat to take Vermont's three electoral votes since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964. Mr. Perot also did well, as he did throughout New England.
The Democratic Governor, Howard Dean, handily won re-election over State Senator John McClaughry, a Republican, who depicted Mr. Dean as a tax-and-spend liberal. But Mr. Dean's supporters, including prominent Republicans, said he had followed a conservative fiscal plan.
Voters also re-elected Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat, over Secretary of State Jim Douglas, a Republican, and Representative Bernard Sanders, an independent.

WEST VIRGINIA - CLINTON
 A Democratic stronghold where the party controls the Statehouse and enjoys a monopoly in the Congressional delegation, West Virginia, to no one's surprise, handed Mr. Clinton its five electoral votes. Having suffered severe economic problems for the last decade, the state viewed the recession as the rest of the nation simply catching up with the downturn.
Gov. Gaston Caperton, a Democrat, won re-election. He got the job four years ago by campaigning against new taxes, but once in office, he shepherded a $400 million tax bill through the Legislature, alienating many voters, but they apparently forgave him.
His Republican opponent was Cleve Benedict, the state's Agriculture Commissioner. Charlotte Pritt, a Democrat, waged a write-in campaign.
Democrats retained their monopoly on the Congressional delegation, as Representative Nick J. Rahall 2d won his eighth term. He defeated Ben Waldman, a Republican who had worked in the White House for Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bush.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT-ELECT -- ROAD TO VICTORY
Sifting Strategies: What Went Wrong, and Right;
Clinton: Forging Discipline, Vision and Luck Into Victory

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4

 BODY:
The Hollywood stars were streaming into the Biltmore Hotel in downtown Los Angeles on the warm night of June 2 to see and be seen with Bill Clinton, who had just wrapped up the Democratic nomination for President. The Clinton California primary victory party was the hottest ticket in town.
But upstairs in the Governor's suite, Mr. Clinton was frustrated, his advisers depressed. The Wednesday morning headlines would proclaim him the winner, but a fatally wounded one. In a politically debilitating turn of events, polls showed Mr. Clinton running a distant third behind the shiny, new independent candidacy of Ross Perot. It looked as if the party might be over before it had properly begun. 
 "We had hit the worst of all possible junctures," recalled Paul Begala, a Clinton strategist who went out for a rare stiff drink that night with his partner, James Carville. "Voters knew all the bad and none of the good."
The campaign's success in changing the course of this year's tumultuous campaign resulted from stern discipline, a measure of dumb luck and a nearly naive sense of purpose that fueled Mr. Clinton's pursuit of the Presidency.
Mr. Clinton overcame extraordinary political adversity by plotting his objectives far in advance and presenting the electorate with a threatening vision of the consequences of re-electing President Bush -- for the economy, for domestic tranquillity and for Washington gridlock.
"The very future of the American dream is at stake," he warned last spring. He was determined not to repeat the mistakes Senator Al Gore, another Southerner, had made when seeking the Presidency in 1988 by failing to plan beyond a sweep of Southern states in the Super Tuesday primaries. Mr. Clinton assembled a circle of victory-hungry strategists and advisers who were determined to establish the Arkansas Governor as a viable candidate nationwide.
The Clinton forces also set themselves the task of overcoming the stigma of the Democratic Party as the home of losers and liberals. What some viewed as a repudiation of traditional party principles were defined instead as an effort to broaden the party.
And when the campaign began to flounder, as on that night in California, Clinton strategists, including his media adviser, Mandy Grunwald, pushed forward on another front: linking Mr. Clinton to pop culture through appearances on the Arsenio Hall show, MTV and the Nashville Network.
In the end, the candidate and his staff hammered out a strategy that looked stubbornly ahead, even during their bleakest moments.
 
Two Miscalculations: Vietnam and Hillary
 In retrospect, Clinton campaign aides now say, it became clear shortly after the Republican Convention that the prize was in their grasp. It was the spectacle in Houston that, in their view, flattened Mr. Bush. Long on conservative rhetoric, the convention was also short on the sort of specifics the Democrats had decided voters wanted to hear.
The mistakes are easy to chronicle.
One of the biggest was Mr. Clinton's failure to appreciate the danger posed by his incomplete explanations of how he had avoided military service during the Vietnam War. Campaign staff members said they gravely miscalculated the damage the draft issue could do to Mr. Clinton's credibility.
During a campaign strategy session in December 1991, Mr. Clinton and his aide, Betsey Wright, asserted that questions about the candidate's draft status had been resolved previously in state campaigns and would be no problem in 1992. Mr. Clinton was adamant that no further research be conducted on the matter, the staff members said.
But for all the problems that the draft issue caused Mr. Clinton, it never became the weapon the Republicans hoped it would be.
Still, there were other perilous miscalculations. For example, Hillary Clinton, who had originally been considered an unqualified benefit to the ticket, faltered when she defended her career with a disparaging aside about women who stay home to "bake cookies and have teas."
"That was a self-inflicted wound," Mrs. Clinton said in an interview this week. "It just was something I had to learn about. That was a learning process for me."
Yet is instructive to note that when Mr. Clinton's closest advisers are asked to name the lowest moments of the Democrat's campaign this year, they do not immediately mention the embarrassments and notoriety over rumors of marital infidelity, the Vietnam-era draft or Mr. Clinton's marijuana, each of which at times threatened to engulf the campaign.
Instead, they talk about the success and failures of their message and how they chose to deliver it. In the end, when they stuck to their message, they overcame their mistakes.
 
Long-Term Strategy: Fix What Is Broken
 One of the most frustrating moments for Mr. Clinton during this year's campaign had nothing to do with the character questions that President Bush would later use against him. It occurred when he found himself battling his competitors for the hearts of the middle class.
Paul Tsongas, Jerry Brown and Ross Perot all proved to be threats. And as each of these slightly offbeat candidates took his turn as prime challenger, the campaign's internal polling showed that Mr. Clinton's negative ratings among voters began to rise correspondingly.
In rapid succession, Mr. Clinton appropriated their messages, railing against Washington and making his prescription for change more somber. But to hear Mr. Clinton talk about it at the time, it would have been easy to believe that each small calibration was his own idea.
"One of the things I've learned in this business is make your own strategy, try to stick to it, hope for the best, assume the worst, and go on," Mr. Clinton said in an interview in March.
He had barely finished elbowing his way to a second-place finish in the New Hampshire primary in February before he started taking aim at Georgia and South Carolina. And by the time the letdown of the California primary victory had passed, the campaign's top advisers had already retreated to Little Rock to begin planning the general election.
"There had been a lot of discussions in May about what we would do in June," Hillary Clinton said. "We assumed we would win the nomination. And we remembered what Bush did to Dukakis in June."
By anticipating the worst of the attacks, the Clinton campaign's vaunted quick-response team deflected nearly everything the Republicans threw at them. "We killed their attacks before they went national, and by the time they went into their convention, their biggest attack was Hillary," George Stephanopoulos, the campaign's communications director, said. "Bingo."
The Democrats also quickly realized they had to repair their candidate's image.
Hillary Clinton said she was "stunned' when internal polls showed that most people thought she and her husband were childless. Instantly, 12-year-old Chelsea appeared with her parents on the cover of People magazine.
The same polls showed no one knew much of anything about Mr. Clinton except for the soap operas of the primaries, which had become fodder for late-night comedians. On Arsenio Hall, they learned he played the saxophone. On MTV, they learned he could sometimes laugh about himself. On morning talk shows and in televised town meetings in targeted states, they heard about health care, educational opportunity and life after the cold war.
Some of Mr. Clinton's advisers thought the whole thing not very Presidential, but using the pop-culture approach was also a purposeful -- and ultimately successful -- attempt to circumvent mainstream press coverage, which the Clintons and their advisers were convinced would endlessly rehash debilitating controversies.
Not all the surprises were bad. Even Mr. Clinton's most forward-thinking strategists had not predicted the galvanizing effect Mr. Gore and his picture-perfect family would have on the ticket.
Although Mr. Gore was limited as a Presidential candidate in 1988 and sometimes long-winded as a Vice-Presidential candidate this year, his presence on the ticket was an unalloyed benefit.
The pictures that emerged from their joint bus trips were effective television images, and Tipper Gore's friendliness on the stump blunted Hillary Clinton's sharp edges as the two giggled together like old cheerleader buddies.
Al From, the executive director of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, said that in choosing another Southerner as his running mate rather than reaching for geographical balance, Mr. Clinton signaled that he meant it when he said he was an unconventional Democrat.
 
Waiting for Attacks Or Signs of Strategy
 Clinton advisers seemed in a state of perpetual surprise over the Republican Party's failure to mount an effective and consistent counterattack.
"They did not a thing, to our great delight," said Ms. Grunwald.
David Wilhelm, the architect of Mr. Clinton's state-by-state strategy, said the campaign targeted 32 states with 376 electoral votes, calculating each state's historical performance in Presidential elections -- something they called the "Southernness factor" -- to gauge Mr. Clinton's regional appeal, to plan where to travel, and more important, to decide where to spend advertising money.
The top tier of states the Democrats aimed for and won were Delaware. Maryland, Missouri, Pennsylvania, Colorado, Georgia, Iowa, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Michigan, Montana, North Carolina, New Jersey, New Mexico, Ohio, Tennessee and Wisconsin.
Shunning network television advertising in favor of state purchases, gave them "gubernatorial level" campaigns at each crucial state, Ms. Grunwald said.
A discordant Republican convention and a listless performance by the President during the debates, particularly his groping response to a question about how the recession had affected him personally, infused the Clinton strategists with confidence.
"When Bush couldn't answer that question, the whole campaign exhaled," said Mr. Stephanopoulos.
 
Assembling Victory From Puzzle Pieces
 Mr. Clinton's victory is a paradox, a hard-won political victory that contradicted the year's conventional wisdom: Voters despised politics but elected a man who had been steeped in political ambition ever since he shook President Kennedy's hand.
This was supposed to be the year that questions of character were to determine the campaign's outcome. But voters elected a man who was forced to answer questions about marital infidelity on national television, who avoided the military draft and who shaded the truth about whether he used had drugs as a student.
All of this turned out to be largely beside the point on Election Day because, as it turned out, Mr. Clinton's timing was impeccable.
Like Ronald Reagan, he sought the Presidency in a year when the country was struggling with a weakened economy and when the incumbent President was perceived as ineffectual on the matters that counted most.
Also like Mr. Reagan, he ran as a can-do governor who promised to move his own party in a different direction. For a Democrat who had worked for George McGovern in 1972, Mr. Clinton did a remarkable job of transforming himself into a moderate who rejected the overtly liberal orthodoxy that had cost his party every Presidential election, save one, since 1964.
"I remind you again tonight, my fellow Americans, that this victory was more than a victory of party," Mr. Clinton told his jubilant supporters late Tuesday night as they shivered in the cold outside the pristine Old State House here. "It was a victory for the people who work hard and play by the rules, a victory for the people who feel left out and left behind and want to do better, a victory for the people who are ready to compete and win in the global economy but who need a government that offers a hand, not a hand-out."

SECTION: Section B; Page 16; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE REGION -- THE JOBS BOND ACT;
Jobs Delayed After Failure Of Bond Act

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Local officials throughout New York State yesterday were placing some public works projects on hold and making plans to scale down or stretch out others after voters' rejection of Proposal One.
A pillar of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's strategy for stimulating the New York economy, the proposal called for issuing $800 million in state bonds. The money would have been used to help finance projects like sewage and water systems, roads, sidewalks, ports and waterfront projects, business parks and parking garages. 
 For Mr. Cuomo, it was the second time in two years that a bond proposal he pushed was defeated. Voters rejected a $1.98 billion environmental bond act in 1990. Proposal One was rejected on Tuesday by 56 percent of the voters, with 96 percent of the precincts counted.
On WAMC-FM radio yesterday in Albany Mr. Cuomo said, "It's not good for New York that the bond act was defeated."
"We needed those thousands of jobs," he said, as well as the taxes that "that economic activity would have generated."
 
'Don't Borrow, Period'
 In an interview later, he said he believed a main reason for the defeat was a general public attitude against government borrowing and spending. "What I think it comes down to," the Governor said, "is people saying, 'These are hard times, we've just seen Perot and this discussion about the deficit and spending. We don't trust the government to spend and borrow. So don't borrow, period.' "
Mr. Cuomo also bitterly accused State Comptroller Edward V. Regan of generating "terrible confusion" among voters by tying the bond issue to his fight for changing the way the state borrows.
The bond issue money was intended to pay only part of cost of each project. Without it, however, some of them -- like a bio-science park in the Bronx and repairs and improvements of piers at the South Street Seaport and the Brooklyn Army Terminal -- will be put on hold. Others, like a parking garage and a development in Mount Vernon and improvements for the Harlem River rail yard, will be reduced in scope or built more slowly.
Some projects will go forward with other financing, like road improvements for a new mall in White Plains and the reconstruction of the Staten Island ferry terminal in Manhattan.
Mr. Cuomo's economic development experts predicted that the spending would have created nearly 35,000 temporary construction-related jobs and, over the long term, would have resulted in more than 122,000 permanent private-sector jobs by enticing more business to the state.
By several measures, New York's tax-supported debt of $24.29 billion is one of the highest in the nation. Voters apparently did not believe Mr. Cuomo's assertion that the bond issue would not end up costing them because it would more than pay for itself by generating economic activity that would produce $2 in taxes for every $1 borrowed and invested.
In assessing the vote, Mr. Cuomo said there was a lot of opposition upstate and guessed it stemmed from traditional resentment against spending programs that heavily benefit the downstate area.
Of the $558 million that had been designated for specific projects, nearly $234 million would have gone to New York City; $85.1 million to Nassau and Suffolk counties; $26.3 million to Westchester County, and $7.6 million to Rockland County.
In interviews, some voters said they were worried that the money would go to pork-barrel projects.
"Certainly it might have been more helpful if we had more detail out there earlier," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, a business and civic organization. He was a leader of the movement to win voter approval. The list of some 390 projects was not released until Oct. 23.
Opponents of the proposal included conservative organizations that advocated a smaller more efficient government, rural groups generally opposed to state borrowing, environmentalists who argued the projects would harm wetlands and would increase road travel and Mr. Regan.
Mr. Regan said yesterday that he had accomplished his goal. "Reform of the way the state borrows is on the agenda," he said. "I'd like to see it in the next legislative session."
He wants to increase the right of voters to authorize state borrowing, to subject borrowing legislation to greater public scrutiny and to stop using government authorities to borrow money for things that have nothing to do with them.

PUB-DATE: November 5, 1992
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1663 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: PRESIDENT-ELECT -- THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton, Savoring Victory, Starts Sizing Up Job Ahead

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
After an election whose results rang with a cry for change but offered no specific mandate, President-elect Bill Clinton set to work shaping his new Administration yesterday, huddling with his transition team, issuing a scarcely veiled warning to Iraq and promising that over the next six months, he would "focus like a laser beam on this economy."
The 46-year-old Mr. Clinton committed his Administration not only to ending the lingering recession, but also to lifting the nation to a higher level of economic productivity for years to come. 
 "My immediate job is, yes, to get us us out of this recession, but to do it with a long-term strategy that will lead to real income growth, so that you won't have people in 10 years working longer work weeks for lower wages than they made 10 years ago," he said in an interview with ABC News.
Earlier in the day in Little Rock, Mr. Clinton briefly turned his attention to foreign policy. Amid word that supporters of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were rejoicing over his victory, he told reporters: "The greatest gesture of good will any nation can make to me during this period is to continue full cooperation with our President, George Bush."
Aides said that Mr. Clinton had worried for some time that Mr. Hussein might be tempted into some new adventure by a changeover in Washington, and that today's declaration was a signal to the Iraqi leader and others not to try. [Page B10.]
Mr. Bush, only the fourth elected President in this century to seek a second term and lose, flew from his hometown, Houston, back to Washington to begin winding down a dozen years of Republican rule in the White House. He told a flag-waving crowd, "Let's finish this job with style."
With almost all the popular votes counted, the Arkansas Governor had 43 percent, the President had 38 percent and Ross Perot had 19 percent -- the best showing by an independent or third-party candidate since Theodore Roosevelt polled 27 percent on the Bull Moose ticket in 1912. It was a broad-based, decisive victory, if not a crushing one, for Mr. Clinton.
Sweeping the New England states, the three on the Pacific coast and the big industrial states in the Middle Atlantic region and the Middle West, Mr. Clinton also cut sharply into the Republican bastions of recent years in the South and the Rocky Mountains. That gave him 370 electoral votes to 168 for Mr. Bush, who took Texas and Florida by narrow margins, and none for Mr. Perot.
It was Mr. Perot's powerful run that confused the message of the election. A large majority rejected Mr. Bush and thus backed change, but it was divided on who was the better agent of change.Surveys of voters leaving the polls showed that many people had serious doubts about all three candidates, including the winner.
 
Third Party Considered
 Orson G. Swindle 3d, the head of the national Perot supporters' group, suggested that he and others might consider forming a third party to press their candidate's program, especially quick reduction of the deficit.
The big turnout on Tuesday, which was expected to reach about 55 percent of those eligible, reflected the widespread interest generated by a campaign that was waged on television talk shows and radio call-in programs as well as more conventional information media. In 1988, barely 50 percent voted.
Mr. Clinton made no appointments to his nascent Administration today, but aides said he would do so soon. He must also establish a sense of direction. Will he offer gestures to a variety of groups that supported him, as has been his past pattern, for example, or will he heed the famous maxim of the one-time French Prime Minister, Pierre Mendes-France, that "to govern is to choose"?
 
Economic Stimulus
 Among the items that he placed at the top of his agenda during the long campaign are an economic stimulus package, including large-scale public construction projects, a comprehensive health-care program, a family leave law, educational initiatives and campaign-finance reform.
It is far from clear, however, how Mr. Clinton will pay for all that while also beginning to reduce the mushrooming Federal deficit.
The President-elect's party will control both houses of the new Congress, though anti-incumbent sentiment proved less virulent than expected. Threatened Senators from John Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, to Bob Packwood, an Oregon Republican, managed somehow to survive. Roughly 93 percent of all the House incumbents who sought re-election achieved it.
The Democrats scored a net gain of one Senate seat, if Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., a Democrat, holds his seat in a runoff in Georgia on Nov. 24, and lost fewer than 10 in the House.
But there will still be significant change on Capitol Hill. The Congress that assembles next year will have 39 black members, compared with 25 now, and it will include Carol Moseley Braun of Illinois, the first black woman ever elected to the Senate. It will also include 17 Hispanic lawmakers, compared with 10, and the first American Indian elected to the Senate in more than 60 years, Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat.
Women did very well indeed in the Year of the Woman. There will be 47 female House members next year, compared with 28 at present, and six female Senators, by far the largest number in history.
Mr. Bush's plans for the 77 days left in his Presidency are not clear. Yesterday he vetoed a bill that would have given tax breaks to businesses willing to invest in poor neighborhoods, complaining about tax increases included in the same legislation. A vacation trip next week, to a destination not yet decided, was said to be a possibility, but a planned trip to Moscow has been scrubbed, White House officials said.
"I can think of nothing other to say then let's finish this job with style," the President told the loyalists who gathered on the White House lawn to welcome him and his wife, Barbara, back to Washington. "Let's get the job done, cooperate fully with the new Administration. The Government goes on, as well it should."
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, who was described by an aide yesterday as "the most powerful Republican in Washington now," served notice that there would be no rubber-stamping of Mr. Clinton's legislative proposals.
"He didn't get a majority," Mr. Dole said in an interview. "The country obviously didn't want Bush, but they weren't ready for Perot and they had plenty of doubts about Clinton. They want change. Well, we want to be responsible and deliver change, whatever that means, but we're skeptical, so we'll wait and see."
Mr. Clinton was in a reassuring mood when he and the Vice President-elect, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, met with a small group of reporters. Mr. Clinton read a relatively brief prepared statement and answered no questions.
For the benefit of Mr. Hussein and anyone else who might need reminding, the Arkansas Democrat, whose lack of foreign-policy experience was a campaign issue, said that "the greatest mistake any adversary could make would be to doubt America's resolve in this period of transition."
 
Soothing Financial Markets
 For businessmen and the financial markets, Mr. Clinton said, "We understand the need to pursue stability even as we pursue growth," and added, "the changes I seek will strengthen America's market systems, not weaken them."
Mr. Clinton has about 8,500 Federal jobs to fill with political appointees, including 16 cabinet posts.
Mickey Kantor, a Los Angeles lawyer who served as campaign chairman and who has been mentioned as a possible White House chief of staff, said key Administration appointments would be announced later this week. But other aides emphasized Mr. Clinton's deliberate work habits, as exemplified in his choice of a running mate last summer.
Either Mr. Kantor or Eli Siegel, who also played a major part in the campaign, is expected to head be chosen as transition chief of staff.
 
Pausing to Look Back
 In addition to looking forward -- Mr. Bush said he planned to "get very active in the grandchild business" -- the Democrats and the Republicans also paused for a moment to look back.
James Carville, one of Mr. Clinton's principal strategists, said at a briefing for reporters that Mr. Bush's criticisms of the Democrat had hurt, but that toward the end, "his attacks didn't have the same pop." Like a boxer's, he said, the President's "hands got heavy."
On the Republican side, Vice President Dan Quayle, whose chances of winning his party's 1996 Presidential nomination were sharply curtailed by Tuesday's results, blamed the state of the economy and the quality of the Republican campaign for the loss.
"Bill Clinton ran a much better campaign and the economy wasn't good," the Vice President said.
 An explanation with the table misstated the pattern of votes by sex since 1980. Women have given the Democrats more Presidential votes than men have.
A list of the new United States Senate on Thursday misstated the political affiliation of Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming in some copies. He is a Republican.
A map showing Congressional results around the country misstated some political affiliations in some copies. Republicans, not Democrats, won the Eighth Congressional District in Chicago, the Fifth and Sixth Congressional Districts of Louisiana and the Seventh Congressional District in Michigan; a Democrat, not a Republican, won the Seventh District in Wisconsin.
The map also referred erroneously to control of the 26th Congressional District in New York; it was gained by the Democrats in this election.
Because of a transmission error, a table of returns for the New York State Senate and Assembly omitted votes for Mary B. Goodhue, a State Senate candidate from District 37 in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties. She received 15,471 votes and came in third. The table also misstated the winner for Assembly District 57 in Brooklyn. He was Roger Green.

Table: "Portrait of the Electorate"
 This portrait of Americans at the polls shows how different groups have voted in the last five presidential elections, measuring the ebbs and flows of political alliances that have elected, and defeated, Presidents. The vast size of each sample makes it possible to study the preferences of some groups, such as Jews, Asians, and Hispanic voters, whose small numbers make them almost invisible in typical national telephone polls.
 
Sex and Age
As they have ever since 1980, women gave the Democratic candidate more votes than the Republican. In particular, Clinton did best with black women, getting 86 percent of their votes. And while he did no better with women of a either political particular party than with men of that same party, he got more support from independent women than from independent men.
The Democratic candidate captured more young voters than either of his opponents, for the first time since 1976. Beginning with Ronald Reagan, Republicans had made inroads among younger voters that led them to hope that a political realignment was under way in the nation. Clinton also led among the oldest voters, which Democrats failed to do in 1976, 1980, 1984 or 1988.
 
Coalitions
 In many ways, the components of Clinton's plurality coalition resembled the old New Deal coalition. He did best among the poor, among Jews, blacks and Catholics, among union members and liberals. But Clinton also did well among independents, and moderates, and middle income groups that Democratic Presidential candidates have had difficulty attracting during the past 12 years. But since Democrats remain the biggest political grouping in the electorate, it may have been even more important that he commanded as much loyalty from Democrats as President Bush did from Republicans. Previous Democratic presidential candidates -- Jimmy Carter in 1976 or 1980, Walter Mondale in 1984 and Michael Dukakis in 1988 -- failed to do as well in their party as their Republican opponents did in theirs.
President Bush held the backing of conservatives, and was strong among the affluent, and among white Protestants, all traditional elements of the Republican coalition.
Ross Perot got about one fifth of the votes cast Tuesday, and was strongest among independents of both sexes, where he got almost as much support as Mr. Bush and did not lag far behind Mr. Clinton. Perot did well among young men and groups in the middle ranges of income and education. He got very little support from blacks.
 
The Pocketbook
 Presidential elections are often about the economy, and recessions are the most frequent cause of defeats for incumbents. In 1984, Ronald Reagan won as the economy boomed, getting the votes of 86 percent of people who thought their financial situation was improving. This time, Mr. Bush got the votes of 62 percent of such people, but they amounted to only a quarter of the electorate, a much smaller share than in 1984. Among the third of voters who said they were worse off in 1992, Mr. Clinton got 61 percent, and the two candidates split the votes of people who thought their situations had not changed.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 844 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 ELECTIONS: THE STATES -- THE GOVERNORS;
Democrats Gain, but With Little Pattern

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD

 BODY:
Democrats won eight of the 12 gubernatorial races Tuesday, picking up two additional seats to give them a total of 30.
 But on a day when another Democrat swept to victory as President, the races for governor were decided less by Bill Clinton's strength than by local issues and personalities and traditional voting habits. In several states, voters elected a governor of one party while favoring a president of another. 
Thad Beyle, a professor political science at the University of North Carolina, said the very lack of a pattern in the outcome of the governors' races may reflect the changes forced on the states in the Reagan and Bush Administrations as the Federal Government reduced its aid to the states while making them assume more of the burden for social programs.
 "So many problems are now ending up on governors' desks that to a certain extent what hapens at the national level is very separate," Professor Beyle, a specialist on governors, said.
 
Incumbents Triumph
 Democrats won all four of the governors' races where they were incumbents, including Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, Gov. Bruce Sundlun of Rhode Island and Gov. Gaston Caperton of West Virginia.
 Mr. Bayh, at 36 years old the nation's youngest Governor, won by a record margin of 63 percent to 37 percent in a state that President Bush carried. And Mr. Dean took 75 percent of the vote to 23 percent for John McClaughry, a state legislator.
 Democrats also wrested control of the governor's mansion from Republicans in Delaware, Missouri and North Carolina.
 The North Carolina result was a personal trimuph for Jim Hunt, a two-term Governor who had lost a bitter campaign to unseat Senator Jesse Helms in 1984. While returning Mr. Hunt to the Governor's Mansion, voters backed President Bush and also ousted the state's Democratic Senator.
 
Gain by Republicans
 Republicans regained a state house in North Dakota, where Ed Schafer, a 46 year-old businessman, campaigned as a leader who could create jobs in a state with a shrinking economy.
 Ideologically, there were few surprises on Tuesday. For example, Utah, one of the most conservative states, gave a victory to Mike Leavitt, a 41-year-old Republican.
In New Hampshire, the most reliably Republican state in the northeast, Steve Merrill, a Republican and a former state Attorney General, defeated Deborah Arnesen, a state legislator, even though Mr. Clinton narrowly carried the state. Ms. Arnesen took the daring but fatal step of proposing a state income tax to reform New Hampshire's archaic tax structure.
 New Hampshire is one of only two states with neither a state income tax or sales tax, and candidates for years have taken what is known as "the pledge" not to propose a statewide tax. Mr. Merrill took the pledge, and won 56 percent of the vote.
 On the opposite side of the country, in more liberal Washington, a former Democrat Mike Lowry, was elected governor despite saying that higher taxes might be needed gto balance the state budget. His opponent, State Attorney General Kenneth Eikenberry, opposed any tax increase.
 
Bot Sides Claim Success
 All three women running for governor lost, a contrast to Tuesday's national trend of more victories by female candidates. The losers were Ms. Arnesen, Dorothy Bradley, a Montana Democrat, and Elizabeth Leonard, a Rhode Island Republican.
 Nationally, Republican and Democratic party officials both claimed victory from the contests for governor.
 "Our odds were uphill from the beginning," said Chris Henick, the executive director of the Republican Governors Association. Mr. Henick noted that for the first time since 1900 there were no incumbent Republican Governors seeking re-election, either because they decided to retire or because they had reached the end of their term limits. By contrast, there were four Democratic incumbents, who all won.
 In Mr. Henick's view, Republican victories in four of the eight races without incumbents, while Mr. Clinton piled up a large victory nationally, represented success. "I'll punch that dance card anytime," he said.
 But Katherine Whelan, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association, said Tuesday's results were "a vote of confidence in the Democratic Party."
 "The message is, Democrats do a great job governing," Ms. Whelan said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Statehood and Puerto Rico
 SAN JUAN, P.R. (AP) -- As a result of elections on Tuesday, supporters of making Puerto Rico the 51st state are in their strongest position ever, with a new Governor and control of the island's legislature.
 Gov.-elect Pedro Rossello, who defeated the pro-commonwealth ruling party's candidate, has promised to hold a plebiscite within a year on statehood.
 Surveys indicate Puerto Ricans are split between those who want statehood and those who favor maintaining the 40-year-old commonwealth status. About 5 percent back full independence. The plebiscite would include all three options.

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 4; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 522 words

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
A Young Group Explores the New World

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
For all its financial and demographic problems, the American orchestra is still an object of envy elsewhere in the world. Technically superior, quick to learn, flexible in its response to different styles and relatively unencumbered by bureaucratic intrigue, this home-grown urban institution has done as much as any European one to uphold a European tradition.
Now to find American symphonic music worthy of its time. The New World Symphony under Michael Tilson Thomas attempted something of the kind at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon. Two of the pieces were by Argentines, but both demonstrated the long arm of North American culture and the powerful African influences that all of the Americas share. 
 It was a program suited to this young group from Miami. Now five years old, the New World Symphony is a kind of postgraduate school with practical applications. It nurtures new conservatory graduates and creates full seasons of professional concerts, tours and recordings.
The four dances from Ginastera's ballet "Estancia" shared with Broadway and the American marching band a love of brass-heavy loudness, a nasty brilliance that mixes optimism with the sarcastic. Also held in common was the use of melody and accompaniment in their most innocent forms. The rhythmic basis was Latin, not black American, but the legitimization, indeed the celebration of vulgarity were qualities with which both ends of this continent could feel at home.
The tone of Astor Piazzolla's "Tangazo" was familiar to anyone who frequents American movies. Here the tango is subjected to dark Wagnerian brooding and then picked apart with cute orchestral flourishes. Unfortunately, there is not enough music in "Tangazo" to support all the inflations and manipulations.
Gershwin's Second Rhapsody would have added a decided American weight to this concert had it not labored so industriously in behalf of European models. There are bright and wonderful moments in it but also a troubling amount of self-conscious gesturing in the direction of Grieg and Rachmaninoff. Mr. Thomas played the difficult piano part himself. He is a talented Sunday pianist, guilty of a few cloudy episodes and a generally thin tone but quite capable of getting through everything else.
The afternoon was really about the Ives Fourth Symphony, a triumph both for what it had to say and for the way it was played. With his celestial (first balcony) harps and strings, the free-for-all competitions within the orchestra and the sophisticated fugue of the third movement, Ives asks questions about the meaning of life that incorporate the naivete of an old-fashioned grange tableau, belly-laugh humor and a deep and worldly sense of regret.
The New World players and the collaborating Penn State Concert Choir have grown up mastering a European style but they have also had rock music, in all its preciseness of movement, sounding around them. With Mr. Thomas's help, they made Ives's hopeless entanglements into clear-cut battles. Having sections of players rise and play standing at key moments reinforced the admirable clarity of this performance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Art Market;
Auction Houses Await The Upturn

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
IT has been a tense few months at Christie's and Sotheby's. With the art market struggling to inch its way out of a two-year recession, putting together the fall sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art hasn't been easy. Many sellers are still holding back, hoping that the market will show signs of a recovery, so it is estate property that the auction houses count on most. Until just weeks ago, when the catalogues had to go to press, the two companies were vying for what little hot property was available.
While the pickings seem slim, the quality is not. Indeed, the 1,260 works up for sale in the next two weeks include some of the strongest paintings, drawings and sculptures to come on the market since 1990. The works go on public view this weekend at Sotheby's and Christie's in Manhattan, beginning tomorrow at 10 A.M. 
 But in this delicate economy, it is hard to predict how the art, conservatively estimated to be worth about $220 million, will fare when the bidding starts on Tuesday night. Most experts are reluctant to speculate whether these sales will signal an upturn in the market.
"It's going to be a slow road back," said Diana D. Brooks, president and chief executive of Sotheby's in North and South America. "Since we are not expecting much dealer participation, the key to the success of these sales will be the private buyers. And until the night of the sale, it's hard to know whether or not they will actually be putting their hands in the air and bidding."
Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads Sotheby's contemporary-art division, said the initial response from collectors had encouraged her to hope that "the stage fright of the last two years has worn off."
Many experts say they have not seen a big change in the market since the last round of major auctions six months ago. "There is still a fair amount of estate property that is reasonably estimated and fresh to the market," said Christopher Burge, president and chief executive of Christie's in New York. Experts at both houses reluctantly concede that a certain number of "retreads," or works that have been up for sale recently, are inevitable in the current economic climate.
Surprisingly, while the auction houses have tried to keep estimates down, there are far more works valued over $1 million this fall than there have been since 1990. While this expensive property is mostly from estates, the question is whether collectors who have made bargain hunting a serious sport for the last two years are willing to spend many millions on one work of art. In May, when prices began to climb into seven figures, bidding tended to stop dead.
"Clearly the waters will be tested for the $2 million-plus paintings," said Michael Findlay, who heads Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art.
In addition to pricier pictures, there is a definite change in the complexion of both auctions, the Impressionist and modern sales and the contemporary. In May, the catalogues of Impressionist and modern works were heavily tipped toward modern art. This season, there are a significant number of Impressionist paintings, works by artists like Monet, Degas, Renoir and Pissaro, whose dollar values have fallen further in the last two years than those of their modern counterparts. "Clearly, we will see what the new level of the Impressionist market will be," Mr. Findlay said.
But he added that the increase in Impressionist works coming on the block was a happy accident. "In a buyer's market, which this one is, often the very best works come up for sale not by design, but by chance -- largely through estates," he said.
Monet's "Waterlily Basin," from 1919, a star of Christie's Impressionist and modern sale, for example, is from the estate of Ralph Friedman, a Manhattan philanthropist and a former director of Bank Leumi Le Israel's North American operations. Christie's issued a separate catalogue to show off the painting, but, playing it safe, won't say what the work may fetch. The catalogue entry reads "estimate on request," and officials at the auction house tell collectors they think the painting should bring about $7 million or $8 million when it goes on the block on Tuesday.
"There hasn't been a waterlilies on the market like this in over 15 years," Mr. Findlay said. "It's one of the few such works that Monet signed and dated when he sold it to his dealers in 1919." And unlike the oversize paintings of waterlilies that one sees at museums, this is 39 1/2 by 79 inches, and so comfortably fits into a home.
The contemporary offerings have changed, too. "It's a more balanced selection, covering four decades across the board," said Diane Upright, who heads the contemporary-art department at Christie's. "This is the first time in 18 months we have seen the Abstract Expressionists up for sale."
Works by artists like Jackson Pollock, Clyfford Still and Mark Rothko are finding their way to auction again. Ms. Upright said that one Pollock, "No. 6, 1948: Blue, Red, Yellow," with an estimate of $2.5 million to $3.5 million, "comes from a private source, has never been on the market before and, most importantly, is of superb quality."
"Last year," she added, "it would have been impossible to have convinced anyone to sell a work of this caliber."
At Sotheby's, Ms. Mitchell-Innes suggested that these significant works were finding their way to auction now because the market had loosened up. "Collectors have lived with the headache of the recession for long enough," she said. "They have become accustomed to the lower prices and want to change their collections." These sellers are also often people who bought the works so long ago they can't help but make a profit.
Many sellers in the contemporary-art market are familiar figures in business. Rothko's "Untitled," from 1957, which is on the cover of Christie's catalogue, is being sold by Marshall Cogan, the New York financier. The work, which carries an estimate of $1.2 million to $1.6 million, is in flawless condition, but art-world experts say it has been offered for sale privately for more than a year. Another highlight of the Christie's sale is Robert Rauschenberg's "Studio Painting," from 1960-61, which is expected to bring more than $3 million. The work belongs to Asher Edelman, a Swiss-based businessman.
At Sotheby's, the seller with the biggest name is easily its chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, who is selling three works from his personal collection: Still's "1947-K," expected to bring $1.5 million to $2 million; Franz Kline's "Elizabeth," from 1958, expected to bring $1.75 million to $2 million, and "Eta," painted by Morris Louis in 1961 and expected to bring $250,000 to $300,000. It is thought that Mr. Taubman is trying to raise money because of today's real-estate market.
Another seller at Sotheby's is Raymond J. Learsy, a New York businessman and collector, who is changing his collection from paintings to drawings. He is offering 11 works by artists including Gerhard Richter, Chuck Close and Julian Schnabel, worth $1.7 million to $2.3 million. And the London-based advertising magnate Charles Saatchi is once again the staple of Sotheby's sale, as he has been for the last year. This year Mr. Saatchi is selling art by such artists as Malcolm Morley, Mr. Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and Cy Twombly.
Of all the Saatchi property, Warhol's "Marilyn X 100," from 1962, is considered so important by Sotheby's that it has its own catalogue. "Of all the subjects that Warhol painted, I think that the Marilyn is the one that commands the most attention and has the most appeal," Ms. Mitchell-Innes said. "The only other one of this scale is in the Tate Gallery in London."
While Sotheby's is reluctant to put a value on the work, Ms. Mitchell-Innes said she hoped it would set a record at the auction on Nov. 17, exceeding the more than $4 million that a single "Red Shot Marilyn" fetched at Christie's in 1989.
In this season, it should come as no surprise that the one artist hogging the limelight at both auction houses is Matisse. It has been years since a great Matisse has found its way to auction, but now a total of 28 paintings, sketches and sculptures by the artist are up for sale. Collectors as well as a museum are hoping to cash in on the success of the Matisse retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Purely by coincidence, two estates also feature important Matisses.
Three paintings are coming down from the walls of the Modern's show just in time for the viewing this weekend and the auctions on Tuesday and Wednesday, and then will be returned to the exhibition until its end on Jan. 12.
Sotheby's and Christie's are each featuring a star Matisse. At Christie's, "Harmony in Yellow," from 1927-28, is expected to bring $5 million to $7 million. The work belongs to Dr. Philip Sandbloom, a Swedish collector. At Sotheby's, "L'Asie," from 1911-12, is being sold by the estate of the fashion designer Mollie Parnis Livingston. It is expected to bring $7 million to $8 million.
To snag the Parnis estate, which also includes paintings by Picasso, Josef Albers and Marsden Hartley, Sotheby's offered Mrs. Livingston an advance, contingent on her promise to consign the property to Sotheby's after her death. She died last summer.
Christie's has also offered advances to sellers. Officials there declined to discuss the subject, but the word in the art world is that the auction house has promised an advance to the heirs of the composer Richard Rodgers and his wife, Dorothy. The property, which also has an important Matisse, is being sold at the Christie's Impressionist and modern art sale.
As the viewing begins, it is the private American collector who appears to be the most likely buyer. "I see many of the people who felt squeezed out of the market by the high prices in 1989 back and interested again," said Mr. Findlay at Christie's. And for bargain hunters, this is one of the last chances to bid before Sotheby's raises its buyer's premium, the commission it charges buyers, to 15 percent from 10 percent on Jan. 1.
"I believe this season will be one of the great buying opportunities for people with courage," said Mr. Nash from Sotheby's. "Bad times like this only last a short while."
 
What, Where and When
 Artworks to be auctioned at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York in the next two weeks will be on view starting this weekend. Admission to viewings and afternoon sales is free. Reserved tickets, also free, are required for evening sales.
Sotheby's is at 1334 York Avenue, at 72d Street, Manhattan. Ticket information: (212) 606-7171. General information: (212) 606-7000. Christie's is at 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, Manhattan. Ticket information: (212) 546-1128. Auction information:  (212) 371-5438. General information: (212) 546-1000.

HEADLINE: Clinton Gets A Letter From Dinkins

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Now that he has "a friend in the White House," Mayor David N. Dinkins is wasting no time trying to capitalize on that friendship, writing President-elect Bill Clinton to tout some of New York City's programs as national models and urging him to spend billions more on urban centers.
Most of Mr. Dinkins's 24-page letter, written less than a day after the polls closed, amounted to a plea for more Federal financing for housing, bridges, roads, health care, schools, job training, police officers and drug treatment. He also asked for the passage of legislation he supports that has been mired in Congress, including a Federal ban on machine guns, bigger tax credits for the poor and a broad-based energy tax. 
 The Mayor urged Mr. Clinton to use several of the city's fledgling programs as models for national initiatives. Specifically, he suggested Mr. Clinton examine the New York police force's "community policing" program, the city's plan to build 20 new neighborhood health clinics that will provide primary care to the poor and its special schools that function as community centers after hours.
Tim Wright, the Clinton campaign's director for domestic policy, said Mr. Clinton had received the letter and that it appeared to include many ideas the President-elect had already said he supported.
Mr. Wright said it was too early to tell what, if any, of the city's programs might be adopted as models by Mr. Clinton's transition team for urban policy. But he said any programs with a proven track records are "going to be important information for us."
But some of the programs Mr. Dinkins cited are still being set up and thus do not have track records, city officials acknowledged. For instance, in the health center program, which the Mayor is urging Mr. Clinton to adopt as a model and finance similar efforts in other cities, 9 of the 20 clinics have been built and the oldest has operated a mere three months.
And in making a pitch for more federally subsidized housing, city officials acknowledged that the Mayor exaggerated the city's efforts to build low-income housing, asserting that "New York City has spent billions of dollars in local resources to rehabilitate hundreds of thousands of housing units." The officials said the city has spent about $2 billion to rehabilitate 115,277 apartments since 1987, but the majority of those jobs involved minor repairs. The city has constructed 9,978 new apartments and done major renovations to 33,321.
Regardless of how many ideas Mr. Dinkins can persuade Mr. Clinton to accept, it is clear that the Arkansas Governor's ascension to the White House is perceived at City Hall as spelling an end to what it perceived as the neglect of cities during 12 years of Republican administrations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The Bush Administration announced a 200 percent import tax on all still white wine from the European Community, retaliating for what it says are barriers to American farm exports. The tax, which takes effect in 30 days, could triple retail prices. But the impact is not likely to be felt until next year, because importers of wine, Cognac and other distilled spirits have been stocking their warehouses, anticipating a trade war. [Page A1.]
 
The Economy
A Federal appeals court dealt a major blow to Hollywood, rejecting a rule that restricted the major television networks from owning and selling the rerun rights to their prime time programs. The decision could allow the networks to sell their reruns to local and cable stations without any restrictions. [A1.] 
 The Justice Department said it would not defend a provision of the new cable television law that requires cable operators to reserve up to a third of their channels for local broadcasters. [D16.]
New unemployment claims in late October fell to 360,000, the lowest in more than two years. [D2.]
 
Companies
Macy promised profound and crucial changes in how it does business as it introduced a five-year plan that it said it hoped would increase sales 33 increase. [D1.]
The nation's big chain stores reported further sales gains in October, raising hopes for a bright holiday season. But most of the October sales came in the first half of the month. [D1.]
Sears won a battle in its efforts to expand its credit card business by issuing Visa cards, when a Federal court jury in Salt Lake City ruled that Visa U.S.A. was violating antitrust laws by excluding Sears. [D1.]
Pondering G.M.'s turmoil and fate, few economists think there is cause for great alarm in the nation if new managers fail to restore profitability or market share. News Analysis. [D1.]
For Ivan Boesky, the price of insider trading rose 50 percent. Mr. Boesky, who has already paid $100 million in penalties, added another $50 million in settling Maxus Energy's lawsuit. [D1.]
A Federal judge in Salt Lake City ruled that USX had idled a mill in Utah five years ago to avoid paying pension benefits to 1,900 steelworkers. The attorney for the steelworkers said the workers might now collect more than $100 million; USX said the damages were more likely to be less than $10 million. [D2.]
Marsh & McLennan and J. P. Morgan opened a reinsurance company in Bermuda, hoping to take advantage of a world catastrophe reinsurance market that is dramatically shrinking. [D4.]
American International Group said net income fell 8.6 percent in the third quarter because of losses from three storms. [D4.]
Terry R. Lautenbach of I.B.M. is taking early retirement, as have 40,000 other employees of the computer giant. He is one of four members of the company's executive committee. [D4.]
 
Markets
All eyes were on this morning's unemployment report as bond traders and dealers prepared their trading strategies. [D12.]
Wall Street stocks ended with healthy gains, buoyed by strong advances in telephone and tobacco company shares. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.80 points, to 3,243.84. [D6.]
Soybean futures plunged sharply as Washington announced punitive taxes on European wine. [D13.] The dollar rose. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
International House of Pancakes is stacking up well on Wall Street, buoyed by its franchisees' fees. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D6.]
D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles is promoting two top executives. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D16.]
