HEADLINE: Times Plans to Build a Plant in Queens

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The New York Times, which had considered moving all of its printing operations out of New York City, has decided instead to build a $280 million printing plant on city-owned land in College Point, Queens, company executives said yesterday.
Under an agreement announced yesterday at a City Hall news conference with Mayor David N. Dinkins, The Times will lease 31 acres in a city-owned industrial park just west of the Whitestone Expressway. The city and state will grant tax incentives, low-cost energy and other benefits worth a total of $29 million over the course of a 35-year lease.
The Times currently employs about 1,000 people in press and delivery operations for the daily newspaper at its corporate headquarters, at 229 West 43d Street in Manhattan. When the new plant is completed -- which company officials said would probably not be until late in the decade, at the earliest -- the printing and distribution operations now in Manhattan will be shifted entirely to College Point. Company officials said they did not know exactly how many people would work at the new plant, which they said was needed to accommodate high-speed color presses.
 
Another Plant in New Jersey
 The business and news operations of The Times, which employ about 2,000 people, will remain on 43d Street, just west of Times Square.
The Times recently completed a $450 million printing plant in Edison, N.J., where advance sections of the Sunday paper are now printed. When that plant is in full operation early next year, the newspaper will begin shutting down an older plant in Carlstadt, N.J. The Sunday sections and some copies of the daily paper have been printed in Carlstadt.
The incentives offered by the city and state to The Times are larger, in proportion to the number of jobs involved, than comparable incentive packages offered recently to other major New York corporations.
But city officials contended that the expense was reasonable because of the large capital investment that The Times will make in the new plant and because manufacturing jobs are particularly hard to attract and keep. The incentives also cover a much longer period than other agreements.
The Times searched for more than 10 years for a large site in the city for a new printing plant for the daily paper, said Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times. Company officials said they had also considered sites in Westchester County and had contemplated rebuilding the Carlstadt plant and equipping it with high-speed color presses.
 
'Host of Reasons'
 That option, which Mr. Sulzberger said would have been less expensive than relocating within New York City, even with the financial incentives, was ultimately dropped in favor of the Queens site.
"For a host of reasons, among them better distribution and a fundamental commitment to this great city, we believe this decision is in the best long-term interest of The Times," Mr. Sulzberger said in a letter to the staff yesterday.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, described the land in College Point -- now the site of a Police Department automobile pound -- as "the perfect size and shape" for a modern printing print.
"We had long hoped to keep some manufacturing operations in New York City," he said at the news conference. Initially, he said, it appeared that retaining the printing operation of the daily paper in New York would be far more expensive than shifting all production and distribution to New Jersey. The incentives helped close the gap, he said.
"The New York Times and the city go back a long way -- to 1851, in fact," he said. "So it's extra fun to stand here and talk about a project that will take us well into the next century. As you must see, we have faith in the city's future and its long-term vitality."
 
'Take Great Pride'
 The Mayor noted that The Times's announcement followed decisions in recent months by other major corporations, including the Morgan Stanley Group, Prudential Securities and four of the five commodities exchanges, to remain in New York.
"We take great pride in serving as the world's communications capital," Mr. Dinkins said. "Today I am especially proud to reaffirm that status in announcing that all the news that's fit to print in The New York Times is going to be fitted and printed in the borough of Queens."
Of the $29 million in incentives, slightly less than $9 million is incentives that the city would offer automatically to any business that would lease the site, said Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The remaining $20 million in incentives are discretionary. About $11.3 million will come from the state, in the form of low-cost electricity from a state-owned nuclear power plant and exemptions from state sales taxes on construction materials, Mr. Weisbrod said.
 
Poor Soil Conditions
 The city will provide an additional $8.7 million in incentives, including a $4.7 million grant to help build a foundation for the building. Soil conditions on the marshy site are very poor, Mr. Weisbrod said. The city will also provide relief from some city sales taxes and payments in lieu of taxes, he said.
The cost of the agreement to the city and state is relatively high, compared with incentives to other corporations. Morgan Stanley agreed last month to a $39.6 million package of incentives to keep 4,100 jobs in Manhattan for 10 years -- or slightly less than $10,000 per job. Prudential Securities is to receive $106 million in tax incentives and energy savings over 20 years to retain 5,000 jobs, or about $21,000 per job. The incentives offered to The Times would come to about $29,000 per job over 35 years if all 1,000 production and distribution jobs now at 43d Street were transferred to Queens.
But Mr. Weisbrod contended that retaining manufacturing jobs was much harder in New York City than retaining white-collar jobs at financial-services companies like Morgan Stanley and Prudential Securities. He also said he could not recall a similarly large investment in a manufacturing plant in the city. "These jobs are awfully important to keep in the city," he said. "They are hard to keep in the city."

HEADLINE: Judge Rules Against Visa In Sears Suit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck & Company won a battle yesterday in its efforts to expand its credit card business by issuing Visa cards, when a Federal court jury in Salt Lake City ruled that Visa U.S.A. was violating antitrust laws by excluding Sears.
The lawsuit charging antitrust violations was filed by Dean Witter Financial Services, a unit of Sears that issues the Discover Card but wants to issue Visa cards as well. 
 Because the Discover card is accepted at only 1.5 million merchants, while Visa cards are accepted by 10 million, Sears in 1990 bought Mountain West Financial, a failed Utah savings and loan association that was a Visa member. But Visa blocked Dean Witter's plan to issue cards through Mountain West.
 
Visa May Appeal Verdict
 Visa officials said yesterday that they planned to ask the court to overturn the jury's verdict, and if that failed, to appeal the decision. They contend that forcing Visa to share its name and expertise in the card business with a direct competitor would lead to reduced competition between the card systems.
"That would be like forcing Dean Witter to share its resource and trade secrets with Merrill Lynch," said H. Robert Heller, president of Visa.
B. J. Martin, an executive at Dean Witter in charge of its proposed new Visa card, said the jury verdict would increase competition by giving consumers more choice about the kind of card they use.
Dean Witter plans to issue a Visa card with no annual fee, and at a variety of interest rates depending on the elapsed time before the consumer pays the bill.
Mr. Martin said that the Discover card and the new Visa card would be two separate businesses with different prices and customer standards, but that they would share some computer centers for processing transactions and maintaining customer records.
Visa officials learned of Sears's plans when they received an unexpected order for 1.5 million new cards from tiny Mountain West. They quickly invoked a rule in Visa's bylaws that says that the corporations owning American Express and Discover may not belong to Visa because those cards are direct competitors. Visa, like Mastercard, is owned by the approximately 6,000 banks and savings institutions that issue the cards.
Dean Witter's efforts to expand in the increasingly competitive credit card business coincide with a recent announcement by Sears that it planned to sell 20 percent of Dean Witter to investors and distribute the remainder to Sears's shareholders.
Last month the Discover card, which earned nearly $200 million in the first nine months of this year and has 39 million cards outstanding, announced plans to reduce its 19.8 percent interest rate for some customers, with the size of the reduction depending on how much the card is used.

HEADLINE: In Possible Sign on Jobs, Subway Ridership Is Up

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
After declining for 32 months in a row, the number of people riding the subway has finally begun to pick up, climbing modestly for three consecutive months, transit officials said yesterday.
The increase, economists and transit officials said, may be an early signal that New York City's long-suffering economy is turning around: above all other reasons, passengers board the subway when they have a job to go to and stay home when they do not. 
 "There isn't any question that the subway is very sensitive to employment," said Alan F. Kiepper, president of the Transit Authority. "While we have no firm figures yet to show employment going up, we suspect that's been happening."
Subway ridership grew 1.3 percent in July, nine-tenths of 1 percent in August and 1.8 percent in September compared with the same months in 1991, according to figures to be formally released at a Transit Authority committee meeting next week. September's daily average of 3.2 million passengers, however, is still more than 7 percent below the subway's peak in 1989, when ridership reached 3.45 million passengers each day. Figures for October have not yet been tallied, transit officials said.
The rise in ridership on the subways has not been matched on the buses. Ridership there has continued a slow decline, falling every month since July 1989. Buses are not used by as many commuters as are subways and have faced growing competition from gypsy vans.
Economists say the subway system is often an early gauge of job growth, available several months before employment figures account for that growth. In the New York City area, they are encouraged by similar ridership increases in other commuter networks.
Ridership grew 1 percent on the Metro-North commuter railroad from July through September, after dropping slightly for seven consecutive quarters. The Port Authority recorded a slightly more than 1 percent growth in the number of vehicles crossing the Hudson River in July, August and September.
"It's an encouraging sign," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "We find that travel data tend to be a good economic indicator, and over the course of the past 15 years it has tracked very well."
Other economists, however, warned that the current economic situation in New York City is still bleak. Unemployment in New York City hit 11.4 percent in September, up sharply from 7.7 percent a year earlier, but down from the recent peak of 12.1 percent in July, according to the State Department of Labor. Retail sales are also down.
"We haven't hit bottom yet from any numbers we're looking at," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner for the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
According to Transit Authority figures, ridership on the subways was relatively stable during the early 1980's, when employment in New York City remained almost constant. A significant growth in ridership came from 1985 to 1989, years when employment in New York City grew most sharply, and also years when the subway system saw improvement in service and conditions.
Since July, transit officials warned, other factors apart from employment could also have influenced subway-ridership figures, measured by token revenue and adjusted for discounted riders such as senior citizens and disabled people. They do not include fare evaders or students who ride for free.
For example, July revenue may have been inflated by the Democratic National Convention and Fourth of July tall ships celebration. And, the August improvement may actually be a reflection of a drop in ridership during 1991, when disruptions followed a derailment at 14th Street that killed five people and injured 200 others.
But Mr. Kiepper said there were no obvious reasons why ridership was up in September, although he noted that the authority had been trying to crack down on fare evasion, which might have had some impact.
Joseph G. Rappaport, coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign, suggested another possible cause of the increase in ridership: Some riders stop using the subway immediately after a fare increase but gradually resume riding as they get used to the higher fare.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS - ADVERTISING;
D.M.B.& B. Promotes 2 Executives to Shore Up Basics

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
D'ARCY MASIUS BENTON & BOWLES is promoting two top executives to newly created positions with worldwide responsibilities, in a move to strengthen the giant agency's capabilities in fundamental areas like landing new business and improving creative output.
Richard V. Hopple, 45 years old, who rejoined D.M.B.& B. in April, is being named vice chairman of corporate strategic development. And John Nieman, 43, who has been vice chairman and chief creative officer at the agency's North American division, is being named vice chairman and worldwide creative director. 
 Both executives, who are members of the agency's board and worldwide management group, will report to Roy J. Bostock, chairman and chief executive.
The two appointments typify efforts by larger agencies to try focusing on longer-range goals at a time when shorter-term problems seem to be consuming most of their energies. D.M.B.& B., with billings of $4.5 billion, is the world's 10th-largest agency organization, according to the 1991 rankings by Advertising Age. Among its huge clients are Anheuser-Busch, Burger King, the Pontiac and Cadillac divisions of General Motors, Kraft General Foods and Procter & Gamble.
"One of the real needs in this industry is to plan longer term," Mr. Bostock said in an interview yesterday at the agency's office in midtown Manhattan, where he was joined by Mr. Hopple and Mr. Nieman.
"It's very easy to get caught up in the crisis of the day," he added, "when you've got a weak economy or a slow recovery or whatever you want to call it, which puts pressure on clients and on yourselves."
The appointments follow a regional realignment of the agency in April. Three regional presidents -- Clayton E. Wilhite, North America; George J. Simko, Europe, and John Ferries, Asia/Pacific and Latin America -- continue to report to Mr. Bostock. He described them as "the line operators of the existing businesses, devoting virtually all their time to current clients," compared with Mr. Hopple and Mr. Nieman, who are becoming "the key staff executives."
Mr. Hopple was expected to be named to a senior position at the agency; he had been operating sans title since he returned to D.M.B.& B. after five years at Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, where he served as president and head of its marketing communications division.
"I've been sort of the chief 'wanderer arounder' here," Mr. Hopple said.
"When you don't have a title," he added, "you understand how unimportant they are." Still, he has now acquired one, and a nifty one it is, too.
Mr. Hopple had been concentrating on overseeing several Kraft General Foods brands, duties he will continue in his new position. He said the ferment on the agency's Kraft General Foods accounts has ended after the loss last month of the estimated $14 million Louis Rich turkey-products account to Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago. There has been widespread speculation that its hold on other Kraft General Foods accounts, like Crystal Light soft-drink mixes and Entenmann's baked goods, remains tenuous.
Mr. Nieman, who joined the agency in May 1989 after stints at McCann-Erickson New York and Young & Rubicam, proudly played a videotape of what he termed the agency's more innovative work around the world for clients like Anheuser-Busch, Philips and Qantas.
"We're better creatively than we're generally given credit for," he asserted. Indeed, the agency is known for producing predominantly prosaic campaigns for stalwart packaged goods like Charmin bathroom tissue, Good Seasons salad dressings and Pampers diapers.
Mr. Nieman was particularly pleased with a new American Burger King campaign, which features Dan Cortese, a young MTV host, in a fast-paced series of spots called BK TeeVee -- as in Burger King Television -- that carry the theme "I love this place!" That campaign is believed to be a make-or-break one for the agency on its $130 million portion of the Burger King account, which it shares with Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York; Advertising Age reported that Burger King has been talking informally with J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., which created the infamous "Herb the Nerd" campaign for the fast feeder.
"Part of my job is to increase the hit ratio," Mr. Nieman said, "and make sure we create more visible work across the board."
Or to have clients exuberantly proclaiming "I love this shop!," to paraphrase Mr. Cortese, rather than pigeonholing the agency as a home to Herbs.

HEADLINE: October Sales Give Retailers a Brighter Holiday Outlook

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The nation's big chain stores reported further sales gains in October, continuing a trend that began in August and raising hopes among analysts that for the first time in four years retailers will not have a cold Christmas.
Still, doubts about the future remain, largely because most of the October sales came in the first half of the month. 
"We are seeing some improvement in the tone of retail sales that dates back to August," said Robert F. Buchanan, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore. "I don't want to make too much of the weakness recorded at the end of the month, but we will keep an eye on what happens in November."
Wayne Hood, a retail analyst at Prudential Securities, said some of the slippage in the final week of October was weather-related.
According to an index of sales at 50 chain stores compiled by Prudential Securities, sales rose by 6.5 percent last month, compared with a rise of 5.9 percent in September.
Meanwhile, an index of sales at 15 leading retailers compiled by Salomon Brothers rose by 7.5 percent, compared with a 7.3 percent increase in September.
Sales gains were particularly impressive at Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer. But some fashion retailers continued to struggle; sales at Gap Inc. were disappointing.
Wal-Mart, which benefited from two extra shopping days last month compared with October 1991, reported a 16 percent gain in sales at stores open at least a year. But even without those two extra days, analysts said Wal-Mart's sales were up about 12 percent.
Among other large retailers, the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fourth largest, said sales rose by 7.4 percent, a gain that was smaller than anticipated.
Stephen E. Watson, president of Dayton Hudson, said in a statement that sales at the company's Target and Mervyn's stores were softer than expected, in large part because of weakness in California.
Wall Street did not like the numbers, and the price of Dayton Hudson's shares slid by $1.50 on the Big Board yesterday, to $74.50.
At Gap, heavy promotions did not bolster sales, which rose a meager 2 percent last month. And the Kmart Corporation said same-store sales rose just 3.2 percent.
At Sears, Roebuck & Company, same-store sales rose by 3.9 percent in October. The company said sales increased in almost all merchandise categories, including big-ticket items like major appliances. But Sears's automotive business, which has been hurt by fraud charges, continued to fare poorly.
Kim Walin, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers, said that despite the continued slow improvement, "department and discount stores still have a better tone than specialty stores."
Analysts acknowledged that significant impediments to a surge in consumer spending, like persistently high unemployment and continued layoff announcements, remain in place.
 
Sign of Hope
 But many said they expected consumer confidence levels to improve in the wake of the Presidential election and lift the Christmas shopping season, which this year is two days longer than it was in 1991.
"There are mixed signals out there, but we believe the environment this Christmas will be favorable, particularly from a profit standpoint," said Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers. Aside from the advantage of being open two more days this year than last, "inventories and expenses will be very tightly controlled" in the coming Christmas season, he said.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Drop to a 2-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
New unemployment claims in late October fell to 360,000, the lowest in more than two years, the Government said today.
The Labor Department report, considered a sign of hope amid other more dismal economic news, said jobless claims fell by 16,000, from 376,000 the week before. 
 Economists had been looking for an increase of 5,000 to 10,000. It was the lowest number of weekly claims since the week ending Aug. 4, 1990, near the start of the recession, when 354,000 Americans filed for jobless benefits.
 
Productivity Gains
 In another report, the department said the productivity of American workers increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.6 percent during the July-September quarter, the best showing in six months.
The Labor Department also reported that labor costs, a measure of inflationary pressures, rose slightly but remained at the lowest level in a year.
A moving four-week average of unemployment claims, considered a more reliable indicator of labor market trends than the usually volatile weekly numbers, also hit a new low. The average was 371,500, the lowest since the four-week period ending Aug. 25, 1990, when the average was 371,000.
Economists cautioned that the number might look more favorable than actual labor market conditions. Since the start of August, some unemployed people have been eligible for benefits under a special emergency program passed by Congress last summer.
Had those claimants been included, the latest weekly number would have been 22,456 higher. The moving four-week average would have been 22,745 higher.
 
Positive Trend
 But even factoring in the emergency claims, the trend is still positive and it could presage an improvement in the nation's unemployment rate in October, which the department is scheduled to report on Friday.
The rate in September was 7.5 percent, down from an eight-year high of 7.8 percent in June.
But economists cautioned that improvement in the job situation would be gradual. Many employers appear to have stopped laying off workers, but companies, turned cautious by the long period of economic stagnation, have been slow to start rehiring.

HEADLINE: Phone and Tobacco Stocks Lead Market Up

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Wall Street stocks ended with healthy gains yesterday, buoyed by strong advances in telephone and tobacco company shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 20.80 points, to 3,243.84, and volume rose to 219.7 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 194.4 million on Wednesday. Advancing issues outpaced decliners, 975 to 812. 
 The Dow transportation index rose 19.94 points, to 1,380.31 and the Nasdaq index shot up 8.56, to 614.08.
"There's a little better tone," said Richard Meyer of Ladenburg Thalmann. "Stocks are reacting to different stories."
American Telephone and Telegraph was up 1 5/8, to 44 3/8, on its plan to buy one-third of McCaw CellularCommunications, which jumped 5 1/4, to 32.
Philip Morris gained 3 1/4, to 78 5/8, after the tobacco company announced that the plaintiff's attorney in a closely watched smoking liability case had withdrawn the lawsuit. The other major gainers among tobacco stocks were RJR Nabisco up 1/8, to 8 7/8; American Brands up 1 1/4, to 43, and Loews 3 5/8 higher at 115 1/2.
Technology and transportation stocks were also strong.
Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist at Kemper Securities said he had raised his stock asset allocation, now that the uncertainty surrounding the Presidential race had lifted.
He allocated 60 percent of his investment portfolio to stocks, up from 50 percent, and lowered bond holdings to 35 percent from 40 percent and pared cash to 5 percent from 10 percent.
"Basically, we're pleased with the way things are developing after the election," he said. "Plenty of stocks which were oversold are coming back to life, especially in the technology area."
Among technology gainers, Novell rose 1 3/4, to 32; Intel added 2 3/8, to 70; Microsoft rose 3 3/8, to 91 7/8, and Apple Computer was up 2 1/2, to 55.
Mexican stocks surged after the Mexican President's office said the United States President-elect, Bill Clinton, had pledged his total support for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
"Today, there's a combination of transport and Nasdaq strength, which are bringing blue chips up," said Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International. "You're also seeing transports doing well again. Some of the airlines are doing well, with the assumption the economy is likely to pick up."
But Mr. Walberg noted that the pivotal October jobs report due today "could be the first challenge Clinton faces." Economists expect payrolls to expand by 25,000 and the jobless rate to hold steady at 7.5 percent.
In the transports, UAL rose 3 3/4, to 125 1/4; Delta Air Lines gained 2 1/2, to 58 3/4, and AMR was up 2 1/8, to 65 5/8.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.23 points, to 418.34. The American Stock Exchange index was up 0.75, to 382.69.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.58, to 230.37. The average share gained 9 cents.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Treasury Official to Join First Boston

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
In one of the first post-election retirements of a high Bush Administration official, David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, announced today that he would be joining CS First Boston Inc. in New York.
Mr. Mulford, known for his Savile Row suits, bright suspenders, detachable collars and gold cuff links, will become vice chairman of the First Boston Corporation and deputy chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston, two CS First Boston units. 
 Mr. Mulford, who became an international affairs specialist at the Treasury -- and its most colorful official -- in 1984, said he was joining CS First Boston because he considered it "the most international of all the major investment banks."
 
A Number of Roles
 He was Washington's coordinator for the meetings of the Group of Seven finance ministers and played a pivotal role in putting together the $24 billion Western aid package for Russia. He also worked closely with the former Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, in developing the 1985 Plaza Accord, which helped bring down the value of the dollar.
At First Boston, Mr. Mulford will work on developing business on a worldwide basis. He will work closely on Latin America, where he has worked extensively on debt restructuring deals as a Government official.
As the Treasury official in charge of international economic policy making, the 55-year-old native of Rockford, Ill., would sometimes mysteriously appear in the same weekend in Washington, Paris and Moscow as part of behind-the-scenes work on a debt restructuring or as a sort of sherpa for the Group of Seven.
Mr. Mulford said in an interview that he decided a year ago that he was going to leave, but added that he stayed on this year to work on debt reduction programs for Argentina and Brazil and on an aid package for Moscow.
He gives Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, high marks for the changes he has made since taking power a year ago. "It's amazing they have accomplished as much as they have in the short time they have been in power."
 
Adviser to Saudis
 Before joining the Treasury, Mr. Mulford spent eight years as senior investment adviser at the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency. Mr. Mulford graduated from Lawrence Uhiversity in Appleton, Wis., in 1959, and received a master's degree in politicial science from Boston University in 1962. Three years later, he received a doctorate in philosophy from Oxford University, where he concentrated on African issues.
Mr. Mulford will also be associated with the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington as a distinguished scholar.
Looking back at his years in the Treasury under Presidents Bush and Reagan, he said: "It's been a period of enormous change in the world economy. We have seen the globalization of our economy, the growth of world capital markets, the deregulation of markets, and the freer and faster flow of capital movements and the need to coordinate policy."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading; Data on Economy Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday in a quiet day of trading, while gold prices fell.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $336.20 an ounce, off 90 cents from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $336.60, off 70 cents an ounce. 
 Marc Chandler, a market strategist with the financial consulting firm Idea, said dollar trading was confined to narrow trading ranges with little customer demand.
"We need to wait for payroll data," he said, referring to the monthly unemployment report the Labor Department will issue this morning. The Federal Reserve will also release its consumer credit report today.
In London, the pound fell to $1.5355, from $1.5510 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.5365 to buy a pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.5435.
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen to 122.85, down from 123.05 yen at Wednesday's close. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 122.68 yen, down 0.22 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 122.75 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5915 German marks, up from 1.5730; 1.4190 Swiss francs, up from 1.4055; 5.3505 French francs, up from 5.3220; 1,352.50 Italian lire, up from 1,335.50, and 1.24975 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2467.
On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.926 an ounce, up from $3.837 on Wednesday. Silver bullion rose in London rose to a late bid of $3.95 a troy ounce, up from $3.85 bid late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Profit Up 82% At News Corp.

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said today that its earnings jumped 82 percent in the latest quarter, with most of its operations posting gains.
 But analysts said the results were helped more by lower interest rates and currency gains from a weaker Australian dollar than by improvements in business. 
 The company said it earned $193.7 million (Australian), or $134.8 million (United States), in its first quarter ended in September, up from $106.5 million.
The company said that in the United States, earnings rose sharply at its Fox television network because of higher advertising revenue, while TV Guide magazine and the free-standing insert division had improved profits.

HEADLINE: On Trade Ties to Hanoi, Japanese Jump the Gun

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Jumping ahead of American policy in Asia, the Japanese Government announced today that it was resuming broad economic ties with Vietnam, including the offer of a major loan package, senior Japanese officials said.
The move comes in response to heavy pressure from Japanese business groups, which have urged the governing Liberal Democratic Party to pave the way for a variety of long-planned investments in Vietnam by Japanese companies. Tokyo is expected to announce a $375 million package on Friday, and that may be followed by loans from its Export-Import Bank. 
 Some government officials and business executives familiar with the internal debate over the issue said the Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa had postponed its announcement until after the American elections. It feared that acting earlier would open Japan to criticism during the Presidential campaign that it was catering to the Japanese business interests while questions remain unresolved about the fate of American soldiers missing since the Vietnam War.
With the recent announcement by Hanoi that it would open its records on American P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s, Washington is expected to move fairly quickly to lift the American embargo on trade with Vietnam and to begin to normalize relations.
Japanese officials said they had informed the United States of their actions, but they declined to characterize the American response. They also said Japan had urged the Vietnamese to provide more information about the missing Americans.
Unlike the United States, Japan never broke relations with Hanoi after the American pullout from Vietnam. But in 1979, after Vietnamese troops invaded Cambodia, it halted virtually all aid to the Communist Government. Vietnam, in return, refused to pay back Japanese loans amounting to nearly $200 million, and since then economic relations have been stalled.
A senior Japanese official involved in the decision over Vietnam said recently that "we are looking at this as a symbol," and that Japan has told the United States that "we want U.S. relations with Vietnam normalized."
American officials have said little publicly about Japan's impending action, though the Bush Administration was apparently informed of it several months ago. Last week Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the acting Secretary of State, said during a visit to Tokyo that "whatever the Japanese Government decides to do, we have our own view of how to proceed."
"We will not be affected by what the Japanese Government decides," he added.
For Japan, the decision appears to edge away from foreign policy positions that were largely defined by the United States. In recent months Japan has been stepping up its warming of relations with China, capped by a tour of the country last month by Emperor Akihito. Tokyo has also kept up a dialogue with the repressive Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, where Japanese diplomats insist that quiet persuasion -- and continued relief aid -- has begun to soften the regime.
For the Vietnamese, courting Japan has been a major priority. Not only is Tokyo the largest contributor of aid, it is also the likeliest source of capital to rebuild the country's decrepit infrastructure. Some here say the expanded relationship with Japan may place subtle pressure on the United States to restore diplomatic relations and end its trade embargo, though Japanese officials deny that this is their goal.
Among Japanese companies, Vietnam is considered one of Asia's last frontiers: a cheap and well-educated work force, in a country with enough population density to become a prime market, over time, for the lowest-tech Japanese goods.
Already Ho Chi Minh City's hotels are brimming over with Japanese businessmen, looking for everything from oil contracts to good sites for low-technology factories. Japanese-made products, especially electronics, are already widely sold. Executives say they want to lay the groundwork for the day when Thailand and Malaysia, two other countries that have received enormous Japanese capital investment in recent years, become too expensive for further expansion.
 
Business Dealings Grow
 Over the last two years, several of Japan's giant trading houses have opened small offices for representatives in Vietnam. Recently five Japanese companies joined to open a shipping and distribution company that could send manufacturing plants and equipment to Vietnam. Mitsubishi Oil Company recently signed a contract for rights to conduct test borings for oil off Vietnam's southern coast.
Before they expanded further, however, the Japanese companies wanted to see Japanese aid pouring into the country, partly as insurance that their bills would be paid. "We knew that we had to get past the burden of the unpaid old loans," said an official of Mitsui, one of the trading houses with a growing presence in Vietnam. "But they have oil and cheap labor, and because the infrastructure is so limited, we can expect some business to build it."
Japanese officials, in announcing the package this morning, said that they had received "support" from the United States for the resumption of aid. Under the package announced today, the $375 million loan must be repaid within 30 years, but Japan will charge no interest for the first 10 years and only 1 percent interest thereafter.
Vietnam will pay off its outstanding loans with cash received under the new program. That is expected to leave more than $200 million for projects to rebuild the country's shattered roads, and to build new factories and housing.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Re-examining Policy
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (Special to The New York Times) -- Buoyed by a Vietnamese decision to turn over archival material on missing Americans, the Bush Administration is re-examining its policy on recognition of Vietnam and the lifting of a trade and aid embargo, officials say.
American companies have been pressing President Bush to allow trade and investment in Vietnam, where, in addition to the Japanese, businesses from Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, Hong Kong and Thailand have been very active.
Under a road map to recognition given to the Vietnamese a year ago, "substantial" progress on explaining the fate of missing Americans could lead to the lifting of the embargo and the opening of an American liaison office in Hanoi and a Vietnamese office in Washington.
Full diplomatic recognition, according to the Bush Administration's plan, would await a democratic election in Cambodia, tentatively scheduled for next spring. President-elect Bill Clinton has given no indication that this timetable would change.

HEADLINE: U.S. RECALLS ENVOY TO BURKINA FASO

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Concerned that a civil war in Liberia may be developing into a wider regional crisis, the Bush Administration recalled its Ambassador from Burkina Faso today, asserting that the country is supplying weapons to the Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor.
The State Department spokesman, saying covert military aid was undermining Liberian peace efforts, also said President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso had been asked to cancel plans for a new envoy to Washington. The Ambassador recalled by Washington is Edward P. Brynn. 
 Libya was the source of at least some of the arms reaching Liberia through Burkina Faso, The Associated Press reported, quoting unnamed United States officials.
Mr. Taylor and the National Patriotic Front are being held responsible for the killing of five American nuns last month in a suburb of Monrovia, the Liberian capital. Mr. Taylor, whose army is challenging a West African peacekeeping force for control of the city, has denied responsibility.
 
Search for Slain Nuns
 Today Momulo V. Sackor Sirleaf, foreign minister in Mr. Taylor's shadow government, said at a news conference here that the accusations were part of a campaign against the rebel leader. But he did not deny the nuns had been killed.
The State Department insisted again that Mr. Taylor was responsible.
"None of us would be happier to see the five nuns alive than the people that have been working on this," the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said today. "Unfortunately the information that we have is that they are dead, and that they died in territory controlled" by the Taylor forces.
He said that American officials were still searching for the bodies. The five nuns, in their 50's and 60's, were members of the Adorers of the Blood of Christ order, in Illinois.
 
Marine Force Delayed
 The Pentagon said today that a Marine amphibious task force was holding exercises near the Canary Islands, off the west coast of Africa. The force, which was on its way to the Mediterranean to relieve a similar unit there, has been delayed by rescue operations after the loss of a helicopter, a Defense Department spokesman said.
In a long criticism of Burkina Faso, formerly Upper Volta, Mr. Boucher said the Administration had warning its Government against giving support to Mr. Taylor, "only to be confronted time and time again, with evidence of continued Burkinabic military aid.
"The situation in Liberia has deteriorated rapidly since Oct. 15, and Burkina Faso has helped exacerbate the situation." Reports from Monrovia say several thousand people have died in recent fighting.
There were reports today that Senegal, concerned about the worsening situation in Liberia, was preparing to withdraw its peacekeeping forces. Without disclosing details, State Department officials confirmed that there had been cable exchanges on the Senegalese position.
Liberia, founded by freed American slaves, traditionally has had close ties with the United States, where Mr. Taylor was educated. Another rebel leader, Prince Johnson, has surrendered to the seven-nation peacekeeping force, installed two years ago by the Economic Community of West African States.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: THE INDEPENDENT;
Why Perot Thrived in Fertile Kansas

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 5

 BODY:
One of the original Kansas populists, an orator named Mary Elizabeth Lease, reportedly urged farmers in the 1890's to "raise less corn and more hell." That's exactly what Kansans did on Election Day, when they turned out in record numbers and gave Ross Perot 27 percent of their vote, one of the highest percentages for him in any state.
While not the only factor contributing to Mr. Perot's success here, the Kansas tradition of prairie populism clearly made the state a fertile field for the seeds that he broadcast. At least partly because of Mr. Perot's influence, President Bush won the state by only 5 percentage points over Gov. Bill Clinton, less than half of the 13-point margin of victory enjoyed here by Republicans in the last two Presidential elections. 
 If there is a common thread running through Kansas and the eight other states where Mr. Perot won at least a quarter of the vote -- Alaska, Idaho, Maine, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Utah and Wyoming -- it is a history of fiercely independent and often contrarian politics. People everywhere talk about not putting up with politics as usual, but in these states they seem to mean it.
And if there is anything that voters in Kansas and other Perot strongholds will not tolerate, it is politicians who do not talk straight.
"The people of Kansas are very fair," said Gov. Joan Finney, a Democrat and self-described populist who was elected in 1990. "They don't demand a lot. But one thing they do demand from their public officials is honesty. For so many years, business here was done just by a handshake. And so your word is important."
In interview after interview over the last two days, Perot voters in Kansas said they did not trust Mr. Bush because of his broken vow to hold the line on taxes. They said they also could not bring themselves to trust Mr. Clinton.
"Both Bush and Clinton tried to appeal to whatever group they were appearing before," said Terry Fink, a 40-year-old pharmacist from Overland Park, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City, Mo. "It was nice to have someone like Perot who said, 'This is what we need to do, and I don't care if it makes some people unhappy.' "
 
The Right Personality
 Experts on Kansas politics said Mr. Perot's personality had special appeal in the Great Plains and Rocky Mountain states. "People saw Perot not getting respect, being denigrated, and they could identify with this guy," said Burdett A. Loomis, a professor of political science at the University of Kansas. "There's a sense in the Plains that we're the part of the country that people fly over. And here's a guy who says: 'Wait a minute. You've got to take us seriously.' "
More than one in four Kansas voters felt that way, and there is no way to tell how much better Mr. Perot would have done if he had not dropped out of the race for a time.
The state's populist streak is not the only factor that helped Mr. Perot in Kansas, where 43 percent of the voters are registered Republicans and 31 percent are Democrats. Kansas is home to what has become known as Bob Dole Republicanism, an amalgam of fiscal conservatism, moderation on social issues and a personal disdain for George Bush, all voiced by Mr. Perot.
Because the state's unemployment rate is 4 percent, compared with 7.6 percent nationwide, many here view the reduction of the Federal budget deficit as more important than job creation. Mr. Perot's relentless emphasis on eliminating the deficit found a receptive audience here.
Mr. Dole, who won his own re-election campaign on Tuesday, questioned whether Perot supporters in the state actually knew that Mr. Perot's deficit-reduction proposals included measures like cutting farm subsidies and Medicare benefits.
"Whether they read the fine print or they just liked what they saw, I don't know," the Senate minority leader said. "But people were blaming Bush for the economy, weren't sure about Clinton, and Perot was fresh and rich and had good sound bite material. He made it all sound easy -- easier than it is, of course."
 
Strained Relations
 Mr. Dole, whose relations with Mr. Bush have been strained since their 1988 rivalry for the Republican Presidential nomination, often had nice things to say about Mr. Perot. He suggested on national television 10 days ago that "there may be a place for Ross Perot in the next Bush Administration." Mr. Perot finished second in Mr. Dole's home county, falling only 87 votes short of defeating Mr. Bush out of 3,959 votes cast.
As in most of the states where Mr. Perot did well, Kansas was not a main target of either the Democrats or Republicans. That was probably because it has only 6 electoral votes and a long history of voting Republican in Presidential elections. In any event, the lack of attention by the major parties left the state wide open for Mr. Perot.
One of his strongest state organizations developed here, and it pioneered what came to be known as "the wave campaign," in which Perot supporters lined highways to shake banners and placards at passing motorists.
Orville Sweet, the director of the Perot organization in Kansas, said his group signed up about 2,000 volunteers, about 400 of whom stayed active in telephoning voters and canvassing. He said they operated for three months on a budget of less than $50,000. Most of the money came from the Perot headquarters in Dallas; the rest from the sale of what Mr. Sweet called "T 'n' T -- trinkets and trash."
Mr. Bush carried Kansas with 39 percent of the vote, compared with 34 percent for Mr. Clinton. But Mr. Perot, aided by the remarkable 85 percent turnout that he helped inspire, won 27 percent. Only Maine, Utah and Idaho had higher Perot votes as the Texan picked up 19 percent nationwide, the best showing for an independent or third-party candidate in 80 years. The states where Mr. Perot excelled are rural, conservative and populated predominantly by whites. He did not fare well with minority voters.
In Kansas, which is 90 percent white, Mr. Perot did reasonably well in all parts of the state. He carried a scattering of small counties and won about a quarter of the vote in each of the largest counties -- 25 percent in the affluent and heavily Republican suburbs of Kansas City, Mo. (Johnson County); 26 percent in Wichita (Sedgwick County); 25 percent in the state capital of Topeka (Shawnee County), 22 percent in the Democratic stronghold of Kansas City, Kan. (Wyandotte County), and 23 percent in the university town of Lawrence (Douglas County).
Mr. Perot seemed to do slightly better in Republican areas than in Democratic ones. He received a total of 28 percent of the vote in the five counties with the highest proportion of Republican voters and 24 percent in the five counties with the highest proportion of Democratic voters.
"I'd say far more Republicans voted for Perot than Democrats, according to my polling," said Representative Dan Glickman, a Democrat. "Kansas Republicans have always been economic populists, and Bush couldn't be more anti-populist in image."

HEADLINE: A Hurricane's Long-Lasting Impact

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Two and a half months after Hurricane Andrew swept through South Florida, officials say the daily lives of virtually all of Dade County's two million residents have been altered in fundamental ways.
And while the cleanup is progressing, county and other officials predict it will be three to five years before residents begin to feel that their lives have returned to normal. 
 According to city and county reports, tens of thousands of people have been forced to change where they work, live or send their children to school, and many are enduring big increases in commuting time and in what they pay for rent, food and building materials.
 
Community to Disappear
 In one especially striking example, Naranja Lakes, a condominium community of more than 3,000 people near Homestead, where the storm's damage was most severe, is about to disappear.
Before Andrew struck, Naranja Lakes was much like any other suburban development here. Retirees, military personnel and young couples once flocked to the two- and three-bedroom units, built around four small lakes and close to shopping malls, golf courses and fishing.
But the storm's ferocious winds destroyed all that, and late last month residents of the development, just north of Homestead Air Force Base, met and decided not to rebuild. Instead, all but 241 of the complex's 1,568 units will be demolished, four of its condominium associations legally dissolved and apartment owners given a lump-sum payment to cover their losses.
"To tell the truth, a lot of the people who used to live here have already moved and started new lives," said Eric Carlo, a former air-freight handler who moved to Naranja Lakes after Eastern Air Lines went under and took his job with it. "They just don't want to have to think about this anymore."
Officials say that because of the extent of the damage and the upheavals in people's lives, it will take years to assess Andrew's permanent aftereffects, but some things are known.
The storm left 85,000 homes in Dade County severely damaged or beyond repair. As a result, disaster relief officials estimate, more than 10 percent of the county's residents have been forced to seek temporary living quarters, many of them in Broward County to the north.
In addition, a study by the Dade County finance and planning department estimates that 65,000 jobs have been lost at least temporarily. In addition, it projects that the local economy will lose $2.9 billion in the output of goods and services over the next year.
The county has said it will take in at least $50 million less than expected in revenue this fiscal year, mostly because of a decline in property tax collections. County officials have ordered every department to make further cuts in an already-austere budget.
 
Housing Shortage
 The lasting impact of the storm has been most immediately visible in the commercial and residential real estate markets, which had been a renter's and buyer's paradise because of excessive construction in the 1980's. With tens of thousands of homes classified as at least temporarily "uninhabitable," Dade County is experiencing a housing shortage that has driven rents skyward and threatens to put the most vulnerable groups, like lower-income families and retired people, out of the market.
A moratorium decreed in September by the city of Homestead on the installation of mobile homes, which were among the structures that fared the worst in Andrew's 145-mile-an-hour winds, has deprived such groups of cheaper alternatives to traditional housing. Many of those displaced from the 9,000 mobile homes destroyed by the storm have said they fear their insurance checks will be eaten up before they find housing they can afford.
The same kind of competition has occurred for prime commercial real estate in the adjoining counties. Large corporations that had their headquarters in the disaster zone, like Burger King and the American Bankers Insurance Group, are moving northward, saying they will return when their main offices can be rebuilt.
Even before Hurricane Andrew hit, Miami was faltering from the bankruptcies of Pan American and Eastern airlines, two major employers. Now, "Dade faces a double recovery, from the recession and from the storm," according to a report by the Bureau of Economic and Business Research at the University of Florida.
Homestead Air Force Base, another large employer before the storm, remains closed, with its future uncertain as a result of Congress's refusal to authorize a $473 million appropriation to rebuild. Cutler Ridge Mall, the largest shopping center in South Dade, is also shut, and businesses there have not been told when they may be able to reopen.
According to the Florida Department of Labor, unemployment in Dade County, which had been running at 11 percent in August, rose in September as a result of Hurricane Andrew to 11.5 percent, the highest rate in more than 12 years. In contrast, the overall unemployment rate in the state fell from 9.4 percent to 9.1 percent. The national average is 7.2 percent.
Faced with the resulting decline in its tax base, the county government has responded by looking for ways to cut spending, among other things ordering delays in $22 million in construction projects. It has also said the fire department and library system will have to absorb the bulk of any revenue shortages.
As Dade's troubles mount, officials say, businesses and residents are heading north in search of more normal conditions, and neighboring Broward County, with a population of 1.25 million people spreading outward from Fort Lauderdale, has been on the receiving end of much of the flow. An unexpected consequence has been increased traffic that has made South Florida look more like Southern California.
"Some days it takes me two and a half hours to get to work," said Rhoda Rosenzweig, a Naranja Lakes condominium association manager who moved with her 90-year-old mother from a mobile home here to an apartment in Pembroke Pines, just southwest of Fort Lauderdale. "Before, I could walk to work and go home for lunch to check on my mother."
Many parents are also making the long trek from their new, temporary homes to their children's old schools, hoping to maintain some degree of continuity in the lives of their children. But the future of many of the schools in the hardest-hit areas is now in doubt.
Local authorities say they hope that the exodus that followed Hurricane Andrew is only temporary and predict that people will return as soon as they are able. But there are signs that at least a part of the hurricane-induced shift of population may turn out to be permanent.
"I have no intention of coming back to South Dade," Ms. Rosenzweig said. "Andrew left a bad taste in my mouth, and I don't want to have to wait to see this place rebuild. I find that I like it in Broward."

Hector Vasquez sorted through the remains of his home after the storm. He and his wife have relocated to Placid Lake in Central Florida. (Phillippe Diederich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: JOB HUNTING;
For Capital Job Hunters, the Spoils of Victory Are Limited

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
With a civilian work force of more than two million people, the Federal Government would seem to offer an inviting source of employment to supporters of President-elect Bill Clinton, many of them no doubt struggling in a weak economy.
But the spoils of victory are neither as numerous nor as easy to obtain as is widely assumed. Experienced capital hands caution that if Mr. Clinton does a proper job mastering his transition, he will decide on policy priorities before picking people to put the policies into effect. This could make going to work for the first one-party Government in 12 years an exercise in frustration. 
 "There's not as many jobs as people think there are," Mark Abramson, president of the bipartisan Council for Excellence in Government, said on Wednesday. "There's going to be a lot of disappointment."
The 1992 version of the "Plum Book" -- officially called United States Government Policy and Supporting Positions -- was sent to the printer by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee on Wednesday morning. It lists about 8,000 jobs outside the competitive Civil Service consisting of career Government employees.
But only about 3,000 of the jobs are doled out through political appointment by the new Administration. And of them the top 700 -- mostly Cabinet and sub-Cabinet jobs -- are subject to extensive background checks by Federal agents, two sets of financial disclosure and Senate confirmation.
 
800 Jobs for Career People
 About 800 others are reserved for the Senior Executive Service, consisting of career people, with the remaining 1,500 accounted for by senior aides or specialists, many of them not considered choice jobs.
Various other jobs, including commissionerships at independent agencies like the Securities and Exchange Commission, are filled by the President when the term of an appointee expires. Such agencies are generally under other strictures as well, like limits on the number of people coming from one political party.
As the first Clinton forces headed for their transition office on the top three floors of an office building a few blocks from the White House, veterans of the process warned that Mr. Clinton should not put personnel decisions ahead of policy decisions.
In addition, Mr. Clinton has obtained 25,000 square feet of office space in Little Rock, Ark., where work on the transition has already begun.
"Set your priorities in policy and then lock people into the policy," counseled Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution. The reverse invites factionalism, particularly if those appointed to senior posts have a free hand in picking their subordinates, as Jimmy Carter allowed to happen when he became President.
More than 600 people will be working at the transition office for the next 11 weeks to set an agenda, select personnel and organize an administration. Congress has appropriated $3.5 million for the task.
"The main lesson in recent years is to get a start before the election but make it so low-key that it doesn't become an issue in itself," Mr. Hess said.
Evidence of their intentions to take a firm hold of matters is the fact that both Mr. Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore will have offices in the Washington quarters, as will their wives.
"The transition is governing," observed Stuart E. Eizenstat, who headed policy and planning for Mr. Carter's White House takeover in 1977. "I feel with enormous intensity that the transition is a seminal period."
 
Carter Transition Errors Cited
 Among what he counts as the Carter Administration's transition errors were failing to designate a White House chief of staff to serve as a traffic cop among competing interests, and introducing conflicts of loyalty by allowing top appointees almost complete freedom to pick their aides. He said the Carter Administration also "overloaded the legislative circuits" by not establishing two or three clear priorities.
Democratic Congresses, Mr. Eizenstat said, can prove quite balky even to Presidents who are Democrats, so Mr. Clinton is also well advised to avoid spending political capital -- or transition effort -- on Government reorganization that requires Congressional approval.

HEADLINE: Ruling by Court Backs Networks On Rerun Issue

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court dealt a major blow to the Hollywood studios today in their effort to keep the big television networks out of the $5 billion business of selling reruns of popular programs.
The unanimous decision by a three-judge panel rejected a rule adopted by a sharply divided Federal Communications Commission in 1991 that restricted the networks from owning and selling the rerun rights to their prime time programs. 
 The action by the court in Chicago could allow the networks to sell their reruns to local and cable stations without any restrictions. But the decision stopped short of handing the networks a complete victory. Indeed, it raised the question of whether, with the court's rejection of the new rule, the F.C.C. can now simply revert to the old, more restrictive rule.
 
Nasty Regulatory Battle
 The decision, written by Judge Richard A. Posner, orders the F.C.C. to reconsider its action in one of the nastiest and most divisive regulatory battles ever for the agency. The battle of the Hollywood studios and the television networks was immortalized by a commissioner as one between the "rich and the very wealthy."
The court's action also reopens the broader debate over the power of broadcast networks in the face of heavy competition for viewers from cable television, independent television stations and videocassette recorders.
At issue is what is known as the Financial Interest and Syndication Rule, which was first adopted by the F.C.C. in 1970 amid fears that ABC, NBC and CBS had the power to choke off competition in the production of television shows.
The rule prohibited the networks from owning a financial interest or resale rights in programs they broadcast. It was enacted to prevent a network from discriminating against independent producers or demanding that producers give them a financial stake in their programming in exchange for broadcasting them.
The networks argue that the rule is out of date and threatens the future of "free" television by making it difficult for networks to match the bids of cable systems and other rivals for the best new shows. The networks, along with the Bush Administration and many economic experts, argued that the rules only protected the major movie studios from competition.
Hollywood studios and producers, on the other hand, view the rule as the most important protection they have, and they spared nothing in their attempts to keep it intact.
 
Industry Reaction
 Network executives praised today's court decision.
"I think it's an excellent decision," said Richard Cotton, vice president and general counsel for NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company. "It's really a stinging indictment of the failure of the F.C.C. to justify any further restrictions on the networks."
Those views were echoed by Jamie Kellner, president of the Fox Broadcasting Company, which operates the new Fox television network. "Today's court decision reveals that the F.I.S.R. emperor has no clothes," he said in a statement, referring to the Financial Interest and Syndication Rule. "With a fourth network and scores of cable networks already in place, and even more competition and diversity on the horizon, the time is past due to set all networks free."
Hollywood lawyers denounced the verdict with equal force. "This action will have a profound and devastating impact on this country's entire television production community," said Michael Gardner, a lawyer for a coalition of producers. "It seems to remove, with one glib gesture, regulatory safeguards that have promoted the financial viability of the creative community."
 
Months of Feuding
 The rule rejected today was adopted in April 1991 after months of feuding between the commissioners and over the vehement objections of the F.C.C. chairman, Alfred C. Sikes. Enacted on a 3-to-2 vote, the rule was an attempt at a compromise between the two sides but it pleased neither.
The compromise rule prevented the networks from producing more than 40 percent of the programs for their prime time schedules. For the rest of the schedule, it prevented networks from negotiating financial interests or resale rights with independent producers until 30 days after a network had signed a deal to pay for a pilot and had committed to terms for buying further episodes.
The rule also barred the networks from investing in programs like "Jeopardy," "Hard Copy" and "Donahue" that are produced exclusively for sale to local stations.
Today's decision by Judge Posner, who was appointed during the Reagan Administration; William J. Bauer, named under President Ford, and Thomas E. Fairchild, nominated during the Johnson Administration, included a blistering indictment of the compromise. It called it illogical, unfounded and full of contradictions that are never resolved or explained.
"The impression created is of unprincipled compromises of Rube Goldberg complexity among contending interest groups viewed merely as clamoring supplicants," Judge Posner wrote.
Arguing that the commission "flunked" its requirement to show that the new rule was rational, the 22-page verdict declared bluntly that "key concepts are left unexplained, key evidence is overlooked" and "contradictions within and among commission decisions are passed over in silence."
The Federal court asked for opinions on whether the F.C.C. could revert to its old rules and gave both sides 15 days to submit arguments.
