HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: PLANS AND POLICIES;
AIDES SAY CLINTON WILL SWIFTLY VOID G.O.P. INITIATIVES

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton aims to convey an impression of boldness and change during his first days in the Oval Office by issuing a whirlwind of executive orders on abortion rights, White House perquisites and government ethics, his aides predict.
They sketch an ambitious domestic agenda for his first weeks, during which Mr. Clinton has said he will "focus like a laser beam on this economy" and "foreign policy will come into play in part as it affects the economy." 
 Aides predict that the new President will quickly move on matters he can change with the stroke of a pen, like doing away with fancy dining room privileges for high officials and reversing Bush Administration bans on fetal-tissue research and abortion counseling at federally financed clinics.
 
Coming Back to Character
 But some of Mr. Clinton's campaign aides and friends, often sounding eerily like President Bush on the campaign trail, say the success of these plans rests a great deal on unanswered questions about Mr. Clinton's character:
*Can a man who is so eager to please say no to the demands of the power-starved interest groups that contributed to his election?
*Can a policy specialist with so many detailed proposals choose a few crucial initiatives and single-mindedly push them through, rather than try to do everything at once?
*Can a man so sharply identified with his generation select a cross section of advisers that balances Washington experience with a youthful urge for change and power?
 
List of Initiatives
 Mr. Clinton's agenda is still embryonic, and it is hard to tell which of the aides now describing it will be around after inauguration day on Jan. 20. And, inevitably, aides sometimes confuse their boss's priorities with their own.
Nevertheless, interviews with Clinton advisers, friends and campaign aides in the last weeks of the Presidential campaign suggest that his first 100 days will begin with several executive orders reversing Republican social policies. They say the list could include all or some of these:
*Ending the ban on homosexuals in the military and the ban on abortion in military hospitals overseas.
*Repealing bans on abortion counseling at federally financed clinics and research using fetal tissue.
*Allowing the importing from France of RU-486, the morning-after abortion pill.
*Establishing a family-leave policy for Federal employees who want time off to care for children or sick relatives.
*Revoking the Reagan-Bush policy of forbidding American aid to foreign organizations that provide abortion services, counseling or referrals.
*Trimming the White House staff and eliminating executive dining rooms and other subsidized perks for top officials.
*Requiring political appointees to sign a pledge barring lobbying of their Government agencies for five years after they leave office. The current legal limit is one year.
 
Legislation
Looking to Set Right Agenda
 The Clinton team says it wants Congress to pass within the first 100 days a combination of tax incentives and public-works spending measures to stimulate the economy, perhaps delaying at first Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to cut the deficit.
As for his other major legislative aims, including health-care and welfare reform and job training, Clinton aides have given themselves a 100-day deadline to submit legislation in these areas. But they do not expect passage that early.
Mr. Clinton's aides say he talks about keeping his legislative agenda broad enough to take full advantage of his mandate for economic change but lean enough to avoid choking the House Ways and Means Committee, through which all tax legislation passes, with so many bills that nothing is passed.
Nevertheless, a friend recalls asking Mr. Clinton in June which transition model he would follow: Ronald Reagan, who in his first 100 days focused on one issue and got tax and budget changes through Congress, or Jimmy Carter, who pressed 15 equal proposals so complex and controversial that virtually none were approved.
Mr. Clinton replied that he would follow the Reagan model, but then ticked off a list of initiatives he would propose.
"Sounds to me more like Jimmy Carter," his friend told him.
 
Personnel
Fierce Competition For Choice Jobs
 Mr. Clinton's first task will be to choose the leading members of his domestic-economic team: chief of staff, director of the Office of Management and Budget, chief of his Council of Economic Advisers, Secretary of the Treasury and White House liaison with Congress, which will be a crucial job in his Administration.
Already, rivalries are building. In the last two weeks of the Presidential campaign, staff members at the Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters in Arkansas were playing a game that could best be called "Did you see who just walked by with his resume?" The words were usually said in disgust, because as Mr. Clinton's victory became more certain the young staff members became more resentful of the job seekers who haunted Little Rock like apparitions from the Democratic past.
For the first time since the cold war began, the fight for 16 Cabinet posts and 8,500 other political appointments is being fought more along generational lines than ideological ones. Officials who served in the middle ranks of the Carter, Johnson and even Kennedy Administrations -- bursting with ambition after 12 years in the wilderness -- are already clamoring for high-level jobs.
But there is a new generation of Democrats, men and women in their 30's and 40's, who think it is their turn and resent having to compete with the party elders.
And there are "Friends of Bill," an informal group of people dubbed F.O.B.'s who have known Mr. Clinton for years and share many of his goals and instincts. It includes Robert Reich, an economics professor at Harvard University; Roger Altman, a New York investment banker and former Treasury official; Ira Magaziner, a Providence, R.I., consultant on domestic policy; Eli J. Segal, a Boston businessman and the campaign chief of staff, and Susan Thomases, a New York lawyer and a leading campaign adviser.
Mr. Clinton's problem is, as one adviser put it, that while he is clearly committed to bringing in new blood, "you also don't want people who don't know where the bathroom is, because there is so much to be done so quickly."
 
Structure
Revamping Office For a New Politics
 Whomever Mr. Clinton chooses, the appointments will almost certainly have to be accompanied by bureaucratic restructuring to reflect the new President's appreciation for the link between politics and governing.
Mr. Bush tended to view politics as something reserved for election seasons, not as an instrument for governing, a task he preferred to pursue behind closed doors with fellow power-brokers.
By contrast, Mr. Clinton and his aides say he will conduct a permanent campaign for his agenda, with regular bus tours and town meetings to build and maintain a public constituency for his legislation. The Clinton team has clearly learned during the Presidential campaign that this direct contact with voters is also a way to get around the filter of the media.
This objective has led to a kind of detailed organizational planning that many Presidents might scorn as bureaucratic tinkering but that members of the Clinton team consider crucial. They think it is important, for example, to combine the White House communications office with the White House Congressional liaison office to reinforce the White House's lobbying of Congress with its broader messages to the public.
As put by one Clinton adviser, who like most others refused to be identified for fear that it might complicate his or her efforts to be chosen to serve in Washington: "You are not going to pass controversial legislation like health care or welfare reform without the American people behind you. That means integrating communications and legislation. Bush's idea of legislative affairs was having the Speaker of the House up for a drink at the end of the day. That will not be Clinton's."
Another bureaucratic change, Clinton aides say, will be to break down the wall between the National Security Council and the Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Clinton has promised to create some sort of economic security council to integrate foreign policy and domestic economic policy, which he contends are inseparable.
Pundits around Washington are already lining up to see who will be the first to write about the inevitable turf clash between a new economic security adviser and the Treasury Secretary.
 
Policies
Setting Priorities, Voicing Concerns
 As for the longer-term initiatives, the top priority will be an economic-stimulus package, which Mr. Clinton and his aides say they want to have in Congress's hands the day after his inauguration.
"Even though he has detailed positions on a lot of issues, and an activist philosophy, some things will take precedence over others," said Bruce Reed, Mr. Clinton's issues adviser. "I think it is safe to say that the economic package will be priority 1A."
The first question that advisers say they will have to decide is which elements of this economic plan go to Congress immediately and which, like health care and welfare reform, may have to come later.
The elements almost certain to go up immediately, aides predict, will be a proposal for an investment tax credit for new plants and equipment, a capital gains tax reduction for investments in new businesses held for at least five years, permanent tax incentives for research and development, initiatives for job training and apprenticeships, and new spending at $20 billion a year for roads, bridges and other public works.
In theory, these programs would be financed by spending cuts in areas like the military and the Federal bureaucracy and by tax increases on overseas corporate profits and Americans earning more than $200,000 a year.
Since many economists have contended that the tax increases will not pay for the new spending, Mr. Clinton has repeatedly promised to reduce his spending plans to the level of revenue available to finance them rather than raise taxes on the middle class.
But while the President-elect and his aides insist they will not go to the still-loosely defined middle class to finance economic stimulation, they have not ruled out increasing the Federal deficit in the short term.
"The question," one economic adviser said, "is, 'If the economy is still dead in the water in January, will we need some sort of net stimulus, something that is not just revenue neutral?' It could be some additional infrastructure spending, it could be a higher investment tax credit or it could be more generous credits for companies which create new jobs over a historical baseline."
Such a package, the adviser said, "would have to be wrapped in a legislative deal that would insure that once the economy is back on track the budget would get cut by an equal amount."
Mr. Clinton's fear of bloating the deficit, his aides say, is at least equaled by his concern that his own, often unrestrained, campaign promises have created expectations for a miraculous economic fix. Whereas six months ago, the candidate's whole emphasis was "I have a plan," now that he has been elected, the mantra of the day is "No quick fixes."
"The big issue out there is what should be in the first legislative package," a leading Clinton economic adviser said. "The sub-issue is how do you handle expectations. The problems are deep and longstanding, and therefore easy, quick, visible successes will be hard to come by."
 
Troubling Thoughts
 Another worry that aides seem to share is that since much of the new spending in any economic-growth package would go into public works the possibilities for a pork-barrel feast are enormous.
"We have to think very carefully about where money will go without looking porkish," one adviser said. "That means making sure that the projects are high priority in anybody's book. Otherwise people are just going to say, 'There go the Democrats. They came back and started throwing money everywhere.' "
Equally tricky will be integrating environmental concerns into the plan for economic recovery, as Mr. Clinton has promised to do. Saying there is "good infrastructure and bad infrastructure," environmentalists want to insure, for example, that public-works spending leans away from autos, trucks and highways and toward rail, mass transit and pedestrian systems. Early drafts of Mr. Clinton's proposals have disappointed many of them.
"The problem," one environmental adviser said, "is that the only plans on the shelf, ready to go, shovel the money out the door and create a lot of jobs, are for more highways. So you lock in lots of long-term spending on things you don't want and you undermine his other environmental goals. If he goes that way, he will be fought by environmentalists."
Whatever happens, once the economic-jobs program is on its way, Clinton aides say they expect other proposals to be broached with Congress in some form in the first 100 days. These include changes in health care, college tuition in return for government service, requiring welfare recipients to work and proposals to improve the energy efficiency of the economy by 20 percent by 2000 and to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions by 2000 at 1990 levels.
But officials say they do not expect such proposals as well as those on family leave and campaign financing to be passed that quickly.
Money is part of the problem, but even more important is the lack of consensus on how to approach controversial issues like health care and welfare reform. Indeed, Clinton aides seem less vexed by finances than by the specter of hostile forces in their own camp. A Democratic Congress, they warn, is no guarantee of consensus.
More than 100 new members of Congress are eager to make their mark, not to mention the other 435 who already have their own agendas. The influence of lobbyists is also as great as ever. Even where there is general agreement among Democrats, there is plenty of room for dissension; for example, there are already at least six health-care plans in the Senate.
"The difficulty will be in persuading Congress to pass his agenda, not theirs," said Mr. Reed, the issues adviser.
Finessing lawmakers will require Mr. Clinton's best imitation of Lyndon B. Johnson's talent for soothing egos and stroking constituencies.
"Labor, minorities, environmentalists, blacks, Hispanics, women, retired people, you name it, all see the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow," a top Clinton aide said. "And somebody is going to be very disappointed."

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Winds of War, 90's-Style

 BODY:
War with Europe: an inconceivable thought that suddenly isn't so inconceivable. This war, however, would be of the post-cold-war variety -- fought not with bombs and bullets but with escalating barrages of trade restrictions.
The Bush Administration was firm and right yesterday when it announced it would impose punitive tariffs on European white wines. That may lead to a trade war and jeopardize completion of the Uruguay Round of international trade talks. But these immense risks have to be taken. 
 Europe has violated agreements and refused to make amends. For President Bush to capitulate would undermine the credibility of trade agreements past and present and deal a crippling blow to economic growth everywhere.
The controversy goes back to the 1960's, when Europe agreed to keep its markets for soybeans and other oilseeds open to U.S. exporters. The European Community subsequently undermined the agreement by subsidizing its farmers to grow oilseeds. U.S. exports plummeted and after the United States protested, two international panels ruled in America's favor.
Under international trade rules, the E.C. then had two choices. It could have compensated the U.S. for the lost exports or cut back the production subsidies. It did neither. Nor would it agree even to arbitrate.
For six years America has fought to resolve the matter without rancor but without success -- until yesterday. It announced that in 30 days it intended to impose punitive tariffs tripling the U.S. price of European white wines and raising the price of imported ingredients of pet food and cooking oils.
At a superficial level, the U.S. action looks rash and irrational. The E.C. has threatened to respond with retaliatory tariffs. That could set off a spiral jeopardizing the Uruguay Round and, therefore, $200 billion in world trade a year. Why risk that? In a word, credibility. The Europeans, by their own admission and international finding, are breaking an agreement. After six years of walking the last mile, the U.S. must either back down -- stripping future trade agreements of credibility -- or take the only legal measure left.
Hence, far from rashly, the Bush Administration acted prudently, obeying international rules scrupulously. It could have targeted $1 billion of European exports; it limited this step to $300 million worth. It could have imposed the tariffs immediately; instead it put such action off for 30 days.
If the Administration had drawn an inflexible line in the dust, it would warrant condemnation. The world is on the verge of a monumental trade pact that will open up economies as never before to foreign investment and trade in services, food, intellectual property and textiles. To squander that achievement for the sake of U.S. oilseed farmers would be a tragic error.
But the U.S. has made no such mistake. The Bush Administration is looking ahead to when it, and the Clinton Administration, will have to sell the Uruguay Round treaty to Congress. That won't be possible if the U.S. has shown itself unwilling even to defend existing agreements.
The way out is for Europe to avoid retaliation against the U.S. once the 30-day grace period ends, then dedicate itself to figuring out how to honor its trade obligations. Europe triggered this trouble. Now it is up to Europe to keep an ugly skirmish from turning into global disaster.

SECTION: Section A; Page 29; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The New Landscape

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
"In victory, magnanimity." So Winston Churchill advised. But for Bill Clinton it will have to be watchful magnanimity.
Anyone who thinks the gracious concession speeches on Election Night presaged an Era of Good Feeling for the Clinton Presidency -- a suspension of partisanship -- has a short memory. To win, Mr. Clinton had to survive an exceptionally vicious campaign against him. Republicans, embittered and divided, are not going to be kind and gentle to the Clinton Administration. 
 To be effective in the White House, Mr. Clinton will have to win the confidence of not just the 43 percent who voted for him but of many of the other 57 percent. The Republican tactic will surely be to destroy that confidence by personal attack. That is the game Newt Gingrich knows, and it is the one George Bush played in the campaign.
(Was there, incidentally, an inadvertent note of guilt about the nature of his campaign in President Bush's concession speech? I thought so. He said, "We have fought the good fight . . . and I believe we have upheld the honor of the Presidency." It was as if he were trying to reassure himself.)
The hard part of Mr. Clinton's confidence-building will be the central promise he made to the voters: to rebuild the economy. It will take years, even with the wisest policy, to correct the distortions of the Reagan-Bush years and cope with the grim international trends.
What he can do on the economic front, in his first days as President, is demonstrate the caring and the commitment to action that the people felt were missing in George Bush. But his task is complicated by the Perot factor: the fact that Ross Perot won a remarkable 19 percent of the vote on one main argument, that we must eliminate the budget deficit.
If Mr. Clinton actually made the brutal spending cuts that the Perot vision requires, the economic effects would be devastating. The recession would worsen sharply. The Clinton idea, rather, is to stimulate the economy first and then, as it picks up, move toward deficit reduction.
Mr. Clinton can adopt one Perot theme, the reform of campaign financing. The only thing is that real reform will also have to reach the Perot phenomenon itself. It is wrong that one person can spend $60 million in the last month of a Presidential race to flood the voters with propaganda. Careful legislation could persuade the Supreme Court to think again about its 1976 decision that limits on political spending violate constitutional guarantees of free speech.
The area ripe for early action by Congress and Mr. Clinton is social. Within months legislation should end the Federal ban on fetal tissue research and the abortion gag rule. A family leave law will be enacted.
Those so-called social issues touch the most sensitive area of division in the Republican Party. The great struggle shaping up pits the Rev. Pat Robertson and the religious right against conservatives who want Government to stay out of such matters, leaving them to private decision.
Mr. Robertson has achieved great power in the party. His Christian Coalition mailed out 40 million voter guides. (Why is the Christian Coalition tax-exempt? There is a question overripe for inquiry.)
On the other hand, the Robertson forces' domination of the Republican Convention this year offended many voters. Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts warned on Election Night against the Republican Party's following the Democratic example of 20 years ago and moving toward the extreme.
The campaign, on reflection, offers one clear guideline to Bill Clinton as President: Play it straight.
Some of us thought Americans had become so cynical that they did not care what politicians said. But it turned out that dissembling hurt.
Nearly half the voters, asked after they voted, said they thought Mr. Clinton was lying about his draft record in the Vietnam War. But 70 percent thought President Bush was lying about his role in the Iran-contra affair, and that really hurt him on Election Day.
Craig Fuller, Mr. Bush's chief of staff as Vice President, said on ABC's "Nightline" a month ago that the evidence of Mr. Bush's falsity in saying he was "out of the loop" on Iran-contra was irrelevant. "It didn't matter in 1988," Mr. Fuller said, "and it won't matter in 1992." But it did.

HEADLINE: Credit Where It's Due for Cold War's End

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The G.O.P. Won the Cold War? Ridiculous" (Op-Ed, Oct. 28), George F. Kennan states that neither political party can claim credit for victory in the cold war: it belongs to the people who resisted Communism, to Americans of both parties willing to bear the human and material costs, to their allies. But if President Bush takes the blame for America's plight in the global economic recession, why deny him recognition for a happy event that occurred on his watch? 
 Mr. Kennan characterizes as childish the notion that United States policies could have decidedly affected domestic Soviet affairs because "no great country has that sort of influence on the internal developments of any other one." This statement is astonishing for two reasons:
(1) It was the fundamental premise of Mr. Kennan's recommendations of the 1940's that containment would encourage an internal implosion in the Soviet Union. As he expressed it in the famous "Mr. X" article of 1947, "it is entirely possible for the United States to influence by its actions the internal developments, both within Russia, and throughout the international Communist movement."
(2) In the same breath in which he now denies we had the ability to promote the collapse of Communism, he blames alleged American belligerency for the tightening of party and political controls in the Soviet Union during the cold war. For no obvious reason, we could exert an influence on the internal course of the Soviet Union, but only of a baneful nature.
In the 1970's and 80's Mr. Kennan repeatedly warned that the cold war was leading to World War III. Happily, he was wrong. Rather than concede this, he now blames us for having prolonged the cold war. He is at odds with the historical record, the views of those who administer today's Russia and his own previously held opinions.
 
RICHARD PIPES
Baird Professor of History
Harvard University
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 29, 1992

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. FIGHTS SOME JOBLESS-BENEFIT CLAIMS

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
I.B.M. is fighting some former workers over their claims for unemployment benefits. Hundreds of I.B.M. employees who left the company in return for a severance bonus have applied for benefits, said Wally Wiegert, director of the State Labor Department's Community Service Center in Binghamton. About half of them have been approved for unemployment benefits, which range up to a maximum of $300 a week, he said. The exact number of claims is confidential, he said. 
 But the International Business Machines Corporation believes that the severance program "is voluntary, so these people aren't eligible for unemployment," said Kathleen Ryan of I.B.M. The computer maker found itself in the position of having to challenge a number of the claims because in New York, people who leave work voluntarily are not always barred from receiving benefits, Mr. Wiegert said. The applications started coming in after July 31, when I.B.M.'s bonus offer ended, he added. Appeals from workers and the company are being heard by an administrative law judge in Binghamton. Unemployment claims can cause an employer's unemployment insurance premiums to rise.

HEADLINE: Fischer Beats Spassky and Carves a New Niche for Himself in Chess

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Bobby Fischer, the temperamental American chess genius, defeated his old rival Boris Spassky tonight, winning a 30-game, two-month exhibition match and re-establishing himself as a force among the world's better grandmasters.
Tonight's victory came after 27 moves when Mr. Spassky, in a hopeless position after accepting a Fischer dare to attack and being crushed by a solid defense, resigned to give Mr. Fischer his winning 10th victory. Mr. Spassky won five games and the rest were drawn. 
 Grandmasters here agreed that the level of play during the match was rather below that of today's championship contenders. Mr. Fischer, who was playing after two decades of mysterious, self-imposed isolation, showed some rustiness, and Mr. Spassky, ranked 101st in the world when the match began, made frequent errors early on. Nonetheless, the experts said, the games were consistently exciting, and Mr. Fischer displayed flashes of his old genius, suggesting that with more practice he would hold his own among the chess elite.
 
May Remain in Yugoslavia
 Mr. Fischer stands to collect $3.35 million in prize money for his victory, while Mr. Spassky is to receive about $1.65 million. Mr. Fischer has hinted he may remain in Yugoslavia; the Treasury Department is threatening him with prosecution if he returns to the United States for violating the United Nations Security Council's economic embargo against Belgrade. At a news conference before the match began, Mr. Fischer held up a letter from the Treasury Department and spit at it.
In 1972, in his last international match, played in the Icelandic capital of Reykjavik, Mr. Fischer also beat Mr. Spassky, who was then a Soviet citizen, gaining the world championship title as a result.
But he was stripped of that title in 1975 by the International Chess Federation after refusing to defend it against Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union. Mr. Karpov became champion by default, and was subsequently displaced by the current champion, Gary Kasparov of Russia.
After losing the championship in Reykjavic, Mr. Spassky took a French wife and French citizenship, settling down to a comfortable life just outside Paris. Though he continued to play regularly, Mr. Spassky, now 55 years old, seldom won tournaments and dropped out of championship contention altogether.
A Yugoslav businessman, Jezdimir Vasiljevic, who organized the Fischer-Spassky match here and who put up the prize money, has said he would like to arrange a match for the official world title between Mr. Fischer and Mr. Kasparov.
But that is not considered likely any time soon. Such a contest would have to be authorized by the world federation, and Mr. Fischer has for 20 years refused to play under its match rules. In addition, Mr. Fischer said recently that he would play Mr. Kasparov only if the Russian accepted a number of unspecified conditions. Grandmasters say they would be astonished if the champion agreed to anything after such an approach.
Meanwhile, negotiations are reported to be under way for Mr. Fischer to play the Hungarian teen-ager Judit Polgar, the world's top-ranked woman, sometime early next year. Ms. Polgar recently became the the youngest grandmaster ever, a distinction Mr. Fischer had held until then.
Today, Mr. Fischer and Mr. Spassky confronted each other on the brightly lighted stage of a darkened auditorium behind a soundproof glass wall. Both sat in high-backed office chairs and studied the chess board between them from under identical black eye shades.
Onlookers followed the moves on color television monitors and large demonstration boards.
This match began two months ago at the luxurious Adriatic resort of Sveti Stevan, a tourist complex built on a tiny piece of land joined by a sand bar to the coast. The setting then shifted to the Sava Conference Center just outside Belgrade.
Grandmasters say they have no idea why Mr. Fischer has decided to return to international competition after his long absence. Some believe he may need the money. Others say he was encouraged to come back by his Hungarian girlfriend, Zita Rajcsanyi, who is herself a good chess player.
Mr. Fischer and Mr. Spassky made no public comment tonight. They are to hold a news conference here tomorrow.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 7, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The first of four chessboard diagrams yesterday with an article about the match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky reversed the players' colors. Mr. Spassky had the white pieces, Mr. Fischer the black.

HEADLINE: Is G.M. Fate Still Crucial to U.S.? 

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
"What is good for the country is good for General Motors, and what's good for General Motors is good for the country," Charles E. Wilson, the G.M. president who was to become President Eisenhower's Secretary of Defense, is said to have told the Senate Armed Forces Committee. The pronouncement by Engine Charlie Wilson instantly became a symbol of corporate arrogance for a nation that simultaneously loathed and worshiped big business, for there was rough truth in his words.
America was the world's largest consumer of cars, and G.M. was the world's largest producer, a mighty engine of prosperity for G.M. stockholders and the families and communities of workers. 
 Four decades later, with G.M. hemorrhaging jobs and cash, its love-hate affair with America may be ending. Although almost everyone wishes its new managers well, few economists think there is cause for great alarm if they fail to restore the company's profitability or market share.
 
 
Moving On
 "A unique strength of this economy is its capacity to acknowledge failure and move on," said Alfred E. Kahn, a specialist in industrial organization at Cornell University.
Irwin Stelzer, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, added, "Even in bankruptcy, G.M. would not disappear." One way or another, its productive plants and accumulated expertise in engineering and marketing would be recycled.
But isn't the decline of the corporation that symbolized America's postwar industrial dominance a prospect that should be viewed with exceptional anxiety? After all, at the end of 1991 some 370,000 people were on G.M.'s $12 billion North American payroll, while the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands more were indirectly linked to the company. More pointedly, if G.M. reaches the brink, should Uncle Sugar step in to save it, as it saved Chrysler in 1980?
F. M. Scherer, an economist at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, cautiously offers a rationale for treating G.M. as a special case. While the company's jobs are widely distributed across the continent, he notes that big cutbacks would still be "a very severe blow to the already badly damaged city of Detroit." Moreover, the timing of the job implosion, in the midst of a long recession, could hardly be worse.
 Mr. Scherer also expects some jobs lost at G.M. to go overseas. And he worries that a failure by the company in the car business may mean a permanent loss of the sorts of highly skilled, highly paid jobs that Americans need to remain prosperous.
 But many other economists are unpersuaded. Mr. Stelzer says the focus on the fortunes of the corporate entity misses the mark. G.M. is certain to shed payrolls and plants, he notes, whether or not the new managers succeed. And presumably, some of those losses would be gains for workers at other American companies making more popular models.
Paradoxically, an unsuccessful salvage effort -- one in which G.M. fails to cut its payroll and capacity fast enough, and slowly bleeds its way into bankruptcy -- might be least traumatic for most of the workers and communities. They would, at least, have longer to make the transition.
Since there is excess production capacity in the American car industry -- and, for that matter, in the world's car industry -- the number of employees in the business is almost sure to continue to slip. But many analysts think the location of the highly-paid white collar jobs, the jobs that Mr. Scherer worries about most, is no longer tightly linked to the location of manufacturing operations.
What apparently counts most in the good jobs equation is the quality of education and other amenities -- safe streets, clean air, good transportation -- that attract what Robert B. Reich of Harvard calls "knowledge workers." Seen in this light, it should be no surprise that Toyota and Mazda are designing cars in the United States for production worldwide.
Of course, many of the good jobs at risk at G.M. and in the rest of the auto industry are semiskilled, where high pay is a matter of inertia and strong unions -- much as it is in the steel, rubber and heavy machinery industries. Last year, G.M. spent $34.60 an hour for labor, including benefits, roughly twice the average total compensation for the economy as a whole. But Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institution argues that high pay in autos and steel has always been a mixed blessing, since it translates into higher prices for consumers.
 Indeed, Mr. Crandall contends that the high pay-high price trade-off has been a rotten deal for the economy. He estimates that the effort in the 1980's to protect blue-collar jobs with import quotas cost car buyers tens of billions of dollars, with much of the money lining the pockets of foreign manufacturers who imported higher-priced, more profitable models.
A common theme running through much of the nascent debate about the public's stake in G.M.'s future is the tension between allowing competitive markets to discipline business, and sparing the innocent the consequences of corporate incompetence. Many economists, including many conservatives, would gladly strengthen the safety net for the underskilled and unemployed.
By the same token, most economists are deeply skeptical about the impulse to reverse the sometimes-harsh judgment of free markets, even when the potential victims are icons of America's industrial might.
The economist Milton Friedman, a Nobel Prize winner, concluded, "If you get into the game of too-big-to-fail, you get into real trouble."

Wilson, then president of G.M., during his Senate hearings for confirmation as Secretary of Defense. According to G.M., Mr. Wilson said, "For years I thought what was good for our country was good for General Motors and vice versa."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: INSIDE THE BELTWAY;
Setting the Table for the Arkansas Travelers

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5

 BODY:
Even before the election, it was happening. Bookstores displaying the novels of Bill Clinton's favorite mystery author, Walter Mosley, in their windows. Music stores selling out of saxophone lapel pins. Joggers in Clinton-Gore T-shirts sweating their way down K Street. By Wednesday, "Arkansas stew" was on the menu, and selling out, among power lunchers at Mo Sussman's.
Faster than you can riffle through a Rolodex, the world of Washington is realigning itself. But to what? Watermelons and drop-those-final-g's Ozark chic? Jesuitical, community-minded Georgetown University chic? Languid, intellectual Oxford chic? Or brown-bag-lunching, policy-parsing, Federal Register-toting geek chic? 
 "There will be a lot of sweet-potato pie and fried green tomatoes and all that, but these are serious people," said Frank Mankiewicz, the top lobbyist for the public relations firm Hill & Knowlton and a former Kennedy aide. "The talk at dinner parties will be the Canadian health plan and permanent replacement of strikers, things like that. It will be intensely domestic. These are serious people, and times are tough.
 
Camelot, the Sequel?
 "This is much more akin to the entrance of Kennedy than the Carter entrance," added Mr. Mankiewicz, a Peace Corps official in the Kennedy Administration and later press secretary to Senator Robert F. Kennedy. "Jimmy Carter's Administration was the last act of Watergate. The Kennedy election was a tectonic shift generationally, like this.
"Johnson's people came in wondering if they'd be accepted at Georgetown parties. Bill Clinton went to Georgetown. These are not people who are coming to town scorning Washington, or worrying that they'll be scorned. Let's not forget that Al Gore is a product of St. Albans School and the Fairfax Hotel."
So, despite a chilly damp turn in the weather (Oxford chic?), the Republican city-that-was has been bubbling with the prospect of becoming the Democratic city-that-will-be. "It's new and exciting, and he is young and vital," said Esther Coopersmith, a Washington hostess, a Democratic contributor, the mother of a Clinton staff member and vice chairman of the Washington Children's Museum.
 
Opera Buffs and Football Fans
 "He is very interested in art, very interested in culture, loves all kinds of music," Ms. Coopersmith said. "He's been educated. You will see a revival of art and culture in Washington. Hillary will be involved with all the wonderful children's activities."
No word on the plans for parties (Mrs. Coopersmith said it was premature) and no word as to whether the local rubber-chicken banquet circuit wIould be featuring Arkansas fowl in place of the birds of Maryland's Eastern Shore. But no one is ruling out the possibility. If Washingtonians had lived in Biblical Jericho, some here believe, they would have been sporting "I <heart> Joshua" buttons before the walls finished tumbling.
For instance, Jack Kent Cooke, owner of the Washington Redskins, said he would invite some of the new crowd to watch the team play from his box at R.F.K. Stadium, a box that is a venerable institution here. The guest list still "won't be very much different from what it has been," Mr. Cooke said.
"I'm a Republican, but strangely I have a great many Democrat friends. Dodd. Brzezinski. Greenspan -- he's of indeterminate lineage. Sam Donaldson -- what's he? Gene McCarthy and George McGovern."
Does he know of any football fans in the Clinton camp? "You must understand, Mr. Cooke said. "The box is not used to ingratiate myself with the Administration. Please quote me precisely on that. I invite people who are good company, happy, cheerful, good-humored people who love football. That's what counts. I don't care where they come from."
Other cultural institutions will also be sounding out the newcomers. Martin Feinstein, general director of the Washington Opera, said he did not know if Hillary Clinton was interested in opera, but added: "I hope so. I hope the President will become interested."
But more than the cultural elite, more than the idea brokers from DuPont Circle, it is the real estate agents who are most eager to find out who the newcomers are and what they want. If any industry has been in the doldrums in this recession-proof area, it is real estate. And while the turnover in administrations is not likely to have a seismic impact on the market -- perhaps 1,000 home sales and a few hundred rentals -- it certainly can't hurt.
Eager agents are already advertising in The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette. "We haven't been getting a lot of calls yet," said Helene Buyten, the receptionist at MGMB Realty, whose ad runs Sunday. The Democrat-Gazette's advertising manager, Karen Hardy, said that a Wall Street Journal reporter's classified ad offering a Washington-area home for rent had produced so many calls the ad was canceled after a day's run.
 
The Big 'They' Factor
 The agents are wondering where "they" will live. Mr. Clinton's transition team is deciding who "they" will be. And carpenters from the General Sevices Administration, the Government's housekeeping agency, are trying to figure out how they can squeeze the 600-member transition team into the top three floors at 1120 Vermont Ave. Idle guards sat among a few random girders and unplugged security gates Wednesday as men with blueprints, hardhats and GSA badges milled around.
Ava Hillman, owner of the candy-and-snack stand in the lobby, said: "I'm trying to figure out if business will get better. I hope it will."
Down Vermont Avenue, David Goldberger at Wonder Graphics Picture Framing hopes they'll mean business for him. "Everyone's going to have to hang up new pictures in their offices," Mr. Goldberger said. "They're going to be putting up new Clinton-Gore glad-handing pictures. They're going to need framing. And we do a very nice job."
At Chapters Bookstore on K Street, the two owners, Terri Meik and Robin Diener, were happily checking their inventories of Mosley mysteries like "White Butterfly" and "Devil with the Blue Dress," of Arkansas poet Miller Williams's book, "Adjusting to the Light," and of Marcus Aurelius's "Meditations."
"Every time Bill Clinton is seen with a book, people want to read that book," Ms. Meik explained. "This is going to be wonderful for us."
 
Yardsticks of Power
 Mr. Clinton's literary tastes are becoming known, but it is the wealth of unanswered questions that add spice to conversations here today. There are the big questions: who will be Secretary of State? Will Mr. Clinton pay his respects to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Mr. Foley's turf or summon the Speaker to the White House.
"The big questions are jobs, ideas and coalitions," said Hedrick Smith, who wrote "The Power Game." "The first thing that matters is jobs. And real estate. Power can be measured in real estate -- offices, homes, parking places."
Lloyd Cutler, a senior partner at the law firm of Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering and a former counsel to President Carter, said: "It's a 12-year drought since all the bright young lawyers in Washington who came here to do public service have had a chance. The line of willing and available people is 10 times longer than the line of jobs, especially when you factor in most people's estimation of what job they should have.
"But there's a sense of great excitement. There was a general feeling, I know, that Democratic administrations are more interesting. The Bush people didn't even fight with one another. There was zero gossip. That should pick up."
Jobs may be the big question, but there are lots of smaller questions, too. Where will the Clinton's daughter Chelsea go to school? Who will give her art and ballet lessons? Where will Mr. Clinton, a Southern Baptist, and Mrs. Clinton, a Methodist, worship? Will Hillary Clinton need a hairdresser, a law clerk or both? Where can a President get a saxophone repaired?
 
New Mistakes, New Laughs
 Joan Cushing, a stand-up comedian here, is exhilarated at the prospect of new material. "It's a new bunch of clowns for me to spoof," said Ms. Cushing, who performs as Mrs. Foggy Bottom at the Omni Shoreham Hotel. "Any time a President comes in for a second term, they're tough to spoof. Reagan was funny for eight years. I don't think Bush would have been funny for eight years.
"What's funny about these guys?," she asked. "I don't know. I'll have to think about the answer to that. Mostly that they're new. They're going to be making all sorts of mistakes."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 23, 1992, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 6 about the influence that Gov. Bill Clinton's election was having on life in Washington misidentified an owner of Chapters Bookstore there. She is Terri Merz.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees displayed its opinion yesterday about the Presidential election outside the organization's national headquarters in Washington. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times) (pg. A19)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The End Of Cynicism

BYLINE: By Steve Erickson; Steve Erickson is author of a forthcoming novel, "Arc d'X."

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
It was only a false alarm, 1988. It had only the potential for national revelation, when we would decide as a country to leap into or withdraw from the future. A different sort of discussion that year -- between Mario Cuomo and Jack Kemp, for instance -- might have fulfilled that potential or confirmed why some of us believed that, at the end of the Reagan era with no incumbent seeking the Presidency for the first time in 20 years, it was Leap Year.
In the four years since, it has become clear that in 1988 the 20th century still had to play itself out. In the four years since, the century reduced itself to the cockeyed reverie of a historical nanosecond, in which walls that once seemed to have gone up forever came down in a day. Countries that once invented themselves in an explosion of revolution and sustained themselves in a rage of nuclear power uninvented themselves. 
 These were the four years in which the century would seduce us into believing that it never happened at all. Nuclear imagination gave way to nuclear memory, the temporal whisper of annihilation's possibilities that occasionally reminds us who we are, and what we learned about ourselves before the century vanished. These were also the years in which those of us who call ourselves Americans became too alienated from the courage and audacity that created us to marvel at how we withstood the vagaries of the century -- or to wonder if, given that alienation, we really have.
This year we found ourselves having exhausted every impulse, the shallower ones and the deeper ones. We found ourselves facing the question of whether we would shake off that exhaustion or succumb to it. The contention that the 1992 Presidential election was about the economy is not wholly untrue; it would be glib and insensitive to make such an argument in the face of so much social pain and anxiety.
But this election, as is almost always the case, was finally about ourselves. The last time we thought it was Leap Year, we were not yet ready to leap because we still had one more impulse to exhaust, after the others of idealism, realism, naivete, confidence and heroism that had characterized the previous half-dozen elections. That was the impulse of cynicism, for which George Bush was a more perfect vehicle than we were ultimately willing to live with.
By the early days of autumn, the 1992 election was no longer a referendum on George Bush. That referendum was over, and the President had lost. The election became a referendum on whether Bill Clinton was a suitable alternative to the cynicism we would reject. The re-emergence of yet another alternative, Ross Perot, only made the Clinton Referendum more real, not less.
Cynicism is always the most bitter expression of broken faith. We are now at the end of a generation of broken faith, which began in the 1960's with Presidents who lied to us and ended in the 1980's with us lying to ourselves. Ronald Reagan's pact with the American people was that leadership would henceforth define itself not by Presidents who told the people what they needed to know but what they wanted to hear: it took only slightly more self-delusion than sense to believe Mr. Reagan could increase military spending, cut taxes and balance the budget, as he promised in 1980 and for which we gave him a mandate.
The real scandal of Mr. Bush's pledge never to raise taxes was our complicity in accepting a promise that so clearly served self-interest rather than national interest. This year, when the President virtually accused his opponent of once being a K.G.B. dupe, he again tried to tether his cynicism to our own, after we rewarded similarly squalid slanders against Michael Dukakis in 1988. The great dirty secret of this election has been our insistence that all we wanted from our politicians was the truth, when our history of punishing the tellers of hard truths, from Bob Dole to Bruce Babbitt to Paul Tsongas, insists otherwise. "I wanted sunshine," said a Michigan woman, explaining her disenchantment with the President as though she were voting for a new Wizard of Oz. "I wanted a rainbow."
If Americans found it difficult to take the past seriously and still support Bill Clinton, they finally could not take the future seriously and support George Bush, or take the present seriously and support Ross Perot. Pervading the campaign was the prospect of waking up on Nov. 4 to a Bush re-election: the great collective mood of the country would not have been merely joyless. It would not have been simply depression. It would have verged on the nihilistic. Mr. Bush's cynicism had become so naked it could no longer be denied. We could never feign shocked hurt the next time faith was broken.
In this light, our electoral decision was more than political. Confronted with a similar prospect in 1980, we had no choice but to elect Ronald Reagan. It didn't matter whether he was going to be a better President than Jimmy Carter; the psychic consequences of ratifying Mr. Carter's perceived failure were too dreadful. To choose George Bush again would have been to accept the inevitability of betrayal rather than dare to have faith one more time. To make a choice like that would be a kind of spiritual death.
This was Leap Year. It was the first important American Presidential election of the 21st century, a century that will, by the dictates of time and technology, devour itself faster than the century before it. In a scrambled moral universe, we had to hope that some constant of American faith was intact enough to extract the poetic justice of George Bush being consumed by his own cynicism: the cynical "promises" whose shameless calculations lay not in their breaking but in their making, the "convictions" characterized more by belligerence than by belief, the "commitment" that was never more energized than when it was focused on the consolidation of their own power. The President lost because America could not accept a dawn when the daylight revealed a country for which cynicism was the only identity that remained.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Top 10 U.S. Government Bond Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
United States Government bond funds are regarded as the safest of all mutual funds. Investors in these funds seek an assured steady income.
As of June 30, the latest data available, Treasury bonds made up 41.8 percent of the holdings in the funds. The bulk of the other holdings were in mortgage-backed securities issued by the Government National Mortgage Association, or Ginnie Mae, (23.5 percent); the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, (9.8 percent), and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac, (8.4 percent). 
 Because the funds invest mainly in Government securities, they have virtually no default risk. But they do carry market risk. As interest rates rise, the prices of the bonds -- and the fund shares -- fall. When rates fall, the share prices of the funds rise.
Government bond funds had a standard 30-day yield of 5.77 percent, on average, in September. They attract more assets, $63 billion, than any other type of bond fund.

HEADLINE: When a Bankruptcy Is the Best Way Out

BYLINE: By DEBORAH M. RANKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Tom and Annie resisted the decision for more than six months, but in the end they felt they had no option other than filing for bankruptcy. In doing so, this Portland couple, who asked that their family name be withheld, joined more than a million Americans who are expected to file for bankruptcy this year.
Earlier, when Tom and Annie lived in Texas, the economy was terrible and Tom, who is 36, was unable to find a job in the advertising business despite nearly a year of searching. His efforts to start his own ad agency in San Antonio were in trouble. As a last resort, Annie, 32, took a property management job 300 miles away. 
 Tom stayed in San Antonio to give his struggling ad business one last try. But after months of commuting on weekends to see his wife and two young children, he picked up stakes and joined them. They put their San Antonio house up for sale as well as a rental property they had purchased when times were better.
But the autumn passed without a single inquiry about either property. So, 10 months behind on their mortgage, the couple told their bank to foreclose on both houses and filed for bankruptcy.
 
A Big Downside
 They typify the families who are using this route to settle their financial problems. A major result of this decision, however, is a blemished credit history with unforeseen consequences. It could make it tough to obtain credit, to rent an apartment and even to get utility services.
"The main reasons that people end up in the bankruptcy court are circumstances beyond their control, usually employment or medical debt," said Kent V. Snyder, a Portland lawyer who represented Tom and Annie when they refiled for bankruptcy after moving back to Portland, Tom's hometown, because of illness in the family.
As the country's recession has persisted, the number of people filing for bankruptcy protection has reached record levels. For the year ended June 30, there were 972,490 filings, a 10.5 percent increase over the previous 12 months period, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute, a Washington research organization. The institute projects about a million bankruptcies by the end of 1992.
"The numbers seeking bankruptcy relief from heavy debt loads are still extremely high, but the worst may be over and we may soon see a leveling off," said Samuel J. Gerdano, executive director of the organization.
There are two ways that individuals can use the Federal Bankruptcy Code to help get their finances in order. Chapter 7, which requires immediate liquidation of whatever assets a debtor may have, is designed for individuals who want to make a fresh start but cannot pay their debts from current income.
By filing for Chapter 7, debtors are allowed to keep certain exempt property such as equity in a home. The remaining property is sold by a court-appointed trustee, with the money then distributed to creditors.
At the end of the case, which usually takes several months, the debtors get a discharge, which cancels most of their debts.
 
The Installment Plan
 Chapter 13, which involves a reorganization of an individual's debts, is designed for people with regular income who want to pay off their debts but are unable to do so. By filing under this chapter, they repay their creditors, in part or in full, in installments that may be spread over three years. During this time, creditors are prohibited from starting or continuing collection efforts.
For Tom and Annie, the decision to file under Chapter 13 was agonizing. "We wrestled with the decision for more than six months," Tom recalled. "It was embarrassing, but we owed about a quarter of a million dollars, including our two mortgages and $20,000 on our two cars. We had only $150,000 in assets. Our family income had dropped to $28,000 a year, or about half of what it had been. There was no other way."
They are now paying a trustee $400 a month, and their creditors are receiving some -- but not all -- of what is owed.
What are the pros and cons of filing for bankruptcy? "The advantage is that virtually all your debts are wiped out, though with Chapter 13 you may pay some of what you owe," said Henry J. Sommer, author of several books on consumer bankruptcy law and a supervising attorney with Community Legal Services in Philadelphia, which provides free legal help for the needy. "It is also a way of protecting some of your property and income from creditors, and stopping creditor harassment."
Another plus for Chapter 13, Mr. Snyder said, is a "cram down" provision that forces lenders to accept repayment terms they may object to but allow a debtor to restructure loans (except mortgage loans) and often stop foreclosure. In addition, a reorganization can allow people to pay off past due Federal, state and local taxes, which are not wiped out.
 
Filing Isn't Cheap
 Another consideration is the cost. Legal fees range from $500 to $800 for a Chapter 7 filing, and can be double or triple that for a Chapter 13 filing. There is also a filing fee of $120.
The drawbacks of filing under Chapter 7, Mr. Sommer said, are that you can lose your nonexempt property, such as some of your equity in your home and car, and in some cases your investments, jewelry or other valuables as well. Bankruptcy can also hurt credit ratings. A filing generally remains on your credit report for 10 years, 3 years longer than most other information.
Mr. Snyder dismisses that negative. "Let's face it," he said, "by the time you're at the brink of filing, your credit rating is already shot, so what difference does it make?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The unemployment rate dropped by one-tenth of a point for the fourth straight month in October, to 7.4 percent, but the creation of new jobs remained at a near standstill. Analysts said the report could be seen as not contradicting tentative signs pointing to a pickup in the economy. [Page 35.]
Consumer credit grew at an annual rate of 2.7 percent in September. It was the first increase in eight months, suggesting that people were beginning to increase spending. [35.]
 
International
European diplomats look to Bill Clinton and Helmet Kohl, Chancellor of Germany, to save the day before a trade war erupts. But it is unclear what either man intends to do. News Analysis. [1.]
American wine makers fear they will be harmed, not helped, by a punitive tax on European wine. Some wine executives fear retaliation on exports of California wine to Europe. [35.]
 
Companies
The Los Angeles Times plans to drop its San Diego County edition and to eliminate 500 jobs through a voluntary buyout program and attrition. The moves are a result of an advertising slump. [35.]
BellSouth plans to reduce its work force by 8,000 employees, or more than 8 percent of its 97,000 employees, within four years. [37.]
General Motors has reduced the age of eligibility for early retirement for some salaried employees to 50. [37.]
Food Lion's stock fell after "Prime Time Live" accused it of poor sanitation practices. The company disputed the report. [37.]
Motorola's Iridium unit plans to sell 85 percent of its stock to telecommunications companies that would share in profits. [39.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks slipped, although over all more issues advanced than declined. The Dow lost 3.78 points, to 3,240.06. [36.]
Treasury bond prices tumbled. In part the market was cautious before the Treasury's quarterly refunding. [43.]
The dollar rose. Traders said that as bond yields rise, the dollar will keep going higher. [44.] Soybean futures were higher. [44.]
 
 Your Money
Personal bankruptcies have grown sharply as the country's economic weakness has persisted. [33.]
Some firms are less than candid about differences between C.D.'s and "C.D. alternatives." Susan Antilla: Investing. [33.]
Bank deposits are less protected because of changes involving the F.D.I.C. Michael Quint: Banking. [34.]

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Is 7.4% For Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The nation's unemployment rate dropped by a tenth of a point in October for the fourth straight month, to 7.4 percent, but job growth remained at a near standstill, the Labor Department said today.
Analysts found an assortment of good and bad in the latest figures as they waded through crosscurrents that included the end of federally subsidized summer job programs, the return to work of striking school employees, a Postal Service early-retirement program and the cleanup of Hurricane Andrew. 
 Even as it issued the first major post-election economic report, the department sought to rebut or explain newspaper articles challenging the accuracy of recent figures, calling "totally and categorically false" an account in The New York Post that it had tampered with the September data to benefit President Bush's re-election campaign.
 
 
Matched Expectations
 Today's report was generally in line with expectations and appeared to alter few forecasts. And opinion remained divided as to the likelihood of another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Still, various analysts said today's report did not contradict tentative signs emerging lately, including higher car and chain-store sales and lower claims for unemployment benefits, that pointed to an economic pickup.
"We've changed to a more mixed pattern of the evidence," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist of the Dreyfus Corporation, although "the economy is still relatively weak."
Payroll jobs, the figure most closely scrutinized by economists, climbed 27,000 last month after a revised decline of 72,000 in September. For the private sector alone -- excluding all levels of government -- the gain was an even stronger 66,000.
 
Effects of Hurricane Andrew
 But analysts noted that the gains were concentrated in health and business services and in construction, where a 20,000 jump reflected rebuilding efforts in storm-damaged Florida and Louisiana.
And these gains, which also included the first monthly increase in wholesale trade in more than two years, were largely offset among workers who produce goods.
Particularly disappointing was a 56,000 drop in factory jobs, following a 38,000 decline in September.
"Employers understand that the third-quarter surge in gross domestic product is unsustainable," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. The Commerce Department reported last week that output of goods and services climbed in the quarter at a 2.7 percent annual rate, a result mainly of higher consumer spending not supported by current income.
In Little Rock, Ark., President-elect Bill Clinton issued a statement on the report in which he called the slight improvement in unemployment "a step in the right direction" while repeating his determination "to stem the continued slide in manufacturing jobs."
While shedding workers, factory managers increased the hours of those who remained on the job. The factory workweek expanded 12 minutes, to 41.1 hours, and factory overtime rose 18 minutes, to 3.8 hours. For the private sector as a whole, weekly hours rose 12 minutes.
This allowed the department's index of aggregate weekly hours, a proxy for industrial production figures to be reported at midmonth, to rise to 121.3, from 120.6 in September.
Another payroll gauge, the proportion of industries adding workers during the month, edged up to 50 percent, from 48.7 in September and 42.6 in August.
 
 
Retirements at Post Office
 Employment in local government rose a bit as teachers returned from strikes, despite the end of summer jobs programs. A 45,000 drop in Federal jobs was attributed primarily to an early-retirement option by the Postal Service.
The Labor Department's other survey, of about 60,000 households, showed a continuation of the contraction in the labor force since June. This decline of about 600,000, mostly among adult women, has been the main factor keeping the unemployment rate edging down.
While moves of a tenth of a point are not material, four declines in a row of this size are significant, an official said.
In October, jobs fell 76,000, but the work force fell 314,000, resulting in a 238,000 decline in the ranks of the unemployed. At 9,334,000, the number of jobless people has fallen 640,000 from its June peak.
 
 
Undercuts News Article
 The work-force shrinkage seemed to argue against the contention made in an article in The New York Post on Thursday that the Bush Administration had "purposely tampered" with the September data by artificially shrinking the labor force, thereby allowing the jobless rate to fall. The newpaper had predicted "a shocker" of a work-force rebound in the post-election report today.
In response to a second challenge, department officials said they disagreed with an interpretation of its data that formed the basis of an article in The Wall Street Journal today.
At issue was a divergence again this year between two measures of payroll jobs: one a national figure and the other a figure produced by adding those of the 50 individual states. In the March-July period, the national estimate rose 400,000 while the states' count dropped by 377,000, a difference of 777,000.
Officials said they took the divergence seriously, but noted that it would have been only about a quarter as big if the May-September period had been used. They also said that historically the sum-of-states method had proved far less accurate than the national estimate.
The department predicted today that this year's revision of its national data will be less than 100,000, in a downward direction, far less than the unusually large revision of 640,000 last year and half the average over the last 10 years.
Geographically, 9 of the 11 biggest states for which figures were published showed declines in their jobless rates last month. In New Jersey, the rate fell to 8.1 percent from 9. The New York rate eased to 8.7 from 9.
Regionally, the jobless rate declined to 8.1 from 8.5 in the Northeast; to 6.9 from 7.2 in the South, and to 6 from 6.5 in the Midwest. In the West, the rate rose to 8.6 from 8.1.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
The Los Angeles Times in Retreat

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6

 BODY:
The Los Angeles Times said today that it would stop publishing its San Diego County edition on Dec. 18 and eliminate 500 jobs through a voluntary buyout program and attrition in the next year.
The moves are a result of an advertising slump caused by the weak economy in Southern California and a decline in the circulation of the San Diego County edition, one of several zoned editions produced by The Los Angeles Times, which is owned by the Times Mirror Company. 
 Industry analysts described the actions as drastic. While other newspapers have offered buyouts because of a steady decline in newspaper advertising linage in recent years, this is the second buyout program offered by The Times in about a year. About 300 jobs were cut in the earlier round.
 
Aggressive Zoning
 Also, while other papers have scaled back zoned editions, analysts could not name another big newspaper that had closed one. The Times has had a more aggressive zoning policy than perhaps any other newspaper because its local market is so widespread.
But with the retrenchment of the military and aerospace industries and the decline of the real estate market in the 1990's, all important components of the Southern California economy, advertising linage has fallen. Last year, the advertising linage of The Los Angeles Times fell 14.7 percent, as linage throughout the industry suffered its worst decline since World War II. Linage at The Times has declined every month this year and is down 4 percent to date. The biggest drop has come in classified advertising -- including employment, automotive and real estate notices -- which now accounts for about 25 percent of total advertising, compared with 35 percent to 40 percent a few years ago.
In 1990, The Los Angeles Times became the nation's largest metropolitan daily newspaper, with a daily circulation of 1.2 million. But The Times has been unable to stop suburban newspapers from gaining market share in areas like Orange County, about 50 miles south of the city, and the San Fernando Valley, an area northwest of downtown in Los Angeles County -- regions The Times once presumed were part of its empire.
Industry analysts said that in hard economic times, advertisers cut back their zoned newspaper advertising because they view it as secondary to the coverage they can get in local papers. As a result, those zoned sections are where newspapers make their first cost reductions, the analysts said.
"In a recession, newspapers tend to cut back spending on their country circulation that is beyond their core markets," said John Morton, a media analyst with Lynch, Jones & Ryan. "It's expensive to keep these editions going, especially if they are losing money, and as a result they tend to get hurt first in a recession."
The San Diego County edition has struggled to gain market share against The San Diego Union-Tribune, which is owned by Copley Newspapers, and local weekly newspapers, many of which have free distribution.
At its inception, the edition for San Diego County, which is about 100 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, had circulation of 28,000 readers, which grew to 65,000 in 1988. But it has since slipped to today's 61,653. The Times does not provide advertising figures for its zoned editions. By contrast, The Union-Tribune, after being formed by the merger of San Diego's morning and evening papers in February, had a circulation of about 390,000.
"Because of its distance from our home base, and the significantly larger numbers of our competitors in San Diego, the overall economics of producing a separate daily edition for San Diego have not worked," David Laventhol, The Los Angeles Times's publisher and chief executive, said in a statement.
"A recent internal study concluded that while our circulation growth has been steady over the years, our base in San Diego is limited by the bigger numbers of other newspapers in the area. There is little likelihood that this would change in the future."
 
Saving at Least $8 Million
 The company said that it expected to save $8 million a year by closing the San Diego County edition but that savings from the employee reduction program had not been determined. The Times will sell its Los Angeles edition in San Diego.
The San Diego County edition's 107 full-time news and business employees will be offered new positions with the newspaper, which will maintain a five-person news bureau in San Diego, the paper said.
The Times introduced its first suburban section in 1952, becoming the first metropolitan newspaper to create zoned editions. Its five regional editions cover broad areas like Orange County and the San Fernando Valley; it also has four weekly or twice-weekly community news sections. In August, the paper introduced a similar section for inner-city neighborhoods, in part a reaction to the riots in the city last spring.
 
Strong Competitors
 The sections and editions are often intended to make The Times more competitive with strong local papers, like The Orange County Register. The Times's Orange County edition has gained circulation in a long-running battle for that market.
For the six months that ended in September, the Orange County edition of The Times had an average weekday circulation of 193,923, a 4.6 percent increase from the similar period of 1991. The Register's average weekday circulation declined 4.5 percent in the period, to 304,755, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Craig Silvers, an analyst for Crowell, Weedon, said that he doubted that The Times would eliminate other zoned editions because it needs them to maintain a presence in markets that are closest to Los Angeles. "Abandoning Orange County or the Valley would definitely be admitting defeat, and they can't afford to do that now," Mr. Silvers said.
Analysts said that The Times had spent tens of millions of dollars on the zoned editions in an effort to keep the suburban papers, like The Register, Union-Tribune and The Los Angeles Daily News -- the key competitor in the San Fernando Valley -- at bay but that the results were not promising. "The Times has been doing quality work in these zoned editions," Mr. Morton said, "but they are not attracting readers and advertisers in large numbers and that is due mainly to the recession."
In the third quarter, the earnings of Times Mirror, which also owns magazines, other newspapers and cable television stations, increased 6.8 percent, despite a significant drag caused by a decline in advertising at The Times. Times Mirror had net income of $43.8 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $41 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1991 third quarter. Revenues rose 2.8 percent, to $914.4 million. The Times's newspaper publishing unit, which includes Newsday, New York Newsday and The Baltimore Sun, posted a 2 percent decline in revenues.
The paper has been seeking to cut costs wherever it can. Some 5,200 employees who have at least a year of service are eligible to apply for the 500 buyouts. The program provides up to two years of pay, depending on length of service and is expected to result in a charge against earnings in the fourth quarter, the paper said.
Shares of Times Mirror closed at $29.75 today, up 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Face of Future At Ferry Dock Is 120 Feet Tall

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
With a clock face large enough to change the whole face of lower Manhattan, a design by two of America's more adventurous architects has been chosen for the new Staten Island Ferry terminal.
The design, by Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, won an unusual municipal competition for a plan to replace the old ferry building, which was badly damaged by fire in September 1991. The contest attracted some of the most important architects in the country, drawn by the opportunity to place their signature at one of the city's most visible portals. 
 One hundred twenty feet in diameter, with the seal of New York City in its center -- and illuminated, in the bargain -- the clock proposed by Mr. Venturi and Ms. Scott Brown would dwarf even the gaping ferry slips beneath it, through which some 70,000 commuters and sightseers travel every day. It might join the World Trade Center and the Statue of Liberty as a landmark in the harbor, not only for its design but for the sharpness of feelings it is bound to provoke.
 
'A Bold New Symbol'
 "We wanted this to have a wonderful, vivid image," Mr. Venturi said at City Hall yesterday, after his design was announced as the unanimous choice of an 11-member jury headed by Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Mayor David N. Dinkins predicted that the structure, known formally as the Whitehall Ferry Terminal, would "become a bold new symbol for the city." It is to be completed in 1998 and the cost is estimated at $112 million. The project is being undertaken by the development corporation and the Transportation Department.
Although the clock, equal in height to a 10-story building, has already come under attack and may be modified as the project goes through two years of design, there are many other noteworthy aspects of the proposal.
Behind the clock, and echoing its shape somewhat, is a vast waiting room with a barrel-vaulted ceiling, about 125 feet high, that is meant to evoke the concourse at Grand Central Terminal. A smaller free-standing clock would mark the entrance to Peter Minuit Plaza, which would be redesigned to serve not only pedestrian traffic but also as a one-acre gathering place for community and cultural events.
The waiting room would be lined with concessions, with a restaurant above. City officials have banned vehicles permanently from the ferry, so the new terminal will not accommodate cars, as the old one did.
 
No Stranger to Controversy
 The new terminal would be the first building in New York designed by Mr. Venturi, an unorthodox Philadelphia architect whose 1966 book, "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture," was one of the most influential criticisms of the spare modernist architecture that predominated after World War II. In the face of Mies van der Rohe's dictum, "Less is more," Mr. Venturi declared, "Less is a bore."
Among the more passionately debated of his own designs was the Sainsbury Wing of the National Gallery in London, completed in 1991. Other well-known projects include the new Seattle Art Museum and Independence National Historic Park in Philadelphia.
The firm of Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates, is allied in the Whitehall effort with Anderson/Schwartz Architects, of Manhattan.
"We wanted to pick something that says something about the city," Mr. Levitt said. "We wanted to pick something that was joyous, something that's important for our children to come to and enjoy."
Mr. Levitt said the new terminal would be a "signature, to be seen from the water and from the air, which will provide New York with another landmark; more significant, I think, than the twin towers or the Empire State Building, largely because of its location and because of its whimsy."
But 120 feet worth of whimsy is too much for Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, who said the timepiece made the terminal "look more suitable for a model village under someone's Christmas tree."
The clock "is out of place and will be difficult to adjust when switching, for example, to daylight saving time," he said. "Its only probable benefit would be to remind people that they're late for work -- again."
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, refused to be drawn into a discussion of the clock. However, she said generally that the Venturi design was "one of the more intriguing and potentially interesting" of the six that had been presented.
The other entrants were Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, James Stewart Polshek and Partners, Aldo Rossi Studio di Architettura, Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Rafael Vinoly Architects.
Municipal projects are usually awarded by bidding, rarely by competition. But Carl Weisbrod, president of the Economic Development Corporation, said the site was "one of the most important" in the city, for transportation and access to the waterfront. "That lent itself to trying to engage the greatest architects of our time to make a major civic statement," he said.
Mr. Weisbrod said that the $6 million for the design work and the $16 million to repair the three ferry slips had come from the city and Federal governments. Sources for the construction money are "not yet fully identified," he said, although officials expect some will come from Washington.
