PUB-DATE: November 8, 1992

SECTION: Section 2; Page 32; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1059 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
The Nina, the Pinta and the Fate of the 'White City'

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Columbia, enthroned on her "Barge of State," sails into the grand lagoon, with Father Time at the helm and Victory at the prow. Eight plaster maidens, representing Arts and Industries, work the oars. From the rim of the lagoon a white city arises, its gleaming arcades and pavilions designed by America's leading architects. Fountains gush. Fireworks explode nightly.
Now, that's the way to celebrate Columbus. Or so it seemed to the builders of the World's Columbian Exposition, held in Chicago nearly a century ago. Unlike the makers of this year's dud Hollywood epics, the architects of the Chicago world's fair knew how to throw a party. Allegory. Spectacle. Classical architecture, an entire city of it, went up in Jackson Park in 1893 to commemorate the discovery of the New World. And for a generation thereafter, Chicago's fabled "White City" was an ideal to which every American city aspired. From the fair emerged the nationwide City Beautiful movement, a progenitor of modern city planning and the force behind such New York landmarks as Grand Central Terminal and the Public Library. 
 The fair's legacy endures. It is evident not just in such banal manifestations as theme parks and festival marketplaces but in the shift of the urban economic base from manufacturing to information. People came to the world's fair not to live, work or shop, but to acquire information -- to gain a global perspective on art, science, history and commerce. A century later, the "world cities" of the global marketplace have come to resemble the White City as places geared primarily to the exchange of ideas.
For Henry Adams, the fair was "the first expression of American thought as a unity." The fair's unified architectural composition of classical facades, spray-painted a uniform white, conferred a semblance of consistency on 19th-century America's cultural hodgepodge. But the unity evoked by the fair's architecture was more than an abstract cultural ideal. In 1893, the Civil War was still a potent memory. An allegorical statue of the Republic, the most prominent sculpture at the fair, was reflected in the lagoon's placid surface; it symbolized a reunified nation.
Above all, the White City expressed the unification of American commerce. As Lewis Mumford observed in the 1920's, the fair's "imperial facade" marked a historical shift in American enterprise: from small, entrepreneurial businesses to large financial trusts; from local industries to national monopolies and the unified rail systems that connected their far-flung operations; from manufacturing to finance.
The world's fair launched the consolidated empire of the robber barons onto a world stage. Its message was commercial warfare. Thus the California pavilion featured a colossal statue of a knight on horseback made entirely of prunes. As the fair's guidebook made clear, the statue "metaphorically impressed the fact that the prunes of that state are being introduced victoriously into all lands, to the discomfiture of the products of other countries." The White City, in short, was a full dress rehearsal for the American Century. It announced to the nations gathered around the lagoon, thanks very much for the Nina, the Pinta, the Santa Maria, not to mention the Mayflower and General Lafayette, too. Now it's the New World's turn to frame a new world order.
We got our American Century. So where's our Beautiful City? How come, instead of fountains and fireworks, the world's richest nation ended up with glass boxes along Sixth Avenue and burnt-out storefronts in South-Central Los Angeles?
Today, the monuments of the City Beautiful movement loom like haunting reminders of a vision that failed to materialize. For every fixed-up Bryant Park, a dozen neglected Beaux-Arts beauties languish. Spray-painted with graffiti, or with white paint to cover the discordant scrawl, their facades speak not of unity but of fragmentation. They lie scattered about a city increasingly polarized into privileged enclaves and settlements that recall Beirut. Nothing could contrast more sharply with the harmonious vision that arose in Jackson Park.
And yet, for all its visual chaos and social segregation, today's splintered city recalls the White City in one critical respect. It, too, marks a historic shift in commercial enterprise. Manuel Castels, a professor of planning at the University of California at Berkeley, has analyzed this development in depth. His book "The Informational City" traces the decline of manufacturing jobs and their traditional social supports; economic globalization and the new information technologies on which it depends; the mismatch between the city's new immigrant populations and the skills required to succeed in the new service industries. These factors have combined to produce a "dual city" that differs in kind from the industrial city's division between rich and poor.
This city is indeed a New World. It has its intrepid explorers: scholars like Castels, and the economist Saskia Sassen, who have pioneered the study of this new urban terrain. Photographers, film makers, metropolitan news reporters and songwriters are also feeding glimpses of the new city into the cultural mainstream.
Architects have had a harder time getting a handle on things. Buildings are identified more closely with the social segregation of cities than with strategies that might overcome it. Designs for corporate towers, luxury housing, museums and other high-end institutions reinforce the view that architecture chiefly serves the elite.
The view is not entirely a distortion. After two centuries of modern democracy, architecture is still a "white city." Even a recession does not drive buildings down in price that far. But the problem lies only partly with the way buildings are designed and paid for. It is also rooted in the way architecture is perceived, taught and written about. There is no shortage of "downscale" buildings. Courthouses, clinics, schools, subways: if building forms such as these seldom conform to our conception of art, the fault lies with the conception, not just the forms.
Information thus has an important role to play in mending the fractured "informational city." A change in the perception of architecture cannot, by itself, heal a divided city. But it could lead us to discover what lies beyond.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
American Indian Art: In the Spotlight at Galleries

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Thousands of American Indian art enthusiasts are expected to converge on New York this week to attend the previews and opening next Sunday of the Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian, at the Alexander Hamilton Custom House in lower Manhattan. And while they are about it, many people will probably visit the gallery exhibitions timed to coincide with the museum festivities.
The Custom House exhibition of 100 artifacts represents the first stage in the transfer of the oil magnate George Gustav Heye's vast collection of American Indian art. Eventually, more than a million items will be removed from their home at Broadway and 155th Street, where they have been on view since 1922. Some will go to the Smithsonian's permanent satellite downtown, which will bear the name Heye (pronounced Hi); the rest will go to the main facility that the institution plans to build by the end of the decade on the Washington Mall. 
 To celebrate this long-awaited move downtown and to help raise money for the Washington museum, Alexander Acevedo is presenting "Masterworks of Native America," an exhibition of 135 ancient and modern works from 20 dealers at his Alexander Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street. Ten percent of the sales from the show, which will run from Friday night through Sunday, will go to the museum.
"Millions of people have gone to the Heye museum uptown," Mr. Acevedo said. "That's where I fell in love with American Indian art as a boy, when we visited it on a school trip. Now it's time to pay back something."
The artifacts assembled at the Alexander Gallery reflect the amazing variety of American Indian styles, from Aztec to Zuni, that flourished between 200 B.C. and the 20th century. They range in price from $4,500 for a Brazilian terra-cotta Janus bowl made in the 1940's, offered by Spencer Throckmorton of Manhattan, to $3 million for a pre-Columbian collection of 150 pieces of gold jewelry, including pectorals, necklaces, earrings, nose ornaments and headdresses, shown by the Ariadne Gallery of Manhattan.
The show is rich in beaded, painted and fringed deerskin clothing, the most impressive of which is a white outfit, from 1830, of leggings and a war shirt, with one shoulder blackened by gunpowder. It was worn by a Madan, more than six feet tall, from the Upper Missouri region, whose tribe was virtually wiped out by smallpox in the late 1830's.
"He was a very important warrior," said Joel Kopp, whose gallery, America Hurrah, owns the shirt. "It's marked with 27 pipes, one for each of the war parties he led, and a dozen marks for coup sticks, indicating those enemies he touched and did not kill." The price is $375,000.
The fringed frock coat of one of Kit Carson's deerskin suits, which Mr. Acevedo is exhibiting in the show, is lavishly embroidered with silk flowers stitched by an Eastern Sioux in the 1850's. It is $75,000.
In addition to colorful examples of such staples as elaborately beaded moccasins, boldly striped Navajo blankets, painted drums, woven baskets and terra-cotta bowls, the displays include ceremonial masks, buffalo robes, lacy mantas and silver belts.
Each dealer selected one or more rarity. Jeffrey R. Meyers, a New York dealer who has lived among the Eskimos part of each summer for the last 16 years, said his most uncommon item is an ivory drum handle, carved in the shape of a human being, from about 600 A.D. and recently excavated on St. Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea. The figure's ringlike eyes are inlaid with metal. The price is $17,500.
James Economos, a dealer from Santa Fe, chose a powerful Hopi kachina doll, one foot tall, with a bear on its back. "It's not an altar doll but a 19th-century household piece," he said. "The carving on its back means the spirit of the bear has gone into the kachina." The price is $30,000.
Transformation, Aztec style, is represented by a sculpture of a seated ruler in a trance. Mr. Throckmorton, the Manhattan dealer, is asking $50,000 for this 15th-century carving, finely chiseled from volcanic stone.
Another exhibition with some American Indian material, "Masks: Spirits From Beyond," is at the Tambaran Gallery, 20 East 76th Street, through February. Among the eight ceremonial dance masks from the Western Hemisphere are a round-faced Eskimo study, framed by a halo of caribou fur, and a Hopi mask with a chalky face and a curly red wig. And one of the four Guatemalan masks shown, an 18th-century carved-wood deer mask, boasts a haunting bulletlike head and one antler. Prices range from $1,800 to $25,000.
Mr. Throckmorton is presenting "Origins: Lithic Stone Votive Figures From the New World" at his private gallery, Fine Arts of Ancient Lands, 12 East 86th Street, through Dec. 5. The exhibition's 50 egg-shaped votive figures, which were regarded in antiquity as sacred stones, began as axes and were later carved with human features by masters of minimalism between 1800 and 800 B.C. in what is now Mexico. These figures, measuring between 3 and 14 inches high, have eyes, mouths and limbs depicted by grooves or deep routing. They range in price from $500 to $40,000.
Here, too, artists concentrated on magical transformation, with axes metamorphosed into people. "But much of the natural form of the stone remains untouched," Mr. Throckmorton said, "which is the essence of minimalism."

HEADLINE: NOBLESSE LARGESSE

 BODY:
The pressures of the 1992 campaign season were such that the use of language by George Bush, Bill Clinton and Ross Perot became more tarnished by the day (On Language: "Noblesse Largesse," by William Safire, Oct. 11). In a speech following the debate on Oct. 15, Bush compared himself to the pennant-winning Atlanta Braves, saying that politics is like baseball: "It ain't over till the last batter swings." The relevant baseball saying is "It ain't over until the fat lady sings." Perhaps he was being careful not to offend any overweight voters.
Clinton was guilty of awkward language. I heard him speak of "growing the economy" and "growing jobs," as if he were running for national groundskeeper. Perhaps, because of the "character" or "trust" issue, he wanted to reassure skeptical voters by planting an image of Clinton the caretaker. 
 Perot, for his part, committed another racial gaffe in the Oct. 19 debate. Referring to the savings and loan scandal, he said, "Nobody touched that tar baby till the day after the election in 1988." But unlike the infamous "you people" remarks, Perot's slur largely was igored by newspapers and TV.
 
DEXTER K. FLOWERS
Baltimore

HEADLINE: New Momentum Builds on 125th Street

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
EFFORTS to revitalize 125th Street have gained momentum in recent months as new ventures have appeared on Harlem's main shopping, entertainment and business thoroughfare.
Last month the Victoria 5 Theater, Central Harlem's only moviehouse, reopened after being dark for more than a year.
In July a local businessman, Joseph Holland, opened a Ben & Jerry's ice-cream parlor on the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 125th Street. And before the end of the year a branch of The Body Shop, a London-based cosmetics company, is to take space in the ground floor of the National Black Theater on the northeast corner of 125th Street and Fifth Avenue. 
 Moreover, some local merchants have improved or upgraded their businesses there and a local development agency official says national retailers, including Pathmark and Caldor, are testing the wind for possible positions on the street.
But in the face of these and other improvements, 125th Street, long the economic and cultural center of Harlem, continues to struggle. With each gain that raises hopes about its future, the street seems to suffer a bruising setback.
The Apollo Theater, for example, underwent a $20 million redevelopment a few years ago that added a state-of-the-art entertainment complex, with a recording studio and television production center. But since then losses suffered by the company that operates the historic and cultural landmark have piled up. One problem has been that revenue from the use of these facilities by outside groups has not been as high as expected.
A plan has been devised that will transfer the theater, which is still in full use, to a nonprofit company. Eugene Webb, the principal of Webb & Booker, said that a contract for the transfer could be signed by the end of the month.
Another blow to the retail strip and community at large came last month when fire severely damaged the Carver Federal Savings Bank. The bank is temporarily operating in space in the garage building adjacent to the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building.
Dorothy Pitman Hughes, who owns and operates two stores on 125th Street, said that staying in business on the thoroughfare is a continuing struggle.
"It is difficult being a business person here," she said, standing behind the counter of her new Harlem Office Supplies store. "I am here because I want to be here. But I think we have to work harder to stay in business than people in other areas do."
Mrs. Hughes's new store, which she opened in June, is the only full-service office-equipment store on the street. Its stock ranges from stationery to office furniture and business machines like fax equipment. She also has a copy-and-printing store on the street.
Just three years ago 125th Street seemed poised for a significant turnaround. Rents, at a record high, were pushing toward $60 a square foot. Today, retail brokers say few spaces, when they are available, can command more than $35 to $40. That compares to an average of $50 that owners get for retail space on 14th Street in Manhattan, and $45 to $60 on Jamaica Avenue, the main shopping strip in Jamaica, Queens.
PART of the bounce on 125th Street a few years ago was in anticipation of the start of several sizable new projects. The most ambitious was to have beeen a $160 million International Trade Center on a state-owned parcel at 125th Street and Lenox Avenue. Plans called for a 30-story office tower, a luxury hotel and conference hall and a municipal garage. The project is still planned, but the lack of leases has delayed it more two years.
Like merchants elsewhere, shopkeepers in Harlem have seen business drop and the number of patrons dwindle as the region's economy has soured. Moreover, an older and longer-lasting problem affects businesses and retailers on the street. They have not been helped by the fact that the neighborhood has seen a significant drop in population over several decades and that housing has been abandoned.
Measurable progress has been made by city, state and nonprofit housing groups in the effort to rebuild the community's decaying apartment buildings and brownstones. An area bounded by 110th and 122d Streets and Manhattan and Fifth Avenues has seen the redevelopment of more than 7,000 housing units. But so far the improvements have not reached a level where they can be felt by local merchants and businesses.
Neither have local businesses been helped by the rise in the number of street vendors on 125th Street. On card tables or cardboad boxes set up curbside, they peddle goods ranging from African-made jewelry, art, fabric and clothing to books, tapes, T-shirts and copies of designer leather goods.
"It has gotten worse," said Eugene Giscombe, a principal of Giscombe Henderson, a local real estate brokerage and property management company. "The fact is that they do not have to pay for space and are unfair competition."
Mr. Giscombe, whose company handles 30 stores on 125th Street, said that in addition to the competition from the vendors, shopkeepers sometimes are fined for the street litter left by the vendors or their customers.
The city's zoning laws are on the side of those who want the vendors removed from the street. But dealing with the problem continues to be a sensitive issue.
Part of the problem is that many of the vendors are black West Africans. Some black merchants are reluctant to have them removed by force and others fear reprisals if they are. In the last few weeks tensions between shopkeepers and the vendors have increased as pressure to removed them from the street has built. A loosely organized group of merchants, public officials and people representing the vendors is working to maintain the peace.
DESPITE the problems, Donald Coggsville, president of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, and others remain optimistic, even about the street's short-term future. He points to projects like the Victoria 5 Theater and Mart 125 and to discussions with Pathmark and Caldor and a commitment from the operators of World Yacht Cruises to start a restaurant cruise from the West 125th Street pier by summer.
Among the most successful ventures has been the development of Mart 125, an indoor complex at 260 West 125th where small retailers can rent stalls instead of full-fledged store spaces.
"Mart 125 has been like an retail incubator for the community," Mr. Coggsville said.
Harlem Urban Development, which owns the movie theater building, awarded a new lease to a minority-owned investment team after the previous leaseholder was unable to keep the theater in operation. The theater, which had undergone a $2.5 million renovation five years ago, has five screens and new projection and audio equipment.
"What is significant," said Mr. Coggsville, "is that not only has the movie theater re-opened, but that the investment team is made up of people from the community who have a personal as well as a financial stake its success."
Evidence of the street's potential is visible in the long block between Frederick Douglass and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards, where there is literally no space for rent on the south side of the street. It holds a mix of local stores as well as as satellites of national chain stores like Lane Bryant, Woolworth's and the Lerner Shop.
But across the street and along the blocks to the east, buildings stand empty and many of the upper floors have no office tenants or residents.
A PARTICULARLY hopeful sign for the street's future is the redevelopment of the corner at Fifth Avenue and 125th Street.
On the southeast corner is the new Ben & Jerry's ice cream parlor, a result of an unusual public-private partnership. It was developed by Joseph H. Holland, a local entrepreneur who also owns Harlem Travel on Fifth Avenue and 124th Street. Mr. Holland's partner in the venture is a nonprofit community organization, Harlem Ark of Freedom, which operates a shelter on West 129th Street.
To open the franchise, Mr. Holland persuaded the New York State Urban Development Corporation to lend $100,000 in revolving loan funds for women's and minority businesses. The venture also got financing from private investors and a construction loan from Community Capital Bank.
Because the store is owned in part by the nonprofit Harlem Ark, Ben & Jerry waived its standard $25,000 franchise fee. Some of the men who live in the shelter are employed in the ice cream shop and 75 percent of the profits are put back into Harlem Ark.
Mr. Holland said that "business has been better than we expected" and that through September the store had been averaging 4,500 customers a week. Mr. Holland, who owns the building housing the ice cream shop, plans to turn the vacant floors above it into permanent, single-room residences for homeless single adults.
"I believe that to make significant changes you have to reinvest in people as well as businesses," said Mr. Holland, a graduate of Cornell University and Harvard Law School.
Directly across the street from the Ben & Jerry's store, the Body Shop expects to open on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 125th Street before Christmas. It will go into the ground floor of the National Black Theater building.
Lisa Hurling, spokeswoman for the store, declined to give details of the lease. When it opens, the Body Shop will follow three other new tenants into the retail space in the theater's ground level. A restaurant, the Gadabout, which used to be in Mart 125, the Uptown Comedy Club and the Jubilee Book Store have also taken space there.
After the theater was destroyed by fire nearly 10 years ago it was rebuilt and expanded. The new building, designed by Gerard Paul of Geppaul Architects in Broolyn, includes a 288-seat theater, offices and rehearsal-hall space, which is often leased to outside groups and performers. The $7 million theater was built with a package of public grants and private gifts.
Barbara Ann Teer, founder and director of the theater, said that in designing the new building the retail space was expanded so that income from the ground-floor tenants could help support the theater, which is a nonprofit company.
SOME business owners on 125th Street, like Mrs. Hughes, who owns the office supply and copy and printing stores, would like to see state funds being used to redevelop large businesses -- like the movie theater -- apportioned out at her level, too.
"Local merchants are sometimes bypassed when contracts are awarded," she said. "The state should be using their products and services when they can."
Mrs. Hughes is negoting with the state purchasing office and Harlem Urban Development to try to provide the agency with some of its office supplies.
"Right now I am paying H.U.D.C. $35 a square foot for space," said Mrs. Hughes, whose office-supply store is in the retail portion of the garage owned by the corporation. "I am in their house, so to speak, and it would make sense to me that an agency that was set up to develop and support local business could do business with merchants on the street whenever possible. A lot has been done for Harlem, but I would like to see more done in Harlem."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

GOURMET ART
 When displaying sculpture made of chocolate there are no options, temperature wise. So Jacques Kaplan's main concern will be keeping cool during the current exhibition at his Paris-New York-Kent Gallery in Kent, on view through Nov. 22. 
 The theme is food, and in addition to the 25-inch-tall chocolate figures created by Chris Zaima, owner of the The Cafe in New Preston, there are dozens of art works dating from the 17th century to the present, all relating to food.
One of the 19th-century pictures by Howard Brunot depicts a lion being fed raw meat for the titillation of an audience of elegant women. Another is a representation of the Last Supper by the Spanish pop artist Carlos Sansegundo. It is almost nine feet wide, executed in oils, collage and tiny mirrors.
William Copley, Richard Lindner, Don Bracken and Joyce Johnson are a few of the other featured artists.
The gallery, at Station Square, is a converted 9-by-60-foot railroad car. It is open on Saturdays and Sundays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. and by appointment. Information: 927-3357.
 
PUPPETS ON THE WALL
 A portion of the 1,000-year-old East Indian epic, the Mahabharata, has been adapted as a Balinese shadow puppet show at Yale. A performance will be given on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. in Jonathan Edwards College, 68 High Street, on the New Haven campus. Admission is $5.
The story, which traditionally unfolds over many hours, is about two prominent related families -- one virtuous, the other consumed by greed -- ending in a bloody civil war over land ownership that involves the entire community.
In this version, which takes more than two hours without an intermission, about 30 shadow puppets will be manipulated by I. Wayan Wija, the dalang, or puppeteer. He also provides the voices for the principal characters. The performance will be accompanied by an orchestra from Bali, called a gamelan.
Shadow puppetry, like most other forms of puppetry, originated as low-cost entertainment for adults. The shadows, cast by flat, cutout figures onto a wall or screen, move in and out of the light, manipulated by sticks in lifelike fashion.
For more information or reservations call the Yale Council on Southeast Asia Studies at 432-3431. This is the third Balinese shadow puppet show produced by the council.
 
IRELAND TODAY
 The continuing conflicts in Northern Ireland will be addressed in Hartford today at 7 P.M. by two clergymen who are part of a national speaking program instituted by the Presbyterian Church USA and the United States Catholic Conference. The program will be at the Hartford Seminary, 77 Sherman Street, and is public free of charge.
The Rev. David Clarke, minister at the Terrace Row Presbyterian Church and active in the Presbyterian Church of Ireland, and Msgr. Sean Rogan, pastor of St. Malachy's Catholic Church and a participant in Roman Catholic affairs in Northern Ireland, both served their churches in the largely Protestant city of Coleraine near Derry.
They will discuss Northern Ireland's religious, political and economic problems, and offer their assessment of American attitudes toward the conflict and how efforts have fared in attempting to reconcile Protestants and Roman Catholics.
 
HARPSICHORD RECITAL
 Richard Rephann, a professor of music at Yale who is a harpsichordist and the director of the Yale collection of musical instruments as well as a specialist in the performance of 17th- and 18th-century music, will give a recital of keyboard works by French composers today at 3 P.M.
The performance in the second-floor gallery of the collection, at 15 Hillhouse Avenue, will feature Chambonniere's "Pieces de Clavecin in A Minor," Couperin's "Quatrieme Ordre," and Rameau's "Pieces de Clavecin in G."
Tickets are $15, or $10 for students and the elderly; Call 432-0825 for reservations.
 
TWIST ON IMPRESSIONISM
 Without a doubt, Janet Cummings Good is immersed in her work. A painter, printmaker, illustrator and designer, she has taken to plastering herself with gesso to create printed images on paper, which she calls "Bodyprints." An exhibition of the results may be seen at the Newspace Gallery of Manchester Community College through Nov. 20.
With the addition of color and tone, using oils, prismacolor and graphite, the pieces take on an abstract quality, although flashes of life-sized realistic detail remain, transforming the ordinary into something other worldly.
The gallery, in the Lowe Building at 60 Bidwell Street, Manchester, is open Monday through Friday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., and Saturday from 9 A.M. to noon.
 
ISSUES OF THE AGED
 One of the most troubling issues for America's older population will be explored in a health insurance symposium for elderly people, to be held on Thursday from 8:45 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. at St. Thomas School, 203 East Avenue, Norwalk.
Speakers will conduct hourlong workshops on such topics as Medigap insurance policies, transferring assets, espousal impoverishment, long-term care, and the prospect of national health care reform.
Danny Albert, principal examiner for the Connecticut Insurance Department, will discuss "Changes, Fears and Trends in Health Insurance for Senior Citizens" at 10:30 A.M. Other speakers include Evelyn Knight from the State Department on Aging, Gerd Weindling and Raymond Moore of the American Association of Retired Persons, Sam Starks of the legal firm of Reiss, Walzer and Starks, and Walter Keenan, an attorney with the Center of Medicare Advocacy.
Advance registration is $2 for those 65 years and older, $5 for those under 65. Registration at the door will be $3 and $6. Call 333-9288 for more information.
 
MUSICAL VARIATIONS
 Tim Prentice, the sculptor, and Robert Andrew Parker, the painter, have a musical side they are exhibiting in a light-hearted show at the Torrington Historical Society Museum through Nov. 21.
For the last 10 years, when not engaged in serious sculptural commissions, Mr. Prentice has been making fanciful musical instruments out of pipe, mailing tubes, 2-by-4's and anything else he might find around the house. For example, his "tenor thump-a-phone," is a sort of xylophone.
Mr. Parker, who moonlights as a drummer at the River Cafe in Gaylordsville, paints pictures that wind up in the collections of the Rockefellers, the Prince of Wales and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But for his own pleasure he has done a series of etchings and paintings of jazz musicians in free-flowing style.
Viewing hours are Monday through Friday from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., Saturday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M. The museum is at 192 Main Street. Call 482-8260 for more information.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 183 words

HEADLINE: Election Talk: Federal Funds, Florio's Future

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
GOV. BILL CLINTON'S victory over President Bush last week, officials and political experts say, could change New Jersey's landscape in the coming months -- literally and politically.
State officials' hopes have been raised by Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to create jobs by rebuilding the nation's aging bridges, roads and sewerage systems. Some officials have speeded up the planning process for their pet projects, preparing to weigh in with financing requests when the bell sounds. 
 New Jersey residents contributed $4 million to the Clinton-Gore campaign, the third highest of any state, and officials expect that Mr. Clinton will be looking to New Jersey for men and women to fill key posts in his administration. Some of these appointments could significantly affect next year's campaign for governor.
In an interview, Gov. Jim Florio said this of Mr. Clinton's election: "It means we'll have rapport with the person in the White House, who understands what we're trying to do in New Jersey with welfare reform, with job training and with making health care more affordable and accessible. It also means we won't have to go to Washington every year to fight for mass transportation assistance. President-elect Clinton understands our needs, and we won't have the annual trauma caused by having an administration in Washington that was trying to dismantle our whole system."
Mr. Florio and Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive who served as chairman of Mr. Clinton's campaign in New Jersey, also said New Jersey should benefit from Mr. Clinton's public-works proposals. "In any fair-minded assessment based on need, New Jersey's aging bridges, antiquated schools and road and rail repair problems would have to be looked at," Mr. Janiszewski said. "Such a program would have to be targeted at older states with elaborate but deteriorating infrastructures." In contrast to Mr. Clinton's conviction that the nation's economic problems required such Federal action, Mr. Janiszewski said, "George Bush incredibly stuck to his position that the country's economic needs and high unemployment could be solved by a capital gains tax cut. When did I.B.M. ever build a bridge?"
Mr. Janiszewski cited a report by the State Education Department last year that it would cost $4 billion to repair or replace antiquated school buildings in the state and bring them up to construction code standards. This, he said, could provide another argument for increased Federal aid.
In addition to the public-works program, Mr. Janiszewski said, Mr. Clinton was prepared to support a $20 billion program for public projects that could be ready to go to construction in 90 days. "In Hudson County we've already invested in the planning and design work for several projects, including an addition to the county mental hospital and the court-orderd construction of a new youth center," he said. "So we'll be ready."
 
'Making Tough Decisions'
 Tuesday's election, Mr. Janiszewski said, benefitted Mr. Florio, not simply because of the Democratic victory but because of Ross Perot's strong showing. Voters seemed to understand the independent candidate's message that solving the nation's economic problems carried with it some pain for the taxpayer, Mr. Janiszewski said, "and that being a government leader means making tough decisions." He said this could help Mr. Florio, whose ratings in the polls have still not fully recovered from the backlash against the $2.8 billion tax program he pushed through the Legislature in 1990.
But Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and a frequent consultant to Republican candidates, called that reading of the election results "a big stretch."
"President Bush ran two or three percentage points better in New Jersey than he did in the rest of the country, and part of that was due to the Republican strategy of linking Clinton with Florio," Mr. Salmore said. "I don't think it bodes well for the Governor's re-election chances. A Florio boost clearly wasn't there."
The Democratic Party is still not the majority party in the state, he added, and most of those who voted for Mr. Perot had been part of the grass-roots anti-Florio tax revolt.
"Republican Congressional candidates were doing much better in their races when the President was attacking the Congress and incumbency was an issue," Mr. Salmore said. "In the last three weeks, however, he didn't talk about Congress in the same way and concentrated his attacks on Clinton." That could have hurt the chances of Republican Congressional candidates in close races, he said. As it turned out, Democrats retained their narrow 7-to-6 majority in the House delegation.
 
Possible Clinton Appointments
 Mr. Clinton's appointments could dramatically alter the dynamics of next year's race for governor, officials say, if he appointed one of New Jersey's two Democratic United States Senators to his Cabinet. Senator Bill Bradley, who campaigned for Mr. Clinton all across the country, has been mentioned as a possible choice for Secretary of State, and Senator Frank R. Lautenberg for Secretary of Transportation.
If either man joins the administration, it would be up to Mr. Florio to appoint a temporary replacement, and a special election would be held next year to elect someone to finish the balance of the term. That candidate's name would appear on the voting machine above the name of the gubernatorial candidate. Assuming that Mr. Florio will be running for re-election, it would behoove him to pick someone who would enhance the Governor's chances.
One name mentioned as a possible Senatorial appointee is Congressman Robert G. Torricelli, who has represented the Ninth Congressional District in Bergen and Hudson Counties since 1982. He won re-election easily on Tuesday. Others include State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak of Elizabeth, the New Jersey State Democratic chairman, and Mr. Janiszewski.
Another theory holds that Mr. Florio would do well to consider appointing a woman to the Senate -- particularly if Christine Todd Whitman, who nearly upset Mr. Bradley last year, wins the Republican nomination for governor. That, some officials suggest, would offset some of Ms. Whitman's appeal to women voters.
 
Speculation on Kean
 The Democratic success last week has also increased speculation about the future of former Republican Gov. Thomas H. Kean, president of Drew University and chairman of the Mr. Bush's campaign in New Jersey. Mr. Kean was one of the state's more popular governors and might easily become the favorite if he ran for the open Senate seat against a Florio appointee.
Mr. Kean and Mr. Clinton became friends while serving together on an education task force of the National Governors Association. Officials speculate that if Mr. Clinton were to offer Mr. Kean a Cabinet post, possibly Secretary of Education, New Jersey Democrats would not be inclined to oppose the move.
For his part, Mr. Florio said that he was aware of the various rumors, but that he would decide what to do if and when a Senate vacancy occurs. He declined to join the speculation.
The Governor added that he agreed with the sentiment offered by President Bush in his concession speech. "The election is over," Mr. Florio said. "Now give us a break from politics and let us govern for a while."

HEADLINE: Passaic Flood Tunnel: A Turning Point

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE moment of truth has arrived for the Passaic River Flood Tunnel. Again.
After more than 16 years, $30 million worth of studies by the Army Corps of Engineers, one false start and unceasing controversy, both supporters and opponents of the engineers' proposed tunnel say the time for decision may be at hand. 
 They point to two key developments. Congress has passed and President Bush has signed a bill that could cut New Jersey's share of the tunnel's $2 billion cost to as little as $90 million from an original estimate of $500 million.
And the forthcoming retirement of several influential New Jersey Congressmen including Representive Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Wayne, a co-sponsor of the bill and the chairman of the House Public Works Committee, is widely viewed as a turning point in the prospects for the tunnel, which is aimed at ending the destructive flooding in the Passaic River Basin.
Mr. Roe, who represents the area where much of the worst flooding occurs, has been the driving force behind the project. Without his support in Congress, and without a clear indication -- so far lacking -- that the state is prepared to pay its share of the tunnel costs, Congressional support for the project could dissipate.
This prospect has produced a flurry of proposed resolutions in the Legislature for and against financing the tunnel. The County Board of Freeholders in Passaic County, where the worst of the flooding occurs, has reneged on its support of the tunnel, while some Essex County officials, who had opposed the project, now enthusiastically support it.
Last weekend, opponents of the project gathered in a park in Kearny, not far from the spot in Newark Bay where the tunnel would discharge flood waters. They heard Richard Isaac, chairman of the Sierra Club's North Jersey Group, a strong critic of the project, call it "the biggest environmental issue in the state." They heard warnings that the tunnel could lower the water tables that provide thousands of residents with their drinking water and could actually increase flooding by causing residential and commercial development in the basin. And they heard State Senator John P. Scott, Republican of Lyndhurst, vow to introduce legislation that would bar the project even if it were paid for in full by the Federal Government.
Meanwhile, along the banks of the Passaic River and its tributaries, where rowboats in driveways are almost as common as cars, residents tried to sort out the issues -- including a proposal, offered by tunnel opponents, to have the Federal and state governments buy out and relocate homeowners in the flood plain.
Since the turn of the century, there have been 11 major floods in the basin, which have led to 26 deaths. In the last two decades, portions of the basin have been declared Federal disaster areas seven times. In 1984 alone, three people died and scores were injured when the Passaic River breached its banks. More than 9,400 residents were evacuated, and property damage topped $330 million.
"The Passaic River basin flood problem is listed as one of the two most severe flood problems in the country," Mr. Roe said. "The only solution that will give us the protection that is desparately needed is the flood tunnel."
The centerpiece of the corps' plan consists of two underground tunnels -- a main tunnel, 20 miles long and 40 feet in diameter, and a 1.2-mile spur tunnel, about 22 feet in diameter, that connects with the main tunnel. The two tunnel inlets, about six miles apart, are both in Wayne. Water would enter the tunnels through these two gated concrete inlets that would be opened only during a flood. The main tunnel runs underground, at depths of 125 to 450 feet, to an outlet in Newark Bay.
Also planned are 17.6 miles of levees and 6.2 miles of flood walls along the river.
The Army is ready to start with the design stage of the tunnel, said Raymond Boc, deputy chief of the engineers' Passaic River Division, but it faces a major roadblock. "Right now," he said, "the State of New Jersey has made no financial obligations to the project."
Gov. Jim Florio, who has not taken a position on the tunnel, sent the tunnel proposal to the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy for its recommendations in 1990. The department says it is still studying the proposal. If Mr. Florio ultimately decides to approve the project, the money would have to be appropriated by the Legislature.
Though estimates of the state's share of the project have run as high as $500 million, the Water Resources Development Act of 1992 signed by the President last weekend would permit New Jersey to use money it has already spent on wetland and watershed land acquisition as a credit toward its share of the tunnel's costs.
The most the state would have to come up with under the new law, Mr. Roe said, is $113 million. And depending upon how certain credits are treated, the state's contribution could be as low as $90 million.
 
Battle in Legislature
 In the Legislature, the tunnel action, for and against, has been heating up. Last month, for example, Assemblyman Gerald H. Zecker, Republican of Clifton, introduced a resolution that would urge the Legislature to commit the money necessary for the project. Before that measure was addressed, another resolution, introduced by Assemblyman John V. Kelly, Republican of Nutley, urged the Legislature to withhold the funds. Neither resolution has reached the floor.
The rally last weekend was sponsored by the Passaic River Coalition, a nonprofit environmental organization based in Basking Ridge that has been fighting the project since it was first proposed in 1988.
Ella Fillipone, the coalition's executive director, said in an interview that the Army engineers' estimates of both the total cost of the tunnel and the state's projected share are too low.
"We come up with $4 billion," Ms. Fillipone said, adding that her estimate was based on what it cost the corps to construct a tunnel under Manhattan -- $100 million per mile. The Army has also underestimated what it will cost to purchase land and easements it will need to build the tunnel, she said, "by at least 50 percent." If her estimates are correct, she said, the state would have to come up with millions of extra dollars beyond the land acquisition credits it would receive under the Water Resources Act. Mr. Boc said he stood by the corps' estimate of $2 billion.
Mr. Isaac of the Sierra Club said the tunnel represented a misguided attempt to change the environment to accommodate development rather than planning development to fit the environment. The tunnel, he said, would lead to increased development in the area, which in turn could negate any benefits the tunnel might offer.
 
Backing a Buy-Out Plan
 "The more you build, the more you accentuate the problem," he said. "You're end up increasing the flooding when there is less grass, fewer trees and more asphalt."
A more economical and environmentally sound approach, he said, would be to buy out and relocate residential property owners who live in the flood plain. "If you insist on building where it floods every year, and you really want to live there, then build a house on stilts or build a house that floats," Mr. Isaac said. "But if you don't like living where it floods, then we will help you move."
Ms. Fillipone said such a plan would cost much less than building a tunnel.
"Let's take the people with the highest risk and relocate them," she said. "It's a one-time cost, and it comes out to $150 million." She said that 774 homes would have to be bought out.
The Army, however, rejected the buyout idea as being too expensive. To buy all the properties that would be affected by a "10-year flood" -- a flood of a magnitude that occurs once in a decade -- would involve as many as 8,000 structures and cost about $2.8 billion, Mr. Boc said.
"When you talk about buying out 8,000 homes and businesses, you're talking about relocating a population," he said. And that would not provide protection against floods of greater magnitude. The tunnel is designed to protect against a 100-year flood.
 
Division Among Residents
 Ms. Fillipone includes only residential structures that are not flood-proofed in her estimates, while the Army estimates also include commercial buildings.
Some residents of the basin, likeJimmy Sulejman, who lives with his wife and child on a street in Wayne that frequently floods, favor a buyout -- "as long as I can get what I paid for it," he said.
But many say they prefer the tunnel.
"The buyout plan is absurd," said Jim Wright, who lives in Lincoln Park, about 500 feet from the Passaic River. "How can you take a town and then just level 'X' number of homes and expect the rest of the town not to be affected?" Mr. Wright said, referring to the effect on the tax base that a large buyout would have.
Elected officials have had decidedly mixed reactions to the project.
In 1988, the corps proposed a shorter tunnel that would have ended in the Passaic River near Clifton. It won the approval of then-Gov. Thomas H. Kean, but it was scrapped following protests from area residents and officials who feared that the tunnel's discharge would create new flooding along the southern banks of the Passaic River.
 
Changes in Support
 In 1990 the corps offered the current plan, winning the support of Newark Mayor Sharpe James, who had opposed the initial proposal.
Meanwhile, the Passaic County Board of Freeholders, which had favored the plan, has recently withdrawn its support, citing water supply concerns raised by some environmentalists.
These critics fear that construction of the flood tunnel could have far-reaching effects on the state's water supply.
Mr. Isaac, for example, expressed concern that the tunnel would be so effective in keeping the Passaic River Basin flood-proofed that it would lower the water tables in the natural aquifer there and reduce the available drinking water.
Mr. Boc, however, said such worries were unfounded. "The intent of the project is to only skim those flows that exceed a 'one-year' flood event and to keep the river in its banks," he said.
As for the charges by some opponents that there would be flooding in the areas adjacent to Newark Bay where the tunnel will discharge, he said: "The water exiting the tunnel is a relatively small volume compared to the carrying capacity of Newark Bay. There will be very little effect. Less than three inches at low tide."
 
 
 
Building a Flood Tunnel

 
 Using laser beams, dynamite and a $15 million drill, the Army Corps of Engineers is prepared to dig a 20-mile tunnel beneath the heart of the most densely populated area of New Jersey.
"We'll be taking out about 10 million cubic yards of material," said Raymond Boc, deputy chief of the corps' Passaic River Division.
The Passaic River Flood Tunnel -- comparable in scope only to the "Chunnel" being constructed beneath the English Channel -- is expected to take about 2,000 laborers 10 years to complete. Mr. Boc described the process.
After digging and blasting a 450-foot-deep work shaft at a point in Kearny near where the tunnel would end, workers would lower a $15 million tunnel boring machine -- known as a mole in the tunnel trade -- piece by piece into the shaft. The machine would be assembled in a work space cut out at the bottom of the shaft.
From there, using a laser beam to keep it moving straight ahead, the mole would chew its way toward Wayne through layers of bedrock 200 million years old, leaving tons of granulated earth -- called muck -- in its wake. Railroad cars and conveyor belts would take the granulate back to the work shaft, where workers would raise it to the surface.
After the mole bored its 40-foot-diameter hole, workers would line the tunnel with concrete.
Except for activity at four other work shafts to be drilled at isolated locations along the tunnel route, work would be virtually unnoticeable on the surface, Mr. Boc said. The tunnel would reach depths of as much as 450 feet on its journey to Newark Bay.
At Newark Bay, workers would construct a cylindrical structure -- a cofferdam -- from the water's surface down to the floor of the bay. They would then excavate down through the floor of the bay, using dynamite and conventional digging machines.
"If your surveying is good," Mr. Boc said, "you meet the tunnel down there."

HEADLINE: Something to Celebrate At Fairleigh Dickinson

BYLINE: By PATRICIA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
TWO years ago few would have predicted that Fairleigh Dickinson University's 50th anniversary this year would have been anything to celebrate. The university was awash in debt, enrollment had fallen more than 40 percent from its high in 1980, the faculty and administration were at odds and morale at the school was low. But on Sept. 30, as a colorful academic procession of more than 300 slowly wended its way down the commencement green on the university's Teaneck campus to honor the installation of a new president and the official start of the golden anniversary, the institution's future seemed as bright and brisk as the day itself. The two years have brought profound change, in terms of financial stability and a renewed sense of vigor, to Fairleigh Dickinson -- the state's largest private university, with campuses in Rutherford, Teaneck-Hackensack and Madison-Florham Park. The feeling on campus and within New Jersey's higher education community is that the school has made a remarkable comeback.
"The university uses the term 'cautious optimism,' but we're probably even more optimistic," said Elizabeth Cayer, assistant director of the New Jersey Department of Higher Education's Office of Senior Institutions. "While we're cautious, we're saying, 'Heavens, it looks terrific.' " 
 This is not the first time the university's turnaround has been trumpeted. In the late 1980's, after a restructuring effort and a brief upturn in freshman enrollment, university officials were talking about a rebound. But continuing low faculty morale and an inability to control the school's mounting debt soon dashed any hope of real recovery.
The latest plan to revitalize the university appears to be having greater success. By consolidating programs, reducing expenditures and offering new programs that are bringing in additional revenue, Fairleigh Dickinson expects to have a balanced budget this year, its first in a decade. Enrollment is stabilizing, admissions standards have risen and school spirit is on the rise, as activities like faculty-student volley ball games, homecoming and pep rallies have taken on a new life. And, perhaps most significantly, the faculty is backing the reforms.
Dr. Francis J. Mertz, the university's president, said part of the university's problem has been that, as a comparatively young institution, founded in 1942, it could not count on history to see it through tough times when the twin forces of a declining college-aged population and emergence of a strong public college system began to rattle New Jersey independent colleges in the 1980's.
"We did not have a solid reputation, and our infrastructure was not solidly in place, so the first frost hurt us more than established institutions," said Dr. Mertz, who was named interim president in 1990 and was installed as the university's fifth president at the anniversary ceremony in September. "While we suffered ahead of the cycle, maybe now our road to recovery will be ahead of the cycle."
Another blow came when the state announced in 1989 that it was withdrawing its support from the university's dental school following a national decline in dental school enrollments. The lost aid compounded the university's already dire fiscal and morale problems. The dental school, was closed in 1990.
 
Loss in Students
 While many of New Jersey's 16 independent colleges and universities have experienced population declines, none has fallen as precipitously as Fairleigh Dickinson. Enrollment, which had held steady at around 20,000 students throughout the 70's, is now just 11,552 students, its lowest level since 1958.
When enrollment began to fall in the 80's admission standards were loosened in an unsuccessful effort to fill empty classrooms. By the middle of the decade, the university found itself saddled with mounting fiscal troubles and a physical plant that was too large for its needs, and by 1990 the university's operating deficit had reached $6.5 million and the cumulative deficit was $32 million.
The trustees gave Dr. Mertz two years to restore the university to fiscal stability. One of his first acts as president was to appoint a commission of all the university's constituencies to take a broad look at the institution to see how it could be salvaged. In one recommendation that is credited with giving the university much of its renewed sense of purpose, each of the university's three campuses, which had been a hodgepodge of classes and degree programs, was to develop of specific mission. The Rutherford campus now focuses on undergraduate and graduate business programs. At Teaneck, there are associate to doctoral degree programs in areas other than business. The Madison campus has extensive honors courses in every discipline.
The commission also recommended tightening admissions standards. Through increased recruiting efforts and what admissions officers call a "shift in perception" about the school's academic offerings, the university was able to maintain freshman enrollment this year while being more selective. S.A.T. scores for this year's 938 freshmen jumped 50 points over last year. Their average score of 950 for this year's 938 freshmen was also 59 points higher than the New Jersey average. The class includes 52 students who were in the top 15 percent of their high school classes.
 
A New Breed of Student
 Students themselves are aware of the new breed of student. "The freshmen are different," said Seth Weisleder, president of the student body on the Teaneck campus and a dormitory resident assistant. "They want to have fun, but they're also academics. They keep asking me to keep the noise down in the hallways, because they have to study. That's amazing, coming from a freshman."
Buildings and services have been upgraded to lure and retain students. On the Teaneck campus once-dingy dormitories have been renovated, and $160,000 was spent transforming a drab campus snack bar into a new student hangout.
Curriculum offerings have been more finely honed with an eye to what the job market needs. Several degree programs with low enrollments have been eliminated, and others, particularly in business, have been added. The university is also actively seeking accreditation from the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, a prestigious honor for business education that only Rutgers and Seton Hall have achieved in New Jersey.
Outside of class there is more interest in student activities.
"F.D.U. has had a problem for a long time with generating student involvement, largely because the apathy of upper classmen was quickly picked up," said Michelle Rochester, editor of the Madison campus' student newspaper. "But recently we've seen a lot more involvement from a lot more students."
 
A Time of Tension
 For years strained relations between the faculty and administration had added to the problems at Fairleigh Dickinson. A five-day faculty walkout at the start of the 1986-87 term over salary issues and the subsequent elimination of the faculty union as a bargaining agent were only the most visible signs of a tension that paralyzed many of the university's efforts to pull itself together.
While the university still lags behind others of its kind in what it pays teachers, it is trying to narrow the gap. Faculty received a 4 percent salary increase this year.
"That isn't tremendous, but given the economy and the state of things, it was a real commitment that necessitated our making other sacrifices," said Dr. Geoffrey Weinman, vice president for academic affairs.
The salary differential between Fairleigh Dickinson and other universities is largest on the upper end of the pay scale. A full professor at Fairleigh Dickinson last year made on average $49,800, nearly $8,000 less than professors at comparable institutions in the Mid-Atlantic region, according to statistics provided by Dr. Weinman.
Dr. Thomas Beam, president of the faculty senate and a professor of accounting, said the faculty were generally upbeat "in anticipation of better things to come."
"Morale is certainly improving," he said. "Frank Mertz listens better than anyone else I've ever seen. Sometimes the response is we can't do anything yet, but at least he responds."
 
80% From New Jersey
 Because more than 80 percent of the university's students come from New Jersey, it is often referred to as the most public of the state's independent institutions of higher learning. Two-thirds of its students attend school part time, an unusually high percentage for an independent college. Dr. Mertz said because of its distinctive demographics and its size, he has never really questioned the university's long-term viability.
"We were big enough so if we had to get smaller, then we could do it with small surgery as distinct from a hatchet," he said. "Pruning rather than cutting down a tree."
For nearly a decade before joining Fairleigh Dickinson, Dr. Mertz, 55 years old, held the dual presidencies of the Independent College Fund of New Jersey and the Association of Independent Colleges and Universities in New Jersey. He said his worst moment as head of Fairleigh Dickinson came on Father's Day, six weeks into the job, when a newspaper ran an article about the possible closing of a campus to solve some of the university's fiscal problems, and he was besieged by telephone calls from alumni, students and faculty members.
"I started reading Truman, I started reading Churchill to get comfort," he said. "It was my darkest day, because I worried what others would say. But it also was a turning point, because the most difficult of options was now out there."
Dr. Mertz said closing a campus was no longer under consideration.
 
'The Pipeline Is Full'
 Edward Hennessy, chairman of the university's trustees for the last eight years and a former chairman of Allied Signal Inc., has mixed reviews for the pace of change at his alma mater.
"Being a businessman, you can make decisions a heck of a lot faster than in academia," said Mr. Hennessey, a 1955 graduate. "But if you look over the past few years, we've accomplished a lot. The pipeline is full, it's pulling together, and in another four years, we'll really have a first-class institution."
Mr. Hennessey credits much of the university's recent progress to Dr. Mertz's ability to bring together different factions of the university to focus on a common goal. While students and faculty members praise Dr. Mertz's accessibility, the president himself frets about the lack of opportunity to develop close personal relationships on a three-campus university.
"I'll never be a Mr. Chips," he said.

HEADLINE: Luckinbill, Portrayer of Giants, Takes One to the Courthouse

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
Laurence Luckinbill strode into the Westchester County Courthouse here, an artist for sure among the briefcases and the suits. His thinning mop of brown hair stuffed into a blue baseball cap, and wearing a beaten-up leather jacket and jeans, he grinned and apologized for being late.
Not the usual place for an interview, but fitting: the 57-year-old actor will play this house on Nov. 16 when he holds forth in the Ceremonial Courtroom as Clarence Darrow, the famed lawyer who is the only character in the play "Clarence Darrow" by David Rintels. The play will be performed here once only at 7:30 P.M. as a benefit for the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts. 
 There is nothing show biz about the craggy-faced actor, who is best known for his work in such plays as "The Boys in the Band" (he also appeared in the 1970 film version), "The Memory Bank" -- for which he won the New York Critics Circle Award -- and such films as "Star Trek V: The Final Frontier."
He drove to the courthouse from the northern Westchester residence that he shares with his wife, the actress Lucie Arnaz, and the couple's three children, ages 12, 10 and 8. They have lived in Westchester since 1983, are "gentleman and lady farmers" who eat "$300 salads" from a garden that cost $3,000 to put in shape, Mr. Luckinbill said, and lead hectic double lives as devoted suburban parents and busy actors. (Ms. Arnaz, the daughter of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, is currently creating the role on Broadway of Bella in Neil Simon's "Lost in Yonkers.")
He smiled, telling of the family's earthy country life, and offered the views of each child on Presidential politics. They have learned about the politics of theater and the theater of politics from their father, who is passionate about both subjects. "Politics is the only four-letter word with eight letters," said Mr. Luckinbill, who has been steeped enough in political affairs to know.
During the Kennedy Administration, he worked for the State Department in Italy and Africa as a director, writer and lecturer on theater. He also passed the Foreign Service examination and was offered a job with the United States Information Agency but ended his work in Government service when President Kennedy was assassinated.
"I didn't want to be part of a Johnson Administration," Mr. Luckinbill said. Years later, fate brought the actor and Lyndon Johnson together in spirit, when Mr. Luckinbill played the title role in "Lyndon," a one-character play by James Prideaux produced in 1987 as a PBS special.
The actor still tours with the play and notes the irony of portraying Johnson. "His fate is in my hands," he said, amused by the idea, but Johnson has earned his respect. "Lyndon himself is a great intellectual on the model of Sam Adams or Paul Bunyan," Mr. Luckinbill said. "He is a figure large on the landscape. But he didn't read books, he read bills."
Clarence Darrow, best known for defending a Tennessee high school science teacher, John T. Scopes, for teaching the theory of evolution, focuses the actor's attention on a different kind of brilliance. "He was a great man, with a passion for mercy," Mr. Luckinbill said of Darrow, who also defended the infamous murder team of Leopold and Loeb. "He believed mercy was the greatest human attribute. He centered himself in the logic of compassion."
Darrow, a fervent opponent of capital punishment and abortion, defended a total of 102 men on death row, none of whom was executed. "He said, 'Open the prisons, rehabilitate people, recognize that when you have unemployment, drugs and ghettos, you're going to have young men committing crimes,' " Mr. Luckinbill said. " 'It isn't fair to lock them up.' "
 
'You Don't Survive Without Laughing'
 Other moments dramatize the lawyer's fight for the eight-hour working day, a decent standard of living, his interest in peaceful integration and the right of citizens to criticize their government. Humor studs both "Lyndon" and "Clarence Darrow," which is one reason Mr. Luckinbill likes the plays so much.
"Everything I do has a lot of comedy involved," he said. "You don't survive in life without laughing." The Arkansas native recounted how he decided to major in drama after seeing his hopes of becoming a doctor dashed. He had finished three years as a premedical student at the University of Arkansas when he got a D-minus in organic chemistry; for the young man, this was as good as failing.
"The man who flunked me, a Dr. Royce, was a chemist who had been on the Nuremberg Trials Committee," Mr. Luckinbill said. "I told him, 'You're wrecking my life.' "
"I had been the class clown," the actor continued, and Dr. Royce said, " 'Mr. Luckinbill, you have amused us all year -- and well. You don't belong in medicine. You belong somewhere in the performing arts.' "
A battery of aptitude tests confirmed the chemist's insight, and after graduating as a drama major, Mr. Luckinbill went on to receive his master's degree in playwriting from the Catholic University of America in Washington. Writing still occupies much of his time; he is working on a musical play called "Desi!" based on the life of his father-in-law and intends to write a pilot for a series dramatizing American history.
 
Second Marriage for Both
 All of his and his wife's projects -- including a nearly completed program based on the home movies of Miss Ball and Mr. Arnaz -- are properties of the couple's company, Arluck Entertainment. Mr. Luckinbill met Ms. Arnaz when they were performing in two other plays on Broadway by Mr. Simon, he in "Chapter Two" and she in "They're Playing Our Song." "It was 'Chapter Two' of my own life," he said, recalling that their present marriage is a second one for them both, and yes, it was nearly love at first sight when a fellow actor introduced them at Joe Allen's Restaurant on West 46th Street in Manhattan.
He, possibly alone among all people "in the hemisphere," he said, had never seen an episode of "I Love Lucy" and had "no knowledge of or interest in her parents." Despite or because of this, the couple were married nine months later, in June 1980. They have since toured together as co-stars in such plays as "Who's Life Is It, Anyway?" "Educating Rita" and "I Do, I Do."
Life as a family man and the portrayer of social giants seems to have invigorated the actor. He even sounds ready to take on the undying, periodically revived campaign for a Westchester performing arts complex. What is needed, Mr. Luckinbill said, is a county-financed structure with five or six theaters in a central location. And, he said, "It should not be tangled up with the politics of an educational institution."
He said he and his wife had come to live in Westchester because "I found the brightest, most motivated and deeply talented people in the world here. But," he added, "I don't see any place in the county where they can express that close to home. New York City is like a black hole, drawing everything toward it."
 
A Backer of Arts Center
 He said he and Ms. Arnaz would love to run such a theater complex, and -- arts activists, take notice -- he would be willing to "lead a fight" to build one in the county.
In the meantime, he has thrown his support to the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts, a 14-year-old, nonprofit organization in Goldens Bridge with activities and classes in all the arts as well as programs in schools, summer camps and community centers.
Bira Rabushka, the organization's founder and director, said that Mr. Luckinbill had offered to waive his fee and perform "Clarence Darrow" as a fund-raising event and that the courthouse had seemed the ideal place to stage it. County administrators agreed to make the 285-seat Ceremonial Courtroom available, Ms. Rabushka added.
The evening, which features a dessert reception at which the audience can meet Mr. Luckinbill in the Mural Room, adjacent to the Ceremonial Courtroom, is co-sponsored by the Westchester Women's Bar Association, the Columbian Lawyer's Association of Westchester County, the Benjamin Cordozo Society and the Pace University School of Law. There are two ticket categories: $100 a person for patrons and $250 for sponsors. Sponsors are offered priority seating and their names will appear in the program. For reservations or more information, the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts can be reached at 232-5740.
