PUB-DATE: November 8, 1992

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2707 words

HEADLINE: Can He Get This Thing to Run?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
On President-elect Bill Clinton's desk in the governor's mansion in Little Rock, Ark., are four thick briefing books. They run to hundreds of pages and lay out the pros and cons of the numerous decisions he must make. Probably nothing is more pressing in these pages than an issue not really dealt with in the campaign: Whether to attempt emergency measures to revive the economy and how to do so.
By all accounts, the new President has not decided whether to act precipitously. But if he does, the main tool widely favored within the Clinton camp is an investment tax credit for business -- reminiscent of what John F. Kennedy proposed when he took office in 1961, during a recession. The credit would return to businesses 10 percent of their investment in machinery beyond a certain level. The only other big measure under consideration to lift the economy quickly, the advisers say, is swift enactment of $20 billion in new spending next year on public-works projects. 
 Mr. Clinton has for months listed these two measures as part of his plan to rebuild the economy over the long run, but now his top advisers are pushing them forward as the new Administration's short-term weapons for ending an economic slowdown that has persisted through most of the Bush years.
If Congress quickly enacts the two measures, they undoubtedly would help the economy, many economists say. But they alone would probably not be enough to end the stagnation, the economists add. Investment tax credits, introduced by President Kennedy and used by most Republican and Democratic administrations ever since, failed to make a noticeable difference during the 1981-82 recession, and before that they were imposed only after the economy had begun to recover.
Furthermore, other factors enter into a company's spending plans. "The credit crunch, the general uncertainty, the low level of consumer confidence, these are all problems that could hold back the economy and discourage investment despite a tax credit," said Alan Auerbach, a University of Pennsylvania economist.
 
Betting in Billions
 As for the $20 billion in proposed new public works spending, it is a drop in the bucket for an economy that generates nearly $6 trillion a year in new wealth. A growing number of economists argue that at least $50 billion a year is needed to move the American economy, all of it through deficit spending so that other wealth is not canceled or diverted to pay for the public works.
"If the economy is as weak in January as it seems to be today, then $20 billion or $30 billion won't be enough," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel Laureate in Economics and a leader of the group lobbying Mr. Clinton for at least $50 billion in public works spending.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton's "Putting People First" platform promised economic growth and job creation, but only over the long term and on a pay-as-you-go basis. Now the debate within the Clinton camp is whether the economy needs a quick fix, even one that might have to be paid for later. If Mr. Clinton decides it does and gambles, failure could be damaging. "I think Clinton is on the hook to deliver some help for the economy fast," said Robert Giordano, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But if he acts and then fails to deliver enough stimulus, the public will not view that as very credible."
Mr. Clinton's decision must be made at an awkward moment in the economic cycle. Every so often, during the nearly four years of stagnation and recession, the national statistics measuring economic performance have turned up for a few months, briefly holding out hope that America was finally regaining its vigor. One such period came last spring, only to evaporate by late July. Another showed itself last month.
"The last thing anyone wants to do is stimulate an economy when the stimulus is no longer needed," said Bruce Reed, issues director in the Clinton camp. "But no one knows whether this incipient recovery is for real."
 
Investment Tax Credit
 Whatever the future holds, the investment tax credit is clearly emerging as the favorite revival tool among Mr. Clinton's advisers. That is partly because it enjoys wide support among American executives. And it is partly because Mr. Clinton's aides have found a way to argue, perhaps incorrectly, that the tax credit would pay for itself, thus not violating Mr. Clinton's pledge to keep the deficit from rising while he rebuilds the economy. "We are not going to have spending now and deficit reduction later," Mr. Reed said.
Gene Sperling, economic coordinator in the Clinton campaign, heartily endorsed Mr. Reed's comment. But he seemed to suggest that a temporarily larger deficit might be considered when he said that Mr. Clinton "has always stressed as a priority the $20 billion-a-year Rebuild America infrastructure program and the targeted investment tax credit."
Mr. Reed and Mr. Sperling have begun to circulate a study, commissioned over the summer by Mr. Clinton, that comes to optimistic conclusions: The Clinton investment tax credit would cost the Treasury $11 billion in the first two years. But growing tax revenues from an expanding economy would recover this amount. And the stimulus would create 500,000 jobs next year.
The study, done by Lawrence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis research and consulting firm, was delivered by Mr. Meyer to Mr. Clinton on Oct. 11. But it is only now being made public by Mr. Clinton's aides. They cite the study in support of their argument that the Clinton investment tax credit would not raise the deficit.
An investment tax credit, in one form or another, was a fixture of every Administration from Mr. Kennedy's days until 1986, when it was eliminated by Congress and the Reagan Administration in favor of a lower corporate income tax. American companies have in the past purchased more machinery and equipment when tax credits existed. But never has a tax credit been shown to stimulate enough investment to revive an economy mired in hard times.
 
The Clinton Plan
 Mr. Clinton's tax credit, never tried, would reimburse a company for 10 percent of its outlays for machinery and equipment -- but would apply only to investments that exceeded some percentage, yet to be determined, of the outlay in a previous year, also to be determined.
The goal is to get companies to keep raising their capital spending. The rising demand for new machinery, in turn, would create jobs among machinery manufacturers. The new workers, spending their wages, would stimulate demand for and production of consumer goods. More new hiring would take place and the economic revival would be under way.
That is the theory. Mr. Clinton takes his approach, known as a marginal tax credit, from the late Walter Heller, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Kennedy. Mr. Heller had wanted Mr. Kennedy to adopt a tax credit that rewarded businesses for increasing capital outlays each year. But the credit finally passed by Congress in 1962 gave a straight 7 percent tax credit on all capital outlays.
"There were two reasons for rejecting the marginal tax credit, and they might come up now in the debate over Mr. Clinton's proposal," said the University of Pennsylvania's Mr. Auerbach. One was complexity -- which investments qualify for the credit and which don't. The other is fairness. In a declining industry, like autos, a company might invest every year, but not at increasing rates. In a growing industry, like biotechnology, a company would be more likely to benefit from a marginal tax credit.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said his group would welcome a 10 percent investment tax credit, but on all investment, not only the increased amount over a previous year. "The neat thing about an investment tax credit is that it stimulates the economy while the machinery purchased improves productivity," Mr. Jasinowski said. "But any immediate increase in the deficit should be in the context of a package that reduces the deficit in later years."
Many studies show that investment tax credits do stimulate capital spending. But whether they are powerful enough to lift an entire economy has never been proven conclusively. The Kennedy credit took effect in 1962 when a recovery was already under way. It was repealed in 1969, during the Nixon Administration, because the economy appeared to be growing too rapidly, and re-established in 1971, again when a brief recession was already ending.
The recession that began in 1974 prompted President Gerald Ford and Congress to raise the credit to 10 percent from 7 percent, but the new rate took effect in 1975, when the recession was ending. The 10 percent credit was still in effect during the 1981-82 recession and made little if any difference during the subsequent recovery. After the credit was ended in 1986, attempts during the Bush Administration to revive a version of it were included in bills Mr. Bush vetoed because they included tax increases.
Whatever the shortcomings of an investment tax credit, Mr. Meyer, president of the St. Louis firm commissioned by Mr. Clinton to evaluate his version, is bullish. He based his calculations on a tax credit that would apply to investments in machinery and equipment that exceeded 80 percent of a company's outlay in fiscal 1992, which ended Sept. 30.
The Treasury would lose $3.1 billion in the current fiscal year and $8.1 billion in fiscal 1994, his report said. But, urging that Mr. Clinton act quickly, even making the tax credit retroactive to Election Day, Mr. Meyer concluded: "Because of the powerful stimulus to aggregate demand and hence income and employment, the deficit would actually decline by $1 billion in fiscal 1993 and would be unchanged in 1994."
If private investment falls short of Mr. Meyer's optimism, then public investment, primarily for public works, might give the economy a lift. But it would have to be sufficiently large and involve deficit spending to have an impact, in the view of most economists. The stimulus from public spending in a weak economy is thought to be lost if it is immediately offset by spending cuts that eliminate jobs in other areas or tax increases that remove money from households.
What is required to keep the deficit from getting out of hand are "sunset provisions" that would end the spending once the economy begins to recover and also raise new revenue to pay off the debt, said Mr. Giordano of Goldman, Sachs.
Mr. Clinton's public-works plan so far does not meet two standards set by the economists: its size and its financing through deficit spending. His proposed $20 billion annual outlay -- instead of the $50 billion proposed by Mr. Solow -- is geared to creating jobs over the four years of his Administration, not immediately, and always on a pay-as-you-go basis, with much of the new revenue coming from a tax increase for the wealthy and for foreign corporations in the United States.
What's more, there is great uncertainty among economists concerning which public investments give the best payoff. Should Federal spending be channeled to highways, to construction of inter-city bullet trains or to an overhaul of the nation's rail system? Everyone knows that shirt makers need a way to get their goods to market. But is a highway more efficient than a better rail system?
But the Clinton camp has overcome one major obstacle. In the past, the great objection to public works spending as an economic stimulus has been the time it takes to plan a project, put out bids, sign contracts, hire workers and get started.
 
The Mayors' List
 The United States Conference of Mayors provided the solution last winter. Its survey of 506 cities produced 7,252 projects all planned, contracted and ready to go, but shelved for lack of municipal funds to pay for them. Their total cost would be $26 billion over several years.
"But realistically, you could spend $12 billion to get them started and generate 418,000 jobs in a single year," said J. Thomas Cochran, executive director of the mayors' group. The list includes projects like a $3.5 million bridge-repair program for Manhattan, employing 200 people.
With the mayors' list in mind, two Democratic Senators, Paul D. Sarbanes of Maryland and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, introduced this year a bill that would have granted $20 billion in Federal funds to help pay for the projects. But the bill failed to include a means of repayment, and under the 1990 budget enforcement act, intended to reduce the deficit, there was no spare money available.
Only if Congress and President Bush had declared an emergency could $20 billion have been appropriated, through deficit spending, without violating the budget act. Neither was willing to do this, so the bill died.
Mr. Clinton faces the same ceilings during the current budget year, which ends next Oct. 1. And that is prompting some of his supporters to suggest that the new President amend or scrap the enforcement act. "I see no reason to be wedded to the budget deal," said Lawrence Mishel, chief economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group that backed Mr. Clinton.
If the hard times persist, then Mr. Clinton's emergency measures, even if they are financed with deficit spending, might become more acceptable to the public, particularly on Wall Street. When the deficit rises or seems about to do so, bond traders in particular become fearful of inflation and drive up interest rates.
Higher interest rates spreading to mortgages, car loans and corporate borrowing to buy new equipment, would make a weak economy even weaker. But in the face of persistent stagnation, a growing number of Wall Street economists and traders have said in recent weeks that modest deficit spending to revive the economy could now take place without the reaction of higher interest rates.
Henry Kaufman, the consultant and money manager who for years personified the bond market as chief economist at Salomon Brothers, put it this way: "A fiscal stimulus of $20 billion to $30 billion over the next 12 months, financed through deficit spending, is something that is now acceptable to the market."
 
 
 
WHAT HOPE FOR A HAPPIER CONSUMER?
 BILL CLINTON is taking over at a delicate moment for the American economy. Since early 1989, the gross domestic product, measuring all the wealth created in the nation, has barely grown, and for nine months starting in July 1990, the nation was in recession, with the G.D.P. actually shrinking. Hundreds of thousands of people have lost their jobs as companies cut back to adjust to the hard times and the huge weapons industry shrinks in the aftermath of the cold war.
Through much of the campaign, Mr. Clinton's aides expressed the hope that while the weak economy would defeat President Bush, a post-election upturn would ease public pressure on the new Administration for emergency action. And some recent indicators, such as a spurt in the G.D.P. in the third quarter and a rise in housing starts and in industrial production, encourage this hope.
One major item that has not turned up in recent months is consumer confidence, a key measure of whether Americans feel secure enough to raise spending. Mr. Clinton's advisers argued before the election that a Clinton victory would revive consumer confidence. "A new President with a long-term economic agenda should have a very positive stimulative effect on the economy," said Gene Sperling, economic coordinator in the Clinton campaign, in late October.
But Fabian Linden, who directs the monthly survey of consumer sentiment published by the Conference Board, a business research organization, disagrees. He argues that politics is too far removed from daily life to affect consumer attitudes.
"You go back to Ronald Reagan replacing Jimmy Carter, and there was no improvement in consumer confidence in the first four or five months," Mr. Linden said. "Ordinary citizens respond to their everyday lives in the economy and not to a new President. We have tracked this through five Presidential elections, the last five, and there was no discernible immediate improvement in consumer spirits."

HEADLINE: All About/Heating Systems;
The Cost and Cleanliness Equation

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

 BODY:
SQUIRRELS gathering nuts and birds winging their way south may be strong indications that winter is approaching, but rising heating bills are an even surer sign in most parts of the country.
Overall, growth in the residential heating system-supply market has slowed along with the hard-hit construction market. But while sales of oil and electric furnaces have fallen in the last three years, sales of gas furnaces are edging back up. 
 Furnaces that burn natural gas to produce hot air are far and away the nation's largest source of residential heating. Industry experts say that the current sales rebound is partly because natural gas utilities have become more aggressive in extending their pipelines -- and marketing muscle -- into the Northeast, where oil heat still predominates.
In any case, 2.1 million gas furnaces are expected to be shipped nationally this year, up from 2.06 million last year and 1.95 million in 1990, said Johnny Johnson, director of residential heating products at the Carrier Corporation's Indianapolis office. Carrier, a unit of United Technologies of Hartford, is one of the nation's largest sellers of heating and air-conditioning systems.
This year, new sales of all furnaces have been aided a bit by a new Federal law that requires builders to install more fuel-efficient furnaces in new homes and apartments.
"The heating industry is moving in the direction of making products as small as we can make them and more efficient to lower monthly operating costs," Mr. Johnson said. "Most importantly we're trying to make products more environmentally correct."
 
Aging Systems
Choosing a Fuel And Delivery Mode
 Home heating systems start with a fuel source, usually gas, electric or oil. The fuel then heats either a hot-air furnace, or a hot-water boiler. Depending on the system, hot air flows through ducts, or hot water or steam flows through pipes and radiators.
Electric baseboard heating systems, with no furnace or boiler, work more like a toaster oven, by heating coils embedded along the bottoms of walls.
Despite the poor economy, companies like Carrier; York International, in York, Pa., and the Burnham Corporation, in Lancaster, Pa., have not suffered as much as they might have, heating experts say. All are among the biggest sellers of furnaces or boilers.
Sales have been helped by homeowners and landlords replacing aging heating systems with more energy-efficient ones. Also, many consumers, staying put during the recession, have been upgrading their systems as part of upgrading their homes.
For some affluent people who are building new homes, the heating system of choice is hydronic radiant floor heating, in which hot water is circulated through a maze of polyethylene pipes beneath floors.
Because of the work involved in snaking coils of flexible pipe throughout a house, a radiant system is very expensive to install. But it is inexpensive to run, because it operates at much lower water temperatures than other systems.
Only about 7 percent of new homes in the United States have the system, but the market for radiant heat has grown nearly 30 percent yearly over the last six years.
Hot-air systems and electric baseboard heating are the cheapest for builders to install, and so continue to be standard in many new homes and condominiums. But monthly fuel charges and maintenance costs are often high.
"The builders don't really care about the monthly cost," said John Kaussner, president of the Hydronics Institute, in Berkeley Heights, N.J., a manufacturers' trade association. "They're interested in building homes and selling them quickly for a profit."
Decades ago, electric heat was cheap. But as the cost has risen, electric systems have become prohibitively expensive, especially in the colder climates.
Heat pumps are largely used in the South. Essentially, they are central air-conditioners with a reversing valve that can provide a limited amount of heat from the outside air in mild winters.
York International says sales of residential heat pumps are expected to fall to 550,000 units this year, from 558,000 units in 1991.
Forced hot-air systems use the same ducts as the central air-conditioning. But the heating system tends to leave cold spots in rooms and circulates dust throughout the house.
 
The Changing Law
More Efficiency Is Now Mandated
 A big reason that gas furnace sales have risen and that others have fallen only moderately is the National Appliance Energy Conservation Act, which took effect on Jan. 1.
The law, which also applies to air-conditioners, heat pumps and other appliances, mandates that furnaces bought after that date have an annual fuel utilization efficiency of at least 78 percent. Older furnaces often operate at 50 percent or less efficiency, experts say, meaning that half the oil or gas they burn does not directly heat the house.
The more efficient furnaces can cost $1,000 to $3,000, depending on size.
"Many people are refinancing and upgrading their houses, especially to make their houses more fuel efficient so that their monthly payments will be down," said Mr. Johnson of Carrier.
Boilers can last 20 or 30 years, compared with 15 years or so for furnaces. Executives at Burnham, a leading boiler maker, said that industrywide boiler sales this year should be 325,000 units (62 percent gas and 38 percent oil). That would be up from 296,000 last year (60 percent gas and 40 percent oil).
Robert L. Coons, vice president for marketing at Burnham, said 80 percent of boiler sales were to replace existing units at a cost of about $3,200 for a 4,000-square-foot home.
"One of the trends that is helping the boiler market grow is radiant heat," he added, because of switching from furnaces or electric heat to boiler-powered radiant systems.
 
Radiant Heat
Installation Versus Monthly Expenses
 Randy Woodworth, an independent contractor and plumber in Hunter, N.Y., has just built a 4,000-square-foot house in the mountains around a hydronic radiant floor heating system. He designed the system with engineers from Wirsbo, a supplier of radiant floor heating systems based in Apple Valley, Minn. Wirsbo's parent company, the Uponor Group, is based in Espoo, Finland, near Helsinki.
He said that the radiant system for the three-bedroom house cost about $16,000 to $19,000 to install. But the heating bill is about $80 a month. That compares with $600 to $800 a month in the winter for electric systems, and $400 a month for a conventional oil-fired hot-air or hot water system.
Besides the initial cost, radiant systems have another potentially big drawback. Improperly installed, the pipes can crack or leak underneath the floor, turning into a homeowner's nightmare.
Joel Hollenberg, a professor of mechanical engineering at Cooper Union in Manhattan, says neither gas nor oil will be the choice of the next generation. He thinks it will be hydrogen. "Hydrogen can be burned with no pollution and I see this as the fuel of the future," he said.
 
DAVIDS, LOSING TO GAS GOLIATHS
 Nearly everywhere in the United States, except in parts of the Northeast where gas pipelines are not yet common, natural gas is the fuel of choice for home heating systems.
And even in the Northeast, gas companies have made inroads by marketing their product as a steady provider of clean, even heat. They also assert that oil is dirty and unhealthy to live with.
 For their part, oil suppliers strongly hint that gas can blow up your house. At least that is part of their counter-advertising. They assert that you don't save money by switching to gas. And they make much of the fact that to get service for gas systems, homeowners have to make a dreaded call: to a plumber.
Gas companies are public utilities with multimillion-dollar budgets. Heating oil companies, by contrast, are mostly small, independently owned businesses.
"It's an impossible battle to compete with gas companies," said Cliff Sullivan, owner of the Sullivan Fuel Company in Salem, N.H., which pumps about 1.5 million gallons of fuel oil a year, for which it currently charges 82.9 cents a gallon. "Every time you look there's another gas advertisement."
His company, which has been in the Sullivan family for three generations, has seen sales decline since the recent installation of natural gas lines in the area.
"Gas is becoming more popular because people perceive it as a better way," said Mr. Sullivan. Despite gas-company ads that depict oil as a dirty fuel, he insisted that oil was no worse for the environment than gas.
To combat gas utilities' marketing campaigns, independent oil companies have joined forces in groups like the New York-area Metropolitan Energy Council, to pool money to pay for better advertising.
A main point of the gas industry ads is that natural gas is cheap, plentiful and not subject to Middle East wars or politics. But people who follow oil prices say they can be slightly cheaper than gas.
"The price of oil is staying about where it is," said Paul Geiger, editor of Fueloil and Oil Heat, in Fairfield, N.J., a trade magazine.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Interest Rates: This Year's Big Speculation

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Rarely have so many bet so much, and with so much borrowed money, as is now being bet on one simple proposition: Short-term interest rates will not rise, or at least will not rise very much.
The public now believes it, but it is not individuals who are doing the bulk of the speculating. The big bettors are institutional investors, banks and brokerage houses. Those who made the bets a couple of years ago have cleaned up, a fact that has enticed many others to follow. 
 But what will happen if they are wrong, if rates move up significantly? The answer could be a financial debacle. If it happens, it will probably be interpreted as a Wall Street reaction to the Clinton Administration. In fact, it will be the result of excessive speculation by bettors in search of a sure thing.
The game now is simple, at least for big investors. With no money down, you borrow at short-term rates, maybe 3 percent or so, and use the money to buy longer-term securities, paying 5 percent or more. The difference is profit.
The brokerage industry, as George Monahan of the Securities Industry Association noted the other day, now has three times the bond inventory it had five years ago. Banks now have more Treasury and Government agency securities than they have business loans outstanding. Hedge funds -- the investment vehicles that try to make big killings quickly -- are said to own upward of $100 billion in Treasuries. Much of that is financed with short-term loans.
The risk, obviously, is that short-term rates will move up, wiping out the profits. Those on Wall Street, you will be happy to know, have an answer for that. We won't get into all the details here, but the idea is that they will sell futures contracts, thereby being able to profit from rising short-term rates and offsetting their losses from the original bond investment. Alternatively, they could dump the longer-term bonds. Both strategies assume willing buyers will be easily found, which might happen only after prices had fallen a long way.
"There are a huge number of people on one side of the boat," commented Gordon Ringeon, a hedge fund manager in San Francisco who is not playing the game. "If they all decide to switch to the other side of the boat, it could get interesting." At worst, it might even bring back memories of 1987, when institutions believed they could protect profits in stocks by selling stock index futures after prices began to fall. That delusion -- called portfolio insurance -- was the major reason the crash was so devastating.
Treasury bill rates have been rising for more than a month, although not yet by enough to do much damage. The consensus is that rates will fall again, but Bill Clinton has yet to unveil his plan to get the economy moving.
History shows that governments are not always determined to lower interest rates, and this year's election shows that low rates do not guarantee popularity. It is puzzling why Wall Street seems to be so sure that they will endure.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1867 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 1-6

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Some Well-Placed Loopholes in the Looming Trade War 

At first blush, it seemed as if the United States and the European Community might be headed for a trade war. After years of talks under the framework of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, negotiations broke down last week over European agricultural subsidies. France, with elections looming, has refused to take anything away from its politically potent farmers. To show the Bush Administration's displeasure, the U.S. Trade Representative, Carla A. Hills, imposed a 200 percent tax on European white wine, cooking oil and pet food ingredients. The Europeans complained. The tax "constitutes an illegal position according to GATT's rules," said Frans Andriessen, the Community's External Relations Commissioner. But Mrs. Hills's tax contained several outs. It does not go into effect until Dec. 5, allowing the Community to formulate a new position. And it applies to goods worth $300 million -- not much by global standards.
 
Bush Veto No. 37
 
He may have lost the election, but President Bush still wields a mean veto. Last week he used it -- veto No. 37 -- to kill a $27 billion urban aid and tax bill. Mr. Bush objected to the measure because it made permanent certain tax increases. It would have required corporations to pay more of their taxes in advance and it limited deductions for individual moving expenses to $10,000. But the provision also contained elements from Mr. Bush's own economic agenda: incentives for setting up enterprise zones, expanded tax breaks for individual retirement accounts and renewed tax breaks for research. Those items were not enough to get Mr. Bush to unlock his jaw. "The original focus of the bill -- to help revitalize America's inner cities -- has been lost in a blizzard of special interest pleadings," the President said.

Uptick in Manufacturing
 
After sputtering along for months, the nation's manufacturing economy finally gained a little ground last month -- but the key word is little. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index rose to 50.6 percent in October from 49 percent the month before. The index, which tracks purchases at about 300 industrial companies, signals expansion when it rises above 50 percent and contraction when it falls below that mark. The rise may be encouraging, but the index "will have to advance to higher levels for the economy to improve at a more vigorous pace," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the survey committee.

Forecast Is Stagnation
 
The economy may be squeeking along now, but watch out after Inauguration Day. The Commerce Department's index of leading economic indicators -- meant to forecast economic activity three to nine months hence -- fell 0.3 percent in September, the third decline in the last four months. Of the 11 indicators that comprise the index, six posted declines. Among them were raw materials prices, the length of the work week and the number of unfilled orders for manufactured goods. "I think we're in a prolonged stagnation," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser at DRI-McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., economic forecasting firm.

The long-dormant construction sector is advancing -- tentatively. According to the Commerce Department, spending on new construction rose by 1.3 percent in September.

A Glow on Retailing
 
For the nation's retailers -- a little relief. An index of sales at 50 chain stores compiled by Prudential Securities registered sales gains of 6.5 percent last month, compared with a rise of 5.9 percent during September. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's No. 1 retailer, posted a hefty 16 percent increase in sales at stores open at least a year. The Kmart Corporation, the No. 2 retailer, said its overall business was up 11.1 percent. "Overall, the tone of the business has been pretty good," said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail analyst at the First Manhattan Company, an investment bank. "I think it will be a decent Christmas."

Nothing Cheery on the Job Front
 
For the fourth time in three months, the nation's unemployment rate fell -- but not for the right reasons. According to the Labor Department, 7.4 percent of the work force was unemployed in October, down from 7.5 percent the month before. But economists say only 27,000 new jobs were created -- not enough to bring unemployment down. So what was the reason for the decrease? The size of the work force -- those employed as well as those looking for work -- contracted by 314,000. With fewer people looking for work, the unemployment rate goes down. "We still haven't had enough growth to create many new jobs," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities Inc.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Lufthansa Bows Out
 
Continental Airlines -- about to emerge from bankruptcy protection -- has been the object of a lot of other airlines' affections. But last week, one of Continental's suitors, Lufthansa German Airlines, said it would have to extricate itself from the competition. Though Lufthansa's management wanted to team up with Continental to feed more passengers into its global system, the German airline's board said no. Lufthansa, which lost $449.9 million in the first half of the year and has laid off workers, was in no financial condition to go ahead with its $100 million investment in Continental and its plan to buy an additional $300 million of Continental's bonds, its supervisory board said. That leaves two bidders for Continental: Charles Hurwitz, the Houston financier, in combination with Aeromexico, and Air Canada, in combination with two Texas financiers. The bankruptcy court will decide who gets Continental in the next few weeks.
 
The Gloom Rating in Germany
 
Polls from the Conference Board may say Americans are gloomy about the future, but it's worse elsewhere. According to a survey of 25,000 German executives by the German Federation of Chambers of Commerce, the mood there has also turned positively morose. Because of pessimism about the economy, one-third of the respondents said their companies would be cutting their work forces next year and 34 percent said they plan to invest less next year. It all means "a recession cannot be ruled out any longer," said Franz Schoser, the federation's executive director. "Confidence in government and politics to solve problems is waning fast."

Breaking the Vietnam Barrier
 
Last week, despite an American-led economic embargo, Japan resumed giving economic aid to Vietnam. Japan said it would provide loans of up to $370 million, which could be used to purchase commodities and Japanese products. With its well-educated, low-wage work force, its deposits of raw materials and its nearby location, Vietnam is an attractive place for Japan to invest. But what about the embargo? "We have our policy and the United States has its policy," said a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Masamichi Hanabusa.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Big Bite for A.T.& T.
 
When A.T.& T. was broken up in 1984, no one ever suspected it might someday challenge the Baby Bells -- the regional phone companies like Nynex that emerged from it. But if A.T.& T. takes a $3.8 billion stake in McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the nation's No. 1 cellular phone company, as it is negotiating to do, it would become one of the largest players in the local markets where the Baby Bells do business. Having A.T.& T. own a third of McCaw would add a lot of muscle to the cellular company, which has two million subscribers. It would enable McCaw to sell its wireless services through A.T.& T.'s 400 retail stores and to its tens of millions of customers and it would give McCaw's wireless customers direct access to A.T.& T.'s long distance system -- advantages its competition doesn't have. The deal will "lift McCaw one level above the rest of the industry," said Robert B. Morris of Goldman Sachs & Company.
 
$39 Million for the Songs
 
Rocker Elton John made a name for himself writing sensitive songs and performing them in sequined get-ups and platform shoes. The public ate it up. Last week, the megahit-maker and his longtime lyricist, Bernie Taupin, made a monster deal with Warner/Chappell Music, a unit of Time Warner Inc., to sell the publishing rights to their catalogue of songs for a cash advance of $39 million against royalties. Mr. John and Mr. Taupin will continue to own the tunes, but Warner/Chappell will collect 15 to 20 percent of sales over the next 12 years.

Acustar Plastics on the Block
 
It may have lots of snazzy new models hitting the showroom floors amid fistfuls of rave reviews, but the Chrysler Corporation still lacks cash. And so Chrysler said last week it would sell the plastics-making operations of its Acustar parts subsidiary. The money would be used to pay back debt in the hopes of raising Chrysler's credit rating, which is in the "speculative" -- a k a junk -- category. Chrysler tried to sell all of Acustar in 1988 but the plan was scotched by the unions. The division does $200 million of business a year.

The Jaffe-Lansing Show
 
As an independent production team, Stanley R. Jaffe and Sherry Lansing had their share of hits -- "Fatal Attraction," and "Black Rain" both with Michael Douglas. But two years ago, the team broke up when Mr. Jaffe became president of Paramount Communications Inc. Last week the team was reunited when Ms. Lansing, who was once president of 20th Century Fox, signed on as head of Paramount's motion picture group; she will report to Mr. Jaffe. Ms. Lansing replaces Brandon Tartikoff, the TV-programming whiz, who resigned unexpectedly from Paramount to spend more time with his family. "I have been offered this type of position several times, but I always said no," Ms. Lansing said. Why did she change her mind? The first reason, she said, "is Stanley. We were partners for 10 years. I missed that partnership."

Piling On the Dismal at Travelers
 
It was already undergoing a restructuring, but last week, when it released its third-quarter results -- it lost $358 million -- the Travelers Corporation said it would restructure even more. Instead of eliminating 3,500 jobs over the next two years, Travelers will cut 5,000. Its restructuring plan includes selling a 27 percent stake in the company to the Primerica Corporation. What would have been only a poor showing was made dismal by $240 million in losses resulting from Hurricane Andrew. Traveler's had a profit of $65 million in the same quarter last year.

China's Steel Bargain
 
Exports have been the engine of growth for the economy. But plant by plant? Last week, California Steel Industries agreed to sell China's Capital Iron and Steel Corporation part of a steel finishing plant in Fontana, Calif. California Steel bought the plant from bankrupt Kaiser Steel. The plant was built in 1978 for $287 million and closed in 1982. China got itself a bargain. Kaiser had originally wanted $60 million. Last week's sale price was $20 million. Capital Iron will send 300 workers from Beijing to disassemble the 10-acre plant, label it and put it on the boat.

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: At Work;
Toward the Factory on a Hill

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
SOME guys just get lucky. On Tuesday, the candidate who inhales policy thrillers between campaign speeches prevailed over the candidate who might rather have been reading "A River Runs Through It." Otherwise, "Negotiating the Future: A Labor Perspective on American Business" (Basic Books) could have been consigned to the testy oblivion of academic conferences, and Irving and Barry Bluestone, the pere et fils team that wrote the book, could have been just a kinship curiosity.
But now all the might-have-beens are history. "Negotiating the Future" was published last week with an ecumenical list of blurbs, including one from "Bill Clinton, Governor of Arkansas." "We wouldn't mind if the publisher changed his title," Irving Bluestone said. 
 The book calls for a rehabilitation of the traditional adversary relationship between labor and management into a civil, cooperative new industrial order dedicated to restoring American competitiveness. It is a message that will find a warmer audience in Mr. Clinton's Washington than in a Bush Administration that did not so much bother to oppose labor as simply to render it invisible.
And it may be a message that business -- especially at companies tired of the wars of attrition that some disputes with labor have become -- will be relieved to hear. Last week, General Motors indicated it was ready to try to find common ground with union leaders as it begins what it hopes will be a march back to viability. Managers will find familiar the book's emphasis on worker empowerment and involvement, even if they pause to gulp over the utopian "enterprise compact" that would replace the typical contracts now governing industrial relations.
"Negotiating the Future" is, first of all, a primer on workplace issues in the extraordinary post-World War II economy. Labor and capital's "glory days" began in the consumer abstinence of the war. After, a convergence of pent-up demand, rising income and full employment created almost unprecedented abundance. With war-damaged foreign competition turned inward to rebuild, the United States was able to assert economic dominance internationally.
THE dream lasted a quarter of a century and ended prosaically, in congestion at the gas pumps during the oil crisis of the early 70's. For the 20 years since, the high amperage of the 80's notwithstanding, the long-term American economy has looked ever more vulnerable and volatile.
The decline of the unionized work force may account for the slighting of labor-management relations in prescriptions for the country's economic troubles. The Bluestones emphasize the dignity and importance of worker-employees. They do not however argue for enlightened self-interest, but in favor of the mutual interests -- "co-responsibility" -- of workers and employers in making a high-quality, competitively priced product.
Their vision is considerably more expansive than the total-quality worker empowerment-employee involvement programs now so fashionable. "We are talking about strategic decision-making at very high levels," Barry Bluestone said. G.M.'s Saturn plant uses aspects of this approach.
The "enterprise compact" is modeled on the Mayflower Compact, a self-conscious break with the past to establish a utopian community, and it may be too much of an errand into the wilderness for some executives. The compact would give workers more than a hand in all kinds of decisions -- pricing, productivity goals, strategic decisions -- that management now reserves to itself, as well as a voice in more traditional labor issues like seniority, layoffs and compensation. "Quality of the product," the book says, "will be a strikeable issue."
Though much of what the Bluestones argue for would happen in the workplace, Government should have a role. They propose labor law reform and re-establishment of programs in the Labor Department gutted during the Reagan-Bush years. Would Barry Bluestone like to run Labor? Hmm. "Ray Marshall is a possibility," he said, referring to President Carter's Labor Secretary. "I'm looking on with a great deal of interest."
 
 
 
THE ACADEMIC AND THE UNION GUY
 SOME families came apart much as the nation did during the 1960's. But when Barry Bluestone decided to go South to join the struggle for civil rights, his parents gave him their car. "In terms of basic social issues, we've always seen eye to eye," said Irving Bluestone.
It is not surprising, then, that both men say differences that arose during their collaboration on "Negotiating the Future" were more of nuance than substance. Barry, 47, a political economist at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, contributed his academic perspective; Irving, 75, a retired vice president of the United Automobile Workers union who now teaches industrial relations at Wayne State University, brought his practical experience. "My father will stress the importance of dignity," Barry Bluestone said. "Dignity is critical, but you can't eat it."
General Motors, a company that has featured large in the Bluestones' lives, could take a lesson from their book. "They could take a crack at an enterprise compact right now, to see if they can forestall cuts, build product and rebuild market share," said Barry Bluestone. Both Bluestones hope G.M. resists pressure from Wall Street to, in Irving Bluestone's words, "sack and use the axe." "That would be a terrible mistake," he said. "It's tough as hell to get decent quality out of workers you're killing off one by one."

HEADLINE: The Growing Battle of the Big Bookstores

BYLINE: By DAVID BERREBY; David Berreby writes on business topics from New York.

 BODY:
Last Aug. 3 was a banner day for Barnes & Noble Inc., the nation's second-largest bookseller. That was the day the company opened five "superstores" -- each stocked with 100,000 books -- in Houston, Chicago, Grosse Pointe, Mich., Orange, Conn., and Auburn, Mass.
Yet Aug. 3 was just a drop in the bucket of the grand plan hatched by Leonard Riggio, the man who controls Barnes & Noble. On Oct. 18, he opened three more giant outlets -- in the Cleveland suburbs of Shaker Heights and Mayfield Heights, and in Jenkintown, Pa. With 105 superstores opened in the last three years, including 30 in the New York area, Mr. Riggio plans to add 28 more by Jan. 1. By the end of next year, he hopes to have about 250. 
 He isn't alone. The Kmart Corporation's Waldenbooks chain, the nation's biggest, began building superstores this year, opening three under the Basset name. Then, last month, Kmart acquired Borders Inc., a widely admired chain of 19 superstores based in Ann Arbor, Mich.
Though the details of the relationship between Waldenbooks and Borders are still being worked out, the two chains will be opening as many as 60 superstores between them by the end of 1993, said Charles R. Cumello, Waldenbooks' president.
Meanwhile, smaller chains, including Crown Books and Books-a-Million, are also active in the superstore marketing niche.
"Retail is very Darwinian," Mr. Riggio said. "The bookseller species is continuing to evolve and change, and this is the next step toward bigger, stronger, faster."
In short, the battle of the big bookstores has been joined in earnest. The stores -- which stock from 50,000 to 100,000 titles, as much as 10 times more than some mall bookstores -- have been popping up here and there for several years. Now, they promise to appear almost as fast as Stephen King turns out bestsellers. If projections play out, the country's current stock of 175 or so chain-run super bookstores could grow to more than 425 by the end of next year.
"You've got to be a dominant category killer in this area," said Mr. Cumello, who cheerfully conceded that much of what went into his chain's three Basset shops was a frank imitation of the Borders stores, which are much praised by booksellers for their combination of efficient marketing and bookish ambiance.
"Mall stores are just not as profitable as they were," adds Robert M. Haft, the founder and president of Crown Books, a discount chain with some 200 outlets in Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. Mr. Haft has 20 "Super Crown" stores and plans to open 20 more by the end of 1993.
Still, a number of other retailers have their doubts that American readers need or can make use of such a vast increase in available books.
"There's a lot of skepticism," said Jack Lamplough, marketing director of the book division of Tower Records, the 76-store record chain. Though Tower has opened 15 super bookstores, each affiliated with one of its music stores, it does not see a huge new market for large bookstores and has no immediate plans to open more. "We just don't see the numbers," said Mr. Lamplough.
But superstore boosters say there's plenty of room for growth. According to the American Booksellers Association, book sales in 1991 came to some $7.9 billion, 8.4 percent above the 1990 level, despite, as Mr. Riggio likes to point out, both a recession and a war.
"We think superstores will become the dominant channel of book distribution within five years," said Lois Connelly, assistant director of investor relations at Kmart.
 WHAT the consumer can expect from the superstore wave is in ample evidence at Barnes & Nobles's shiny new outlet in Manhattan on Lexington Avenue near 86th Street. The 8,000-square-foot store features carpeting, soft music and dark wood. Poster-size signs proclaim store policy: A 30 percent discount on best-sellers, 20 percent off books recommended by the staff and 10 percent off everything else.
One recent Saturday, the author of a book on cat horoscopes sat at a table, promoting her work by offering readings "for all your cat's nine lives." No cats were in evidence but, Mr. Riggio indicates, they'd have been welcome. "The store is a public space," he said. "I'd like to put up a sign -- 'Pets, food, people welcome.' "
The superstore rivals differ in the details, but they agree that the book version of the category-killer store has to offer superb service and a welcoming atmosphere.
"The strength of a bookstore is the people managing it," said Mr. Haft of Crown, a unit of the Dart Group.
Each Super Crown store has a children's play area and future stores may also have cafes. A cafe to encourage people to browse and linger is already a fixture at Borders Bookshops and at Basset.
In fact, while amenities differ slightly from superstore to superstore, the book chains' plans are remarkably similar: All stress giving managers autonomy to make their store fit its area by stocking local authors and sponsoring readings and activities for children.
To a large degree, all are following lessons learned from the independent operators, which still account for 60 percent of the nation's 4,500 bookstore companies. The stores run by independents have gotten larger and more comfortable over the past 15 years -- some are even superstores -- as a way of distinguishing themselves from the mall outlets opened by the chains in the 70's.
 THAT'S an irony that distresses Bill Kurland. Mr. Kurland and his partners, who own Shakespeare & Company, which runs two bookstores in Manhattan, were not happy to learn that Barnes & Noble is planning two superstores on the Upper West Side, not far from their shop on Broadway near 83d Street.
"Independent bookstores spend years developing a market," he said. "Then a chain sweeps in and says there's room for two more giant bookstores. I don't think there is. I think this is predatory, frankly."
Mr. Kurland fears the book superstore will do to the independent sellers what Wal-Mart did to the general store or what Kmart's Home Depot is doing to hardware stores.
"In the short run, it appears better for the consumer," he conceded. "There are more stores, everybody's on his toes about service. But in the long run, when the little guy is knocked out, the consumer is not served. Because a locally owned store can serve the community better than some absentee company."
 MR. RIGGIO dislikes being portrayed as the heavy. In his own eyes, he represents the forces of good, up against a Kmart army of number-crunchers just as happy to sell widgets as Wittgenstein. "Ours is a bookseller's culture," he said. "We are not an appendage of some larger empire." His company has about 900 stores, including the B. Dalton chain, Bookstop, Doubleday and Scribners. Waldenbooks has about 1,400, including Brentano's and Basset.
In any event, Mr. Riggio argues, "The more bookstores you open, the larger the market's going to be." In fact, he said, some 60 percent of superstore sales represent new business, not sales taken from elsewhere.
Some independent store owners concede there may be some truth in this argument. "When the chains put stores in all those malls in the 1970's, they argued that they were creating new markets," said Charles Robinson, the current president of the American Booksellers Association and the owner of an independent bookstore in Bellingham, Wash. "In retrospect, I think they did expand the market."
Superstores could have the same effect, Mr. Robinson said, when they're opened in areas that don't have bookstores already. "But to the extent that they're going into well-established markets like Chicago, they'll be taking from each other and from other stores," he said.
The sudden appearance of many more superstores will soon reveal whether Mr. Riggio is right, and that's "the particularly interesting question" for publishers, said Laurie Brown, vice president for sales and marketing at Farrar Straus & Giroux in New York.
Ms. Brown sees some virtue for publishers in the creation of better stocked stores; with more room for some of the 950,000 titles in print, the superstores should help publishers sell their "backlist" of works published in previous years, she said.
In the meantime, all Mr. Kurland can do is stay on his toes. "You sharpen your pencils and try to be better," he said.
 
 
 
RAISING THE MONEY TO RAISE THE STAKES
 TURNING an empty retail shell into a book superstore is an expensive operation -- they typically cost more than $1 million apiece -- and so several companies with big-store ambitions went looking recently for capital.
Barnes & Noble Inc. announced plans in September to raise $130 million by taking part of the company public. The market, which has not been enthusiastic lately about many public offerings, was no kinder to Barnes & Noble's president, Leonard Riggio. Some analysts recommended avoiding the stock, citing the company's $275 million in debt and the fact that it lost $7.8 million last year on $892.6 million in sales. (Waldenbooks, by contrast, reported profits of $38 million on sales of $1.14 billion.)
Undaunted, Mr. Riggio canceled the offering and turned to private sources. He says he has raised more than $100 million -- from his own funds, those of Vendex International (the Dutch firm that owns the 50 percent of Barnes & Noble that Mr. Riggio doesn't) and private investors. He insists his initial filing was just a means to keep his options open, and that his offering was never really tested in the market.
"We didn't even do a red herring," he said, referring to an initial prospectus.
Last August, Borders Inc., the respected 19-outlet chain of book superstores, also announced that it would go public, hoping to raise as much as $190 million for its planned expansion. Less than two months later, the chain was acquired by Kmart for a sum the giant retailer did not disclose.
"Their problem was lack of money to grow," said Charles R. Cumello, president of Waldenbooks, now a member along with Borders of Kmart's specialty retail division. "Now they have Kmart's cash, so that's not a problem."
Two months ago, Books-a-Million Inc., a family-owned chain based in Birmingham, Ala., announced its plan to raise some $34 million by selling 2.275 million shares. Unlike the other two chains, Books-a-Million stuck by its plan. Its shares began trading last Tuesday on the Nasdaq exchange. The chain has some 100 stores in the Southeast, including 12 superstores. It hopes to build 25 more of the big stores within the next year.
Of all the companies gathering money for expansion, Mr. Riggio's is the one with the most on the line. His plans call for more stores and more spending than anyone else.
If Mr. Riggio is worried, he's not showing it. Barnes & Noble will report a profit in 1992, he said, precisely because he's opened so many superstores in time for the Christmas season, when some 40 percent of book-buying takes place. "We've been loading up-front all the costs of jumping into the superstore business," he said.
Other retailers agree that, despite the recession, a big burst of spending on superstores makes sense.
"The customers are spending twice as much time in the store," said Clyde Anderson, president of Books-a-Million. "If they spend more time, they spend more money."

HEADLINE: First, We Need to Have a Peacetime Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Cold War: Get Over It" (editorial, Oct. 22) raises the central issue facing Americans -- the imperative to put an end to our semimilitary economy and construct a system geared to peacetime needs. Many of us can recall when the country faced the dangers from the Rome-Berlin-Tokyo Axis. The Roosevelt Administration, after grappling with a number of problems, was able to mobilize our economic strength to cope with the prospects of war. 
 Committees were formed under Federal auspices, with the support of Congress, to organize our economic resources for military production. The plans and programs put into action by these committees developed our military might and brought the Axis powers to their knees.
Today neither the executive nor the legislative branch has addressed the challenges emerging from the end of the cold war. Instead, we hear voices cautioning against reducing military expenditures because of the alleged baleful effect on the economy. We are told that thousands of jobs are at stake. Hence both major parties avoid taking positions that would threaten the livelihoods of workers.
However, these workers need not experience pain if both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue genuinely want a peacetime economy. That is, the joint action of the executive and legislative branches could create a council of conversion, consisting of representatives from government, labor, business and science, to work out programs for converting the economy to meet the needs of all Americans. Such a body could minimize the problems facing defense workers.
If the economy could be mobilized to meet the exigencies of war during the Roosevelt years, certainly we can convert to meet the exigencies of peace.
 
HERBERT KRIEDMAN
Lido Beach, L.I., Oct. 29, 1992
 
The writer retired as a professor of history and political science at Nassau Community College.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
In This Three-Sided Civil War, Only Death Is Claiming Victory

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast

 BODY:
NOT long ago, the violent struggle over the fate of Liberia seemed nearly over. Charles Taylor, the American-educated guerrilla leader, had agreed to disarm and encamp his forces. Meanwhile, troops from a multinational West African peacekeeping force had begun fanning out through territory under the rebel leader's control, which includes nearly 95 percent of the Liberian countryside-- and appeared poised to enforce a truce. There was even talk of elections this year, the first in nearly a decade.
But in a blink, the conflict was rekindled last month, and now Liberia's warring factions appear to be thrusting the country once again into chaos, and this time possibly engulfing its neighbors in the region. 
 That fact was brought to the world's attention last week by news that five American nuns had been slain near their convent on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia's capital; the city became the focus of the latest fighting when Mr. Taylor's forces laid siege to it on Oct. 15 after weeks of mounting tensions. Mr. Taylor, however, has disavowed any involvement by his forces in the killing of the nuns, insisting that the area where they died was not under his control.
It was not a case that acquaintances of the nuns found persuasive, in part because the killings resembled other atrocities in which Mr. Taylor's troops were involved. "We hold Mr. Taylor responsible, directly or indirectly, consciously or unconsciously, for the death of these five lovely people," Archibishop Michael Francis of Monrovia said last Sunday.
In any event, the nuns were only the most publicized victims of Liberia's seemingly inexorable slide into anarchy. Tens of thousands have died in the Liberian civil war so far, and relief workers and diplomats say at least 3,000 -- most of them unarmed civilians -- have died just since mid-October.
The current fighting involves Mr. Taylor's forces, a rival rebel group and the West African force, which backs an interim Government. On Tuesday, Nigerian jets were reported to have killed 38 civilians in a raid on a rubber plantation east of Monrovia where military officials said Mr. Taylor's forces were storing munitions.
"What's happening now is everyone's worst nightmare," said Janet Fleischman, an expert on Liberia who works for Africa Watch, a New York-based advocacy group.
What went wrong? Archbishop Francis and many others in Liberia blame Mr. Taylor, who they say has time and again sabotaged efforts to settle the crisis. The latest breakdown began in mid-September, after fighting between the two rebel groups broke out and peacekeeping troops who were entering Mr. Taylor's territory came under attack. The West African force then withdrew and the situation deteriorated, culminating in the present siege of Monrovia.
"Taylor is driven by an all-consuming desire to become Liberia's President, and nothing short of that goal will ever satisfy him," said Makau wa Mutua, director of the Human Rights Project at Harvard Law School. "He's too power-hungry to ever sit down at a negotiating table."
Mr. Taylor has mostly blamed leaders of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States, a trading consortium that installed the interim Government in Monrovia in 1990 as part of a regional peace plan. Mr. Taylor has argued that the interim Government is a puppet of Nigeria, the region's dominant power, and indeed Nigeria has supplied most of the troops and materiel for the peacekeeping force.
Mr. Taylor, now 45 years old, has been involved in Liberia's power struggles since he was a student at Bentley College near Boston, when he helped organize Liberians in the United States against President William R. Tolbert Jr. When Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe overthrew President Tolbert in 1980, Mr. Taylor returned to Liberia to join the new leadership. But he fell out with Mr. Doe, and in 1983 fled to the United States.
In December 1989, he and about 100 guerillas invaded northern Liberia from the Ivory Coast. The insurgency gained momentum but split into rival factions. Eventually a former Taylor follower, Prince Johnson, captured, tortured and killed President Doe.
At first, Mr. Taylor was hailed by many Liberians as a hero. But the accolades turned to condemnation when he refused to surrender territory he controlled on the ground that the peacekeeping force was not neutral. For nearly two years the acrimony stymied efforts to resolve the crisis.
Then, inexplicably, Mr. Taylor reversed himself in April and agreed to allow peacekeeping forces to be deployed in much of the area he controlled. He said he would disarm his fighters in anticipation of elections.
What neither side counted on, however, was the complication posed by yet another rebel group, the United Liberation Movement of Liberia. It began to attack Mr. Taylor's positions just as the West African peacekeeping forces were being deployed, and it was during this fighting that the peacekeeping troops came under attack and withdrew.
For a time, leaders of the West African force believed the best strategy was to negotiate a settlement between Mr. Taylor and the other rebels. But that effort failed and the West African force launched an offensive against Mr. Taylor. The current carnage in and around Monrovia followed.
The increasingly bloody three-way struggle over a tiny war-weary country presumably has its limits. If there is no clear winner, the pressure to talk could well grow. Chances are, though, that many more Liberians will die before that point is reached.

HEADLINE: TAKE A NUMBER;
What Can Clinton Change, and When?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GOV. BILL CLINTON and his supporters had just begun to savor the sweet taste of election victory when the heartburn of governing set in.
By the end of last week, they clearly recognized that the policy changes Mr. Clinton promised daily during the campaign can only take effect slowly, incrementally and painfully even if they are enacted early in the year. "The word now," said an adviser in Little Rock trying to dampen expectations, "is no quick fix." 
 The economy cannot be turned on like a light switch. The country's health care, welfare and education systems cannot be reformed until a consensus is built in the country on which directions to go. Competing interests in many areas will have to be weighed against one another, with some supporters sure to be disappointed. The Republican influence on the bureaucracy and the courts will last for years.
Some campaign promises can indeed be fulfilled in Mr. Clinton's first days in the White House. He will almost certainly sign orders changing the Government's restrictions on abortion -- lifting the ban on abortion counseling at clinics receiving Federal money, permitting abortions at military hospitals, allowing aid to go to organizations overseas that provide abortion services and permitting the importation of RU-486, the French abortion pill. Mr. Clinton will probably sign other orders permitting homosexuals to serve in the military and ending the ban on medical research using fetal tissue, and he will doubtless appoint a coordinator of the Government's AIDS policy. He will also surely withdraw President Bush's proposals to open for development all of Alaska's wetlands and half of those in the other states.
Beyond that, some measures President Bush vetoed are likely to be reintroduced and enacted quickly once Mr. Clinton takes office. Bills in this category include those guaranteeing workers unpaid time off for birth and family emergencies, changing campaign finance laws and requiring states to let people register to vote when they get a driver's license.
 
Tough Choices
 Many fervent Clinton supporters, out in the cold for 12 years, say the most pleasant change for them will not be so much in policy as in tone and attitude. "We're going to have a sympathetic ear in the Government," said Tom Joe, one of the capital's authorities on policies affecting the poor. "Instead of mean, callous, insensitive people, ignorant about what's really going on out there, I expect an intelligent debate now, a dialogue on the main issues."
But all that is relatively small stuff. In the last days of the campaign, Mr. Clinton began to enumerate his highest priorities: turning the economy around and creating more jobs; controlling health-care costs, while extending medical insurance coverage to everyone; reducing the Federal budget deficit, and improving the country's education and job-training systems.
Many of those elements are interdependent; some are contradictory. The tax cuts and spending increases needed to stimulate the economy would worsen the deficit in the short term. Universal medical insurance could lead to more spending on health care, not less. The deficit cannot be reined in without limiting the Government's medical expenses. The promise of more jobs depends in part on better education and training, and those cost money, which in turn would make it harder to lower the deficit.
Such are the tough choices to be weighed initially by the transition team led by Warren M. Christopher and Vernon E. Jordan, who were appointed on Friday. But Mr. Clinton has a big advantage many of his predecessors have not enjoyed: he has big majorities of his own party in Congress dying to follow the lead of a Democratic President. The lawmakers say it is in their own self-interest to prove that they can be productive.
THE ECONOMIC 'LASER BEAM' Mr. Clinton won the Presidency in large part because of the economic hard times, and last Wednesday, the day after the election, he promised to "focus like a laser beam on this economy." He has not said and probably does not know yet exactly what he will propose. But these are good bets: tax credits for business investments in new plants and machinery (Look for what is called a "marginal" tax credit, intended to reward businesses only for investments they would not otherwise have made); permanent tax breaks for business spending on research and development; billions of dollars in grants to states and cities for public works like highways and waste treatment plants; higher tax rates on family incomes above $200,000, and stricter enforcement of tax laws affecting foreign corporations.
That is a popular package, even if Mr. Clinton does not include the tax cut for the middle class he proposed during the campaign. Congress would doubtless pass the measures quickly. But two big questions remain: Would they actually succeed in giving a quick boost to the economy? And will Mr. Clinton ask for long-term steps to lower the budget deficit as part of his package?
Reflecting the prevailing view, Charles L. Schultze, a top economist in the Johnson and Carter Administrations, said, "My judgment is that you can't do a lot very quickly, but you could feel the effects, maybe, in 1993, by the end of next year."
Meantime, the determination of many businesses to cut their operating costs will continue in light of international competition, lessened demand for military equipment and other fundamental changes in the economy over which Mr. Clinton will have little or no control. That means more layoffs. Just in the last couple of weeks, for example, such corporate giants as American Express, Bell South, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Borden announced plans to eliminate among them more than 20,000 jobs in the next year. Against such forces, the Clinton economic package might seem feeble.
The matter of dealing with the budget deficit is even more of a conundrum. Mr. Clinton did not stress it during the campaign. But many Democratic economists, Mr. Schultze among them, hold that the deficit is the country's most critical problem, one that is slowly eroding the nation's foundation by borrowing against the future. They say that unless the Clinton Administration tackles it at once, enacting early next year foolproof legislation to lower the deficit once the economy improves, the chance for success will be lost.
Ross Perot's surprising strength in the election and exit polls showing many voters demanding deficit reduction could give Mr. Clinton political cover. But here's the rub: the only way really to reduce the deficit is to raise the taxes of middle-income Americans, cut popular programs or both. Those moves are politically unappealing; if Mr. Clinton pressed for them, it might delay if not completely block the chances for approval of his economic stimulus plan.
Other important campaign promises like changing the health care and welfare systems and granting college scholarships in return for public service will not be acted on until the primary economic issues are disposed of. In the case of health care especially, that might enhance the likelihood of eventual success because it will give the new Administration time to develop a consensus for its proposals.
"The public hasn't been prepared by anyone to face the explicit trade-offs a new medical system would require, like higher taxes and restrictions on choices," said John Rother, chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons. Without such careful spade work, he added, major health care legislation can never blossom.
COMPETING DEMANDS Like any new President, Mr. Clinton owes debts to important supporters. Big-city mayors have a seven-point plan that would cost $35 billion. Teachers want more money for schools. Women's groups want to see women get top jobs in the new Government. Some of these and other interest groups will be rewarded; others will not. For Mr. Clinton it will be a delicate balancing act.
Nowhere is this clearer than in the case of the philosophy he assumes on protecting the environment. Mr. Clinton's running mate, Al Gore, and former Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont, who will probably get a big position somewhere in the new Administration, favor sharply increased Government regulations on business and development. Other important advisers like Senator Tim Wirth of Colorado and Fred Krupp, the influential director of the Environmental Defense Fund, generally oppose new rules and restrictions and prefer tax breaks for businesses and other market-based inducements to improve the environment. How Mr. Clinton comes down on this matter may be seen in whom he appoints to be Secretary of the Interior and head of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Whatever the case, the authorities agree, Mr. Clinton must move quickly. The two recent Presidents most successful in turning the Government's policies around, Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan, won most of their triumphs in their first year in office. Harry C. McPherson, who was Johnson's White House counsel, gives Mr. Clinton a year before a political backlash develops. Joel H. Silbey, a historian and Presidential scholar at Cornell, allows 18 months. Mr. Rother, the lobbyist for retirees, thinks Mr. Clinton may have as much as a two-year grace period, but no more.
No President can completely prepare for everything he might face. But Mr. Clinton intends to make sure that at least he is not blind-sided by the substance. Asked by reporters in Little Rock on Friday how he was spending most of his time, he said, "I'm reading volumes of stuff on things that I need to decide on."
