HEADLINE: Conversations/Wang Chigang;
An Illiterate Peasant From Nowhere Speaking Volumes About China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: TUQIAO, China

 BODY:
HE IS an unimportant man. He did not go to school, cannot write his own name, and never makes decisions that affect his village, let alone his nation.
Wang Chigang is a Chinese peasant, one of about 800 million. A sinewy 76-year-old, short, lean and beginning to bend with the years, he lives in the little village of Luqiao, miles and miles from nowhere in the central Chinese province of Anhui. His face is rough and covered with creases, the texture of a softball that is about to be retired. He wears a navy blue version of the tunic known as a Mao suit, with a matching cap on his close-cropped head. 
 "Sit down, sit down," he says, beaming a smile that displays his three remaining teeth as a foreigner in search of a Chinese Everyman wanders over to his new two-room concrete home. "Let me pour some tea." He follows the ritual of insisting several times before being persuaded that tea is unnecessary, and then he sits on a folding chair in the bare living room and begins to speak of his life.
Mr. Wang's tale is not unusual in these parts, nor is he especially articulate. He is simply a fairly typical member of the Chinese peasantry, which accounts for one person in seven on Earth. It was the peasants who played a fundamental role in China's Communist Revolution of 1949, who today are the main builders of China's ongoing economic miracle, and who continue to provide the troops who protect the party -- those who three years ago fired their machine guns at university students demanding more democracy. Collectively the peasants exert a stabilizing force in China, and Mr. Wang offers a window into their feelings of contentment, docility and indifference that help keep the Communist Party in power.
"Life was very poor when I was growing up," Mr. Wang began expansively, as his grandson and great-granddaughter watched quietly from a few feet away. "All the homes in the village were made of mud, and there was no school. Most girls in those days bound their feet, of course, wrapping them up to make them as tiny as possible."
"My family was among the poorest in the village, and it was impossible for me to go to school," he said. "I was the fifth son in a large family, and so I didn't get any land."
 
Chinese Gothic
 Mr. Wang spoke without a hint of bitterness; indeed, he seemed to relish the chance to relate what he had endured. He grinned repeatedly, sometimes disconcertingly, even when recalling painful periods of his life. Unflappable and self-satisfied, he was not in the least inquisitive about life in America.
At the age of 21, Mr. Wang married a young woman who was also from a poor family -- too poor to worry about binding her feet to make her more beautiful. There was no work to be had in those days, in the 1930's, so in desperation he set off to try to get food any way he could.
"We went begging," he said, speaking easily in Mandarin with a strong local accent. "We were together then, because one guy alone can't get anything. You need a wife and babies to beg."
Asked what it was like to beg, Mr. Wang paused and seemed to regard it as a silly question. "It was terrible," he said. "How could a beggar be happy doing that?"
Over the years, Mr. Wang worked on-and-off as a day laborer, a farmhand and a quarry worker. The revolution in 1949 turned everything around and for a while his village was full of hope. The fields were divided up, so that Mr. Wang, his wife and three children received some land of their own.
Life began to go awry in Luqiao in 1958, when Chairman Mao proclaimed the Great Leap Forward, a bold plan to catch up with the industrialized West. Mr. Wang's farmland was taken away and made part of a commune, and he and other peasants obeyed orders to build a steel furnace -- part of a scheme to industrialize by making steel in backyard furnaces rather than huge smelters. Mr. Wang and the other peasants ate their meals together in a village cafeteria, and everything was supposed to be shared.
"At first, we could eat as much as we wanted in the cafeteria, but that only lasted a few months," Mr. Wang said. All China was then in a frenzy, with officials setting impossible goals for grain harvests and steel production, and then falsely claiming to have met the targets. Most peasants and workers joined in the giddiness, for they felt enormous faith in Chairman Mao and could not believe that he could be so wrong this time.
But he was. The hoes and pots that Mr. Wang and millions of other peasants put into the backyard steel furnaces ended up as useless gobs of metal, and farm work was so neglected that China suffered the worst famine ever recorded in world history. Perhaps 26 million people died.
"Nobody in my family died, but a lot of others did," Mr. Wang said coolly. "About 20 percent of the people in the village died then."
The Cultural Revolution had only a slight impact on Luqiao, Mr. Wang said, because it was so remote. A few city youths came to live in the village for a while, to learn from the peasants, but went away after the glamour wore off.
 
Deng's Revolution
 The real revolution in Mr. Wang's life, with far more impact than 1949, came after Deng Xiaoping became paramount leader in 1978. The commune was dissolved and Mr. Wang and his eight-member family again got land of their own: 1.6 acres.
Life improved steadily, and lately his family has begun to go into business. Mr. Wang's grandchildren have turned the entrance to their home into a small shop, selling baby clothes and knickknacks. One grandson has made modest amounts of money selling piglets.
"Young people think very differently," Mr. Wang said, gazing proudly at his 25-year-old grandson, Wang Zhichun. "They think big! Me, I figure it's enough to get a bite to eat. But the kids want to do a lot of business and make pots of money.
"Young people are so much more capable than I am, so I never interfere in the business decisions. Why, they can make 100 yuan in just a few days. I sure can't do that."
One hundred yuan is equivalent to about $18. The per capita cash income for peasants in Anhui Province is about $100 per year.
Electricity arrived last year, and the family bought a television. Now Mr. Wang has turned into something of a couch potato, watching three or more hours of television each evening -- especially dramas and musical performances.
"Sometimes I stay up half the night watching programs," he acknowledged, with a hint of embarrassment.
Mr. Wang does not pay much attention to the news, and he could not name the Prime Minister (Li Peng) or Communist Party leader (Jiang Zemin). But he is interested in the food on the table. "Before, I could never eat meat -- three years could go by without eating meat," he said. "Now I eat meat almost every day."
These days Mr. Wang helps his family with the work, and he is also thinking about getting a coffin ready in case he dies unexpectedly. Like most elderly villagers, he plans to keep the coffin in a corner of the house so that it is ready if necessary. "It's best to be prepared," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wang Chigang and great-granddaughter in Luqiao, China. (Nicholas D. Kristof/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Bypassing the Press Helps Candidates; Does It Also Serve the Public Interest?

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
MARISSA HALL, the young woman from Richmond, Va., who stood up at the second Presidential debate and asked "How has the national debt personally affected each of your lives?" probably wasn't expecting to become a major campaign figure. But as William Figueroa, the student Dan Quayle coached to spell "potatoe," can attest, celebrity sometimes comes in unexpected ways.
After the second debate was over, many Americans hailed Ms. Hall's question as one of the campaign's most illuminating, calling it proof that the political process functions best when the role of the news media is minimized. Others argued that the question itself was wrong-headed -- Ms. Hall seemed not to understand the difference between the recession and the national debt -- and called it one of the best arguments that could be made for the importance of the press. 
 Perhaps better than any other incident, this debate over a question illustrates a theme that was central to the 1992 campaign, but never appeared on a candidate's position paper: Who should ask the questions?
Never before had so many Americans -- from reporters to talk show hosts to rock stars to ordinary citizens -- had the opportunity to stick a microphone in the face of a Presidential candidate. With the campaign ending in record voter turnouts, even many journalists of the "old news" school have been commending the broadening of the political process to include "new news" types like Phil Donahue and Larry King.
"Obviously it generated an enormous amount of interest by people who normally weren't turned on by the process," said Tim Russert, the moderator of NBC's "Meet the Press."
At the same time, traditional journalists are clearly anxious about losing their franchise. And while almost everyone agrees that it can be informative to see the candidates in a relaxed setting -- as on MTV, for example -- this fall the settings often seemed a little too relaxed. In the final weeks, Ross Perot submitted to hardly any questions except those posed by a friendly interviewer who happened to be on his payroll. Some journalists wonder whether Bill Clinton's plans for direct interaction with ordinary people will mean fewer press conferences.
As early as the New Hampshire primary, it was clear that the struggle for control of the questions was going to be a big subplot.
When the Gennifer Flowers story broke, aides to Governor Clinton insisted that New Hampshire voters were not much interested in the story. Reporters, however, were. They questioned the Governor about it wherever he went.
 
Friendly Coverage for Sale
 Finally Mr. Clinton decided that he was going to get a different kind of coverage, even if he had to pay for it. He bought a half-hour of local television time, assembled a group of undecided voters and let them ask the questions.
After that, at almost every important juncture of the campaign, Mr. Clinton tried to find forums beyond the political press corps. During the New York primary, when polls suggested he might lose to former Gov. Edmund G. Brown, Mr. Clinton spoke with Don Imus, the radio host. After the California primary, when the polls showed him third behind George Bush and Mr. Perot, he appeared on Arsenio.
What he was trying to avoid was the kind of questions that reporters love to ask and candidates hate to answer -- ones that center on unfavorable polls, rumors of misconduct and contradictions in the candidate's positions. Many press critics say the tactic worked because voters, too, are tired of such questions.
"The press is dedicated to a 'gotcha' frame of mind, to an interrupting style, to a way of almost saying 'I'm am as important to the process as this person who is President or who wants to be,' " said Marvin Kalb, director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "The voters have for a whole variety of reasons developed heavy scar tissue when it comes to professional journalism."
It is not clear, though, that the alternatives are much better.
With several billion dollars at his disposal, Mr. Perot was able to go through much of his extraordinary campaign avoiding reporters almost completely. On his paid programs, the independent candidate sometimes posed questions to himself and sometimes had them asked, in near-reverential terms, by a paid interviewer. On Election Day, Mr. Perot received almost 20 percent of the vote, a tally that suggested many Americans were satisfied to see the candidate only in a controlled setting. But Mr. Perot's performance also prompted calls for campaign reforms that would prevent future candidates from buying their own coverage.
Talk show hosts like Mr. King do not play "gotcha." Presumably to many viewers, and certainly to the candidates, this is a virtue. But a campaign run entirely on "Larry King Live" would leave a rather lopsided view of the candidates.
What about letting the voters themselves ask the questions? This happened frequently this year -- including in the second debate -- and many people say that this was one of the best aspects of the 1992 campaign. But one reason the press exists is that most Americans have neither enough time nor enough access to examine the candidates' positions in great detail. And if one listened to the many forums at which voters queried the candidates, one found that many of the questions were repetitive and involved a single theme: themselves.
"There is nothing more self-centered than an audience of untrained voters who ask the same question: me, me, me," complained Michael Robinson, a professor of government at Georgetown University.
Even with the campaign over, average citizens may get to keep asking. Mr. Clinton has said he will use bus tours and town meetings to try to build public support for bills he favors.
"We had a talk show campaign," said Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "Will we have a talk show Presidency?"

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
It's a Wonderful 2d Term (Apologies to Mr. Capra)

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
OF all the reasons why George Bush unravelled, the one most often cited is the 1990 bipartisan budget deal that broke his "read my lips" pledge. Lyn Nofziger, the former Reagan aide, called it "the wound from which all blood flows."
With a little humorous license, it is possible to imagine what would have happened in the Bush Administration if the President had, at the last moment, just stood up to John Sununu and Richard Darman, his aides who worked out the deal, and said: "Can't do it. Can't break my promise to the American people. Wouldn't be prudent. Might lose in '92." 
 In a variation on Frank Capra's revisionist 1946 fable "It's a Wonderful Life" starring Jimmy Stewart, here is what might have been:
Although Mr. Bush does not like to fire people, he is put on the spot when Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman, the "Raging Bulls" of the White House, paw the earth and threaten to quit if he does not sign the tax pact. He accepts their resignations, names Dick Cheney chief of staff and installs Phil Gramm, the conservative Texas senator with a Ph.D. in economics, as budget director.
The new advisers escape what they regard as a trap set by Democratic leaders, and, after a 16-day Government shutdown noticed by few Americans, get Congress to agree to a package of spending reductions without tax increases.
Concerned about internal polling numbers that show 75 percent of Americans think the country is "on the wrong track," the new team refocuses the entire Administration on domestic affairs.
Mr. Bush asks Peggy Noonan to write a speech for the George Bush-Puts-America-First Bus Tour and, at her urging, huddles with Housing Secretary Jack Kemp. "My friends, in small towns and big cities all over the country," he says, "what's past need not be prologue. We must remake economic policy and change the flow of money in America so the government gets less and the people get more. Message: I care about the economy."
Instead of recommending that Republicans running in mid-term Congressional elections distance themselves from Mr. Bush, Ed Rollins, the party's strategist, recommends that they cleave to the President, because he is on the right track. The appreciative Mr. Bush then cleaves to Mr. Rollins, who finds it impossible to defect to a tart-tongued Texas billionaire named Ross Perot.
Pat Buchanan decides not to run for President, because the conservatives, while never content, are not grumbling too much about Mr. Bush. He even says nice things about Mr. Bush on his television show, "Crossfire."
At the end of the gulf war, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf calls the President and recommends that the allies push on into Baghdad. Mr. Bush, confident of his domestic base and less anxious about a long entanglement, decides to go for it. Baghdad falls the next day, and Saddam Hussein is carted off by vengeful Kurds. Everybody forgets the word wimp.
In less need of conservative approval, the President and his wife, Barbara, spend 15 queasy minutes watching the Anita Hill testimony to Congress. Mr. Bush calls Judge Clarence Thomas and suggests that he withdraw his name.
Cruising at a 97 percent popularity rating at the beginning of 1992, President Bush decides he feels smothered by rich, white, middle-aged males, and reaches for some younger blood to run his re-election campaign: the Vice President's chief of staff, Bill Kristol, the State Department's Margaret Tutwiler and James Pinkerton, the junior White House aide. The President goes on MTV. "Message: Rock the Deficit," Mr. Bush raps.
On "Larry King Live," Ross Perot grudgingly gives credit to Mr. Bush for getting under the hood and tinkering with the engine, for dealing with that crazy aunt in the attic, the deficit. Says he won't run himself.
Before the Houston convention, after a lunch with Mr. Bush, Dan Quayle announces he's bored with politics and has decided to take a job as the chairman of the United States Golf Association. Mr. Bush takes Gen. Colin Powell as his running mate.
With the conservative base intact, the convention emphasizes Lee Atwater's inclusive "big tent" and showcases uplifting moderates like Education Secretary Lamar Alexander; Tom Kean, the former New Jersey Governor and Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts. Pro-choice night gets the biggest TV ratings of the week. Coming out of the convention with a big bounce, the President feels no need to insist G-O-D is on the Republican side.
Instead of slouching back to run the campaign, Secretary of State James Baker stays in the Middle East, works out a comprehensive peace deal and wins the Nobel. The 35-year sibling rivalry between George and Jimmy intensifies.
In Little Rock, Ark., Bill Clinton's strategists decide it will be hard to get any traction on the economy, so they tack up a sign at their headquarters that reads "Social Justice, Stupid!" and with this theme alienate Reagan Democrats. They worry, since Mr. Bush has kept all his major campaign promises, that the Republicans may have success using the character issue. And they worry that Mr. Bush will be able to successfully attack Congress, since he never made any cozy deals with them.
Mr. Bush wins, taking larger percentages of the black vote, the women's vote and the youth vote than any Republican in history. In his second Inaugural Address, the President calls himself an agent of change and becomes the first President to (almost) quote Bette Davis. "My fellow Americans, fasten your seatbelts," he says. "It's going to be a bumpy ride."

HEADLINE: NOV. 1-7: Washington's Warning Shot;
Europe Holds Its Fire But a Trade War May Have Begun

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
In the global economy, where nations risk trade wars when diplomacy fails, weapons can be as mundane as soybeans or as stylish as fine wine. So it went last week in the apparent failure of talks between the Bush Administration and the European Community.
Soybeans -- innocuous cream-colored legumes about the size and shape of green peas -- figure centrally. The United States wanted Europe to end or reduce the farm subsidies that allow its growers of soybeans and other oilseeds to unfairly undersell American growers. After European officials refused, the United States moved to impose 200 percent taxes on some imports, chiefly white wine. 
 The taxes would effectively triple the price of these products, but would not be collected until Dec. 5, allowing time for possible further talks.
The European Community, which for months had threatened to retaliate with stiff taxes on American products, took no immediate action. With its headquarters in Brussels in chaos as officials blamed each other for finding themselves on the brink of a trade war, the foreign ministers of the community's member countries planned to meet tomorrow. And the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a world trade body in Geneva, planned an emergency meeting for Tuesday.
American officials predicted that just as European countries have never been able to agree among themselves on how to resolve the soybean dispute, they will also be unable to agree now on how and whether to retaliate.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Budget Crisis Set for Replay as Costs Rise but Revenues Stay Weakened

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
After three straight years of fiscal crisis, beleaguered New Jersey budget makers may be about to tangle with the worst budget year yet.
Barring a bold upswing in the economy, which most analysts consider unlikely, the state is looking at yet another year of lean revenues. Furthermore, in closing last year's budget gap, legislators used nearly a billion dollars in one-time opportunities, like a revaluing of pension plans, that will not be available again. 
 In addition to the loss of one-time revenues, said Treasurer Samuel F. Crane, "Health care reform will have to be added, along with new correctional facilities. Medicaid grows $200 million plus per year."
"I think it's safe to say that growth in revenue will not match growth in expenditures," Mr. Crane said.
 
Planning Process Starts
 The current budget, itself cut sharply in the Legislature this year, producing a painful round of job cuts at state agencies, runs through June of next year. But the state's 19 department heads are already drafting their requests for the next budget, which Gov. Jim Florio is to submit to the Legislature in January.
Mr. Crane expects economic growth to produce at best only a modest increase in revenues.
The Republican Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, has a rosier forecast. He said he was optimistic that the state would pull out of the economic doldrums and see enough growth in the next 18 months, through the next fiscal year, to meet budget demands.
"There has already been some growth in the economy," he said. "By July 1 of 1994, we should be out of the doldrums. I think the economy will be humming along by then."
And if not?
"If the economy stays flat?" Mr. Haytaian said. "We would be $1.2 billion, or $1.3 billion short of this year."
 
Anger Over Taxes
 That would mean that the state would have only about $13.4 billion or less to spend compared to the $14.6 billion budgeted this year, which is itself more than a billion dollars less than the Governor asked for.
But Mr. Haytaian also says a tax increase would be "literally impossible," with anger still simmering over the record $2.8 billion increase in sales and income taxes in 1990.
The state over the last two years has significantly cut its work force, through attrition and layoffs, from 71,000 to 66,000.
If revenues do not pick up as he expects, Mr. Haytaian says, "we still think there are areas in the present budget we can go into" for further reductions, including, he said, the Departments of Human Services, Transportation and Corrections.
 
One-Time Fiscal Devices

The bleak fiscal situation did not develop overnight, nor did it have a single cause.
Because of the bad economy, tax collections have been almost flat for three years. The sales-tax rollback reduced revenue by $608 million this year.
To balance the budget in the face of the severe revenue reductions, the Florio administration has resorted to several one-time devices.
This year, for example, the state managed to raise $1.2 billion through a change in the method of valuing pension funds. Last year, it accelerated collection of utilities taxes and raised $150 million.
 
Paying for Past Gimmicks
 But in the coming budget, the state will pay for the gimmicks it has used. The pension revaluation benefit, for example, means $773 million less in the new budget, and accelerated collections of utilities taxes will also provide $110 million less next year than this year. That means that if all else stays even, the state will have $883 million less in the next budget than it now has.
And the Republican Legislature, to keep its promise to continue to hold the line on taxes, has already imposed a series of revenue measures such as fee increases that cannot be stretched much farther.
Hospital admission fees, for example, were raised from $3.55 to $5 to get $1 million more in revenue. The amount the elderly and others chip in as co-payments for prescription drugs was raised from $2 to $5, which raised about $16 million. A similar increase in the prescription fee for state employees raised another $3 million. All told, the fee increases in the budget produced about $24 million in new revenues.
There have also been a rash of separate bills that would raise other fees or return money to the treasury from other sources. One measure, for example, would raise $47 million by returning certain savings in local pension funds to the state.
 
Further Cuts Possible
 Another would increase the fee for filing for divorce from $35 to $160; another would increase beverage license fees to raise another $1.2 million; another would impose a $15 surcharge for certain traffic violations.
None of these raise large amounts of new revenue, but the grumbling and complaining even over them will make further such increases difficult.
To make up for the tax cut and other budget problems, the Legislature also cut the Homestead Rebate program by more than half, from $685 million to $300 million, eliminating or sharply reducing rebate checks.
The Florio administration is already trying to turn the rebate reduction to its political favor. The Democratic State Committee is running radio ads pummeling the Republican Legislature for cutting the rebates, and the Governor is sending out letters, at at cost of $250,000 to taxpayers, reminding those who got a check of up to $500 last year why they are getting none or less this year.

PUB-DATE: November 8, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1925 words

HEADLINE: For One Lawmaker, Allure of Capital Had Double-Edge

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
He was one of the brash, bold reformers who swept into Congress 18 years ago on a wave of popular revulsion over Watergate and the Vietnam War. Elected at age 25, he was so boyish that he was carded in bars and mistaken for a Congressional page. And no one really begrudged him when, with an immature charm, he researched whether he could be called the youngest person ever to enter the Congress.
Representative Thomas J. Downey of Amityville literally grew up in the marble corridors of the Capitol. He married during his tenure in Washington and made a home with his wife and children in a Capitol Hill townhouse. 
 But as the years passed, voters in Long Island's Second Congressional District began to wonder if he had drifted away from his roots and from the people who had elected him. And last week, they resoundingly defeated Mr. Downey in favor of someone who was remarkably reminiscent of the Tom Downey of old: a young Turk from the Suffolk County Legislature who said the incumbent had become too high and mighty and distant.
 
'Lost Touch' With Voters
 Mr. Downey, whose only adult job outside government was a brief stint in the personnel department of Macy's, was devastated. "I did not have any sense that I had lost touch with the community," he said, but he admitted that his opponent had fatally wounded him with that charge. "Sadly it stuck and had nothing to do with reality."
Some members of Congress now see Mr. Downey's defeat as a cautionary tale of how the power and the perquisites of Washington can seduce them all; of how even the brightest star of the post-Watergate era could eventually seem to the voters as too much like the insiders he once scorned.
And in Suffolk County, some wonder whether the voters had turned on Mr. Downey precisely because they had once loved him so, mothers and grandmothers cooing over the boy Congressman, with the Paul McCartneyesque cap of brown hair.
"That kind of -- it may be too strong to say adoration -- that kind of feeling for him, love for him, may have dissipated as he climbed up the ladder," said Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk County Democratic leader.
Mr. Downey first went to Washington on a tidal wave of voter revolt against the Nixon presidency and the Watergate scandal. Campaigning door to door and undaunted by the seeming futility of being an anti-war liberal running in a district that had given Richard M. Nixon 72 percent of the vote just two years earlier, Mr. Downey prevailed over the incumbent Republican Representative, James R. Grover. The next day's papers had pictures of the young Congressman-elect playing basketball with his 11-year-old brother.
 
Symbol of His Time
 In his youth, fervor and brashness, Mr. Downey was symbolic of his time. The elections of 1974 sent 75 freshmen into the House of Representatives, Mr. Downey the youngest among them. They were righteous, idealistic, ready to change the world, and they promptly ran a minor revolution in the tradition-bound House by toppling three committee chairmen. Mr. Downey did his part on the House Armed Services Committee, where he helped deposed the aging chairman, Representative Edward Herbert of Louisiana.
Mr. Downey quickly became one of the leaders of the Democratic newcomers, a tight-knit circle who shared anti-establishment political views and played ferocious basketball in the House gym. Along with Al Gore, who came to the House two years later, he made himself into one of Washington's select coterie of arms control experts.
His colleagues remember his utter confidence. "He would be announcing, 'We're going to do this. We're going to that,' " recalled Representative George Miller, a California Democrat. "We'd say that the Speaker won't like that and he'd say it didn't matter."
Mr. Downey also emerged as one of the Democrats' most articulate -- and vitriolic -- polemicists , a role that left him with enemies on the Republican side of the aisle. "If he had a weakness as a speaker, it was that he'd leave you no quarter. He'd cut you off at the knees and take a second swipe at you," Mr. Miller said. "That would cause you problems in the Congress because members of Congress weren't used to being devastated publicly."
 
Serving the Voters
 As he became an ever larger presence in Washington, Mr. Downey remained a model of the constituent-oriented Congressman. He invited thousands of voters to his parents' home in West Islip to talk issues. He made a van into a mobile office to move about the sprawling South Shore district. Former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, who entered Congress in 1978, remembers that Mr. Downey was so successful that he was asked to address freshmen on how to serve their districts.
In 1980, with the birth of his first child, Lauren, Mr. Downey and his wife, Chris, who had been an elementary school teacher in Dix Hills, were faced with the choice all members of Congress must wrestle with, how to mix the demands of family and politics. They moved to Washington so that Mr. Downey could spend more time with his daughter and later, with his second child, Theodore. On weekends, the Congressman would commute back to Long Island.
The Downey home in Washington eventually grew into a social center for a small circle of House Democrats. Once a week, Chis would cook dinner for a group that could include Marty Russo of Illinois and Leon E. Panetta, Barbara Boxer, Nancy Pelosi and Mr. Miller, all of California.
In hindsight, several of Mr. Downey's colleagues said that his relocation to Washington might have set the stage for his defeat. "I really think that matters," said one representative, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "You by nature stay in touch more if you live in your district. You live in Washington, you just get sucked into Washington."
In fact, it was sometime in the mid-1980's that Frank R. Jones, a Republican official who is now supervisor of Islip, first began hearing complaints about Mr. Downey. "He had good constituent service, he absolutely did -- for the first 10 or 12 years," he said. "After that, real or perceived, it began to fall off. I had a fellow, a staunch Democrat, who said to me, 'You know, I've had innumerable meetings with Congressman Downey and he was always late.' "
By the late 1980's, Mr. Downey had reached the height of his legislative powers as an influential member of Ways and Means Committee and the Select Committee on Aging.
He also became acting-chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources after Representative Harold E. Ford, a Tennessee Democrat, fell under the cloud of an indictment. And there he became one of the lead legislators in the Congress on welfare policy and child care. On an issue of key concern to Long Island, he also led the effort that prolonged the life of Grumman's F-14 fighter plane for three years.
But in 1990, just before an election, Mr. Downey was one of many members of the Ways and Means Committee caught by hidden cameras on ABC's "Prime Time Live" at a junket in Barbados, jet-skiing in a bathing suit and playing football on a beach. He apologized to his constituents and said he had made a mistake. And he was re-elected.
 
'Vulnerable This Year'
 But Republicans noted that he had won with only 56 percent of the vote against an weak opponent. It was, said Suffolk Republican leader Howard C. DeMartini, "the early warning signal that Downey would be vulnerable this year."
Mr. Downey also saw the trouble signs. "I had a sense that things were very wrong in 1990," he said in an interview. "I have all these diary notes about this: You've got to get to work. You've got to work a little harder." He said he started serving his district with renewed vigor, returning to Long Island one out of every three days in 1991 and every other day in 1992.
Then the House bank scandal struck at a time when Long Island was in deep recession. It was bad enough that Mr. Downey had overdrafts on 151 checks totaling $83,000. It was worse still that Mrs. Downey, who had a patronage job working for the House sergeant-at-arms, had been hired on a budget line that listed her job title as auditor of the House bank.
Rick Lazio, a 34-year-old two-term Suffolk County legislator, built his campaign against Mr. Downey around the bank scandal and Barbados trip, in a race that was strikingly reminiscent to Mr. Downey's own battle 18 years ago against an entrenched incumbent.
 
Anger Toward Congress
 Mr. Lazio sent out a last-minute blitz of direct mail playing on the popular resentment of Congress. One flier offered "Tom Downey's Limousine Liberal guide to surviving the recession," a 10-point primer.
"Tough times on Long Island getting you down?" it asked. "Move to Washington. Rent out your multiple-family Long Island home (one of three homes he owns); put your children in private school in Virginia." That was just point No. 1.
Mr. Downey was thrown on the defensive, forced to invite voters to drop by his two-family house in Amityville to prove he still had a place to live on Long Island. "I live on Long Island, I have lived here all my life," he said in a televised debate. "If you have any doubt, come to 155 Cedar Street where I have lived for 13 years."
Mr. Lazio, a moderate pro-choice Republican, offered a refreshing gee-whiz quality, as evidenced in his reflections on the race a few days after victory. "There's something bigger than how powerful you are, how many powerful people you know and whether you get invited to powerful cocktails parties," he said. Of the voters, he added, "what they want is to say, 'I know him. He goes to the same diner I go to.' "
Election Day was bittersweet. The Democrats had recaptured the White House and Washington hung on the threshold of generational change. Mr. Downey's close friend, Al Gore, had become Vice President-elect. It should have been Mr. Downey's time; he still so young at just 43 and yet with nearly two decades of Congressional seniority.
But instead, he spent election night consoling his children about his defeat and telling them they should be happy for the victory of Bill Clinton. The next day he drove back to Washington and strove to put the best face on things. "This has been -- all losers must have this sense -- this has been a wonderful 18 years," he said. "That's how I'd prefer to remember it."
 
'No Tom Downey'
 He showed a small hint of his old sharp tongue, when asked if he had the feeling that he had been beaten by a new Tom Downey. "I know Tom Downey, and he's no Tom Downey," he said of Mr. Lazio. "I'm sure there's some irony in all of this, but it's lost on me at the moment."
Across the country, Mr. Downey's House colleagues raged that Long Island's voters had not appreciated Mr. Downey as they had. "This is a person who is extremely bright, very talented in knowing the possibilities of government," said Representative Pelosi. "He was masterful at shaping legislation and he was very respected." She added, "It's hard to understand why there wasn't a recognition of his value in his district."
But at the West Islip firehouse, near Mr. Downey's campaign headquarters, the dispatcher, Mel Lauber, said he had voted against Mr. Downey although he had supported him in the past. "I didn't like the idea of rubber checks," he said, "and I didn't like the idea of him parading around on vacation on taxpayers' money." All that puzzled him was why so few other Congressional incumbents had fallen: "I thought they wanted a clean Congress."

HEADLINE: A Republican Message That Roiled the Waters;
Just Who Makes Jobs?

 BODY:
President-elect Clinton has said that an economic stimulus program, including money for new roads and other public works projects, s at the top of his agenda. As an indication of how dominant an issue the economy was in the Nov. 2 elections, readers are continuing to respond very strongly to "The Beauty of Indexing Capital Gains" (Viewpoints, Oct. 25) by Theodore J. Forstmann, national co-chairman of the Bush-Quayle re-election campaign. Some of their letters follow.
To the Editor: 
 No one is as blind as those who will not see, as Mr. Forstmann's love song to subsidizing investors demonstrates again.
"New jobs are not created by the government or big corporations," he announces. Governments employ about 27 percent of America's work force. Does Mr. Forstmann believe small entrepreneurs created those jobs?
If government builds a school or a road or a dam, who "creates" the jobs of the men and women who do the construction and staff the facility when it is finished?
Many of our mightiest industries got started with government as a partner. Government land paid for our railroads. The government subsidized airlines with lucrative mail contracts when interstate air travel was in its infancy and with government-designed airplanes later.
If Mr. Forstmann were not so caught up in the tendrils of latter-day Republican orthodoxy, he might note that government, America's largest industry, is in a deep recession, laying off workers and cutting their salaries. That government recession in no small measure is attributable to Mr. Forstmann's masters, who have been in charge and bad-mouthing the product (government services of all kinds) for so long that the customer-taxpayers won't buy any more.
How long would a General Motors president who detested cars, and told customers they should abandon them, last?
We've suffered too long from Forstmann-Bush myopia. Out, out, you nitwits! It's time we had a President who believes in the business he runs, that government is important enough to pay for and make effective again.
 
GEORGE B. DRIESEN
Chevy Chase, Md., Oct. 25

HEADLINE: About Those Stats on Women's Pay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Women's Progress Stalled? Just Not So" (Oct. 18) confirms that while the glass ceiling is still a popular notion and a reality for some, it is less of a barrier than once believed. 
 I wish the writer had looked beyond the numbers, however, and focused on a subtle but more significant issue; progress should be measured not by salary levels or job titles but by what women are doing from their positions of leadership to influence their community's social and economic future.
Many accomplished women in cities across the country have emerged as powerful and effective leaders in their companies, trade associations, chambers of commerce and union halls.
These women are bringing energy, talents and vision to numerous economic and civic enterprises, working in close partnership with their male peers. They are not only influencing their community's economic future, but have also become important role models for younger women.
 
DAWN-MARIE DRISCOLL
Cape Coral, Fla., Oct. 19, 1992

LENGTH: 706 words

HEADLINE: An Incomplete President

 BODY:
Angry Republicans point fingers in every direction to account for President Bush's defeat. Some blame an unfortunate turn in the business cycle from which no President could have escaped. Others blame bad advice from passive economic strategists, the nasty convention in Houston, his unaccountably late and lame campaign.
All true, but the main reason for George Bush's precipitous fall from political grace was George Bush himself. 
 Even after four years as President and a quarter-century in public life, Mr. Bush remains an oddly bifurcated, incomplete figure. He spent the better part of his life preparing for the White House -- and fate dealt him probably the strongest hand in foreign affairs ever awarded a new President.
For the most part, he played that hand cleverly and energetically. But on the home front he was just the reverse, clumsy and irresolute. As the cold war receded, his domestic agenda was exposed as little more than a list of talking points.
His political persona was no less baffling. Capable of kindness and courage, the amiable and well-bred President turned into something quite different on the campaign trail, pinched and shrill.
In the end, voters saw a Presidency without cogency and a President without credibility. His approval rating last May wavered between 35 and 39 percent. His share of the vote total Tuesday was 38 percent.
So hapless was Mr. Bush's last year that it's easy to forget some early accomplishments. He began smartly, moving quickly to end the endless ideological combat of the Reagan years. He broke cleanly with his indifferent predecessor on important environmental issues, faced up to the savings and loan scandal and offered creative new approaches to third world debt.
Of his diplomatic successes, three stand out. Confronted early in his tenure by a crippling debate over Nicaragua, he cut a deal with Congress to send humanitarian but not military aid to the contras -- removing in one stroke an issue that had paralyzed Mr. Reagan's relationship with Capitol Hill.
His ability to orchestrate a collective global response to Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf was a greater triumph still. And he deserves great credit for nurturing the continuing peace talks between Arabs and Israelis.
Behind all three successes lay a willingness to muster a principled explanation of his objectives and to exercise the power of his office to achieve them. But on matters closer to home, Mr. Bush vacated the bully pulpit, subcontracting domestic policy to his advisers and leaving the impression that he really didn't care.
Even when he did something that was both essential and courageous -- like reversing his "no new taxes" pledge of 1988 to win a budget agreement in 1990 -- he failed to defend it coherently. Worse, in that case, he apologized for it.
Mr. Bush did get bad advice, especially from those who kept telling him that the economy would turn around. But his own passivity made him vulnerable to that advice. Last January, given a last big chance to establish his economic management, he came up empty. His State of the Union rhetoric was strong: "I look at hard times and make this vow: This will not stand." His programs were pallid.
Mr. Bush did devote time and energy to one domestic cause: romancing the right wing of his party, especially on abortion, civil rights and Supreme Court appointments. Yet it gained him little. For all his supplicatory gestures, the right always suspected him to be an Establishment Republican at heart.
Meantime, his Brahmin friends -- economic conservatives with a social conscience -- felt betrayed by his positions on individual rights and his bargains with the cultural right. Of these, the most exasperating was his willingness to cede the party's 1992 platform, and the Houston stage, to Pat Buchanan's and Pat Robertson's exclusionary anger.
Perhaps, in a second term, freed from the exigencies of politics and popularity, George Bush might have found a clearer sense of direction. Perhaps history will judge him, and his diplomatic record especially, more kindly than the voters did last Tuesday.
The sad judgment for now, however, is that he sailed well at the start, then lost his compass.

HEADLINE: Help the Cities First

SERIES: BILL' LIST: These are the first articles in a occasional series commenting on ideas and issues facing the new Clinton Administration.

BYLINE: By Edmund G. Brown Jr.; Edmund G. Brown Jr., Governor of California from 1974 to 1982, was a 1992 Democratic Presidential candidate.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Dear Mr. President-elect:
Since our last meeting, you have been besieged by many voices. Mine will continue to be for those who have grown silent because they have lost their jobs, because they are poor or because they have no hope. For them, stand and deliver. 
 The specter of "Blade Runner" haunts our cities as global trade and technology separate the professionals at the top from the growing third world of welfare and poverty wages at the bottom. It is ripping apart our social and civic fabric.
This Great Urban Crisis is just as much a threat to our society as the Great Depression. Our second-largest city would not have exploded in burning and insurrection if something was not profoundly wrong. In community after community, the intolerable conditions are worsening: burnt-out buildings, rubble strewn about as small children play nearby, homeless lying in doorways.
This is why the nation's mayors marched on Washington and pleaded all year for their seven-point $35 billion program of urban aid. We sat there together in New York City and you promised them face to face that you would hear their plea.
Many pundits and advisers are now coming forward to tell you to focus on policies to stimulate economic growth and reduce the deficit. That is important. Yet, let me warn you, economic growth by itself will not diminish the crisis tearing at the country.
Look at the facts: since 1973, our national income per capita rose 28 percent while weekly paychecks fell 18 percent. In the past decade alone, the number of young people working full time but paid below the official poverty line doubled. Perversely, the number of jobs and the size of the G.N.P. increased but in ways that dangerously widened the gap between those doing well and those millions of other Americans who are daily thrust into a twilight zone of economic hardship. This growing inequality and social injustice must be the first priority of your Administration.
During the campaign, you repeatedly called attention to the loss of "high-wage jobs" and set forth a plan for "putting people first." In that strategy, you have the elements of a bold and Rooseveltian response. Now you must redeem those campaign promises and pave the way for an entirely different type of economic recovery -- one that is grounded in social justice rather than that "trickle down" you condemned.
More than anything, people are looking for something real. That is why you need to take action right away -- before you are inaugurated.
Call in the mayors this month and tell them you embrace their seven-point agenda completely. During the California primary, you said, "We will find the money." Follow through on your pledge to extend the Earned Income Tax credit to all working families so that they no longer fall below the official poverty level. And ask Congress to raise the minimum wage a dollar in addition to your promise to index it for inflation. These two actions alone would immediately lift up the spirits of those struggling at the very bottom of our society.
Inaugurate your Youth Opportunity Corps, National Service Trust Fund and Community Service jobs. As a start, enroll in the first year at least as many people as have been and will be mustered out of the military. Roosevelt established the Works Projects Administration, the Civilian Conservation Corps and a National Youth Administration. There's your $20 billion model -- anything less is politics.
I implore you to block the North American free-trade agreement until you have locked in iron-tight protections for American wage and environmental standards.
Health care, education, tax and campaign reform come next. But first, take care of the core. Listen to the desperate. Rise above the politics of the past. Rise to the trust invested in you.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Death After Police Beating Inspires Fear in Detroit

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 7

 BODY:
All day, in the cold and the swirling snow, cars carrying people like Florence Frazier and her grandchildren pulled up to the curb in front of a ramshackle two-story building.
"Is this where they killed him?" Mrs. Frazier's 9-year-old grandson, Lawrence Newell, asked today. 
 "Yes," she said, the cold wind and hard facts making her eyes water.
On Thursday night, a 35-year-old, unemployed black man, Malice Green, was beaten to death by police officers here on Warren Avenue on the city's west side after being stopped on suspicion of a drug violation.
Violence is nothing new near the avenue of crumbling buildings, but the death of Mr. Green has shaken the city and turned the curb where he died into a shrine of anger, tears and betrayal.
 
'People Are Numb'
 People here said this was not supposed to happen in this overwhelmingly black city, where the 4,000-person Police Department is more than half black and where Mayor Coleman A. Young has long stressed making the force sensitive to the community.
But the two officers suspected of the killing are white, longtime members of department with reputations for toughness.
"People are numb," Mrs. Frazier said. "It's like who do you lash out at? Who can you trust? I'm having a hard time dealing with another Rodney King incident where my grandson lives, where my son lives. It could have been them."
Her grandson is now scared of the police. "One day," he said, "it will probably be me."
The sharp similarities between the incident and the beating of a black motorist, Rodney G. King, in Los Angeles last year have made city officials and neighborhood advocates nervous. It was the acquittal of four officers in that case that led to rioting in Los Angeles last spring.
What happened exactly and why is still unclear. But the city and the police department have moved quickly to begin an investigation and to maintain calm.
 
'This Is a Dream'
 The police Chief, Stanley Knox, on Friday ordered the two white plainclothes officers, Larry Nevers, 52, and Walter Budzyn, 47, suspended without pay. He also suspended four white officers and one black sergeant who are believed to have seen the beating.
The Detroit Free Press today quoted Officer Nevers as saying: "I must've done something wrong, a guy died. If I can ever sleep again I'm going to wake up and say this is a dream, it didn't happen, it didn't happen."
But he added, "Nobody knows what it's like out there."
Paul Hubbard, the president of New Detroit Inc., an organization formed to rebuild the city after the 1967 riots, said the Chief's quick actions have helped maintain calm.
"The community stayed cool because they felt these officers would be put into the criminal justice system," Mr. Hubbard said. "If the Chief had not immediately taken action, we may have had a problem."
 
Something in His Hand
 A senior police official said the incident began about 10:30 P.M., when Mr. Green dropped a friend off in front of the run-down building, which the police said is a crack house. Moments later, Mr. Green was stopped by Officers Nevers and Budzyn.
When they asked Mr. Green for his driver's license, he reached into his glove compartment, then appeared to hold something in his hand. One of the officers asked him to drop it. Mr. Green did not and the officers began hitting him on the hands with their 3-pound flashlights, the official said.
The struggle quickly escalated and Mr. Green was dragged out of the car. The beating continued as backup police units arrived, and at least one other officer also struck Mr. Green, the official said.
Mr. Green was taken to Detroit Receiving Hospital where he was pronounced dead on arrival about 11 P.M.
It is unclear what, if anything, Mr. Green had in his hand. Later, four pieces of crack cocaine were turned in as evidence by one of the officers.
Mr. Green spent most of his life in Detroit and had no police record there. His sister, Sherry Green, said he worked for a time in a steel mill near Chicago. At the time of his death he was preparing to move to North Carolina where his wife lives.
Mr. Green's mother, Patricia, said her son "was a gentle man."
Mrs. Green said she had driven by the curb twice since he died. One time she stopped and got out.
"His blood was still in the street," she said. "It was like somebody had run over a cow. I don't think he even had a good bone left in his body after they got through beating him."
Today, the blood had been covered with sand, but bloody rags were still visible and so was anger.
"The neighborhood is upset," said Dossa Merchant, 55. "People, young people, talking about burning again like they did before unless something is done about it. They're very serious."
Clayton Smith, a Baptist minister, walked by carrying his daughter. His older children had asked him to bring them to the curb.
"I thought we had made it a little further than this as a city and a country," Mr. Smith said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The beating death of Malice Green by Detroit police officers on Thursday has been compared to the beating of Rodney G. King in Los Angeles. Patricia Ann Green, the victim's mother, held a photo of her son on Friday at her home. Seven officers have been suspended. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: European Is Hopeful Trade War Can Be Averted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HATFIELD, England, Nov. 7

 BODY:
The European Community's chief trade negotiator said today that he was confident that Europe and the United States could settle a dispute over farm subsidies that threatens to turn into a trade war. But France continued to plan for possible retaliation.
The community's Trade Commissioner, Frans Andriessen, speaking after a two-day meeting of trade ministers from the 12 community countries, said he had no plans to meet with negotiators from the United States. But he said further developments could come on Monday after a meeting of community foreign ministers.. 
 Mr. Andriessen said he was optimistic that an agreement could be reached by Dec. 6, the day that Washington has threatened to impose 200 percent tariffs on some European products, mainly white wine.
Germany's Economics Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, who attended the meeting of trade officials outside London, said Prime Minister John Major of Britain, President Bush and the president of the European Commission, Jacques Delors, should meet if the trade talks fail.
Talks between the United States and the community broke down on Tuesday in Chicago, and on Thursday the United States fired the first salvo in what could become a trade war. Washington said it would impose the punitive tariffs within 30 days on $300 million worth of French wines and other imports if the community refused to reduce payments to farmers.
France, Europe's biggest farm producer, opposes efforts to cut agriculture payments to the extent demanded by the United States. French farmers are viewed as a powerful constituency, and France's Socialist Government is worried about how the party will fare in legislative elections in March.
The farm subsidy dispute is also the main obstacle delaying a 105-nation accord on liberalizing world trade sponsored by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT. The organization has called an emergency meeting for Tuesday in Geneva, where it is based. Britain, Germany, the Netherlands and other nations have pleaded with the French for a compromise.
Dominique Strauss-Kahn, France's Industry and External Trade Minister, said his Government would not act for a month, but could demand retaliatory measures if the United States acted. In an interview in the weekly Journal du Dimanche, he said France would ask the community to start drawing up a list of potential American products on Monday. Excerpts from the interview were made available ahead of the paper's publication on Sunday.
Mr. Strauss-Kahn said that at least three other community nations -- Ireland, Belgium and Spain -- would support retaliation but that Germany and Britain opposed it, arguing that a global trade battle could further cripple recession-bound economies.
Trade between the United States and Europe amounts to roughly $200 billion each year, and a trade war could threaten hundreds of thousands of jobs on both sides of the Atlantic.
The United States Agriculture Secretary, Edward R. Madigan, told BBC radio today that the two sides remained far apart.
"I must have an honorable deal, a responsible deal and a deal that is going to be perceived as being fair to the entire world, and we are not anywhere near that," Mr. Madigan said.
Washington says the subsidies keep prices for European farm goods unfairly low and rob American farmers of export sales. France says deeper cuts could drive many of its small farmers out of business.
Despite the seeming firmness of both sides, Mr. Andriessen said: "I remain optimistic for two reasons. The first is that I think the differences in view, although not insubstantial, could be bridged. And secondly, because we are not entitled -- the commission, nor the United States -- to make a failure."
Mr. Major said Friday after meeting with Mr. Delors of the European Commission that they agreed the talks should resume "without delay."

HEADLINE: Jordan's King Urges Iraqis to Put an End To the Hussein Era

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 7

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan said today that Iraq was suffering badly under sanctions imposed by the United Nations and suggested it was time for Iraqis to end the Government of President Saddam Hussein and push for a democratic, pluralistic society.
Although the King did not specifically call for Iraqis to overthrow their President, he provided a bleak description of conditions in Iraq and an unusually caustic assessment of the man he long viewed as his friend and ally and actively supported during the Persian Gulf war and in its aftermath. The King did not directly refer to the Iraqi ruler by name. 
 "I think that the situation cannot last for very long in any event, and I think that there is every need for the Iraqi people themselves to put an end to it," the King said, speaking at his palace office in the capital.
He added that there was also a need "for all of us to see what can be done to see Iraq recover its territorial integrity and the unity of its people under conditions of freedom of choice and for them to be able to move ahead."
The King's remarks were a significant departure from his silence in recent months as the United States and other Western nations have stepped up pressure on Iraq, tightening economic sanctions, intensifying inspection missions and barring Iraqi aircraft from specific zones in northern and southern Iraq.
The remarks by the King could well be be a psychological blow to Mr. Hussein because Jordan is the last neighbor with which Iraq has a relationship. Over the last year, it has become increasingly clear to Jordanian decision makers that Iraq's strategic value as a major commercial outlet and a significant military power has evaporated under the weight of sanctions and military defeat.
Furthermore, senior Jordanian officials eager to bring about an Arab reconciliation that would benefit Jordan appreciate now that key Arab countries like Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia would not agree to include President Hussein's Government in a reconciled Arab world.
 Some in the West maintain that Mr. Hussein has been able to circumvent the sanctions and keep the country going, but the King's remarks seemed to give a totally opposite view. During the Persian Gulf war, the King was widely criticized in the West and by some Arab leaders for his sympathy toward Iraq.
King Hussein said he felt enormous sympathy for Iraqis because of their country's deteriorating situation.
Speaking of his onetime Iraqi allies, he added, "Some people may say I have no right to speak in this tone, but this is something I have felt very, very strongly, and I haven't hidden it from the Iraqi people."
 
Tells Jordan of Cancer
 He said he was speaking out because "one cannot look at the suffering of people, at the damage to an upcoming generation in terms of all their needs and the continuous deterioration of that country to the point where it has been turned gradually into a pre-industrial state."
King Hussein looked fit and relaxed in what was his first interview after his report to the nation on Thursday that he had undergone treatment for cancer at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., in September and that, although he had been cured, he would need further checkups.
The King's left ureter, a duct that carries urine from a kidney to the bladder, was found to be cancerous and it and a kidney were removed. He said today that he had recovered speedily.
"My health is fine, and they are thrilled that my progress since the surgery has been excellent," he said of his doctors. "I have been able to come back to work much quicker than anticipated before. It was quite a major surgery, but nevertheless I have done very well. I think the surgery was successful. They were optimistic they have dealt with the problem; however, it was their view that there should be regular checkups.
 
Sense of Urgency Noted
 The King also expressed optimism that the peace talks with Israel were progressing well.
He declined to give details of the agreement reached with the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, that the goal of the two countries is a formal peace treaty within the framework of a comprehensive Israeli-Arab settlement. The King described it as a positive development that Jordan planned to pursue in future talks.
"I have always been guardedly optimistic," the King said. "But I believe there is a sense of urgency there as there is here and there must be everywhere. Things are certainly moving, and hopefully in the right direction."
Offering indirect praise for Israel's recent negotiating stance, he added, "I think that we saw a sign that was very clear as far as I was concerned with the Israeli elections when the Israeli electorate decided on a change to move toward peace and commit toward it and this, in itself, is probably a major turning point or has been."
King Hussein warmly praised President Bush, describing him as a friend and predicting that the bitter Arab divisions engendered by the Persian Gulf war, which divided the Arab camp between supporters and opponents of Iraq, might soon come to an end with a summit meeting of Arab leaders.
The King said he had sent a congratulatory message to President-elect Bill Clinton but had not yet spoken to him. He added that he expected the new President to continue American involvement in the region and the peace talks because of the United States role as the "one and only superpower."
 
Important New Assessment
 The King's remarks were significant because of the widespread sentiment here that Iraq is putting up a valiant resistance to the accumulating hardships and that it can resist these pressures for an indefinite period.
Because of his friendship with the Iraqi leaders and the extensive network of ties between Jordanian and Iraqi business establishments, King Hussein's comments are likely to be taken as an important new assessment of a situation that is difficult for outsiders to evaluate.
The King emphasized that his vision of a future Iraq was one of a society that differed radically from the current one-party rule of President Hussein.
"What do we wish for Iraq? What we have always wished, a national reconciliation, pluralism, democracy, respect for human rights and then for the Iraqis to harness the tremendous assets that they have toward building a country that is stable and that has a place under the sun as it did in the past".
These comments, coming from one of the few Arab leaders to have instituted tentative measures of democratization here over the last three years, are likely to be seen in the Arab world as a challenge to other totalitarian regimes as well.
The Jordanian program of democratization, which the King said was continuing, encompassed the first free parliamentary elections here and a liberalization of press censorship.
Returning to his new theme of opposing dictatorships in the region, he mused that it "is such as pity that I have lived through this Arab nation to see time and again tragedies occur when people believe that life begins with them and as if it ends with them."
"This doesn't reflect upon them only but it reflects upon their people as well. That's where, hopefully, in the future, we will see greater democracy and greater power-sharing and therefore stability and continuity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I think that the situation cannot last for very long in any event, and I think that there is every need for the Iraqi people themselves to put an end to it," said King Hussein of Jordan yesterday, referring to Iraq's suffering under its current Government and economic sanctions. (Hanna Farrag for The New York Times) (pg. 20)

HEADLINE: Europe's State-Industry Ties: Successes, and Utter Failures

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 7

 BODY:
In 1969, a discussion began in Germany between the Government and industry about the development of a train without wheels, powered by electromagnets. After an investment of $1 billion of German taxpayers' money, the Transrapid train is now ready for use; its first route may be between the Orlando, Fla., airport and Disney World in 1996.
It is too early to say whether the Transrapid, which travels at 180 miles an hour, will be a commercial success. But the development of this relatively quiet, fast and ecologically desirable train illustrates the way in which governments and private companies have frequently worked together in Europe on innovative but costly industrial projects. 
 "This train was such a long-term development that it would not have been possible without public money," said Christian Rausch, an official at Thyssen Henschel, the leading company in the development of the train. "No private company could have carried the costs over 23 years."
 
The Question: Does It Work?
 With President-elect Bill Clinton talking admiringly about aspects of Europe's industrial policy and advocating a strengthened role for the Government in technological research and worker training, the question arises: Has European industrial policy worked, or has it largely consisted of the protection and financial support of businesses and projects that would have collapsed without Government money?
During the Reagan and Bush years there was little doubt in Washington as to the answer: European industrial policy was protectionism or worse.
In fact, the European record is distinctly mixed, with industrial successes and humiliating disasters in roughly equal measure. There was the Concorde, the British-French supersonic plane that was a commercial flop, and Airbus, the dynamic four-nation consortium that -- after receiving $26 billion in government money -- now has captured more than one-third of the world aircraft market.
The most centrally directed economy in Europe is in France, where about 33 percent of industry is under Government guidance. France is now widely regarded as having the Continent's strongest economy, with low inflation, a balanced budget, a big trade surplus and comparatively resilient growth.
"The Clinton victory shows that we were right not to fall into the dogmatic, laissez-faire craziness of the Reagan years," the Finance Minister of France, Michel Sapin, said in an interview. "We have always felt the state had a big role to play, even if that role could change."
France has indeed been modifying the Government's role in recent years, selling shares in some state companies, doing away with exchange controls and reducing central planning. Its shift has been in line with a marked change in European industrial policy over the last decade, as Europe's emerging single market has brought pressure for greater competitiveness.
"We have tried to use this old-fashioned expression -- industrial policy -- and fill it with new content," said Reinhard Buscher, a senior official of the European Commuity's Executive Commission in Brussels. "The old style of subsidies, quotas, insistence on local content and other protective measures is over and finished. There is no alternative to being competitive, but you can set guidelines and policies to encourage that."
The priorities of the emerging European policy sound remarkably like "Clintonomics": professional training, technological research and development, and the coordinated establishment of ambitious public targets in areas like transport, the environment and telecommunications, combined with fiscal incentives and other measures to encourage industries in these sectors to invest.
What seems to have been widely recognized in Europe is that industrial policy has a role to play in setting broad guidelines, in modernizing core industries and in financing certain long-term projects of special public interest, but that it should not get involved in bailing out losers.
 
Not Following Japan
 It is also clear that Europe has rejected the model of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which sets targets for certain key sectors. Thus there has been no centrally coordinated attempt to streamline the troubled auto or computer sectors by forcing mergers that would probably make sound business sense.
As a whole, the current policies are described as "horizontal," to distinguish them from the old "vertical" practice of pouring money into one particular industrial sector.
One example is the $180 billion high-speed train network being built around Europe, known as the T.G.V., for Train a Grande Vitesse, or very fast train. This project, unrelated to Germany's magnetic train, is being coordinated and financially backed by the European Community.
Having begun as separate developments in different countries, each with a different standard, the network is now being standardized and extended across borders. Smaller countries, like Belgium, get hundreds of millions of dollars from the Community's $85.8 billion annual budget to build their sections of a project that would otherwise be financially impossible for them.
"European industry will clearly benefit both directly from the construction and later from the network that will result," said Jean Hourcade, an official overseeing the project at the European Commission.
 
Frictions Over Trade
 European subsidies are, of course, a matter of dispute in trade relations between Europe and the United States. Just this week, Washington imposed punitive tariffs on white wine and other products from Europe, arguing that European oilseed subsidies unfairly denied markets to American farmers. And the American aircraft industry has long argued that Airbus can compete unfairly because of the subsidies it receives.
European officials counter that the American military-industrial complex has for decades acted as a hidden source of subsidies for a range of industries, serving as the chief vehicle of an industrial policy that was not openly declared. They also say that American farmers receive as many subsidies as those working the land in Europe.
For every success like the T.G.V., however, there is a skeleton in Europe's industrial closet. The European computer industry has been piling up huge losses in recent years and, in some instances, various national governments have continued to pour money into uncompetitive enterprises. They contend that this is sound industrial policy.
The worst offender has been France, where the state-owned computer maker Groupe Bull S.A. has lost more than $1.5 billion in the last two years alone. One change of strategy has followed another, but there is as yet no sign of the company's breaking even. Still, this year the European Commission approved a $1.3 billion subsidy from the French Government to the company in the hope that it would soon return to profit.
 
Supporting French Computers
 "Policy at Bull has not been an error, because France still has a computer industry, and that is vital," the Industry Minister of France, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said. "Our problems have not been any different from a private company like Siemens, because there is a worldwide crisis in the sector."
Yet the French policy at Bull smacks of the approach that has left Europe littered with perennially unprofitable industries in coal, steel, shipbuilding and other lines, all sustained by government money.
On another front, the French Government last year decided to merge the loss-plagued consumer electronics and semiconductor activities of Thomson with the profitable nonmilitary operations of its Atomic Energy Commission. Both entities are owned by the state, and what France seemed to be doing was fusing a highly successful example of industrial policy -- the Atomic Energy Commission's 56 nuclear plants provide more than 80 percent of France's electricity -- with a struggling and unrelated state industry, merely to shore up the latter.
"It was an example of the old and bad style of interventionist industrial policy," said Mr. Buscher of the European Commission. France argued that the merger would allow Thomson and the agency to draw from each other's research activities.
Similarly, the European Community has insisted on forging ahead with its own analog system for high-definition television -- a technology that provides picture clarity similar to that of film. Almost all industry analysts believe the American digital system is superior and should eventually be adopted worldwide. Here again, industrial policy looks suspiciously like protectionism.
But over all, it seems that Europe's integration is producing a steady modernization of the concept of industrial policy. And it is this new, improved version, based largely on German practice, that inspires Mr. Clinton and his advisers.
"There is certainly a Continental European platform to Mr. Clinton's agenda, when it comes to the retraining of workers, education programs, infrastructure networks and a stronger safety net," said David Hale, the chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, who has contacts with many of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers. "But nobody's talking about subsidizing industry or creating state industries."
 
Creating a Compromise
 Over all, as the European Community has come together, it seems that the clash of the more free-market cultures, like Britain and the Netherlands, with the more directed economies, like those of France and Italy, has defined the shifts in development of industrial policy and shaped a compromise.
Roughly at the halfway point stands Germany, whose economy has been basically free market but has allowed the state to play a role in promoting the general good.
"When we think there is an industrial project that is beyond the financial horizon of private companies, like the magnetic train, but that can bring real social benefits, we will back it," said Walter Moenig, spokesman for the German Research and Development Ministry, which has an annual budget of $6.3 billion.
But criteria are strict, and a recent discussion at the ministry on whether to put Government money into developing the next generation of microchips ended with a rejection because it was felt private industry had the means to do so.
