HEADLINE: 2 Reports Find Wide Abuses by India in Kashmir

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
A new Indian Government drive on separatists in the Kashmir Valley has resulted in dozens of killings of suspected militants by military forces and the widespread terrorizing of civilians, according to two American human-rights organizations that sent representatives to the area in October.
A military campaign called Operation Tiger, which began in August, has also resulted in the sexual abuse and murder of noncombatants, a preliminary report from Asia Watch and Physicians for Human Rights concludes. It says that patients are dragged from hospital beds and medical staff detained and assaulted in raids. 
"Detainees are routinely subjected to severe and prolonged beatings, electric shock and other forms of torture," the report says. "The Asia Watch-P.H.R. team documented a number of cases of renal failure caused by the extensive use of the roller torture treatment, which crushes the muscle tissue and releases toxins, which cause serious, and sometimes fatal, damage to the kidneys."
A final version of the report will be published before the end of the year, according to Asia Watch.
An armed rebellion has been growing in the Kashmir Valley since 1989, prompting harsh retaliatory measures from New Delhi, which accuses Pakistan of fomenting terrorism in the disputed territory. Kashmir has been under martial law since 1990, with all civil rights suspended and troops empowered to shoot on sight during curfews.
Indian officials argue that much of the violence in the region is caused by the militants and that all allegations of military abuses are investigated. They say that human-rights groups do not adequately condemn violence by militants.
Kashmiris are predominantly Muslim, and most Indians are Hindu, but the dispute is not a religious one. It has its roots in political and economic alienation, residents of the valley say. The separatists have wide middle-class support as well as the backing of virtually all political factions in neighboring Pakistan, which has controlled another part of the former princely state of Kashmir since 1947.
The State Department's 1991 human-right reports said that while militants also were responsible for abuses, there was evidence that troops were killing suspects and detainees.
"Little is done to punish those responsible for extrajudicial killing," the State Department said.
It also found official abuses in Punjab state, where Sikhs are fighting New Delhi.
Although the Indian Government bars official visits to Kashmir by international rights organizations, representatives from Asia Watch and Physicians for Human Rights were able to travel in the valley as tourists for a week, interviewing victims or relatives of security operations in Srinagar, the Kashmiri summer capital, and other towns.
"In one case, four students who were arrested during a search operation on Oct. 14 in the Dal Gate area of Srinagar were shot dead that night and their bodies handed over to the families the next day," according to the preliminary report made available to The New York Times. "The security forces also broke up peaceful protests against these killings by beating, tear-gassing and shooting demonstrators."
Among other incidents investigated by the two organizations' representatives were these:
On Oct. 1, after an attack by militants on a patrol near the village of Bathekut, in which one soldier died, troops "rampaged through the village, killing 10 villagers, raping 4 women and burning houses and grain stores."
On Oct. 15, a man and woman were burned alive in the town of Badsagam after Border Security Forces troops locked them in their shop and set fire to it.
In a search operation by an army unit near Shopian, also on Oct. 15, eight women and an 11-year-old girl were raped, the human-rights groups were told.
"Throughout the conflict, the Indian Army and other security forces in Kashmir continued to exhibit blatant disregard for international norms of medical neutrality," the report says.

HEADLINE: Cuban Says Next Chief Shouldn't Be an Exile

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
A young leader of Cuba's human rights movement on his first visit to the United States says a new generation of Cubans looking toward a more democratic future wants to choose a national leader from within their society, not from among the exiles in Miami.
In what amounted to a message to those exiles who might be positioning themselves for political power after Fidel Castro leaves the scene, the rights leader, Sebastian Arcos Cazabon, said at a news conference on Friday that his contemporaries "want mostly economic support from Miami." 
 "But they know they will have to choose their leaders from inside," he said. Mr. Arcos, 31 years old, who is active in the Cuban Committee for Human Rights, added that a democratic election would and should be won by a Cuban citizen.
"In Cuba, the need for change is so overwhelming that everyone is thinking about the future," he said.
Neither the supporters of Mr. Castro nor his longtime adversaries seem relevant to a new post-cold-war era, Mr. Arcos has told his American hosts, according to Frank Calzon, Washington director of Freedom House, the human-rights organization. Mr. Calzon, who was born in Cuba, broke several years ago with the Cuban American Foundation of Jorge Mas Canosa, the Miami exiles' most powerful and most conservative leader.
"Young people no longer care about 1959 and the revolution, an important time to both the exiles and the supporters of Castro," Mr. Calzon said.
Mr. Arcos, who had been applying since 1986 to leave Cuba legally with the intention of returning, is a member of a prominent Cuban family that first backed the Castro revolution but has moved into opposition over the years.
His father, Sebastian Arcos Bergnes, who joined Mr. Castro in the 1953 attack on the Moncada Barracks, a milestone of the revolution, later served an Ambassador for the Castro Government in Europe.
A few weeks ago he was sentenced to four years and eight months in prison on charges of disseminating enemy propaganda. The elder Mr. Arcos had been communicating with the United Nations and its special human rights rapporteur for Cuba. At his trial, Mr. Arcos was accused of accepting money from the United States National Endowment for Democracy, an accusation his son denied.
Gustavo Arcos Bergnes, the elder Mr. Arcos's brother and general secretary of the Cuban Committee for Human Rights, is widely considered a potential political opposition leader if Cuba's closed Communist system is opened to other parties.
The younger Mr. Arcos, who does not know why he was permitted to make this trip abroad, said on Friday that the Cuban human rights and democracy movements were seeking support from the international community beyond the United States, Mr. Castro's traditional foe. He said that while Latin American presidents had apparently spoken to Mr. Castro privately about political liberalization, they would have to say so publicly to have an effect on the Communist leadership.
Facing an economic crisis so severe that many Cubans are reduced to one daily meal of beans, rice and eggs, Mr. Castro has apparently decided not to debate the international human rights organizations, Mr. Arcos said. The Cuban leader has decided instead to try to isolate Cuba by curtailing international direct telephone communications and stepping up interceptions of local calls, making it difficult for local human rights groups to collect information and send it abroad.
Mr. Arcos said that despite a new wave of arrests and harassment over the last year, human rights organizations are growing in Cuba and spreading from the intellectual circle of Havana to small towns throughout the island. "Our leaders are mostly older people who fought against Batista," Mr. Arcos said. "We have intellectuals, even professors of Marxism."
Young Cubans of both African and European descent are now joining the ranks, he said, carrying the movement beyond Havana and those "who understand politics."

HEADLINE: RUSSIANS PLANNING TO CONTINUE USING FAULTED REACTORS

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 6

 BODY:
Senior Russian nuclear officials have told a watchdog group of Western experts that Russia's notorious graphite-core nuclear reactors -- the kind that blew up at Chernobyl in 1986 -- will go on operating indefinitely. If the West wants to make them safer, it can help to pay for improvements, but in any case, the reactors will not be shut down.
The official United States position on these reactors has strongly opposed their continued operation, and has sought to discourage or bar financing of measures that would prolong the reactors' lives. 
 But American and European technical experts acknowledged at the meeting of the watchdog group this week that this position is unrealistic, and that the former Communist countries using the reactors should get all the help the West can afford, since the reactors are essential to the faltering economies of Russia, Ukraine and the Baltic countries.
 
Nuclear Experts Meet
 At the meeting sponsored by the United Nations International Atomic Energy Agency that ended here on Thursday, nuclear experts from nine Western countries conferred with senior nuclear power officials of the former Soviet Union on the safety of Soviet reactors of the Chernobyl type.
Of 62 Soviet-designed reactors operating in the former Soviet republics and Eastern Europe, 47 are pressurized-water reactors similar in principle to most American types. American experts believe that although some of the older pressurized-water reactors could be made reasonably safe, all 15 of the Chernobyl-style reactors, called R.B.M.K.'s, should be scrapped without delay.
The R.B.M.K.'s are seen as threats not only to their operating crews and nearby communities, but also to much of Western Europe. Millions of Europeans were exposed to fallout from the Chernobyl disaster, possibly suffering long-term health effects, and many Western experts believe that it could happen again.
 
Larger Stakes Seen
 Moreover, the future of nuclear energy itself could be at stake. "All of us here are acutely aware "that another serious nuclear accident could doom nuclear power everywhere, with immense economic consequences for many nations," said Dr. James Guppy of Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.
Realizing that it is unrealistic to expect the R.B.M.K.'s to be shut down in the near future, organizers called this week's meeting to review Russian documentation that significant steps have been taken or are planned by Russian administrators to make the reactors safer. Although neither the Atomic Energy Agency nor the experts it invited to the meeting have regulatory authority over the Russian reactors, their opinions carry weight with international lending agencies from which the Commonwealth of Independent States is seeking assistance. Some of these agencies insist on enhancement of nuclear power plant safety as a condition for granting credit to the commonwealth.
Western experts who spent the week reviewing mountains of Russian technical reports and data were impressed by the scope of measures adopted or in progress to enhance the safety of R.B.M.K.'s.
Some of the improvements adopted by the Russian engineers seemed almost ridiculously simple. One change was in the "scram" button used in the reactors -- the button that stops the reactor in an emergency. Before Chernobyl, an operator had to keep his finger on this red button for up to a minute to complete the reactor shutdown, but now the scram is completed by just pushing the button and releasing it.
The Western engineers "applauded" this change, as they did scores of others, including a change in the enrichment of the uranium fuel to reduce the chance of a runaway chain reaction. The Russians explained that they had also drastically modified the design of R.B.M.K. control rods -- which, when inserted into a reactor core, slow and stop the reaction.
But the consensus of Western experts was that the R.B.M.K. (for Reactor, Big Power, Channel Type in Russian) has inherent design flaws, and probably never can be made as safe as the best Western reactors.
 
Disagreement
Internal Disputes In Ex-Soviet Union
 The Russians sharply disagreed. The newest and safest versions of the R.B.M.K. are on a par with the most reliable reactors in the West, they said, and have some significant advantages over Western counterparts.
"We have had 40 years' experience with these reactors," said Dr. Eugene O. Adamov, who, as chairman of Russia's Research and Development Institute of Power Engineering, is his country's top nuclear-power official.
"Like your Western reactors," he said in an interview, "our oldest ones are the least safe. But development is an evolutionary process, and our newest R.B.M.K. designs, we believe, are the safest and best reactors in the world. We certainly intend to pursue R.B.M.K. development."
The people and political leaders of the former Soviet Union do not necessarily share Dr. Adamov's enthusiasm for the reactors. The Ukrainian Parliament has ruled that next year at the latest, the functioning reactors at Chernobyl must be shut down, along with Chernobyl's Unit 4, which has been buried in concrete since it blew up in 1986, and Unit 2, which closed down last year after a very dangerous fire.
But the Ukrainian Government faces problems far more pressing then nuclear safety. On Thursday, Prime Minister Leonid Kuchma told reporters in Kiev that if his nation could not quickly stabilize its economy, "we will face a major social explosion." More than 25 percent of the Ukraine's electricity is nuclear -- some of it from Chernobyl's two surviving reactors -- and the country could ill afford the loss of power.
"Chernobyl's two remaining reactors could safely continue indefinitely," Dr. Adamov said. "The decision to close them was political, not technical."
 
The West
Foreign Critics Show Anxiety
 Dr. Ivan Selin, director of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, is among the many foreign critics of the R.B.M.K. toward whom Dr. Adamov addressed some of his comments.
"Selin told me when he visited us that he just doesn't like R.B.M.K. reactors on principle," Dr. Adamov said, "but that's like saying you don't like the looks of a woman. It's an emotional reaction, not a scientific assessment. The R.B.M.K. is a type of reactor that is not understood in the West, and we can't explain all the technical details of the R.B.M.K. to your officials overnight.
"It's true that we need help from the West, especially in the form of trade, but instead you've been sending us lawyers who come just to condemn our reactors," Dr. Adamov said.
To emphasize his faith in the R.B.M.K. -- including the reactors at Chernobyl -- Dr. Adamov invited the entire group meeting here to reconvene in Chernobyl next February.
The affection of Russian nuclear officials for the reactor causes considerable anxiety to many Europeans who might be downwind of radioactive fallout from a future disaster. Sweden in particular, where much of Chernobyl's fallout landed in 1986, is investigating the safety of the reactors on its own, and is expected to issue a detailed report next spring. Many Scandinavians are fearful of some new R.B.M.K. accident, like the one last March at the Sosnovy Bor plant near St. Petersburg (which leaked radioactive gases), or at the Ignalina plant in Lithuania (the largest of all R.B.M.K. plants) which has had a series of minor accidents -- or at Chernobyl itself, where contamination by radioactive debris and operating problems persist.
Moreover, despite many recent improvements in the reactor, Western experts have decided that this type of reactor is even more inherently dangerous than they were led to believe during the first few years following the Chernobyl disaster.
Just after the Chernobyl accident, Soviet authorities ascribed the blame to plant operators, who supposedly took unauthorized steps during an experiment with Chernobyl's steam turbines. Human error rather than design flaws was chiefly responsible for the disaster, Moscow asserted, and this explanation was widely accepted by Western experts.
But new evidence has come to light, said Dr. Ahmed Karbassioun of the International Atomic Energy Agency, that suggests the R.B.M.K. design was at least as much to blame as operator bungling. Part of this evidence was a letter sent in March last year to the agency's director, Dr. Hans Blix, by Anatoly Stepanovich Dyatlov, who was the chief engineer in the Chernobyl control room on the night of the disaster on April 26, 1986.
Mr. Dyatlov was one of six Soviet reactor officials sent to prison for their supposed blunders. But after his release, Mr. Dyatlov complained in his letter to Dr. Blix that he and the other convicted operators had been scapegoats, and that nothing they did violated Chernobyl's operating rules or the procedures for which they were trained. The fault, Mr. Dyatlov said, was in the vague and uncoordinated administrative system of the Soviet nuclear power authority, including a lack of communication between safety officials, as well as the flawed design of the R.B.M.K. itself.
The testimony of Mr. Dyatlov and others prompted a major review by the Atomic Energy Agency of its original assessment of the Chernobyl accident, the results of which have just been disclosed. The agency's new report substantiates some of Mr. Dyatlov's charges, and places much more blame on the R.B.M.K. design than did its 1986 assessment.
Dr. Adamov sharply disagrees with the agency's new criticism of R.B.M.K. design. "Dyatlov was in charge that night, and he was criminally responsible for the consequences of the Chernobyl disaster," he said.
 
History
 Soviet Secrecy Produces Suspicion
 Traditional Western suspicion of the R.B.M.K. is partly the result of longstanding Soviet secrecy concerning its technical details, details that only now are fully available to Western examination.
The Soviet R.B.M.K. is the descendant of a family of military reactors designed partly to produce plutonium as bomb fuel. Unlike commercial power reactors in the United States, the reactor's core is a huge graphite block into which a myriad of holes is drilled.
Graphite, a form of carbon, serves as a "moderator" in these reactors; it slows down neutrons that spew from spontaneously splitting uranium atoms so these neutrons can readily combine with other uranium atoms and hasten the fission process. This is called a nuclear chain reaction. If it happens suddenly the result is a nuclear explosion; in a reactor, the chain reaction is slowed down to produce useful heat.
Some 1,690 of the holes in an R.B.M.K. graphite core hold fuel rods, hollow metal rods filled with enriched uranium fuel, which are embedded in "channels" through which boiling water and steam normally flow, cooling the reactor core and carrying away useful heat. The steam, heated by nuclear fission in the fuel rods, drives turbines that power electric generators.
A strength of the R.B.M.K. not shared by other reactors is that it can be refueled while it operates, thereby reducing shut-down time. Each channel is independently loaded and serviced, and an average of one fuel channel is reloaded every day.
Another set of holes in the graphite core of the reactor is designed to accommodate control rods, rods made mostly of boron. When a reactor's control rods are fully inserted, they instantly bleed away so many neutrons that the fission chain reaction quickly slows and stops, a process known as a scram.
But because the Chernobyl control rods were tipped with graphite, which the Russians admit was a design failure, their insertion initially caused a surge of power rather than a reduction. Moreover, the water flow to the core had been turned off the night of the disaster, and a dangerous peculiarity of the R.B.M.K. reactor is that when it is drained of liquid water, the chain reaction can speed up; in Western reactors, a loss of water stops the chain reaction and shuts down the reactor.
Dr. Adamov's team members said they had cured this deficiency by increasing the level of enrichment in R.B.M.K. fuel from 2.0 percent uranium-235 to 2.4 percent. The added enrichment requires compensations in the controls that reduce or eliminate the reactor's tendency to speed up when water is not flowing.
Dr. Adamov said the R.B.M.K.'s control rods had been lengthened to make them more effective, and their insertion mechanism has been greatly speeded up, so that insertion can be completed in about 2.5 seconds instead of the 19 seconds it formerly took.
 
Concerns
Western Experts Remain Worried
 Scientists here approve of the change in enrichment, but call the complicated piping system inside the R.B.M.K. "a plumber's nightmare." Much of the piping lies buried in inaccessible channels within the core, where it cannot be easily inspected.
The possibility that one or more of these steam pipes could break open also worries experts. If several high-pressure pipes were to give way simultaneously (which probably happened in the 1986 disaster), their combined steam pressure might be enough to blow the top off the reactor and expose the entire core -- a development that would produce another Chernobyl disaster.
Perhaps worst of all, Western engineers say, is the lack of a "containment" surrounding either the R.B.M.K. reactors or older versions of the Soviet pressurized-water reactors called V.V.E.R.-440/230s.
Western reactors are fully enclosed in reinforced concrete housings designed to contain radioactive debris even if an explosion occurs. Some Soviet reactors are equipped with "bubbler towers" to remove radioactive matter from escaping gas, but the R.B.M.K.'s and the old pressurized-water reactors can vent dangerously radioactive substances directly into the atmosphere.
But Dr. Adamov adamantly defends his country's general approach to reactor design, if not its safety failures.
"During this week I've seen how difficult it is for Westerners to understand our channel reactors. We've tried to explain our modernization process, but outsiders really need two or three years experience with our reactors to judge them fairly."
He grimly added: "Reagan and Bush set out to destroy the 'Evil Empire,' and they succeeded. Now it seems you want to destroy our economy as well. There's nothing wrong with our reactors that some economic help in the form of better trade terms won't solve, but instead you seem to want to close us down. What we need from you is medicine for the illness, not just the symptoms."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Foreign Policy;
PROBLEMS ABROAD MAY FORCE CLINTON TO CHANGE AGENDA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7

 BODY:
While President-elect Bill Clinton puts together an Administration devoted to keeping his promises on domestic affairs, the outgoing Bush team is leaving him with a series of problems abroad that could force him to devote much more time than he had planned to foreign policy.
Now that they are on their way out, some Bush Administration officials concede that there has been very little top-level focus, direction or Presidential political capital expended on foreign policy since former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and President Bush went on the campaign trail last summer.
 
Stalled and Broken Talks
 Partly because of the absence of such high-level American attention, several sets of negotiations have stalled or broken down and some trouble spots around the world have worsened. Subordinates of Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker have continued to work on these problems, from arms control talks with Moscow to the Arab-Israeli peace process. 
 But Bush Administration officials said that without the attention of the President and the Secretary of State, who kept the reins of foreign policy tightly in their own hands, lower-level officials were not being taken as seriously abroad.
"It was obvious to a lot of people abroad that the Administration was not engaged in foreign policy at a level that was politically significant," said a senior Administration policy maker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "The President was not paying much attention to foreign affairs, and the only other guy with clout was Baker, and he was otherwise engaged.
"The perception of the outside world was that things here were on hold, and that perception created a different reality. It gave some people who wanted to redirect or redefine things in their area an opportunity."
 
Series of Problems
 President Bush still has time to refocus on foreign affairs, but for now, Administration officials point to a series of diplomatic problems that worsened during the campaign:
*Backpedaling by the Russians on their commitments with Mr. Bush last June to destroy SS-18 intercontinental nuclear missile silos and some other multiple-warhead missiles as part of the follow-on agreement to the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty. Had he not been distracted, Mr. Bush would almost certainly have sent Mr. Baker to Moscow to get the agreement back on track.
*Turkey is close to a decision to stop allowing its bases to be used by the United States to support the no-flight zone over northern Iraq and relief operations for the Kurds. Without Turkey, a Clinton Administration would have much less room to maneuver against any new Iraqi military threat.
*The Arab-Israeli peace talks have stalled because high-level American pressure, which all the parties need as an excuse for making concessions to one another, has vanished.
At the same time, while the nation was focused on the election, several new problems that were hidden beneath the surface have erupted, including a potential trade war with Europe. Mr. Clinton said during the campaign that he favored retaliating against countries that closed their markets to American exports, but he has refrained from commenting now to avoid complicating the matter for Mr. Bush.
In addition, the Khmer Rouge are threatening to scuttle the United Nations election plan in Cambodia, which the Bush team helped to forge; there has been a new surge of Haitian boat people, and the civil war in Angola, which Washington and Moscow helped to settle, has resumed because Jonas Savimbi, the rebel leader who had been supported by the United States, was unhappy that his party lost the recent election.
 
The Challenge: Finding Continuity
 This is the backdrop against which Mr. Clinton will arrive in Washington. While Mr. Clinton used his first public statement the morning after the election to emphasize his intention to maintain continuity in American foreign policy, his advisers are beginning to realize that, in several major areas, there may be little continuity to build on. In many areas they could be plugging into a broken socket.
As a result, it is likely that Mr. Clinton's untested instincts in foreign policy and crisis management will be challenged as quickly as his well-honed instincts in domestic policy, if not sooner.
Lyndon B. Johnson wanted to hold the world at bay until he built the Great Society at home, but his prosecution of the Vietnam War would not let him. Mr. Clinton is not so naive as to think he can keep the world at bay, aides say, but they insist he can juggle both foreign and domestic affairs. That will depend, however, on the nature of the problems that arise abroad, and whether they are of the boilerplate variety or those that will require the sustained attention of the President.
"Congress may gave Clinton a honeymoon, but the world will not," said Joshua Muravchik, a foreign policy expert at the American Enterprise Institute, who has written several policy papers for Mr. Clinton.
For now, his advisers say, Mr. Clinton plans to continue the basic approaches of the Bush Administration in the Persian Gulf, Arab-Israeli peace talks, Cambodia and in the still incomplete arms negotiations with Russia.
They say he wants to move away from the Bush policies on China, where he intends to be tougher on Beijing; on Haiti, where he has promised to let in refugees seeking political asylum, and on Bosnia and Herzegovina, where he has vowed to do more to protect the former Yugoslav republic from Serbian forces -- if Bosnia still exists by the time Mr. Clinton takes office.
Mr. Clinton, they say, also plans to revamp the moribund Agency for International Development and to transform American military strategy to put greater emphasis on smaller, more mobile forces, and on helping military industries shift to commercial manufacturing.
Those who have been advising Mr. Clinton on foreign affairs divide his policy in-basket into two categories: the urgent and the important.
 
The Urgent: Gathering a Team
 The first urgent matter is to assemble a foreign policy team that can work together as smoothly as the Bush national security team did, Clinton aides say.
The Clinton advisers include Anthony Lake and Samuel Berger, former advisers to Jimmy Carter; former neo-conservative Reagan Democrats like Richard Schifter, Penn Kemble and Mr. Muravchik; young Democrats like Nancy Soderberg on the staff of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and academic experts like Will Marshall and Michael Mandelbaum.
There are also lawmakers: Representatives Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, Lee Hamilton of Indiana and Les Aspin of Wisconsin and Senators Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Sam Nunn of Georgia, and retired military officers like Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. and diplomats like Morton Abramowitz.
Forging a coherent team from this group and others will not be as easy as it might look. There are pro-Israelis and pro-Palestinians, former hawks and former doves, and all sorts of other strands. Virtually none of these Clinton foreign policy advisers have worked together in government before. In addition, they will be asked to wrestle with post-cold-war issues that few of them, or anyone else for that matter, have any experience in handling.
Once he has a team in place, Mr. Clinton's first task will be to deal with the unease among long-time American friends or important powers, from Saudi Arabia and Syria to China and Russia, that have been rattled by the downfall of the Bush Administration.
"This has been the first change in party in 12 years," said a Clinton foreign policy adviser, "and we will have to move quickly to let everyone know that in most areas there will be continuity, and where there will be change there will be prior consultations."
Another priority for Mr. Clinton in foreign policy will be dealing with the American economy, say Clinton aides. Their reasoning is that without some success in resolving domestic problems, Mr. Clinton will have no support for playing a major role abroad, nor will he have the economic resources with which to influence events.
 
The Important: Arms, Peace, Trade

In the basket labeled "important" will be a variety of negotiations that the Clinton Administration will inherit. The follow-up agreement to the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which was negotiated by Mr. Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia last June, is still up in the air: the Russians have voiced second thoughts about provisions relating to the destruction of their SS-18 missiles silos.
The Russian military is apparently trying to persuade Mr. Yeltsin to use the recent hiatus in American foreign policy to secure a better deal. Mr. Clinton will insist that the Russians abide by the original agreement, his advisers say.
On the Mideast, the Arab-Israeli negotiations are by no means on a smooth track. The Syrian-Israeli and Palestinian-Israeli negotiations are basically dead in the water.
Mr. Clinton has promised "continuity" with the Bush Administration in pushing for progress in these talks, but says he will have a warmer relationship with Israel. But by the time he takes over in January, his challenge may be to revive negotiations in a state of serious decline.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton's mere election will almost certainly invite the Syrians and the Palestinians, even the Israelis, to test the new President. They want to see if Mr. Clinton is more amenable to their demands than was the Bush Administration before they determine what concessions they intend to offer one another.
The Baker-Bush peace process was primarily an effort to bring the parties to the negotiating table. It was never really intended to get the parties to agreements. The Clinton Administration will need new ideas for proposals, not simply a spirit of continuity.
The North American Free Trade Agreement does not have to be renegotiated, but Mr. Clinton has said he will only accept it as written if there is a supplemental agreement with Mexico on enforcing Mexican labor and environmental standards. He would also insist on additional legislation for retraining American workers who would lose their jobs because of the accord.
Mr. Clinton has said that he will support the use of limited trade sanctions, if necessary, to pressure the Chinese leadership on human rights. Congress will not have to take up the question of most-favored-nation trade benefits for China again until June 2, although Clinton advisers are pressing for him to have a new policy in place before then.
But any change in the already volatile relations between Washington and Beijing could create a crisis for the new President, a prospect that clearly alarms Japan and other Asian powers.
On Bosnia, Mr. Clinton has said that he is ready to use force, in conjunction with the United Nations, to get aid to Bosnia this winter; that he wants to tighten the embargo on Serbia, and that he will consider lifting the arms embargo on Bosnia.
But his foreign policy consultants note that by the time he takes office on Jan. 20, Bosnia may have been so dismembered by Serbian and Croatian forces that for all practical purposes it will no longer exist.
The same is true with Somalia. Mr. Clinton's instinct has been to press the United Nations harder to get peacekeeping forces in Somalia, on the assumption that "if you can get security you get supplies in," said one adviser. But whether the United Nations can negotiate access with the local Somali warlords, or should muscle its way in is something that may be determined by January. Instinctively, Clinton aides say, the President-elect would favor a muscular approach.
On the question of Japan, there is a clear division already between Clinton advisers, with some preferring to move aggressively against the Japanese on what they perceive as unfair trade practices. Others want to be tough in bargaining trade access agreements but prefer, as one adviser put it, to do it "in the context of building and maintaining mutual confidence."

LENGTH: 381 words

HEADLINE: First, We Need to Have a Peacetime Economy;
More Than Skin Deep

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Economic Scare Stories" (Op-Ed, Oct. 16), Professors Robert E. Hall and John B. Taylor would have us believe that the sad state of the American economy is simply due to massive withdrawal by a misunderstanding and angst-ridden public. The professors seek to exorcize this psychic condition with charts presenting statistical evidence that shows our problems to be mild compared with previous recessions. 
 Their triumphant demonstration that in the economic downturn gross domestic product is off by only 1 percent in contrast to the 30 percent drop during the Great Depression of the 1930's is not only well known to any serious student of the problem, but should also constitute the starting point for studies of the nature of the present crisis.
The statistical evidence Professors Hall and Taylor present is also, doubtless, well known to the heads of G.M., I.B.M. and other corporate giants now undertaking massive downsizing, though it has not deterred them from plant closings and mass layoffs. I do not see any corporations acting on the notion that the crisis results from a vast misunderstanding by the buying public.
Are these two professors not aware that an increasing number of economists now speak of the economy's problems as structural and that other scholars and commentators are discussing the American economy in terms of historic decline, with massive downsizing as one symptom? Can (or should) this phenomenon be kept a secret from the public? Is not the public's curtailment of purchases in favor of debt reduction and savings cause for respecting the public's keen awareness of what is happening?
The public is also vaguely aware that the roots of the crisis are not solely economic, as seen in the outcry against widespread "greed" -- essentially a protest against our ethos of acquisitive individualism run amok. It is hoped that the public will also discover that remedies will require, not only major restructuring of our economy -- probably farther reaching than that of the New Deal -- but also altering our underlying value system in favor of greater communitarian concerns.
 
ERNEST ERBER
Columbia, Md., Oct. 25, 1992
 
The writer is associate editor of the newsletter of the American Planning Association.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 210 words

HEADLINE: First, We Need to Have a Peacetime Economy;
For a New R.F.C.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Old Idea Gains New Respect: Spending Way Out of Slump" (front page, Oct. 8):
There is another old way out. It worked brilliantly before, but the men you interviewed are much younger than I am and do not remember the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. It was run by Jesse Jones and credited by most economists with having done more to bring us out of the 1929 Depression than all the costly alphabetical agencies created. When liquidated, R.F.C. returned a profit to the Treasury. 
R.F.C. was financed by the Government, but its stock was always carried as an asset on the books. I suggest such a corporation now. It could be partly financed privately. It is desperately needed first to finance the hundreds of banks in trouble to bring them back to health. They then can return to lending badly needed funds to corporations for expansion, and thus more employment. This would be much cheaper for the taxpayer, who otherwise would have to foot the bill for failed banks.
Such an agency could lend to new corporations formed for specific purposes. For instance, a corporation of engineers chartered to repair our bridges equals employment. Likewise one for nationally repairing our roads.
 
FRED SAIGH
St. Louis, Oct. 22, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 306 words

HEADLINE: First, We Need to Have a Peacetime Economy;
Jobs Plan That Worked

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell's Oct. 15 Economic Scene column states that Gov. Bill Clinton's advisers have been looking positively on a suggestion for employment tax credits -- say, $2,000 for the first year for employers who add workers. Mr. Passell then quotes a critic who mentioned that the 1977 credit was only used by about one-third of the eligible businesses. 
 I was an author, along with the economist Robert Edmonds, who originated the idea, of two reports to the Economic Development Administration that described a humaninvestment tax-credit program. We suggested a group of employment tax credits and provided research to support turning them into law.
The 1977 job tax credit program, which reflected some of these ideas, generated 900,000 private-sector jobs, fully 20 percent of all new jobs created that year. It resulted in more jobs in less time than any other single piece of legislation in our history.
A Census Bureau survey showed that only 34 percent of all businesses were aware of the little-publicized program. The White House opposed the job tax credit, and it was little advertised. If promoted effectively, with all of the recommended incentives, it might have met the original goal of generating three million to six million new jobs and encouraging one million to four million people to become self-employed.
Since Congress created the program over Administration opposition, the following year the program was gutted and became the targeted jobs-tax credit, with only a small fraction of its previous effectiveness.
Unemployment remains our most pressing problem. The tax incentives in the human investment tax credit program need to be updated and voted into law as the first order of business for the new Administration and Congress.
 
MARK GOLDES
Sebastopol, Calif., Oct. 24, 1992

HEADLINE: City Hall and Sex: 'My Character Is Up for Grabs'

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
When Barbara Wood heard on the radio that her former boss was about to be named a Deputy Mayor of New York City, she thought of the night five years ago when, she said, Randy Daniels walked her to the subway station and propositioned her with crude, explicitly sexual remarks. And then she put that thought aside.
Ms. Wood said she never had any desire to block Mr. Daniels's career path, not when she quit her job working for him in City Council President Andrew J. Stein's press office in 1987 and not after the radio report in October. But her experience was leaked to news organizations without her consent, she said, thrusting her into a public scandal. And, in the ensuing uproar, Mr. Daniels withdrew as Mayor David N. Dinkins's new deputy, even though no formal investigation had been conducted, and he filed a libel and slander suit against her. 
 As the country vividly learned during the Anita F. Hill-Clarence Thomas hearings, sexual harassment cases usually pit her word against his word, with little outside corroboration. In high-profile cases like this one, the public is left to judge what really happened. And in this case, however, Ms. Wood has offered few words publicly until now. But on Thursday, sitting cross-legged on the rug of her lawyer's office at Rockefeller Plaza, Ms. Wood sipped hot soup, pinched the bridge of her nose and reluctantly started talking.
"I don't want to tell you anything -- because it's the past and because it's ugly," she said in her first newspaper interview since her story was made public on Oct. 21. "So why am I here? Because my character is up for grabs. All kinds of things are being said just to hurt me. So I feel I have to set the record straight."
In the interview, Ms. Wood described a work environment in which Mr. Daniels routinely complimented her appearance, brushed by her in their small office, proclaimed himself her mentor and asked her out on dates. She said she gradually grew discomfited by his insistent attentiveness, which culminated in the night he walked her to the subway station. And she said that after she rebuffed him once and for all, Mr. Daniels sought retribution by refusing her assignments and withdrawing his offers to further her career.
In a telephone interview yesterday from his home in the Bahamas, Mr. Daniels rejected her accusations as lies. "It's sick, it's pathetic, she's lying," he said. "I am more convinced than ever that Barbara Wood has a problem. I guess she got angry with me way back then and still needs to spite me now. It's out of control.
Ms. Wood also said that she never filed a formal complaint against Mr. Daniels because of a previous experience pressing charges of sexual harassment against a co-worker at RKO Radio in 1983. The co-worker used to tickle her good morning every day, and she just wanted him to stop, she said. But as a result of her complaint, she was questioned in a way that she found humiliating, and her harasser was transferred to another department, a punishment that she found excessive.
During hours of conversation, her tension dissipating, Ms. Wood spoke of her coming of age as a professional woman, of the hard lessons she learned when she was younger and more vulnerable. As she talked about sexual harassment and the belated aftermath of her encounters with Mr. Daniels, she described an apprenticeship in the delicate balance of power in the modern work place.
"It's all about power," she said. "Randy Daniels pressured me to have a relationship with him outside the work place so that I could have a good relationship inside the work place. He held my job over my head."
Mr. Daniels claims that Ms. Wood, who worked for him for four months, fabricated the sexual harassment, perhaps because he criticized her performance on the job. In a news conference announcing his libel suit against Ms. Wood, Mr. Daniels did not mention the previous incident at RKO Radio. But he did say that she had made accusations against men at two other news organizations -- both companies denied this -- exhibiting what he described as a paranoid pattern. That characterization enraged Ms. Wood.
"Because I say it happened it before, does that preclude any future occurrences?" she said. "I mean, wouldn't that be nice if you were inoculated against sexual harassment just because you once made a complaint? Am I to be persecuted for having a certain standard, for just saying I don't want people to do this to me?"
Ms. Wood's lawyer, Stanley S. Arkin, called a reporter at The New York Times last week to offer an interview with his client. He said he selected the reporter on the basis of her previous articles. He requested that the interview be run on a Sunday for maximum readership but was told The Times made its own decisions on when stories appeared. And after consultation with his client, he said she would not sit for a photograph because she did not want to appear to be seeking celebrity.
 
Watched Anita Hill And Sighed in Relief
 Twenty-nine years old, Ms. Wood, an only child, lives in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, with her father, a retired Metropolitan Transit Authority supervisor, and her mother, a retired lab technician. She was happily settling into a new job as a television reporter at New York 1 News, a cable-television station, when the story of her relationship with Mr. Daniels resurfaced.
"I did not wait for him to get a good job to come forward and try to take it away from him," she said. "I would have been perfectly happy to keep this to myself and run into him at City Hall and say nothing to him. I mean, I watched Anita Hill just thanking my lucky stars that I didn't have to go through that type of interrogation."
Mr. Daniels's lawyer, Regina Darby, said she did not believe that Ms. Wood had any intention to derail Mr. Daniels's career.
"At this point in her life, she is not a vindictive, vengeful person," she said. "But some time ago, she either misinterpreted him, or fabricated a story for her own psychological purposes."
After graduating from Brooklyn Technical High School, Ms. Wood worked at odd jobs in the city -- from a messenger to a desk assistant at RKO -- saving money to go to college. At the age of 21, she began night classes at the Harvard Extension School, working full-time during the day at a Cambridge, Mass., photocopy store. When she graduated, she moved back to New York to accept a reporting internship at Newsday.
Through an editor at Newsday, Ms. Wood obtained an interview with Mr. Daniels for a press officer's job in Mr. Stein's office, she said. She started work shortly after Labor Day in 1987, with the belief that Mr. Daniels planned to take her under his wing professionally. She was 25 years old, and, she said, excited to be near Room Nine, the reporters' office at City Hall.
As Ms. Wood describes it, what she eventually saw as harassment began innocently.
 
At First, Self-Doubt; Then, a Proposition
 "I knew something was wrong but you can kind of doubt yourself," she said. " 'Oh, gee, that's nice,' he says. 'Oh, gee, that looks good.' And it escalates. You may not even catch the escalation, but you start to feel uncomfortable, with the way he is saying something to you, the way he is looking at you. And it feels inappropriate, but maybe you're wrong. But it's happening too much. But maybe you're wrong. And maybe he shouldn't have brushed up against me like that -- it didn't feel good -- but it's a small office. And certainly he shouldn't be asking me out -- he's married! -- but it's couched in terms of an after-work thing."
Ms. Wood continued: "That stuff was intermingled with, 'So, where do you want to go with your career? It's really tough out there. I can make calls for you.' And, those things together were putting pressure on me, and then one day after work, he walked me to the train station and propositioned me. And, yes, he told me what I could do. Graphically, explicitly."
Not for publication,Ms. Wood specified the sexual activity that Mr. Daniels had proposed. She continued: "He said, 'I know what you need, like I know how to satisfy you,' " Ms. Wood said. "It was disgusting and it was trashy and it was so sexual."
Mr. Arkin noted that men sometimes claim they were getting signals. Ms. Wood responded explosively.
"If he got any signal at all, it was a signal to stop," she said. "I was not responding. He didn't have to get a billboard, 'Barbara, do me.' He didn't have to basically give me a diagram of what his appetite was for."
After that night, Ms. Wood said, Mr. Daniels's behavior toward her changed. He withheld work from her, she said, and ignored her. And after her uncle, Bob Teague, a WNBC News reporter for 28 years, visited Mr. Daniels to complain about his behavior, her boss lashed out at her, she said.
"He said: 'Do you think your uncle can scare me? He can't scare me," she said. "He said: "I know what you're about. I knew what you were about when you first came in here.' And then he let me know he was not going to help me in any kind of way at all."
Mr. Daniels said yesterday that Mr. Teague had met with Mr. Stein and had only paused to introduce himself as Ms. Wood's uncle and to tell him, "I am very well connected down here."
 
Getting Out Of the Situation
 Ms. Wood said she confided in Sara Vidal, another employee in Mr. Stein's office, who told her to work out the problem with Mr. Daniels. Mr. Daniels's lawyer said Ms. Vidal told her she was misinterpreting her boss.
Ms. Darby, the lawyer, recalled, "Sara said: 'Girlfriend, let me tell you something. I know boys that play around and he's not one of them.' Then Sara called Jackie, Randy's wife, and told her to come down there in her finest and let the woman know that this man has no need to be looking outside his marriage."
Ms. Wood, meanwhile, took a trip to Israel, hoping the situation would improve on her return. When it did not, she said, she resolved to quit. But she was uncomfortable telling Mr. Daniels that she was leaving, so she went to see Maggi Peyton, Mr. Stein's chief of operations, and eventually Mr. Stein, too.
"She was really afraid," Ms. Peyton said. "She wanted me to get her off the payroll without telling Daniels."
Ms. Wood said she met with Mr. Stein, whose staff encouraged her to file a formal complaint against Mr. Daniels. She did not want to do so.
"I didn't want to bring down a black man who had made it," she said. "Also, at RKO, it had turned into this big thing where it felt demeaning." After Ms. Wood quit, with a month's pay, she was unemployed for 18 months, doing freelance articles. She did a lot of work for a Long Island television news program, and in June landed a job with the new New York cable news station. When she heard the news of Mr. Daniels's appointment, she had one reaction.
"Dread," she said. "Dread, dread, dread that it would come out. And when it did -- New world. Re-creation. Nothing will be the same. Life changed. Printing press did it to me."
In defending himself, Mr. Daniels claimed that Ms. Wood was a pawn being used by Mr. Stein to attack Mr. Dinkins. Defenders of Mr. Daniels have cast aspersions on Ms. Wood's professionalism and suggested that she was excessively flirtatious. Some blacks have criticized her for making accusations against a black professional.
But Ms. Wood, who sighed continuously during the interview, said she was sleeping and eating and working, intent not "to lose another job over this situation." Although she said she wants to remain on the reporter's side of the microphone, her experience seems to have made her an advocate for women, particularly vocal on the insidious, murky subject of sexual harassment.
"It's not always going to be a hand in your blouse or up your skirt," she said. "It's not always, 'Hey, baby, let's go do the motel thing.' It's more the double-entendre game, the setup. And it's not done for witnesses, because it's bad behavior, and they know better. And so people say they're not the type. And then after, when you say no, they don't have to fire you. It's just easier to disrespect you completely in the work place until you decide you can't take it anymore. And then you speak up, and boom, hunting season is open on your character."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I don't want to tell you anything -- because it's the past and because it's ugly," said Barbara Wood who accused Randy Daniels of sexual harassment. During her first interview since, she continued, "So why am I here? Because my character is up for grabs. So I feel I have to set the record straight." Ms. Woods appeared on television on Oct. 22. (NY1 Channel)

HEADLINE: A Republican Message That Roiled the Waters;
The Zero Return

 BODY:
President-elect Clinton has said that an economic stimulus program, including money for new roads and other public works projects, s at the top of his agenda. As an indication of how dominant an issue the economy was in the Nov. 2 elections, readers are continuing to respond very strongly to "The Beauty of Indexing Capital Gains" (Viewpoints, Oct. 25) by Theodore J. Forstmann, national co-chairman of the Bush-Quayle re-election campaign. Some of their letters follow.
 To the Editor: 
 In failing to differentiate sufficiently between ordinary income and capital gains, the government actually loses revenue. Investors holding high-interest, long-term municipal bonds find their bonds have appreciated considerably in the current low-interest climate. To take profits, however, means incurring taxes and having to re-invest at the lower current rates.
A person with a municipal bond portfolio might have a paper profit of $10,000. Under the previous tax law, a sale would produce $2,000 for the government and $8,000 for the investor. Under the present law, since the investor will pay 28 percent in taxes and need to invest what remains in lower-yielding instruments, there is no advantage to selling. When the bonds mature, the investor receives face value and the government, zero.
 
ANITA LIFSON
Washington, Nov. 2

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Searing Examination Of Private Adoptions

BYLINE: By LEAH D. FRANK

 BODY:
RECENT plays like "After Shocks" by Doug Haverty, at the defunct Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre, and the poignant "Phantasie" by Sybil Pearson, at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, have explored the subject of adoption. Now the Studio Theater is taking another look, in "The Baby Dance" by Jane Anderson.
The play had its premiere in Pasadena, Calif., in 1990. Last year it was at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Christopher Street in Manhattan. 
 Where "After Shocks" and "Phantasie" examined the effects of adoptions on adults' searching for their birth parents and geneaological roots, the subject of "The Baby Dance" is found in the morally ambiguous world of surrogate motherhood and private adoptions.
The story opens in the trailer home of Al and Wanda, an uneducated unemployed couple who have nothing except children. Wanda is pregnant for the fifth time. Practicalities about how they will be able to pay for the hospital and doctor, and then baby food and clothing, seem overwhelming. Wanda sees a newspaper advertisement asking healthy pregnant white women to consider putting up their children for adoption, and she responds.
A lawyer who arranges private adoptions matches Al and Wanda with Richard and Rachel, a wealthy educated couple who have everything life can offer except the ability to have children, and "The Baby Dance" begins in earnest. Ms. Anderson uses the couples and the lawyer to create a microcosm of cultural difference. The question of American diversity and problems of national unity underlie and add complexity and depth to this otherwise simple melodrama about surrogate parenthood.
Ms. Anderson is too clever a writer to dictate solutions to the problems that she addresses. "The Baby Dance" guides the viewer, but the final character analyses and moral judgments are left to the audience.
Macey Levin has directed with a sensitivity for the charged emotional content, and he eschews histrionics at every point. The play could easily become a melodrama about selling babies, but because Mr. Levin avoids soap-opera pitfalls, the searing ending retains its power.
Mr. Levin has also cast well. Justine Dennis as Wanda and Karen Rowan as Rachel, who wants to adopt Wanda's baby, give riveting performances. Wanda is in conflict about what she is doing, but consoles herself with the dream that her daughter will have the material benefits that she and Al could never provide. Ms. Dennis displays the desire to give her child the best of everything, but she also reveals Wanda's base nature.
Ms. Rowan's Rachel complements Wanda. Although one is left with every societal advantage that the other lacks, an empathy develops between the two that yields the play's sole ray of hope. Ms. Rowan is sympathetic and gentle as Rachel, but like Wanda this Rachel has a cold pragmatic streak that makes the character real and appealing.
The men are written more as stereotypes than the women. Al, Wanda's virile husband, is an ignorant Southern redneck. T. Patrick Shore captures the essence of a "good ole boy" and adds a depth to the character that makes Al into a believable man. Mr. Shore is a charismatic actor, and the scenes he shares with Ms. Dennis are among the play's most riveting.
Eric Leone struggles with the role of Richard, a rich Jewish financier. At times, he explodes with anger and frustration as the man who is put in the position of buying a baby; at other times, Mr. Leone seems to be doing nothing more than reciting memorized dialogue.
The lawyer, Ron, is everyone's nightmare of a well-dressed legal flesh peddler. He is smooth, unflappable and unconcerned with anything other than concluding the deal and moving on to the next one. Christopher Riordan's polished manner makes Ron appear as irritating as his character was meant to be.
"The Baby Dance," which continues through Nov. 28, is receiving a first-rate production.

HEADLINE: Johnny Jiggles the Planet

BYLINE: By Ed Regis; Ed Regis is the author of "Who Got Einstein's Office?" and "Great Mambo Chicken and the Transhuman Condition."

 BODY:

JOHN VON NEUMANN
By Norman Macrae.
405 pp. New York:
A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/
Pantheon Books. $25. 
 BY any measure, John von Neumann was a rare creature. Unequivocally one of the brightest minds of the 20th century, he made an indelible mark in mathematics, physics, economics, nuclear weapons technology and computer science, and had a hand in inventing at least three new fields -- cellular automata theory (showing how groups of inanimate cells can be made to behave as if they were alive), game theory (applying mathematics to the art of decision making) and the systematic study of the similarity of minds and computers. In one of his own pet phrases, he "jiggled the planet." So why is it that most people haven't the faintest idea who he was?
Good question. Norman Macrae, the former principal editor of The Economist, sets out to rectify matters in "John von Neumann," the first full-scale biography of this polymath, who was born Jewish in Hungary in 1903 and died Roman Catholic in the United States at the age of 53. And Mr. Macrae has some great stories to tell.
Von Neumann's grammar school tutor, we learn, "came home with tears in his eyes from his first encounter with the young prodigy." One of von Neumann's college professors happened to mention in class an "unsolved" problem in mathematics. "Johnny came up privately at the end, and solved it."
When he was 17 years old, von Neumann decided to pursue his undergraduate and graduate degrees simultaneously, in two different disciplines and in two separate countries. He wound up getting a diploma in chemical engineering from Zurich's famous Federal Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in mathematics from the University of Budapest, both in the same year, at the ripe old age of 22.
But he was also one of the guys. He loved money, fast living and gawking at women. When he was working at Los Alamos, N.M., to develop the atomic bomb during World War II, Mr. Macrae writes, the secretaries, who had desks open in the front, used to stick cardboard there "because, they said, Johnny had a habit of leaning forward, muttering, and peering up their skirts."
Von Neumann was, in spite of some quirks, a man of considerable charm and wit. On one occasion he and his colleague Jacob Bronowski had been arguing late into the night about the correct solution to a problem. "When I called his hotel in London," Bronowski recalled, "he answered the phone in bed, and I said 'Johnny, you're quite right.' And he said to me, 'You wake me up early in the morning to tell me that I'm right? Please wait until I'm wrong.' "
Almost involuntarily, Mr. Macrae believes, people took a great liking to von Neumann, even those who disagreed with his right-wing politics. (After World War II, von Neumann worked with Edward Teller to push for the development and possible deployment of thermonuclear weapons and was "grieved" by the pacifism he found among physicists.)
The risk in writing a biography of a man like von Neumann lies in contracting a bad case of hagiography disease. Mr. Macrae has not managed to avoid it -- one of the drawbacks of the book, he says, is "a danger of praising Johnny too glutinously" -- nor has he even tried very hard. From this account, one would think that von Neumann, whom Mr. Macrae calls "Johnny" throughout the book, rarely did anything bad, boring or stupid -- other than occasionally driving cars into trees while contemplating the glories of higher mathematics.
But a more serious drawback than the possibly justified hero worship is that the book's explanations of scientific theories are often facile, unintelligible or just plain wrong. In one case the author mentions nine major scientists and seven different versions of quantum mechanics, all in a single breezy paragraph. This is name-dropping, not science writing.
In another case, we read: "Hilbert had a spectral theory for bounded symmetric operators, but this did not help explain much until Johnny unveiled the notion of symmetry for unbounded operators. He did this by creating a spectral theory for unbounded operators that are self-adjoint." Such unintelligibility is not mitigated by the author's frank admission in the next sentence that "the ordinary reader (and this ordinary writer) may be staggering with incomprehension."
Godel's theorem, Mr. Macrae says, is "an assertion something like 'The following statement is unprov able.' " This rendering omits the single most distinctive feature of Godel's theorem: self-reference.
For all its faults, Mr. Macrae's biography has rescued a lot of good science gossip from probable extinction, and has introduced many of us to the life story of a man we ought to know better.

GRAPHIC: Photo: J. Robert Oppenheimer, left, and John von Neumann at the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J., 1952. (Alan W. Richards)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1345 words

HEADLINE: On the Slag Heap of History

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich teaches political economy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. His most recent book is "The Work of Nations."

 BODY:

HOMESTEAD
The Glory and Tragedy of an American Steel Town.
By William Serrin.
Illustrated. 452 pp. New York:
Times Books/Random House. $25. 
 ONLY 17 percent of working Americans now manufacture anything, down from 22 percent as recently as 1980. More than one million manufacturing jobs have disappeared during the last four years alone. Factory jobs that used to pay unskilled workers middle-class wages have been among the first to go. On average, the incomes of Americans without college degrees (roughly three-quarters of the adult population) are 16 percent lower than they were in 1970.
These are the data, but numbers have no soul. William Serrin, formerly a labor correspondent for The New York Times, has given them life in this tender account of one community's rise and fall during America's industrial century. "Homestead: The Glory and Tragedy of an American Steel Town" is, in microcosm, the story of American steel, which in many ways is the story of American manufacturing.
Homestead, Pa., rode the crest of the wave of American steel, and when the wave crashed Homestead was pulled under. Its population swelled from 2,000 in 1880 to 20,000 in 1940. The Homestead Steel Works was closed in 1986. Today, no more than 4,000 people remain.
Mr. Serrin tells us that the Homestead Works pioneered the open-hearth process, which generated cheap steel in large quantities -- supplying rails for the railroads that thrust westward, plates for helmets and warships in the two great wars of this century, beams for bridges and for the nation's first skyscrapers. When the mill opened in 1879, the United States Army was at war with Indians and the Industrial Revolution had just taken off; by the early 1950's, when the mill was breaking production records, the United States was making half of all the steel in the non-Communist world. By the time the mill closed, more Americans worked on Wall Street than in the steel industry, and the country's second-largest export (behind jet aircraft) was entertainment.
Homestead also traced the turbulent arc of the American labor movement. Mr. Serrin offers a stirring account of one of the nation's earliest and bloodiest confrontations, the Homestead strike of 1882. Andrew Carnegie and his second-in-command, Henry Clay Frick, decided to break the power of the incipient Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers -- then the largest union in the nation, with 24,000 members. The company won, and the growth of American unionism was seriously stalled until the New Deal. Thereafter, with the help of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the spur of World War II, unionism in America grew to embrace 36 percent of all workers. But the battle continued in other ways -- through management's use of spies, scabs and intimidation; through labor's indulgence in nepotism, overmanning and theft. As manufacturing jobs grew scarcer in the 1970's and 80's, industrial unions imploded. Today, only a bit over 12 percent of the nongovernment work force is unionized, and the percentage is shrinking daily.
Homestead was its mill. The plant provided almost all of the employment in the town, most of its taxes, many of its services. Mr. Serrin shows how the mill owners dominated politicians, controlled the police, infiltrated the town's social organizations, summoned the state militia when necessary. The Slavic immigrants who constituted a large portion of the work force in the first half of this century were especially tractable; few were citizens, most were illiterate. Generations worked in the mill; by 1951, more than 40 percent of its employees were father-and-son combinations. Workers and townspeople were proud of the mill and enjoyed the economic security it provided. They also hated the control it exerted, the long hours it demanded, the dangers, the deaths.
Always in the background and influencing these lives in ways the people of Homestead barely comprehended was the American steel industry and its place in the American and global economy. Mr. Serrin traces this history, too, and aptly demonstrates the close relationship between industrial innovation and competition.
GREAT strides were made in steelmaking methods in the 1880's, when companies battled one another for markets, but the industry fell into lethargy as steelmaking became a comfortable oligopoly. By the mid-1930's, Germany had become the leader in steel technology; in 1950, Austria developed the basic oxygen furnace. American steelmakers were unprepared for substitutes such as aluminum and plastics, and even after gaining protection from foreign imports in the 1970's they were dogged by poor quality and waste. Today, profits are up but foreigners are still blamed for the industry's problems, and the layoffs continue.
Mr. Serrin tells his story well, but he is less successful helping us decide what to make of it. Sometimes he suggests that Homestead's demise -- like that of so many other American industrial towns -- was the inevitable result of technological change ("it is an immutable rule of industrialism that advanced methods mean fewer people"). But that is surely wrong. Henry Ford's advanced methods of making automobiles created hundreds of thousands of new jobs, and even Andrew Carnegie's steelmaking experiments created more jobs than they replaced. At other times Mr. Serrin seems to lay blame on management, or on the steel industry in general, for cutting employment and closing mills. That is simplistic. Steelmakers would have gone bankrupt had they continued to run giant mills with swollen payrolls, providing wages and benefits 80 percent higher than the average for American manufacturing.
The reality is that both management and labor failed to use technology to keep Homestead's mill and its workers competitive. With little domestic competition, followed by decades of protection from foreign imports, management didn't much care; with secure job classifications, work rules and cost-of-living adjustments, the workers didn't either. Homestead and the other great steelmaking towns of the United States could have survived had steelmaking technologies been upgraded continuously, and workers retrained to use them. That way, steel might have evolved into new materials of ever greater strength and lighter weight, just as iron had evolved into steel. Demand would have grown, so that even with higher output per worker, larger numbers of workers would still have been needed. Unskilled blue-collar workers could have become semiskilled technicians, monitoring computers and maintaining complex machinery, thus justifying higher wages. If all this sounds too good to be possible, it is the route that was followed by Japan and Germany.
But even this cheery possibility begs the question Mr. Serrin continually raises but never answers. Why should we care about Homestead, or, for that matter, about any town or city in decline? Where, exactly, is the "tragedy," other than in this book's subtitle? Americans are always leaving some place behind; departures are in our ancestral genes. Shouldn't the objects of our concern more properly be the people who once inhabited such places, and the lives they are able to lead elsewhere? Or does rootedness matter more than we have allowed ourselves to admit?
Mr. Serrin feels obvious affection for Homestead and its people, but the two are separable. In fact, they already have separated, for the most part. His narrative might have been more complete had he examined what became of some of the tens of thousands who have departed from Homestead during the last three decades. Homestead's demise would be less worrisome if its former residents had gone on to achieve better lives for themselves and their children. But available data suggest the opposite: most of them, after migrating west and south, got jobs in the service sector paying no more than one-half to two-thirds of what they had once earned in the mill. This is not so much the tragedy of an American steel town as it is the tragedy of modern America.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers forging an axle at the Howard Axle Works, part of the Homestead Steel Works, in 1937. (William J. Gaughan Collection/From "Homestead")

SECTION: Section 3; Page 25; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 980 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Silicon Valley Spin On Financing the Arts

BYLINE: By Michael S. Malone; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

 BODY:
A tycoon tired of being pestered and industry executives with an eye to the arts have combined to produce in Silicon Valley what may be a model for fast-growing communities too new to have a tradition in cultural fund raising.
The new Silicon Valley Arts Fund, based in San Jose and composed of 11 big cultural organizations, each of which hopes to raise more money than it would alone, aims to bring in $20 million by the end of 1993. 
 Even before its formal introduction on Oct. 14 the fund had raised more than $6 million, not only from longtime contributors like the city of San Jose, but also from companies and individuals never noted for their cultural ties. Ten of the 13 historically fractious cities in the valley are already committed.
The man behind the fund is David Packard, chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company, who had tired of the many fund-raising pleas from scores of local arts groups. Shouldn't it be possible, he asked, to create a one-stop giving program that would distribute money more fairly and give these groups more long-term financial stability?
The idea fell on fertile ground with local arts groups, which, though normally competitive, are suffering in one of the worst recessions in decades. Under the aegis of the area's Community Foundation, a community-service organization that is manager of the fund, 10 nonprofit organizations with revenues greater than $1 million a year -- including the San Jose ballet, opera and symphony and arts groups from other communities -- began to meet. They were joined by the Arts Council of Santa Clara County, which represents smaller arts organizations.
The idea was just as appealing to the business community. Hewlett-Packard, for example, had never given more than a few thousand dollars or some company computers to local arts groups. For the Silicon Valley Arts Fund, it put up a prompt $250,000.
"I think the main reason was the leadership of the campaign," said William E. Terry, an H-P executive vice president. (Let it be noted in this context that Mr. Packard, a big charitable giver locally, leaves his company and its officers to their own devices in causes ranging from the arts to politics. For example, an outspoken Bush supporter, he found H-P's chief executive, John A. Young, equally outspoken for the Clinton cause.)
Mr. Terry went on to explain: "The approach always used to come from the arts people themselves, or from their trustees, most of whom weren't business people. Groups were always coming around, hat in hand, saying, 'We've got to save the ballet, symphony, etc.' This group was different. They talked our language."
Indeed they did. The structure of the fundreflects its Silicon Valley origins. Fifteen percent of the money will be designated as "bridge funding," to help participating groups pay off existing deficits. Seventy-three percent will go to create the endowment, meant to provide a predictable source of capital for the groups, good times or bad, and to signal to the community that these institutions are truly established -- a crucial factor in their independent fund-raising. The final 12 percent is for a "venture fund" to allow the groups to support new activities through interest-free 12-month loans.
H-P gave so much, Mr. Terry said, for two reasons: a growing recognition that most of the area's cultural organizations were in financial trouble and, again, business. "I can't quite put my finger on it," he said, "but certainly the valley, as manufacturing is moving out, is becoming increasingly filled with professional people. This group, with its greater discretionary income, tends to put the arts high on its value list." So, by supporting cultural institutions, he expects to cultivate employee loyalty.
Steve Kirsch, vice president and co-founder of Frame Technology, a software company in San Jose, had a different reaction to the pitch. "Basically," he said, "I got this thing in the mail inviting me to a reception. I went not knowing what to expect. One of the most impressive things for me was a fellow got up from the Knight Foundation." It was giving $1.05 million, the largest donation to an arts organization in its history.
"As it turns out, this is the largest donation I've ever made -- $100,000 over five years," Mr. Kirsch said. "And no way it was a business decision. That was the farthest thing from my mind. I did it because I feel a sense of pride in being able to contribute in some small way."
To be sure, not everything is perfect in this philanthropic paradise. As currently structured, about $2 million will go to the Arts Council of Santa Clara County. Spread out over 350 organizations, these shares don't amount to much. And there has been some grumbling, albeit only on a not-for-attribution basis, among heads of these smaller groups that the Silicon Valley Arts Fund may actually hurt their own fund-raising programs and starve local diversity by skimming off the big donors.
Stung by this criticism, the fund has gone to great lengths to show solidarity with the Arts Council members and to urge donors to continue helping smaller groups.
But its case is undermined by comments like this one from Mr. Kirsch: "This one contribution is going to pretty much blow my arts philanthropy budget for the next few years."
Still, there may be some validity in the fund's argument that building a spirit of philanthropy in what has been a notoriously tight community can only help. Certainly its novel strategy and early success have caught the attention of other communities.
Barbara Beerstein, consulting director of the fund, says she has had inquiries from groups as far away as Virginia and Delaware and thinks the program will provide a useful model for fast-growing cities that have been in the shadow of more established neighbors. Just as San Jose is to San Francisco.
