HEADLINE: Can Clinton Close The Vision Gap?

SERIES: BILL' LIST: These are the first articles in a occasional series commenting on ideas and issues facing the new Clinton Administration.

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills, adjunct professor of history at Northwestern University, is author of "Lincoln at Gettysburg."

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Democrats are under standably elated. They hear hoofbeats the cavalry's arrival, in the nick of time, to rescue the Supreme Court. A high turnout, a landslide Electoral College win, the customary graciousness of the losers. These things help dispel, for the moment, the sourness that pervaded much of the campaign. But we should not forget, in the fizz of celebration, that the overall winner this year was not F.O.B. (Friends of Bill) but N.O.B. (None of the Above).
Sometimes N.O.B. ran under his own name, sometimes under that of Jerry Brown or Paul Tsongas or Patrick Buchanan or Ross Perot. But mainly he ran -- and won big -- as Term Limits. The clearest margins of the year were given to energetic dismissal. The message was simple: be gone. 
 As late as Election Day, CBS published a poll showing that 60 percent of the populace had misgivings about Bill Clinton's character. But the nation could not (yet) throw this rascal out. The one it could, it did. There is nothing unusual about this in a time of economic hardship. Exit polls showed that Ronald Reagan was not chosen in 1980 for his own person or programs. There were lingering doubts about him (as extremist or dopey or both), but those had to wait on the first order of business, the throwing-out job. The same thing occurred in 1932. Franklin D. Roosevelt announced no real reform plan in his campaign. He did not have to. Whatever else he might be, he was not Herbert Hoover.
Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan correctly diagnosed the troubles of their predecessors and addressed the economy with vigor and imagination. President-elect Clinton intends to do the same. But he is hampered in ways they were not. It will be harder for him to spend, regulate and insure the nation out of an economic trough, as Roosevelt did, since the deficit, regulations in place and insurance-become-entitlements have pre-empted those solutions.
Not only must Mr. Clinton not "tax and spend," but he cannot spend and spend as Mr. Reagan did, since the bill for that orgy of unfunded expenditure has come due. Some Republicans were at least partly comforted to see that their man is now spared the demanding, perhaps impossible, task of dealing with the economy in the coming year.
Yet even this is not the full measure of Mr. Clinton's problems. There were deeper than economic discontents expressed in this race. The political system itself was under attack -- the Congress, the special interests, the very idea of incumbency. This mood was profound but diffuse. It was not merely a reaction to the excesses of campaigning: this was a more substantive campaign than the last one, than most in our history.
Nor can blame for any cynicism be pinned on a corrupt Congress; this Congress is cleaner than most if not all in our history (the House bank scandal was small potatoes by past standards). Yet people were ready to believe the worst of Washington. They sensed that something had gone wrong somewhere. George Bush's last-minute attacks on "gloom and doom" people just confirmed how out of touch he was.
The end of the cold war obviously had something to do with this spiritual restlessness or drift. The crusade that justified so much of our activity has been taken from us, leaving a gaping hole where there was, once, a sense of purpose.
After all the weapons gaps, we have a mission gap. The idea that we have reached some kind of imperial plateau is also asserting itself in quiet but discernible ways -- the sense that foreign competitors are all around us where we used to have only foes or clients. It is hard to say "We're No. 1" with the old easy assurance (except, of course, where we are No. 1 -- in murders committed, drugs consumed, debts run up).
President Bush's ultimate failure, nebulous as it sounds, was in "the vision thing." Roosevelt and Mr. Reagan did not simply institute piecemeal economic changes. They made their efforts coherent in a framework of mobilizing ideals. This requires political genius, a thing one cannot count on.
In Arkansas, Bill Clinton did base nitty-gritty reforms on the vision of a new state, competitive with others because it is better educated, more open to the world, less bound by provincialism. But he was cramped in what he could do there by the state's anti-governmental constitution, by historical resistance to taxes and by skepticism about change. After he pushed too hard, in his first term as Governor, he was defeated and became far more cautious.
In the Presidency, a stalled economy calls for boldness and the opportunity of the energetic first days must be capitalized on. A President can recover from mistakes made early in his term (Roosevelt trying to expand the Supreme Court as his second term began, John F. Kennedy invading Cuba). But Mr. Bush's lassitude at the outset made later accomplishments all the more difficult.
In foreign policy, Mr. Clinton ran the typical Democratic campaign, trying to be as tough as the Republicans, avoiding criticism of Mr. Bush that might sound "unpatriotic." But the end of the cold war calls for reconceptualizing America's place in the history of our times, if Mr. Clinton is not merely to respond in an ad hoc fashion to trouble spots. Here, too, a coherent vision can brace people to depart from old reflexes.
It is not only our physical infrastructure that has decayed but our intellectual infrastructure. That collapse explains the perception of discredited leadership, tainted procedures, resented measures. We have been eating into our intellectual as well as our financial capital, living off depleted supplies of anti-Communism, trickle-down capitalism and Rooseveltian liberalism.
It is catch-up time in our history, when government must not be so much reinvented as relegitimized. What vision does it serve? What mission does it have? Mr. Clinton ran an efficient if cautious campaign. That will not be enough to reverse the trend of recent years in government. It is clearly unfair to put political genius at the top of the list of things required of Mr. Clinton now. That, nevertheless, is what we need.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Political Memo;
Clinton, After Raising Hopes, Tries to Lower Expectations

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 8

 BODY:
As President-elect Bill Clinton begins the transition from campaigning to governing, his overarching concern is to cope with the emotion he has stirred: hope.
A volatile expectation colors everything about the beginning of the Clinton years. Against accepted political wisdom and the currents of an angry year, Mr. Clinton's Presidential campaign seemed to revive at least a limited belief that Washington can actually do something good for people. 
 Now, as the President-elect settles into his job, he and his strategists face the tricky task of bringing the grandly hopeful promises of his campaign into line with the grimly difficult realities of governance: a huge Federal deficit, a highly taxed public, a Congress determined to hold onto its own share of power and the factionalization of politics by pressure groups.
The inculcation of a vast and passionate Hope (the word, uttered every few seconds in Clinton circles, seems to come out capitalized) was at the core of the Clinton electoral strategy, a plan based on the idea that people eager for change would vote for him if their hopes could be made to rise above the level of their trepidations.
"This is a race of hope against fear," was Mr. Clinton's slogan. The glowing biographical film that created the candidate's general-election image celebrated his upbringing in Hope, Ark., and in speeches Mr. Clinton made a point of saying he "still believed in a town called Hope."
 
Facing the Perils of Hope
 Post-election polls indicate the strategy's success: an overwhelming percentage of the voters who chose Mr. Clinton did so not just to remove President Bush from office, but also in the belief that the new President, as he had promised, would improve their lives. Among other things, the candidate promised to end working-class poverty, to change welfare, to provide health care for everyone and to eliminate illiteracy.
Publicly, Mr. Clinton's advisers describe the national expectation level as a great opportunity. Privately, some of them regard it with worry as well. Hope got Mr. Clinton elected, they figure, and will be the crucial weapon of the first hundred days of his Administration, a stick with which to beat the recalcitrant and critical forces of Congress, the permanent bureaucracy and the press. But hope expects success, and deferred, sours with nearly the violence of spurned love.
To retain the political promise of hope while minimizing its peril, Mr. Clinton and his strategists are beginning to chart a course of contrary impulses. The nascent strategy is directed at maintaining expectations for a Clinton Presidency at a high enough level that Congress, the bureaucrats and the press will fear thwarting the Administration's aims, while simultaneously dampening those expectations to bring them closer to what can be achieved.
Mr. Clinton voiced the dual nature of this approach in his first official statement of Presidential intent, a five-paragraph speech delivered the day after his election.
 
Lowering the Expectations
 "We have entered a period of great challenge and extraordinary opportunity for our nation," he said, in a passage that spoke in high and rich terms of national greatness. But the next, and final, passage sounded a note of shared sacrifice, a signal that greatness would not be achieved without pain.
"America has called on me to be our next President," Mr. Clinton said. "But our forebears call on all of us at this moment to honor their efforts, their sacrifices, their ideals and their lives by working hard and working together to improve this good and great nation as much for our children and our children's children as those who preceded us did for us."
It is this latter theme of sacrifice and a lowering of hope to reality's borders that is most urgently sounded now by Mr. Clinton's advisers. The imperative, in the wake of a campaign of blue-sky, no-pain promises, is obvious to them. Asked how much patience the American public might have with the Clinton Administration as it sets out to fulfill its promise, Eli Segal, Mr. Clinton's campaign chief of staff, had a succinct answer: "Not much."
And so, this week, the low-balling began.
"The expectation is not that he will solve everything in a hundred days, but that he will address the problems seriously, and begin the process of working toward solutions," said Mandy Grunwald, one of Mr. Clinton's chief image and media consultants.
Bruce Reed, Mr. Clinton's issues adviser, said: "I'm not that sure how high expectations are. Obviously, in record numbers people demonstrated that they thought there was a lot at stake in this election, and they care deeply about the outcome of the questions raised, but I think people still have doubts about what Government can do.
 
Considering Many Ideas
 "The Governor never promised that Government could solve every problem; he just promised it was time that leaders start trying," he added. "As he has said over and over, we didn't get into this mess overnight and we won't get out of it overnight."
Possible means of furthering this point are under discussion within the wide circle of Mr. Clinton's advisers. A strategy pushed by one economic adviser calls for him to address the nation in a televised "national audit," in which he would, in Ross Perot style, grimly lay out economic realities.
A Clinton campaign official cautioned that neither this idea nor any other specific plan had yet been brought to Mr. Clinton's attention. But the essence of the ideas is clearly in line with the desires of a number of Mr. Clinton's policy advisers.
"I think leveling with people is a good idea always," said Al From, the director of the Washington-based Democratic Leadership Council and one of Mr. Clinton's advisers. "If you level with the people, they're going to be more willing to help you get along with what you need to do."
 
'Audit of Where We Stand'
 Another Clinton policy adviser, who would speak only if not identified, said: "I think it clearly makes sense a lot of people would recognize, telling people how bad the economy is. Is the best way to go about it us doing a national audit? Or is it better to have the guys in Congress do it? Is it better done in November or January? These are all things we're talking about."
Warren M. Christopher, Mr. Clinton's transition director, spoke of another version of the "national audit" idea today on the CBS News program "Face The Nation."
Saying Mr. Clinton would convene a group of business executives and economic leaders to advise him, Mr. Christopher called that effort "an attempt to make an audit of where we stand now."
The need for reducing hope to a manageable level arises directly from the oratory that helped elect Mr. Clinton. The Democratic candidate, in the course of the campaign and especially toward its conclusion, did often make the point that positive change could only come with shared responsibility and that it would not be easy to achieve. But he also spoke, and more often, in promises that were breathtaking in their ambition.
In the course of the 13 months in which he ran for the office he will soon hold, Mr. Clinton uttered promises that seemed to commit his Administration to many goals.
He said he would end welfare "as we know it." He would restore America's industrial manufacturing base so that good, high-paying jobs are widespread. He would insure that no working family would fall below the poverty line. And he would make "health care a right, not a privilege," for all Americans without subjecting businesses to an additional tax burden or rationing health care.
 
Problems and Promises
 He promised to eliminate adult illiteracy in five years, to halve the Federal deficit in four years without raising taxes on the middle class or significantly cutting the Government entitlement programs that account for the bulk of Federal spending, while offering a modest tax break to the middle class.
He said he would guarantee all Americans either a college education or two years of vocational training after high school, under the guidance of a national service program that would "solve the problems of this country while educating a generation of Americans."
Mr. Clinton pledged to keep abortion legal while "making it as rare as possible," to end racial, religious, geographical and sex-oriented divisions in society, safeguard environmental concerns without costing jobs and protect the rights and privileges of workers without costing business growth.
Implicit in every speech, and directing the course of the campaign, was the allure of hope. "This is a race of hope against fear," Mr. Clinton would say in almost every speech.
And while Mr. Clinton also voiced tough-minded opinions that put him at odds with the positions of such crucial groups in the Democratic coalition as blacks and organized union workers, it often appeared during the campaign that those statements were taken by leaders of the groups as indicators more of the politics of the moment than of the policies of a Clinton Administration.
It is the hope of Mr. Clinton's advisers that he will be able to cope with both the heightened hopes of the public at large and the deferred expectations of Democratic interest groups through the great skill of promoting himself and his ideas through the mass media that he demonstrated during the campaign.
Increasingly, the model for Mr. Clinton's Administration was seen as that of Franklin D. Roosevelt, another President who took office amid doubts of his trustworthiness and whose fireside chats induced in the nation a sense of shared sacrifice and common good that carried it out of the Great Depression and through World War II.
"Bill Clinton is an information age politician; he understands the importance of communication," Mr. From said. "With that talent, what he has to do is what Roosevelt did, which is subsume the narrow agendas of organized interests into a larger national agenda for progress. I believe he is going to make this an idea-driven Administration, and an idea-driven Administration can appeal to a potpourri of interests. If he can do that, he will be fine."

PUB-DATE: November 9, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1179 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The Overview;
CLINTON TO SUMMON ECONOMIC LEADERS TO SET PRIORITIES

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 8

 BODY:
In an effort to demonstrate a commitment to boosting the battered American economy, President-elect Bill Clinton plans to assemble a conference of business and economic leaders within the next few weeks and create an Economic Security Council after he takes office, his transition leaders said today.
The council, Mr. Clinton's advisers said, would be separate from the three-member Council of Economic Advisers, whose role is to evaluate the economic impact of the President's policies. The new council would effectively usurp the role of the existing Domestic Policy and Economic Policy Councils. It would be modeled after the National Security Council and headed by an assistant to the President for economic affairs, who would coordinate the efforts of Cabinet departments that handle economic affairs, the advisers said.
 
Littler Rock Meeting Planned
 The transition leaders, Vernon E. Jordan and Warren Christopher, appearing on four television news programs, said they had been given the responsibility of filling 27 major Administration posts by Inauguration Day. They also said they would bring "structural change" to the new White House that would include fulfilling Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to reduce the White House staff by 25 percent. 
 The top 27 jobs would presumably include all the senior Cabinet posts, but Mr. Jordan said it would not include the new official whom Mr. Clinton has promised to appoint to coordinate Federal response to AIDS.
"I think it's fair to say that sometime very soon, that the Governor will convene in Little Rock business leaders, economists, a variety of people with expertise in the economy and international economy to come and have a conversation with the Governor and with Senator Gore about priorities and about his approach," said Mr. Jordan, who is the chairman of Mr. Clinton's transition team. Senator Al Gore of Tennessee is the Vice President-elect.
 
Emphasis on Analyzing
 Mr. Christopher, the transition director, said that the business leaders would meet with Mr. Clinton in "an attempt to make an audit of where we stand now, to get advice from these individuals who run big companies or who are well known in the economics field as he moves through this process."
Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's press secretary, said that Mr. Clinton was eager to hold such a meeting, probably within the next three weeks, but that no details had been worked out.
"It's an idea that's been kicked around for a while, and it's something they have talked about with the Governor," she said. "And he's high on the idea. It's something he would very much like to do.
"But it will take some more talk. There is right now no guest list, no location, no date set." The emphasis, she said, would be on analyzing the state of the economy rather than on prescribing specific solutions.
Both Mr. Christopher and Mr. Jordan, appearing on NBC's "Meet the Press," CBS's "Face the Nation," ABC's "This Week" and CNN's "Newsmakers Sunday," said that the first major Cabinet appointments would probably not be made before Dec. 1.
"I'm sure he wants to make careful, wise choices," Mr. Christopher said of the President-elect. "He has about 75 days between now and the time he's sworn in, and we hope to use them very well."
 
Early Announcements Possible
 Mr. Clinton, who spent his day in Little Rock exercising and attending church services, refused to respond to all specific questions about the transition, but he agreed with his new advisers that little would be done quickly.
"I'm going to work hard, but not rush decisions," Mr. Clinton told reporters after returning from jogging. "We're going to work very hard not to rush things."
He added, "I want to make some decisions in a fast way, but I want them to be good decisions, and I think it's important that we kind of get this whole thing reoriented, you know."
Mr. Jordan said that if Mr. Clinton was satisfied with "the person" and "the process" the transition team had set up, some announcement could conceivably be made by Thanksgiving.
"We will do it with a word, or phrase, that I am not sure I want to use -- with all deliberate speed," Mr. Jordan said.
Mr. Jordan also said that he assumed that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, would serve out his term, which expires in 1995. But he added that he had not yet had "a specific conversation" with Mr. Clinton about the subject.
Mr. Clinton said today that he had been resting since Election Day to overcome the exhaustion of the campaign and that he had been reading briefing books provided him by his transition staff.
"I was so exhausted I couldn't read very much for two days," Mr. Clinton said. He said he advised his staff to stop thinking about the campaign and sleep for two days. But he said he did not know when he would take a formal vacation.
"The way things are going, I've got a notion there won't be a lot of vacations in that first year," he said. "There's a world of work to be done."
Mr. Christopher, who met with Mr. Clinton over chicken soup at the Governor's mansion last week, said he expected that the emphasis of Mr. Clinton's first months in office would remain on economic concerns, and that appointments in that area would be equivalent in importance to appointments made to the National Security Council.
He also said he expected that Mr. Clinton would travel to Washington to meet with Congressional leaders at some point during the transition. Mr. Clinton told reporters today that he had not decided when that would occur.
Mr. Christopher confirmed that there had been a struggle for power among some of Mr. Clinton's former campaign staff members about who would run the transition. At the time, some campaign officials involved in the fight publicly called reports of discord "ridiculous."
"Governor Clinton resolved it very quickly," Mr. Christopher said today. "It was not allowed to fester."
Mr. Jordan, who is a senior partner in the Washington law firm of Akin, Gump, Hauer & Feld, also said that he would not advise clients who do business with the Federal Government during the time he helped Mr. Clinton with the transition. But he said he would continue to participate on the boards of corporations on which he serves, with the understanding that he would divulge no details of transition planning.
"The one thing I've learned on these boards is when to talk and when not to talk," he said. "I've learned that as a lawyer. I understand privilege, I understand confidentiality. And this will prevail in that process."
Unlike Mr. Christopher, who said on Friday that he assumed that by taking the transition job he would be taking himself out of the running for a Cabinet post, Mr. Jordan made no attempt to do so today. He has been mentioned most frequently as a candidate for Attorney General.
"You know, to everything there is a season," he said. "Right now, this is the transition season. At some point in that transition season, that bridge will obviously have to be crossed and will be dealt with then."

HEADLINE: A Culture Strives to Root in Freedom's Stony Soil

SERIES: The Arts in Russia: A Loss of Glory -- First of three articles

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
The collapse of Communism and the Soviet empire awakened widespread hopes that the arts in Russia, so long repressed, might suddenly blossom into a new golden age. But that flowering has been blighted by the grim, uncertain realities of the country's economic and political life.
Although there are signs of stability in the provinces and of innovation throughout this vast land, the most immediate image of the country's cultural life is of poverty and creative paralysis. A cultural establishment accustomed to virtually total state support and centralized control was suddenly cut adrift, its subsidies reduced by fiat and inflation and its administrators forced to cope on their own. And it was the most prominent museums, theaters and conservatories, the glories of the Soviet system, which had the greatest obstacles to overcome. 
 The lack of money, the dead hand of the past and an almost hopeless capitulation to the worst of the West can now be seen everywhere: in routine performances before dated and shabby opera sets at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, in crumbling hallways and decaying facades at the country's leading museums and conservatories, in cheap popular entertainments at its theaters, in third-rate American films on television and in movie theaters, in pornography sold at flea markets.
Most established artists and arts administrators believe that the artistic life of the country has suffered with the breakup of the Soviet Union. "The whole level of culture has been lowered," said Yevgeny Y. Sidorov, the Russian Minister of Culture, who is an ally of President Boris N. Yeltsin with firm progressive credentials.
Anatoly F. Malkov, the administrative director of the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, the home of the Kirov Opera and Ballet, was optimistic about his own companies, but pessimistic about the country as a whole. "My general impression is that the situation is getting worse," he said. "And to a great extent, that is connected with the difficult economic situation of the country at large."
The most immediate sign of crisis has been an extraordinary diaspora of Russian arts and artists. Sometimes the flight to the West, of performing groups capitalizing on known artistic brand names, or cobbled together for the sole purpose of earning hard currency, becomes dizzying in its confusion.
"They're tripping over one another," said the promoter John Cripton of Satra Arts International, speaking of four competing Red Army Choruses that have crisscrossed North America this year.
Most museums still refuse to "deaccession" -- to sell off their assets -- but they happily diminish their collections by sending them on long tours with precious little in the way of exchange exhibitions from the West. Contemporary artists are likewise restless. Oleg Kulik, who runs the Regina Gallery in Moscow, grumbled: "No artist here loves his country. They all want to go to New York."
 
An Upward Talent Drain
 The drain began before the relaxation of Soviet rigor by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, with dissidents, star soloists and rank-and-file dancers and orchestral musicians. Some emigrated to Israel. Many more are fleeing now to the West, or even to other former Communist countries, in search of hard currency and a better life. Every absence worsens the quality of artistic experiences available to Russian audiences now and Russian arts students for the future.
"This year we lost seven solo dancers, who went to Moscow and St. Petersburg to replace others who went to the West," said Igor M. Nepomnyashchy, the director of the Voronezh State Opera, Ballet and Theater, 300 miles south of Moscow. "It takes years to train a good dancer."
 
Decentralization
No More Control, No More Money

With the dissolution of the Soviet Union, one unlamented victim was the old Soviet Ministry of Culture, which with the Communist Party, the K.G.B. and the various artists' organizations sought to control the arts from on high. In its place, Russia and each of the former Soviet republics gained their own ministries of culture.
Yet the Russian ministry's role and budget were sharply reduced as part of President Yeltsin's decentralizing reforms. Mr. Sidorov, the Minister of Culture, said that under the Soviet system, culture received between 3 and 4 percent of the national budget but that now the share was below 1 percent.
And the regional and municipal agencies that are supposed to fill the gap are undeveloped or are crippled by the country's economic upheavals and rampant inflation. The old Soviet artists' unions or associations have lost most state subsidies, and artists are being forced to struggle for survival on their own.
Nor has there been much help from sponsors, or private and corporate philanthropists. Mr. Sidorov, the Minister of Culture, along with arts leaders all over the country, laments the absence of a provision in the tax laws that would significantly reward arts support. The current law allows companies to donate 2 percent of earnings, but the definition of a nonprofit entity is vague (if a troupe sells tickets at the box office it may not qualify), and Mr. Sidorov would like the figure raised to 5 percent. So far, efforts to pass such a reform have been bottled up in the recalcitrant Russian parliament.
 
Cultural Plenty, on Paper
 Even without its former Soviet satellite republics, the Russian cultural establishment is enormous. According to figures supplied by the Ministry of Culture, there are 402 state-supported seasonlong repertory theaters in Russia. These include 23 opera and ballet companies (the two are usually combined here) and 19 theaters for operetta and musical comedy. There are 80 full-scale symphony orchestras. There are more than 200 major arts museums (the figure is vague because some museums blend in history and natural history). There are nearly 4,000 state-supported music schools. In each case "state" can mean national, regional or municipal, with many institutions now falling painfully into the cracks.
 
Coping
Trying to Stretch What Isn't There

Some of the big performing institutions have managed to sustain performances and hold ticket prices within reach of their old audiences (at the Bolshoi, Russians can still pay as little as 3 rubles, or about 1 cent, while tourists are asked to pay up to $75 in hard currency). But others have watched their audiences slip away, unable to afford rising ticket prices, distracted by popular entertainment on television or, in the words of Mikhail V. Bychkov of the Voronezh Theater for Youth, "spending time trying to find food, clothing, everything."
Some former showcases of Russian culture, like the Pushkin Drama Theater in St. Petersburg, rent out their space several nights a week for popular revues or commercial exhibitions. "It's another lost fragment of our national culture," lamented Leonid N. Nadirov, the director of the Vaganova Ballet Academy in St. Petersburg and himself a former actor. "There are still people there who worked with the famous actors of the previous century."
Most arts institutions seem unsure about how to cope in a new international world in which their currency is practically worthless, and how to handle the new fund-raising and marketing needs thrust upon them by the withdrawal of state control and support. "Not everyone is inclined to appeal for help," said Vladislav A. Chernushenko plaintively. Mr. Chernushenko is the rector of the Rimsky-Korsakov State Conservatory in St. Petersburg, and his biggest problem is obtaining quality musical instruments from the West, for which he needs hard currency.
 
The Day-at-a-Time Approach
 In the general economic confusion, long-term planning becomes nearly impossible as attention is focused on day-to-day survival. Backstage machinery and physical plants grow antiquated and dangerous. Even now, with the first snow of the season gracing the bare trees and crumbling facades, ("Winter is not all bad; it covers the dirt," Muscovites like to say), the decay of the infrastructure cannot be escaped.
Mr. Bychkov in Voronezh needs 3 million rubles to fix a leaky roof, but has no prospect of getting it. Even when restorations are undertaken, they are often protracted into a years-long holding pattern in which nothing much seems to get done, as in the desultory construction at the Tretyakov Museum in Moscow. The new wings are handsome and up to date, but the main central building has been closed for eight years.
Most museums, like the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, have little immediate hope of installing modern air-conditioning or security systems, leading to fears in the West that their masterpieces may be damaged or stolen. And masterpieces they are: the Hermitage has one of the great collections of Western art, with especially extensive examples by nearly every major Italian, Flemish and French artist from the Renaissance to early modernism.
On the horizon looms an even greater danger to the large museums. In the treaty establishing the Commonwealth of Independent States, it was agreed that cultural artifacts from the former Soviet republics would be returned to them. Although no formal claim has yet been filed, Ukraine has threatened to do so, and Russian officials are apprehensive.
 
Specter of Culture Wars
 "This is a very serious issue," said Dr. Vitaly A. Suslov, who retired this past summer as director of the Hermitage. "The agreement was not properly thought out. If we had to return objects, science at large would suffer. It would be as if all the Italian and Dutch paintings were taken from the Louvre."
Anatoly N. Konstantinov, of the Mayor's Cultural Committee in St. Petersburg, said, "If this decision were implemented, we would lose the Hermitage Museum completely."
 
Artistic Effects
Old Methods, But New Problems

Most of the big state institutions are still administered by holdovers from the Soviet regime, people who either were Communists or had made some sort of peace with the old regime. Many are simply unable at this stage of their lives to adapt to the straitened economic realities and the artistic challenges of today.
"Instead of trying to create a new kind of theater, they struggle to sustain the kind of theater they had before," complained Mr. Bychkov in Voronezh. "In the current situation, that's outdated." An official of the United States Embassy in Moscow, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "Younger people who work in these institutions are dying to do different things, but they are terrified."
Big companies like the Kirov Opera can at least count on sponsorship from well-established firms, Russian and Western, that hope to profit from an association with a widely recognized artistic brand name. The Kirov Opera's summer tour to New York included transportation provided by Baltia Air Lines, which said it "wanted to be linked with the best."
Smaller troupes, museums and municipal arts programs, victims of cutbacks at the local level, must rely more heavily on private sponsors. But in Russia's chaotic economy, that is an almost impossibly unsure way to build a company over the long run.
Yevgeny Panfilov, a modern-dance choreographer in Perm, near the Urals in central Russia, dramatically shaved his flowing locks last spring to protest the reneging of a local sponsor. Mr. Panfilov later conceded, puckishly, that he also rather liked baldness as a fashion statement. The loss of the promised funds was no laughing matter, however: it meant Mr. Panfilov had to cancel a new production of his Experiment Modern Ballet Troupe, and his dancers went without pay for several months.
"A lot of people who are very wealthy now in this country are not very cultivated," said Viktoriya Pavlova of Ardani, a private arts management organization in Moscow. "They have no idea what modern dance or the avant-garde is. They simply do not understand what it means to be a sponsor. They think we bring them rubles, and they somehow gain hard currency."
Writers, painters and other individual artists are suffering from a collapse of the Soviet institutions that assured them privileges and access to the public. In every city, composers or writers' unions offered publication, performances, income, pensions, weekend homes and a host of other benefits, along with repressive ideological control.
 
No Skills Beyond Art
 Though many such unions have been given their buildings by the regional authorities, they have little money to sustain their privileges. For artists accustomed to the old system, with or without political complicity on their part, adjustment to a free-market artistic climate, as in the West, can be painful.
"A hundred members of the Artists' Union used to work and live in Voronezh," said Yuri Pchelkin, the head of the Arts Department of the Regional Department of Culture in Voronezh and a proud former Communist. "Now, no one buys their paintings. What can the artists live on? They have no other skills or professions. It's not right."
Former dissidents who never, or only fitfully, enjoyed Soviet sinecures are often discouraged, as well. For them, the solidarity they experienced in common opposition to the state has been replaced by a queasy sense of uncertainty, a loss of center and purpose. For some, the depredations of capitalism are as painful as the repressions of totalitarianism.
"Today, you can do what you want and make a living out of it," said Garik Sukachev, the lead singer of Brigada S, a popular and respected Moscow rock band. "But the hard thing is that somehow it evolves into a profession, and it was never supposed to be that."
 
Popular Arts
High Art's Woes Are Low Art's, Too

Curiously, given the widespread complaints in Russia about the triumph of commercialization in the arts, the popular arts are in similar crisis. Film production has almost ceased at the old Soviet studios, and private investment is erratic at best and shady at worst. At the last Berlin International Film Festival, a common thread in discussions of film financing in Eastern Europe was that underworld money, in need of laundering, was being plowed into any and all film projects.
In fact, few films are being made in Russia today. With a ramshackle distribution system and heavy competition from cheap or pirated Hollywood rejects, the chances for profit are slim. Especially since so many contemporary Russian films accent a bleakness that can hardly be expected to entertain a large public. "The tone of Russian movies is too gloomy," said Sergei V. Koptilov of AIST, the private television station in Irkutsk. "They promote the black side of Russian reality."
The former state television networks limp on, plagued by inefficiencies, nepotism and a capitulation to the sorts of soap operas and game shows that routinely clutter Western television. Leonid Orlov, a producer for the second, and supposedly innovative, national channel, complained that "a lot of the people who work there aren't even professionals." High culture on the state networks has declined. The most popular program in the country just now -- work in offices and shops grinds to a halt when it comes on -- is a Mexican soap opera called "The Rich Also Cry."
 
Lure of Private Enterprise
 Private television stations like AIST, which have sprung up around the country, have siphoned off many of the trained technicians who used to work at the state stations. But they are usually reduced, given Russia's economic woes and its refusal to sign the Bern copyright convention, to recycling Hollywood's worst.
"The distributors try to get the cheapest films possible," said Mr. Koptilov in Irkutsk. "Sometimes they ignore the copyright laws and show good American films, just to prove that American movies aren't always bad. If anyone complains about copyright questions, it's the distributor's problem, not ours; we just buy them."
Rock and jazz, though still popular among young people, have been undercut by commercial pop music far removed from the political and moral passions that inspired the dissident bands. "There is a distinction between rock and pop," argued Dmitri Groisman, the manager of Brigada S. "Rock music is what was before perestroika, and pop music is the result of perestroika."
In the Communist system, there was a coherent network of folk groups and community arts activities, often paid for by contributions, voluntary or expected, from factories and workers' groups. But in many Russian cities, former community centers stand empty as local amateur folk-dance groups, choruses and theater ensembles have withered away.
Throughout the country, leaders in the arts seem overwhelmed by the despair and confusion of their everyday lives. Vladimir Martyanov, a composer of sacred music who teaches at the Zagorsk monastery near Moscow, worried that "as in the West, more freedom does not automatically mean a deeper or better culture."
Mr. Sidorov, the Minister of Culture, put it this way: "Now," he said, "we are free, proud but poor."
NEXT: Cultural life in Russia's provincial capitals.

Companies
 
 If A.T.& T. succeeds in acquiring a third of McCaw Cellular, it would threaten one of the sacred cows of telecommunications policy -- the separation of local and long-distance telephone companies. The deal would give A.T.& T. a significant presence in local telephone markets, allowing it to muscle into the core businesses of the Baby Bells, the seven regional telephone companies carved from A.T.& T. in 1984. LENGTH: 1169 words

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Facing Deficit of $260 Million

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
In the opening move of a complex political joust likely to last into next year, the New York City Transit Authority will announce this week that it is facing a 1993 deficit of about $260 million, Transit Authority officials said.
For New York City residents, such deficits -- the result of declining tax revenues and continued low bus and subway ridership -- have become something of a fall ritual auguring the threat, implied or overt, of a fare increase. This year is no different. 
 "The fare increase is the least attractive alternative," said John Cunningham, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency. "But without financial assistance, it remains an alternative."
 
Competing Interests
 But whether that most drastic and politically unpalatable step occurs depends on the intricate byplay of Albany politics. In a special session expected to start in December, the State Legislature will debate not only the Transit Authority deficit, but also proposals to help the agency replace, rebuild and renovate its aging systems to attract new riders and -- Transit Authority officials hope -- prevent future deficits.
The debate will pit region against region, city against suburb, even borough against borough. And on a much broader scale, it is part of an unfolding dialogue over the allocation of $16 billion in new state and Federal transportation funds expected to flow through Albany in the next six years.
How the Legislature deals with the M.T.A. this winter is likely to set the tone for how those billions will be spent into the next decade.
"How do you divvy all this up?" said Steven A. Greenberg, spokesman for Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin. "Mass transit or roads? Upstate or down? There are a lot of questions."
The deficit is primarily the result of the region's weak economy, M.T.A. officials say. A slump in real-estate sales has caused the authority's revenue from taxes on those transactions to drop from $302 million in 1988 to $118 million this year, according to M.T.A. statistics.
To close the shortfall in the Transit Authority's anticipated $3.7 billion budget, prevent a 1993 fare increase and finance a five-year capital program, the M.T.A., which has an overall $5 billion budget, has developed a sweeping legislative proposal that includes these measures:
*The State Legislature would allocate more funds from state and Federal sources to mass transit. The largest of these pots is $700 million from the petroleum business tax; the M.T.A. wants half of it.
*The Legislature would give the M.T.A. greater discretion in parceling out its government subsidies. Currently, strict formulas prevent the authority from moving funds from its cash-rich division, the commuter railroads, to its deficit-ridden one, the buses and subways.
*New York City would give the Transit Authority $65 million more in operating funds.
*Tolls at the nine bridges and tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority would be increased 20 percent in January. Public hearings on the proposed increase, which would provide about $45 million to the Transit Authority, will begin this week.
These are big ifs. Only the toll increase, which is subject to approval by the M.T.A. board, seems certain.
Upstate legislators will want more money from the petroleum tax to go toward road and bridge construction. Suburban legislators will be squeamish about allowing the M.T.A. to divert subsidies meant for the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North to subways and buses. And residents in Queens and Staten Island are objecting to toll increases on the bridge and tunnel authority crossings, which include the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the Triborough Bridge and the Queens Midtown Tunnel.
M.T.A. officials concede they face a daunting task. But they say they most want to avoid a replay of the bitter 1992 budget fight in which the Legislature approved one-shot accounting maneuvers that closed the Transit Authority's $165 million deficit without providing means to prevent the 1993 shortfall.
 
Long-Term Deal Sought
 Even if the transit fare does not increase next year, the M.T.A. officials say, they could still emerge losers this winter if they do not win larger measures that make the authority more self-sustaining and less vulnerable to the annual rites of budget brinkmanship.
"If all they do is save the fare, they won't give something real to riders," said Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, a subway-riders advocacy group.
Key to the M.T.A.'s long-term plans is a $10 billion, five-year capital plan. Earlier this year, the Legislature approved only the first year of that plan.
But M.T.A. officials say they cannot invest in major improvements without at least a five-year plan in place. And many of those improvements are central to the M.T.A.'s broader vision for preventing future operating deficits, the officials say.
Labeled the "Fare Deal" by Peter E. Stengl, the M.T.A. chairman, the plan sounds as simple as Marketing 101: improve services, keep fares down, and the riders and their money will come. The plan calls for Transit Authority fares to rise only once before 1997: to $1.50 in 1994.
Improvements would range from the small, such as improving the public-address system, to the large, such as installing automated fare-collection systems, which would enable the Transit Authority to offer a wide range of discounted fares, including reduced prices for two-fare zones and monthly passes.
"We're approaching things differently this year," said Mr. Cunningham. "If you are constantly on a treadmill to raise fares and cut services, you can't attract new riders."
But the fate of the plan in Albany depends heavily on two people: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and State Senator Norman J. Levy, the Republican chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee.
This week, the staffs of Governor Cuomo, State Senator Ralph J. Marino, the Senate majority leader, and Mr. Weprin are expected to meet to begin thrashing out the proposals.
Mr. Cuomo, who can provide the most carrots and sticks in Albany, has the greatest power to bring harmony to the cacophonous Legislature. Some transit advocates say he will be particularly motivated to push M.T.A. proposals this year to help Mayor David N. Dinkins, who is up for re-election next year.
"Fares just do not go up just before mayoral elections," said Mr. Russianoff.
To many in the Republican-controlled Senate, Mr. Levy is the last word on transportation issues. Earlier this year, the Nassau County legislator blocked the shifting of $90 million in surplus money from the commuter railroads to the Transit Authority. As a result, the city and state had to contribute millions more to prevent bus and subway fares from rising to $1.40.
"The M.T.A. proposals are very complicated," said Bill Stevens, a spokesman for Mr. Marino. "Senator Levy will clearly be involved in any thoughts about what will happen with them."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Post-Election, Bonds Remain Vulnerable

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
A lot of uncertainties for the bond market were eliminated last week. But not enough was made clear to fire up a rally or push market yields out of their recent trading range.
Right now, the market is vulnerable to prices falling a little further and yields inching up, even above the 7.76 percent yield reached Friday on the 30-year bond -- the highest since the end of June. At the same time, balancing forces -- the old friends of slow economic growth and low inflation -- help check any rout. 
 "The scales are evenly balanced," said Stephen Maher, head of fixed income at Nikko Securities. "I can't see this market climbing out of this range that it is in."
What happens beyond the spring -- when the promises of the Clinton campaign should be becoming programs of the new administration -- is much harder to forecast. Remember that just two months ago, as the bond market rallied to a 7.21 percent yield on the long bond, the lowest in six years, many forecasters were talking of reaching 7 percent soon.
 
Continued Vulnerability
 John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the market would remain vulnerable over the next several months because of the uncertainty of the new Presidency and doubts about the economy. But he still forecasts that by the end of next year continued slow economic growth and low inflation will bring yields down again, leaving the 30-year bond with a yield in the 7.5 percent range.
Between the election on Tuesday and the October unemployment figures released on Friday, several important questions were answered.
But traders and investors are still wondering what kind of fiscal stimulus program President-elect Bill Clinton will propose. And they want to know who will be appointed to the crucial economic positions in his Administration, especially Treasury Secretary.
"If Clinton would give us a couple of appointments, that would help the market," said Barbara L. Kenworthy, portfolio manager for taxable fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation. "The infighting raises uncertainty."
 
A Confidence Factor
 Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said he did not think Clinton policies or proposals "would have any direct impact on the economy for some time." But, he added that the appointments "will have a confidence-related impact."
Mr. Kudlow, the former chief economist in the Office of Management and Budget at the beginning of the Reagan Administration, said he is not worried. "I am taking the attitude that Clinton ran a brilliant campaign and will make equally good appointments," he said, adding that he thought the President-elect would work with the current chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan.
The unemployment report showed the economy was still weak yet inching ahead, with an increase of 27,000 in nonfarm jobs. Other data, including car and truck sales and initial claims for unemployment compensation, indicate that the economy may be rising to a firmer footing if not growing a little faster than expected.
Both the Clinton Presidency, until its plans for fiscal stimulus are outlined, and the slightly firmer economic signals seem to end for now the speculation over whether the Fed will ease interest rates further, which is a certain disappointment for the bond market.
 
No Easing Seen
 "Given the context, no Fed easing is plausible," Mr. Lipsky said. Ms. Kenworthy said the Fed probably would not ease because it wanted to wait to see what Mr. Clinton would propose.
"The economic numbers will give the Fed the opportunity to do so if they want to," she said. "But politically I am not sure they will."
Compounding these uncertainties is this week's Treasury auction of $37 billion of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. This certain pipeline of new supply has already helped knock prices down sharply, with the 30-year bond tumbling more than three-quarters of a point on Friday.
For all these reasons, Ward McCarthy, managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J., does not expect the Treasury auction to go all that well. "The market has a downward momentum and the psychology is very poor right now," he said.
He also also suggested that the Veterans Day holiday on Wednesday, when the bond market will be closed, could hurt by interrupting whatever momentum might develop.
The bidding will be done under the traditional system where the securities are awarded starting with bids at the lowest yield (highest price) and rising until all the securities are sold. Under this system, one dealer can pay more than another for the same security.
But auctions are hard to predict. Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, said he thought the yields on the notes and bonds to be auctioned were attractive, especially after the selloff on Friday.
The 5.11 percent yield at which the three-year note was trading in the pre-auction or when-issued market was the highest since the beginning of July, just before the two most recent cuts in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Of the three auctions, this should do the best, analysts said, because of the attractive yield and the shorter maturity, which makes the purchase less risky. (In pre-auction trading Friday, the yield on the 10-year note was at 6.99 percent and the 30-year bond at 7.64 percent.)
Many traders said the selloff on Friday was mostly motivated by dealers trying to set up for the auction. The selling cleared dealers' shelves and brought prices down and pushed yields up to make them more attractive.
"It is healthy to get set before the auction," Ms. Kenworthy said. "Why give the Treasury a break? Let's give ourselves a break. This is what we want to see happen so that we can have good bidding at the auction."

HEADLINE: A Quiet Alteration at Brooks Bros.

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
When Brooks Brothers installed escalators in its flagship store on Madison Avenue three years ago, it incited something approaching hysteria among its clientele. The offending contraptions, standard fixtures in most stores of more than two levels, became the symbol of unwelcome change at an institution that had stoically upheld the status quo for well over 150 years.
Today the escalators rarely arouse the attention of anyone other than the occasional repairman, and the revolution they were supposed to portend has failed to materialize. Brooks Brothers has instead undergone an appropriately subdued metamorphosis, evident in Hermes-esque neckwear, stylishly faded sports shirts and stirrup pants hanging unobtrusively alongside the rep ties, button-downs and kilts that are the chain's signature merchandise. 
 Its most obvious deference to the times is the liberation of its boxer shorts, now ensconced in help-yourself fixtures instead of discreetly housed under glass counters.
 
Owned by British Retailer
 After four tumultuous years in which economic recession and life-style changes made the nation's oldest retail clothier seem every bit of its 174 years, Brooks Brothers has finally started giving Marks & Spencer P.L.C. a return on the $750 million it spent to acquire the company in 1988.
In a recent interview, Sir Richard Greenbury, chairman of Marks & Spencer, firmly set aside the persistent rumor that the British retailer wanted to sell Brooks Brothers. "We're here for the long run," he said, although tartly adding that Marks & Spencer had paid too much for its American subsidiary.
For the year that ended on March 31, Brooks Brothers' sales rose 4.6 percent to $314 million, an increase that was somewhat better than average compared with other American retailers. But operating profits accelerated 64 percent, thanks to stringent cost controls and computerized inventory management systems. For the first six months of fiscal 1992, through September, operating profits rose 30 percent from the comparable period a year ago, while sales increased about 10 percent.
"The message today is: we're back," said William V. Roberti, president of Brooks Brothers, who nonetheless is still sensitive about the escalators. He refused to have his photograph taken anywhere near them.
Independent assessments of the chain's status are difficult to obtain. British investment analysts who follow Marks & Spencer say Brooks's parent keeps news about its American stepchild to itself. And since Brooks contributes less than 2 percent to the bottom line and generates only about 3 percent of the British retailer's revenue, they find it easy to ignore. "I'm quite sure you know much more than us," said one analyst at a major British investment bank.
 
Locked Into a Niche
 Retail consultants contend that Brooks's very strength, its lock on the niche market for traditional clothing, is its weakness. They say Brooks has so locked itself into that niche that it cannot respond to changes in tastes. "They cannot go out of suit," said Walter K. Levy of Walter K. Levy & Robert E. Kerson Associates Inc., a retail consulting firm. "They have no credibility with the updated customer."
The chain has also been dogged by questions about the quality of its merchandise and its relevance in a world enamored of deconstructed casual clothes, jeans and Lycra. It narrowly averted a strike by unionized employees this spring, and the weak economy in Japan is buffeting its stores there.
Most recently, Consumer Reports gave a lukewarm rating to a $595 Brooks Brothers suit called a Brooks Ease, the chain's second-best seller in tailored clothing. While the magazine's panel, which tested 17 men's suits, gave the Brooks suit high marks for tailoring, it did not like the way it dry-cleaned, its finishing details or its price. In fact, the panel preferred $240 and $325 suits from J. C. Penney to the Brooks suit.
The peppery Sir Richard is undaunted, although irritated, by such adversity. "Men have got to have a trouser to cover their backsides," he said, putting into perspective others' concerns about the impact of currency fluctuations, the weak Japanese economy and declining sales of the tailored suits that were once Brooks Brothers' bread and butter.
For men who still want a suit but do not want to spend $500 or more, Brooks has developed what it calls the Wardrobe Collection. Using new dyeing techniques that allow it to match different bolts of fabric instead of having to use the same bolt of woven fabric to create a suit, Brooks Brothers has cultivated sales of "suit separates," pants and jackets for men whose waistlines are out of synch with their shoulders or who simply want to mix and match. The Wardrobe Collection, with jackets priced at $270 and trousers for $125, gives Brooks a bridge to customers who are looking for more moderately priced clothes.
As for Consumer Reports, Sir Richard said, "I find it utterly appalling and disgraceful that any trade paper, magazine or newspaper can, on the basis of one garment when we sell thousands and thousands, use that garment as a yardstick by which we are judged."
Mr. Roberti said the suit used by the magazine to test quality had been made in 1989 in a factory the company no longer used. He said new technology in tailoring and sewing had improved all of Brooks's suits since then.
And the computerized systems Marks & Spencer has installed to monitor Brooks's inventory, distribution and buying should insure that no suit made in 1989 is available for sale in 1992. In the use of computers to reduce costs and increase productivity, Marks & Spencer is the British version of Wal-Mart, and the parent has shared its expertise with its subsidiary.
Sir Richard said he had been shocked by how backward the chain had been when Marks & Spencer had acquired it, technologically and physically. On his first visit to the flagship store, he tripped over a hole in the carpeting.
"We had to maintain all the best traditions of Brooks Brothers and what it stands for, but that doesn't mean we have to keep it dowdy and hidebound," he said. "We want to attract somebody who wants more than a gray flannel suit."
Unlike many of its competitors in the tailored clothing business, Brooks has recognized a fundamental shift in the psyche of its customers. Unemployment has affected the ranks of loyal suit wearers in banking, law and financial services, and those who have managed to hang on to their jobs think twice about paying $600 for a new suit. More fundamentally, corporate culture is relaxing, making twill pants and a sportcoat acceptable attire in an increasing number of workplaces.
 
Permanent Taste Change Seen
 "I don't see the suit business coming back," Mr. Roberti said. "The life-style change we're seeing now is permanent."
Brooks is keeping step with what it calls the Friday shirt, a less formal shirt with a button-through breast pocket, and items like whimsical ties and soft, pigment-dyed shirts that should generate $1 million in revenue for Brooks this year. The chain introduced varsity jackets, this fall's fashion statement, three years ago, and at $195 the garments are competitive with those The Gap has made famous.
Therein lies perhaps the most nettling of Brooks' problems: getting its message out to new, younger consumers whose tastes are markedly different from that of their grandfathers. While the Gap has unabashedly used eye-catching advertising to make varsity jackets de rigueur, at Brooks Brothers they have been a well-kept secret for three years, like many of the chain's other gems.
But Mr. Roberti and Sir Richard shake their heads emphatically when asked whether Brooks will use advertising to draw attention from a new clientele. Mr. Roberti said the chain was instead using thirtysomething models in its catalogues to convey its unbuttoned side and posters in each of its departments to clearly spell out the message that Brooks Brothers clothes have value.
"We don't spend a whole lot on advertising and marketing -- don't believe in it," Mr. Roberti said. "The downside is you don't get recognized for doing anything."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
A Judge's Interest in Being Governor Is Decided the Hard Way

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
AS Chief Judge of New York State's highest court, Sol Wachtler was the Republican Party's great robed hope -- the suburban, moderate, Jewish jurist who might some day challenge the Democratic hegemony that has held the governorship since 1974.
Judge Wachtler himself was ambivalent about elective politics. His arrest Saturday by Federal agents, who accused him of a bizarre extortion scheme involving a woman with whom he had had a long relationship, renders the debate all but irrelevant. 
 When, 25 years ago, he was defeated for Nassau County Executive, he announced that he could see no circumstance that would draw him into politics. Five years later, though, he mounted a successful campaign for the Court of Appeals. The race was remarkable for its high cost and for a television commercial in which Mr. Wachtler, slamming a jail door, pledged to "get the thieves and muggers and murderers into these cells."
As an associate judge of the Court of Appeals, he nearly declared his candidacy for Governor once. (Among those who he said had encouraged him to run was Mario M. Cuomo, then the Lieutenant Governor). But one weekend at the United States Open tennis tournament at Forest Hills, a brash upstart named Donald J. Trump wagged his finger in Judge Wachtler's face and said, as the judge later recalled, "I hear you may run; we should talk."
If that encounter suggested the pandering to which Judge Wachtler would have to stoop during a campaign, he wanted no part of it. He held his news conference, on schedule, but announced that he would not run.
Three years later, Mr. Cuomo appointed him Chief Judge. Twice since then, leading Republicans urged him to challenge Mr. Cuomo. He politely declined. Bereft of talent, the party of giants like Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller chose lesser candidates: Andrew J. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, who was reduced to toting around a cardboard cutout of Mr. Cuomo to dramatize the Governor's disinclination to debate; and Pierre A. Rinfret, an economist whose name was plucked from a telephone book and whose campaign proved embarrassing.
Last week, Republicans survived a Clinton landslide in New York -- retaining control of the State Senate and preserving the United States Senate seat that they have held for nearly five decades. But nothing would invigorate the party more than to win the governorship in 1994.
Judge Wachtler's uncle, Abe Minsky, once confided to him a fundamental tenet of burlesque: a woman is most alluring when she leaves more to the imagination. The same rule applies to politicians. Another cardinal rule of politics is that you can't beat something with nothing, which may leave Republicans in the same straits as in 1986 and 1990.
Among those who may run are Richard Rosenbaum, an affable former Rochester judge and Republican state chairman, and Evan Galbraith, who, because he had served as Ambassador to France, failed four years ago to meet the state residency requirement. That impediment might also disqualify Jack Kemp, who moved to Washington to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
That leaves, among others, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who, immediately after winning a third term last week, retreated from his pledges not to seek re-election or to run for Governor. Mr. D'Amato is regarded as so Machiavellian (make that Bismarckian, to avoid inferences of ethnic stereotyping) that the elaborate sting operation that snared Judge Wachtler and the unseemly clambering for credit by so many prosecutors even raised the suggestion that Mr. D'Amato, somehow, had had a hand in it.
Judge Wachtler and Mr. D'Amato were products of the Nassau County Republican machine. But they differed philosophically and politically -- particularly since the Senator, as Judge Wachtler recalled, had crowed that Mr. Cuomo would never name him Chief Judge and because Mr. D'Amato originally promoted another New York jurist, Roger J. Miner, for the United States Supreme Court, without even mentioning Judge Wachtler's name publicly.
It was uncertain whether Judge Wachtler would have agreed to run for Governor in 1994. But he was certainly considering it. He was reluctant to relinquish the power to shape judicial precedent and policy; yet he was frustrated at the shortage of funds. He was increasingly angry with Mr. Cuomo, describing his unusual lawsuit against the Governor over court financing as his most agonizing decision.
The judge's second most agonizing decision might have been whether to run for Governor. He planned to decide by next summer. If he decided yes, he planned to resign from the court and announce that he was exploring a possible candidacy -- assuming, until Saturday, that he would have the nomination for the asking.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
A G.M. Issue Has Created An Anomaly

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN a world of uncertainties, it is unusual to find one investment that is absolutely certain to be better than a competing investment, no matter what else happens in the world.
But that is the case now in General Motors securities. General Motors common stock is clearly a superior investment at current prices relative to one type of G. M. preferred stock, known on Wall Street as a perc, for preferred equity redemption certificate. That will be true if G. M. stock goes up, or if it falls, or if it does nothing. 
 The anomaly, which has persisted for several weeks, reflects investors' desire for current yield on their investments. The G. M. perc does provide a better current yield than the G.M. common, but that advantage will not last long and is more than offset by the higher price.
What has happened is that some mutual funds have locked up large quantities of the G. M. percs to get high reported yields for their funds. Yields are a big selling point with some funds, and that may have helped them in marketing.
But as Emmett J. Hardy, president of the Parallax Group of Stamford, Conn., and an expert on such securities, notes: "There is more to investing than simply looking for current yield. There is a buzzsaw waiting to take their heads off."
There is not a lot of argument on that point. "Anybody who has looked at those percs says they are overpriced," said John Maurice, co-manager of the Putnam Growth and Income Fund, which at last report owned 800,000 G. M. percs. So why does the fund own them? "For the yield," he replied, adding that an income-oriented fund could not participate in G. M. because of its low dividend, except through the percs. Mr. Maurice said the fund still owned a large position in the security, but declined to say whether it was more or less than at the last required report.
Here is how the G. M. perc works: It pays a $3.31 annual dividend, and because it is a preferred stock, that payout is quite secure, even though the common dividend was halved last week. At the current price of $37.625 for the G. M. perc, the yield is 8.8 percent. With today's low interest rates, that is a tempting figure. By contrast, G. M. shares, which closed Friday at $30.50, yield only 2.6 percent, based on the new annual dividend rate of 80 cents a year.
The catch is that G. M. will pay that rate on the percs only through July 1, 1994. Then the G. M. perc will convert into common stock, almost certainly at a ratio of one perc to one common share. (In the very optimistic case, where G. M. common is trading at a price above $53.79 on that date, the perc could be converted into less than one common share of G. M.)
A buyer of the G. M. perc now will get six dividend payments, one a quarter from March 1, 1993, through June 1, 1994, of 82.75 cents each. That is a total of $4.97. (The record date for the Dec. 1, 1992, payment is this Thursday, so a buyer of shares today would not get that payment, assuming the trade settled next Monday, as would normally be the case.) Then, at best, a holder of the G. M. perc will get one common share of G. M.
By contrast, a holder of one G. M. share will get six quarterly dividends of 20 cents each, assuming the dividend is maintained at the current rate, before the mandatory conversion of the percs. That adds up to $1.20, but of course it could be more or less.
If you assume that G. M. will maintain its current dividend rate, that adds up to an advantage of $3.77 in dividends for the G. M. percs over their life. The maximum advantage, of course, is $4.97. Those calculations ignore the time value of money -- the fact that a dollar a year from now is worth less than a dollar today -- so in fact the maximum price advantage of the G. M. perc over the G. M. common ought to be less. Mr. Hardy says he finds it impossible to justify a premium over $4, whatever assumptions are made. But at Friday's prices, the premium was more than $7.
One might expect arbitragers to narrow that difference. Indeed, a strategy that would seem to be guaranteed to earn a profit would be to sell the G. M. perc short and buy the common. Unfortunately, to short the perc one must be able to borrow it, and all the shares that can be borrowed have been. Thus the premium can persist unless enough current holders decide to take advantage of the anomaly and sell their shares.
Last summer, when it seemed more believable that G. M. stock would rise above the $53.79 limit by July 1, 1994, the common and the G. M. perc traded for the same price. Since then, the G.M. perc has held up better than the common, creating the clear overvaluation.
It is possible, of course, that both the G. M. common and the G. M. perc will provide good returns from here. And it is possible that neither will be a good investment. But it is impossible that the perc will do better than the common, and mutual funds that are holding onto the perc, thus inflating the reported yield of the fund, are doing a clear disservice to their customers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines;
Interior Design and Social History

BYLINE: By Deirdre Carmody

 BODY:
The sale of Metropolitan Home to Hachette Magazines last week parted the curtains and provided a glimpse into one of the most fascinating and fluctuating categories in magazine publishing -- the interior design and home decorating field.
Tracking these lushly illustrated versions of the American dream usually provides pretty good social history. It did so again last week when Des Moines-based Meredith Magazines decided to cast its lot with the simpler, more traditional articulation of that dream. It sold its sophisticated urban child, Metropolitan Home, and will now stick to its knitting with Better Homes and Gardens, Traditional Home and Country Home. 
 On the other hand, Hachette is betting that although the 80's are over, even Americans on tight budgets will still want to read about beautifully appointed dwellings and furnishings they couldn't possibly afford. Met Home is, in fact, a better fit with Hachette's stylish, European-inspired Elle Decor than it was with Meredith's more practical publications.
For the last few years these two categories -- the voyeur books and the country books -- have engaged in a tug-of-war for advertisers. The high-end magazines -- Architectural Digest, HG, House Beautiful and Met Home -- have been hit particularly hard by the recession. In 1989, for instance, they totaled 4,920 advertising pages. In 1991, the number had fallen to 3,872. (Elle Decor started in 1989.)
On the other hand, the circulation of magazines like Hearst's Country Living and Colonial Homes; Hachette's Home; The New York Times Company's Decorating Remodeling, and Meredith's Traditional Home and Country Home are all up or about even for 1992's first nine months compared with a year earlier.
"The first group are the leadership books, and for the vast majority of the readership, they are a source of ideas," said George Fertitta, president of the ad agency Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss. "The second group is reality. But I don't believe that the second-tier publications could exist without the first tier."
"I think the top category can support five books," he added. "If you normally ran 20 pages of ads spread over five books, you might want to run 15 pages spread over three books and then after two years, rotate to the other two books."
Karen Ritchie, senior vice presidenta and director of media services at the ad agency McCann-Erickson in Detroit, disagrees. "I think in general there are too many magazines," she said, "and this is especially true in the shelter market.
"I think you tend to see some editorial that tends to be dated and some of these magazines locked in the 50's. This is one field where we are likely to see some fairly dramatic disasters occur."
Louis Oliver Gropp, editor in chief of House Beautiful and a former editor in chief of both HG and Elle Decor, sees the second category as "the field within the field."
"This is a whole category that grew up around the vision that Country Living first enunciated, and it is a field that has grown astronomically over the last 20 years," he said. "The top category includes people that travel more, are better educated and certainly have more worldly interests that it does take a little money to pursue.
"But something happened and there was a profound shift in the mood of the country. The 80's did leave a kind of bad taste, and some of the top magazines got borderline vulgar."
Two of the beneficiaries of the switch in mood are Deborah Jones Barrow, publisher of Traditional Home, and Karol DeWulf Nickell, editor in chief. They preside over a magazine where circulation is climbing and ad pages are up 73 percent this year compared with 1991.
The magazine is just what its name suggests, filled with articles about new country French furniture, gracious decorating for the Christmas holidays and rooms that do not look very different from the suburban homes in House Beautiful. In fact, Traditional Home, with newsstand sales of 203,000, has just surpassed House Beautiful in single-copy sales.
"Everybody thinks back to the 80's as big spending, and we are now into more family-driven values," Ms. Barrow said. If so many people's sense of themselves changed, it stands to reason that the books and magazines that honor those changes will come forward. "Certainly there is no time in the last 30 years when a magazine that has the word tradition in its title would have more marketing equity than right now as the baby boom is into its families," she said.
Better Homes and Gardens, with a circulation of eight million, is far and away the leader in the home field. David Jordan, editor in chief, thinks it is essential for his magazine and Traditional Home to be based in the Midwest rather than New York. "I think we get a sense of what's going on in the country much more than if we were in a major urban area," he said.
Better Homes focuses directly on what people can do with their families. It has spun off dozens of smaller once- or twice-a-year publications for Meredith, like Country Kitchen Ideas, Remodeling Ideas for Kids' Rooms, and Window and Wall Ideas.
Country-based publications, like Hearst's Country Living with its circulation of 1.8 million and Meredith's Country Home with one million, are also riding on a real wave. They may hit bumps in the road, however.
"We are in a country phase now, and it sounds good," Ms. Ritchie of McCann-Erickson said. "But I think they are going to find that titles like that are going to be a serious handicap someday."

They preside over a magazine where circulation is climbing and ad pages are up 73 percent this year compared with 1991. (Jeff Davis for The New York Times); drawing
