HEADLINE: Peace Corps' Training Using Camden Schools

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, Nov. 7

 BODY:
In an elementary school in the poorest neighborhood of one of the most impoverished cities in the nation, graduate students from Rutgers University are training as Peace Corps volunteers.
Camden, where 65 percent of the children live below the poverty line, was seen as "perfect training for the third world," the director of the Rutgers program said. 
 Crouched next to a child-sized table, one of the graduate students, Michael Merola, dredges up bits and pieces of his high-school Spanish to coach a bewildered 8-year-old Hispanic girl in arithmetic.
"I had no idea that things could be this bad in this country," said Mr. Merola, 22, who with seven other students began work in the blighted neighborhood six weeks ago. "I'm embarrassed and I'm ashamed."
 
Real-World Experience
 The four-year-old program at Rutgers's Camden campus is one of 18 master's programs in the nation run jointly by universities and the Peace Corps specifically for Peace Corps volunteers. But what has set the Rutgers program apart is the real-world experience of Camden.
"Rutgers is the only school to send people into the inner city to train as part of its formal curriculum," said Kristin Wennberg, a spokeswoman for the Peace Corps in Washington.
Three days a week, Mr. Merola, of Cranford, N.J., his fellow graduate students and 15 undergraduates in a public policy course make the trek from the Camden campus to the Rafael Cordero Molina Elementary School and the nearby Pyne Poynt School to spend two hours tutoring about 100 elementary-school children after classes have let out for the day.
"Unfortunately, Camden does mirror a lot of the problems that are experienced in third-world countries," said Ian Jacobs, an assistant professor of public policy at Rutgers University-Camden and director of its Master's in Public Policy/Peace Corps Program. "You have a high level of poverty, unemployment, poor housing and tremendous pressure on the school system.
"It's not a real positive thing, but it's a reality."
 
Cannot Rely on Native Tongue
 Another part of the reality, for many of the Rutgers students, is that for the first time, they cannot rely on English as their primary language.
Here at Molina Elementary School, Hispanic students account for 70 percent of the school's 750 children in kindergarten through fifth grade and at least that percentage of the students who attend the after-school tutoring program.
The 8-year-old girl seemed baffled by a set of simple addition problems until Mr. Merola used his halting Spanish to try to help her. She quickly seemed to grasp the problems.
"These kids are so bright and there's so much potential," he said. "The two words I hear the most during the two hours here are, 'Help me, help me.' I'm not going to change Camden in one year here. But you just have to make small victories."
Home to nearly 88,000 people, more than a third of them below 18 years old, Camden is New Jersey's sixth largest city and its poorest. Statewide and nationally, it ranks at or near the bottom in virtually every economic and social category the government measures.
Half of Camden's residents receive welfare, and its percentage of children living in poverty, 65, is the highest of any major United States city. The teen-age death rate is 354 percent of the state average, infant mortality 185 percent and low birth weight 167 percent.
In an article that still rankles city leaders, Time magazine described it in January as a city where "only people with no other choice" live.
Within view of Philadelphia's gleaming skyline, Molina Elementary School sits in a north Camden neighborhood that residents and outsiders alike agree is the worst section of the city. Open drug deals on street corners, youth gangs and drive-by shootings have given the name Danger Zone to the five-square-block area of dilapidated or gutted houses.
"It's a very difficult life in the neighborhood," said Dr. Frances C. Gibson, principal of Molina Elementary School. "Yet the school has sat here for years like an oasis."
Inside the school there is a well-stocked library, neat classrooms and hallways full of posters and other artwork, much of it with anti-drug themes. There also are full-time security guards.
Students are served breakfast and lunch at school and a snack during the after-school tutoring.
Most of the children are picked up promptly at 4:30 P.M. by parents or much older siblings for a short walk home. Many are not allowed to walk alone or to play on the streets because it is too dangerous, parents said.
"The situation is very similar in many ways to the third world," said Rhonda M. Horried, 23, of Baltimore, a member of the master's program and the student supervisor at Molina Elementary. "It's very disheartening because we are suppose to be the greatest country on earth."
When she completes the Rutgers course next spring, Ms. Horried hopes to be posted to Namibia, which she visited during a stint as an aide to the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa.
"I think this will lessen the shock for us," she said.
Mr. Jacobs became director of the Rutgers Master's in Public Policy/ Peace Corps program in 1990, when it involved only the traditional classroom lectures. "We were giving our students a good academic foundation, but I wasn't convinced that they had the practical foundation," he said. "I was told straight up that Camden was perfect training for the third world."
Mr. Jacobs said his approach has startled some participants and toughened others, but there have been no dropouts among the 20 students who have finished the course at Rutgers.
"Sometimes it's frustrating here, but when they reach overseas they are going to find there are lots of problems that they can see but will be unable to solve in the years they are there," he said. "They have got to look at it on a micro level, that even if they only make impact on one child in the Camden city schools or somewhere overseas, that is important."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Camden, N.J., one of the most impoverished cities in the nation, was decided upon as the perfect training ground for Peace Corps volunteers. "I had no idea that things could be this bad in this country," said Michael Merola, who is working with second graders. "I'm embarrassed and I'm ashamed." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
Necessity, Ingenuity and Gourmet Tomato Sauce Yield a Thriving Company

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The tale of how Nancy Battista DiStefano became a businesswoman could begin with the memory of her father bringing home bushels of tomatoes for her and two sisters to can in Mason jars with a bit of olive oil and basil.
Or it might start with lonely midnight runs in her Volkswagen to the rough-edged Hunts Point market in the Bronx to buy tomatoes to supply a tiny new enterprise. Once she saw a man stabbed a few feet away from her. 
 But this is an entrepreneurial career that had the starkest of origins. It grew out of the disappointment of a failed marriage and the urgent drive of a mother to insure the well-being of her precious son, Daniel, then 2 years old.
 
'On a Mission'
 "I was on a mission," said the president of Pomodoro Fresca Foods, which in January moved from a minuscule former ice-cream parlor in Queens to a 10,000-square-foot factory in West Sayville, L.I.
It is selling gourmet tomato sauce in all 50 states, though mainly in the New York metropolitan region. Sales this year are expected to exceed $500,000.
"And I don't see any problem doubling or tripling that every year," Ms. DiStefano, who is 31, said.
She is part of a tidal wave. Census data from 1987, the latest figures available, indicate that 30 percent of all businesses in the nation are now owned by women, a proportion expected by census officials to increase to 50 percent by the year 2000. Two of every three new businesses, most beginning with just one person, are started by women. Many of them, like Ms. DiStefano, never set out to be entrepreneurs, but, when faced with the necessity of making ends meet, they tap an ingenuity and drive they may not have known they possessed.
 
'The Only Way'
 Marsha Firestone, vice president of the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation, says this surge is the result of women having less chance of making it to the top of big companies, where only 3 percent of top managers are women.
"The only way they're going to be at the top is to do it themselves," she said.
It was three years ago that Ms. DiStefano drove her husband to the train station, hoping he would at the last minute beg to stay, but knowing he wouldn't. At the same time, her best friend was dying of lung cancer.
It all made her so tense she thought her throat was constricting. To help her relax, she carried a paper bag to breathe into. She now believes she experienced a minor nervous breakdown.
And paying the bills was no picnic. Ms. DiStefano had a mortgage on a Queens condo and regular fees for day care and baby sitting.
 
Italian Peasant Menu
 She was working as a technician at a design company in SoHo. Since it held frequent business lunches, she asked if she could cater at a cost of $15 to $25 a person. Her bosses said yes, and she devised what she calls an Italian peasant menu.
The biggest hit was her homemade tomato sauce, pretty much the same recipe she had devised as a teen-ager. Some of the guests asked her to cater events at their offices too. Friends persuaded her to print business cards.
Though she soon was catering for customers as varied as television production companies and art galleries, she could not bring herself to quit her regular job and become a full-time caterer.
"I worried that people would stop liking it, and not use me," she said.
She would work a full day at the design company, maybe cater a lunch there, cater another event in the evening, then go home and cook until 2 A.M. or later. She lost weight, and worried about how little time she was spending with Daniel. But the catering business was growing by leaps and bounds.
Then people started asking if they could buy the sauce she usually brought in Mason jars. "People would pay whatever I charged," she said.
Ms. DiStefano figured she had a hot commodity. She paid a visit to the Manhattan headquarters of the Food Emporium, the upscale chain of food stores. She arrived with a bowl of sauce, "a beautiful napkin" and absolutely no idea how the grocery business works.
 
A Trial Run
 But the sauce "had panache," said Robert Damato, director of the deli and bakery divisions, and Food Emporium executives decided to give the product a trial run in five stores.
The battle was far from over. Ms. DiStefano needed to find someone to pack her sauce in sufficient quantities. She turned to "co-packers," companies that specialize in packing for other companies' labels.
She was disappointed to learn that all said they could not pack the tomatoes cold but would have to heat them first. No matter that she argued that the beauty of her sauce was the pure taste of the chopped-up fresh tomatoes.
"Every co-packer from here to Florida told me I was crazy," she said.
She is not the type to take no for an answer. "I was on a mission," she said. She would do it herself. Somehow.
Ms. DiStefano's brother let her use a 300-square-foot store near Shea Stadium he had leased. The space was cramped, and the hours were endless. Ms. DiStefano sometimes bathed Daniel in the same sink where she washed tomatoes. The crew was mainly women from Ecuador.
Fresh tomatoes were the key. Thus it was that Ms. DiStefano ventured to the Hunts Point market, a place she had not known existed. She arrived in her Volkswagen a little after midnight, when she had been told the selection was greatest.
It was a world she was clearly unprepared for. Wandering aimlessly between the huge trucks, stacks of crates and piles of produce of the world's biggest vegetable market, she pushed sleeping Daniel in a carriage. Her mother walked beside her, waving about a big pocketbook.
"Get out of here!" an alarmed merchant screamed. "Take the baby away! Hide that pocketbook!"
He then led the odd entourage around personally. And gradually, but only gradually, she acquired market smarts. People would show her a sample of beautiful tomatoes, then slip her ones much inferior. When she asked for credit, she was told, "Do you know what we do to people who don't pay their bills?"
"You don't know the humiliation I had to face," Ms. DiStefano said.
But things were improving. In January 1990, she finally quit her job at the design studio. She began taking around her sauce, which retails now for $6 a pint jar, to gourmet stores. Many were interested.
She even got an early nibble from a major food distributor, whose representative mentioned quantities she could not then dream of producing. To hide the facts, she lied and said she was in the process of building a 100,000-square-foot plant and hiring her own sales force.
"In the meantime, I'm hysterical, crying," she said. "Every day, I thought it was going to end."
What happened next is the key to her present success. Louis DaGroza, a businessman she met through friends, was impressed with what Ms. DiStefano was doing. And he was interested in a new plant for his own company, Bruno's Specialty Foods, which makes kosher frozen entrees.
When he came upon a 10,000-square-foot building in Sayville, he made a proposal to Ms. DiStefano. She could have half the space and he would put $100,000 into her company. In return, he would get 45 percent ownership of Pomodoro.
Pomodoro now has distributers in California, Colorado, Illinois, Massachusetts, Maryland and elsewhere.
 
A Blur of Motion
 Ms. DiStefano's typical business day is a blur of motion. She checks a broker on constantly changing tomato prices; she converses with the rabbi who regularly comes to make sure her processes -- as well as Mr. DaGroza's -- are kosher; she checks operations with her 21-year-old sister, Lia, who is operating the eight-foot-tall, 300-gallon 1948-vintage kettles she bought from Chef Boy-Ar-Dee.
Not that she doesn't have help, mainly from women. Her accountant, lawyer, production manager and all other supervisors are women. Most of her 30 other workers are local housewives who are welcome to adjust their schedules for personal needs.
Lately, Ms. DiStefano has begun to get inquiries from big companies interested in buying into her dream. She isn't ruling them out, but said, "I'd like to keep it a privately owned profitable company."
Most important, her feet are now firmly on the ground. She pays herself $39,000 a year, is renting a house in East Hampton, L.I.; schedules her life so she can often pick up Daniel, now 6, from school, and after years of nothing but struggle is dating a man she calls "a prince."
She feels this incredible pride. "I walk around the plant, and I still get butterflies in my stomach," Nancy DiStefano said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: Peruvians Refuse to Give Up Hope

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In Peru profound changes are coming from the grass roots, which may explain why President Alberto Fujimori has extensive popular support. Despite desperate economic times, produced partly by the developed world's demand that Peru repay its foreign debt and damage (estimated at $22 billion) resulting from terrorist destruction, not all is glum in Peru. 
 Mr. Fujimori was elected by the people, who felt themselves disenfranchised by their government. He seems to me to have stayed attuned.
The large-scale move to the large cities has produced not only misery but also a way out of misery. The largely indigenous immigrants from the Andes bring a fierce capacity for hard work and an ancient commitment to community. Democracy is rarely talked about and frequently practiced. The slums of 20 years ago are no longer slums.
In the last five years, I have taken 70 volunteers from Fordham University, St. Peter's College and other places in the United States to work in southern Peru beside the people. Most of this time Peru has been in economic decline. The people we worked with have become much, much poorer. But they have not given up hope. Nor have they remained paralyzed. Having no money, they tithe time and energy to build schools, health posts and waterworks; they run breakfast programs so that all their children can eat a meal a day.
These people support Mr. Fujimori; they do not canonize him. He provides their best hope that Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) terrorism and corrupt government can be overcome. Remarkable police work has led to the capture of Abimael Guzman Reynoso and other Shining Path higher-ups. The terror practiced by police and military on the people caught in the middle has also apparently diminished in recent months.
Watch President Fujimori as he tries to empower some of the grass-roots leadership to speak with the voice of their people in the constituent assembly, which will rewrite the constitution and restore representative government.
 
(Rev.) PAUL BRANT
Jersey City, Oct. 21, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Peruvians Refuse to Give Up Hope;
The Struggle Continues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The arrest of Abimael Guzman Reynoso is undeniably a serious loss for the Peruvian revolution. However, in "Peru Waiting to See if Rebels Open Offensive" (news article, Oct. 18), you mistakenly state that I share the view of Prof. David Scott Palmer that the leadership of Shining Path, the Communist Party of Peru, will fracture in a "bitter power struggle" or end up a "loose confederation" with Mr. Guzman in jail. 
 Mr. Guzman and the party leadership spent 15 years building an ideologically unified, revolutionary Maoist organization able to withstand severe repression and replace fallen leaders even before beginning the armed struggle in 1988.
This unity has been tested through a 20-year "people's war." This is why a 1992 Rand Corporation report acknowledges that previous losses of top leadership had "no noticeable long-run impact on group actions."
Mr. Guzman has been central to the growth of the party, but he himself stated: "What is important to me is the conviction that others will continue the work to which I am committed." Unquestionably, a collective leadership has been forged to carry on the party strategy during his incarceration.
 
HERIBERTO OCASIO
Berkeley, Calif., Oct. 20, 1992
The writer is national spokesman for the Committee to Support the Revolution in Peru.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1011 words

HEADLINE: House Leaders and Freshmen Agree To Try to Avoid Carter Era's Failures

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Freshman Democrats and House leaders met behind closed doors today to exhort each other to work together with the Clinton Administration and to avoid repeating the conflicts of Jimmy Carter's Presidency.
In the first of three regional meetings with their freshman class of 63 or 64 (depending on the outcome of a vote count in one district) the leaders heard two California newcomers, Jane Harman and Lynn Schenk, recall their frustrating days working for the Carter Administration. Those difficulties, they said, had to be avoided. 
 And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader who strongly opposed Mr. Carter's proposal to contain hospital costs, told the group: "Now we've got a quarterback on the field. We've got to follow his plays." He said he had urged the new members to offer their ideas to the Clinton Administration as soon as it was organized, but then to be loyal to what it later proposed.
 
'A Failed Opportunity'
 Speaker Thomas S. Foley told reporters that the Carter years of 1977 through 1981, the last time the Democrats had controlled the White House and both houses of Congress, were widely acknowledged to be "a failed opportunity."
"We didn't work closely enough together on the legislative agenda" because of failures in personal relationships, he said.
Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a chief deputy whip, said he was optimistic because President-elect Bill Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore had "reached out to members of the House in their campaign."
"We know these two guys," Mr. Lewis said confidently.
Ms. Harman, who worked in the Carter Administration as deputy secretary of the Cabinet, said today's meeting was "fabulous."
"We haven't had this fast start before," she said. "Some of us remember 1976, with a new Democratic President and a Democratic Congress, and things didn't go so well."
Conversations with the traveling leaders and with the newly elected members suggested there was near consensus on legislative priorities: spurring the economy, cutting the deficit and dealing with health care. Jay Inslee, a freshman from Washington, said later of the meeting's mood, "We do realize that we have to act, and we have to act quickly."
There was apparently little talk of Congressional-reform topics like term limits or staff sizes, topics popular with Republicans and talk-show hosts during this fall's campaign.
"We don't have an image problem," said Karen Shepherd of Utah. "We have a substance problem. We're going to go to work on the substance, and the image problem will evaporate."
The tone of the meeting appeared to be generally warm, with neither lectures from the leaders nor ultimatums from the newcomers. "The leadership sat there and listened to every one of us," said an impressed Lucille Roybal-Allard of California.
Maria Cantwell of Washington said: "We weren't asked to go to Washington. The leadership came to us."
 
No Balloons and Lollipops
 Sam Copersmith of Arizona, an advocate of a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, said differences over whether such an amendment was a wise course would not cause serious problems as long as Congress and President Clinton were "on a winning team," with progress being made on the deficit and on a few other key issues like the economy and health care. Mr. Clinton and the House Democratic leaders oppose a balanced-budget amendment.
Anna Eshoo of California, one of the few to stress internal House issues, said she told the group that she expected to be "part of a Congress that is willing to reform itself internally, streamline itself." She said the meeting's tone was "no nonsense," and that the members knew that the tasks they faced would be hard.
"There isn't anyone sitting there saying bring out the balloons and lollipops," Ms. Eshoo said.
Another freshman, Walter R. Tucker 3d, the mayor of Compton, on the edge of the Los Angeles riot area, said he told the meeting that more had to be done for the cities: "We're just one step away from another riot if we don't get our act together."
Mr. Foley said one purpose of the meeting, and of those in Chicago on Monday and in Atlanta on Tuesday, was to acquaint the new members with the accelerated organizational pace planned for this year. In the past, he said, organization of the House had been "somewhat leisurely."
But in 1993, Mr. Foley said, "We'll be ready in every sense of the word before Bill Clinton takes office," and will be able to act on his recommendations immediately.
Mr. Foley told the freshmen, "Without divided Government to be an excuse for failure to act, there is a responsibility on the Democratic Party to act."
 
Committee Wish Lists
 This was not a group of naive or starry-eyed new lawmakers. Dan Hamburg, who defeated an incumbent Republican, Frank Riggs, in a district on the coast north of San Francisco, said he was here to "meet people and angle a little bit for committee assignments."
"I want an influential committee," Mr. Riggs said. With a seat on a powerful committee like Ways and Means, which handles tax legislation, or Appropriations, which doles out money, he added, "you can influence things on other committees."
Those two committees and Energy and Commerce traditionally do not have freshman members, but Mr. Foley has said it is "likely" they will in the next Congress.
Among the 18 freshmen present today was one who may not be a new member after all. Mark A. Takano of Riverside, Calif., came to report that he had just fallen behind by 400 votes in the still incomplete counting of absentee ballots. If he ends up losing to Ken Calvert, the net Democratic losses will be 10 seats, leaving them 258 seats in the House in the 103d Congress.
 Because of an editing error, the article also misattributed a quotation. It was Mr. Hamburg, not his defeated opponent, Frank Riggs, who said, "I want an influential committee" and explained that by sitting on a powerful committee like Ways and Means "you can influence things on other committees."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a meeting of new members of Congress identified a California Representative-elect incompletely in some copies. He is Dan Hamburg.

House leaders met in Los Angeles with freshman Democrats to foster harmony with the Clinton Administration. (Liliana Nieto del Rio for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Guerrillas Are Imperiling Colombia's Oil Bonanza

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARRANCABERMEJA, Colombia

 BODY:
A recent series of attacks by two left-wing guerrilla armies is spreading anxiety in the Colombian Government, endangering the economic future of the country and clouding its hopes to become one of the Western Hemisphere's major oil exporters in the 1990's.
Responding to the threat, the Government has strengthened its armed forces and dispatched them to strategic areas to try to stop the violence. 
 [After another spasm of rebel attacks over the weekend, including a raid in which 26 policemen were killed, a 90-day state of emergency was imposed by President Cesar Gaviria Trujillo. The measure enables Mr. Gaviria to impose security measures by decree.]
Of particular concern to the authorities is the country's oil industry, which has been in existence for decades but was catapulted to a new level of importance by the announcement in late October that two oilfields in remote Casanare State contained two billion barrels of oil, the largest find in the Americas since the discovery of the Prudhoe Bay field in Alaska in 1969.
 
Home of Rebel Armies
 Even though the Casanare fields, 150 miles southeast of here, are smaller than preliminary estimates, the new oil production is expected to displace coffee as the country's most valuable legal export by 1995, and to propel Colombia into the club of major Latin American oil exporters, after Venezuela and Mexico. But the fields are in a section of the Andean foothills that since the 1960's has sheltered two of the hemisphere's most obscure and most durable guerrilla armies: the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the smaller and more radical National Liberation Army.
The oil industry is expected to become a major battleground in a war that already takes 2,000 lives a year, and could force Washington, which focuses almost exclusively on stopping the country's drug traffickers, to reassess its priorities in Colombia.
After nearly three decades of combat against the two Marxist rebel groups, which were founded in the 1960's with help from the Soviet Union and Cuba, the Colombian Government has been able to confine most rebel activity to remote areas, away from the major cities. But the importance of the new-found oilfields, which sit squarely on the guerrillas' turf, makes them an inviting target.
Already, Colombia's 8,000 guerrillas extort at least $200 million a year from rural businesses, according to a recent study by Semana magazine, Colombia's most widely read newsweekly.
Guerrillas levy taxes on coal and gold production and provide paid guard services to cocaine and heroin laboratories. Responsible for about one half of the 900 kidnappings recorded in Colombia so far this year, guerrillas specialize in kidnapping cattle ranchers and managers of banana plantations.
 
State Capital Isolated
 The guerrillas are also increasing their attacks on oil installations. They have recently dynamited the oil pipeline leading from central Colombia to the Caribbean and have temporarily isolated Yopal, the capital of Casanare, by blowing up a telephone installation and blocking a highway with buses.
The campaign was part of a larger offensive that included raids on other oil installations and attacks to enforce a nationwide intercity bus stoppage, and provoked the Government to indefinitely suspend peace talks, which had been scheduled to resume on Oct. 31 in Mexico. Officials said the rebels had carried out 198 major attacks since the last round of peace talks in May.
Vowing to keep guerrillas out of the oilfields, the Government has created an 8,000-man "energy police" force to protect oil and electricity installations. In addition, it plans to station in Casanare a regular army brigade specially trained in counterinsurgency.
"It's a versatile, fast and highly mobile unit," Brig. Gen. Fernando Tapias Stahelin, the commander of the brigade, said here as he watched his men going through a training exercise, clambering on and off an American-made Blackhawk helicopter.
General Tapias is a graduate of counterinsurgency training at the United States Army center at Fort Bragg, N.C., and his helicopters were bought from the United States. But other units of the Colombian armed forces and police receive their helicopters virtually free of charge as part of Washington's antidrug aid to Colombia, which totals $58 million this year.
This allocation of American aid reflects Washington's priority on drug trafficking, which captures the vast majority of the international attention and assistance turned toward Colombia. But the oil discovery could force the United States, the largest buyer of this country's oil, to take more interest in Colombia's domestic war.
"With United States oil production declining, it is in our geopolitical interest to lessen dependence on the Middle East," said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, an industry research group based in New York.
In fact, the drug war and the guerrilla war often intersect. General Tapias said that in a recent raid his men had captured a cocaine laboratory and, alongside it, a guerrilla bomb factory.
Jorge Gomez Lizarazo, head of Barrancabermeja's civil rights group, asserted that most of Washington's anti-narcotics aid was not being used for its intended purpose. "The majority of the police aid is used to combat the armed insurgency," he said in a telephone interview from Washington.
Mr. Gomez left here in September after four co-workers at the Regional Committee for the Defense of Human Rights were killed in 20 months. Since 1988, 48 leaders of the oil workers' union here have been killed. The deaths, attributed to right-wing death squads, which often have links to the military, make this oil center of 250,000 people one of the most violent places in Colombia, where the nationwide homicide rate is seven times that of the United States.
But even though the oil bonanza and the breakdown in peace talks are expected to sharpen Colombia's political violence, few expect the issue to be settled by fighting.
"The Government now marks two years of a continuous and intense military activity against the guerrillas, with all the maximum war power, without succeeding in decimating or even limiting the action of the guerrilla groups," said Voz, the weekly newspaper of the Colombian Communist Party, an orthodox group sympathetic to the guerrillas.
Horacio Serpa Uribe, a former Mayor of this city who resigned in September as the Government's chief negotiator with the guerrillas, also acknowledged the strength of the rebels, but he said it was doing them no good.
"The guerrillas have advanced militarily, but they have lost politically," he said, referring to opinion polls that indicate a hardening of public attitudes against the insurgents. "I told the guerrillas, the more you push, the greater the reaction will be."

Mr. Gaviria carried the coffin yesterday at the funeral in Bogota of one of the police officers killed. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Transit Fares May Rise, M.T.A. Says

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
The transit fare in New York City will increase 25 cents next year unless the state helps close the Transit Authority's projected $266 million budget deficit, city transit officials said yesterday.
The officials called on the legislature to enact a broad range of proposals that would give the Metropolitan Transportation Authority greater control of its government subsidies and a larger portion of state transportation funds. 
 "We're either going to swim together as a region or sink as separate geographic areas," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the M.T.A., the Transit Authority's parent agency.
 
$165 Million Shortfall
 The Transit Authority found itself in a similar situation earlier this year, when it appealed to Albany to help close a $165 million shortfall. State legislators responded with a series of accounting adjustments and subsidies that closed the gap, but did nothing to insure that the Transit Authority would avoid the same predicament next year.
In unveiling the proposed 1993 budget of $3.7 billion yesterday, transit officials fired the first salvo in the annual battle over state transportation funds. Mr. Stangl said that while he opposes a fare increase, it may be inevitable if "structural problems" in the way the Transit Authority is financed are not reformed.
Alan F. Kiepper, president of the Transit Authority, said that revenues from real estate taxes and token sales have fallen by almost $250 million in the last three years. During the same period, state and Federal subsidies have remained almost constant, he said.
Mr. Kiepper said the Transit Authority has sought to keep expenses down by freezing management salaries, cutting positions and reducing material purchases. Between 1990 and 1992, the authority's operating expenses rose by $2 million, an amount Mr. Kiepper said was negligible.
 
'Doing More With Less'
 Mr. Stangl said that during the same period, bus and subway service improved, according to surveys of riders. "We're doing more with less," he said.
To close the projected deficit and to help finance the M.T.A.'s $10 billion five-year capital program, Mr. Stangl has asked legislative leaders to give the M.T.A. about $280 million from a state tax on oil companies. The M.T.A. has also asked Albany to change state rules that prevent the authority from transferring surplus money from its commuter railroad lines to the transit system. Earlier this year the Legislature rejected an M.T.A. request to transfer $90 million from the commuter lines to the Transit Authority.
In the past, such proposals have been opposed by suburban and upstate legislators, who have wanted to use state transportation money for highways and commuter railroads instead of city subways and buses.
Yesterday, Mr. Stangl appealed for support from those legislators, particularly state Senator Norman J. Levy, the influential Nassau County Republican who heads the Senate Transportation Committee. In comments clearly directed at Mr. Levy, Mr. Stangl noted that 65 percent of the people who ride the Long Island Rail Road into Manhattan use city subways.
"The economy of Westchester and Long Island is very much linked to the city's," Mr. Stangl said. "We need to look at this broadly."
Mr. Levy did not return phone calls to his office yesterday.
 
$65 Million in Dispute
 The M.T.A. has also asked the city to restore $65 million that was cut from the city's subsidies to the authority in 1988. The $65 million has been a source of dispute: the M.T.A. has said the reduction should have been temporary; the city has said it was permanent.
Barbara J. Fife, deputy mayor for planning and development and a member of the M.T.A. board, said yesterday that the Dinkins administration was prepared to negotiate with the M.T.A. about the $65 million. But she said the city also wants the state to allocate more money to the Transit Authority.
"We have an interest in keeping the fare from rising," she said. "But $65 million alone is not going to put this budget into the black."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 0.81, to 3,240.87, After Rally Fades

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed barely higher yesterday after comments about the economy by President-elect Bill Clinton ended a rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 0.81 point at 3,240.87 after retreating from a high of 3,259.78. 
 In the broad market, advancing issues edged out declines, 992 to 853. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 197.6 million shares, compared with 205.3 million Friday.
The Nasdaq index retained a strong gain of 5.23 points to close at 622.05, buoyed by a rally in biotechnology stocks.
 
Remarks by the President-Elect
 The selloff in blue-chip stocks came when Mr. Clinton told reporters in Little Rock, Ark., that he saw "a lot of very troubling signs in the economy."
Clinton aides announced during the weekend that the President-elect was planning a gathering of business, government and economic leaders to discuss the economy and try to determine what the problems are and identify solutions.
"They're trying to downplay expectations," said John Blair, head trader at County NatWest. He said that the market was generally satisfied so far with the election of Mr. Clinton, but that investors were eager to see his Cabinet choices.
The new President will face not only a ballooning budget deficit but also a looming trade war concerning European Community oilseed subsidies, which Washington wants to be cut along with other farm support.
Analysts said investors were also keeping an eye on this week's Treasury refunding of more than $37 billion. The first leg of the refunding yesterday went through as expected.
 
Biotechnology Stocks Gain
 Storage Technology topped the actives list on the New York Stock Exchange, losing 8 1/8, to 23 5/8, after it announced another delay in its Iceberg disk array product. Testing of Iceberg will now extend into the second half of 1993.
On the Nasdaq, Medco Containment rose 1 3/8, to 33 5/8. It said it might reduce the number of shares offered for Diagnostek, which made a downward revision in its first-quarter results and said it sees a big drop in its second-quarter net. Diagnostek fell 6 3/4, to 9 1/8.
Walt Disney rose 3/4, to 40 7/8. Oppenheimer and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette repeated their buy ratings.
Biotechnology stocks gained on a combination of positive individual company news and analysts' recommendations. Centocor rose 2 1/8, to 15 1/8; Biogen added, 2 1/2 to 44 3/4; Gensia Pharmaceuticals rose 2 1/2, to 28 3/4, and Synergen added 2 7/8, to 55 7/8.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks edged up 1.01 points, to 418.59. The American Stock Exchange index rose 2.10, to 385.36.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.54 point, to 230.63.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of New York, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 4,087.784, up 13.757, or 0.34 percent.

HEADLINE: Jersey City Mayor Warns of Possible Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The 33-year-old investment counselor who was elected Mayor here last week said today that the city could be bankrupt before he completed his seven-month term.
The new Mayor, Bret Schundler, who finished first in a field of 19 candidates, was sworn into office in a 45-minute ceremony in which he held out the promise, or at least the hope, of lower taxes and improved services, but added a warning. 
 "I will ask the state to give Jersey City the help it deserves," Mr. Schundler said, "and I believe state officials will want to go along. If the residents face another property-tax increase and a drop in tax collections in the coming months, the city will be technically bankrupt by the summer, and the state will have to deal with the city's $600 million debt."
The Mayor said he would take a permanent 25 percent cut in his $60,000 salary and a further cut of one-third, which translates to reducing his salary to $30,000, until his plan for a citywide tax cut bears fruit. The announcement drew loud applause from 200 supporters who crowded into the City Council chambers to watch Mr. Schundler be sworn in by his wife, Lynn, a lawyer.
 
Selective Cuts Called For
 Mr. Schundler said he hoped to raise revenues by selling city tax liens and to ease taxes by lowering real estate assessments, which would reduce the taxes the city owes Hudson County.
He also said the city must improve its collection of delinquent taxes. The city is required to maintain a budget reserve to make up for uncollected taxes, and, with 20 percent of property owners unable or unwilling to pay their taxes, the fund is now up to $40 million. The rate of city tax collection has dropped about 18 percentage points in the last five years, to 80 percent.
Mr. Schundler said he would reject the budget presented by the City Council, which he said would require a $6 tax increase for each $1,000 of residential assessment and drive even more people off the tax rolls.
The Mayor promised to work with the Council members on a new spending plan in the next seven weeks. He also said he would not agree to a 10 percent cut in funding for all city departments. "That would cut into the muscle of some departments that have already trimmed down," he said. "We must first attack the waste to avoid service cuts and unnecessary layoffs."
Mr. Schundler said he would keep campaign promises to put more police officers on the streets, this time on motor scooters, and to seek the state Legislature's permission for city residents to receive state education aid in the form of vouchers that could be used to send their children to schools of their choice.
 
Seeks to Form Coalition
 Mr. Schundler was elected with only 10,500 votes, out of more than 50,000 cast, to succeed a series of interim mayors in this city of 228,000. The office became vacant early this year when the incumbent, Gerald McCann, was convicted of Federal fraud charges. He is serving 33 months in prison.
The new Mayor was the beneficiary of splits in a number of recognizable political blocs last week but will face more unified opposition in the next regular election in May. He said he recognized that he must put together a coalition, including a slate of nine Council running mates, to be a viable candidate then.
Jack Finn, the campaign manager for Councilwoman Marilyn Roman, who served for four months this year as interim mayor and finished third in last week's election, shared that assessment. "There were many new voters pulled out by the presidential election who wanted to have nothing to do with anyone connected with the government," Mr. Finn said, "and they ended up supporting Bret. The real question now is can he forge a coalition that can win in May."
Mr. Schundler, who was born in Colonia, graduated from Harvard Unversity with honors in 1981 and then worked as a Congressional aide and a campaign coordinator for Gary Hart's 1984 presidential run. He moved to Jersey City in 1985, when he went to work for Salomon Brothers. He later joined C. J. Lawrence, an economics research company, and in 1990 left to work on his own as a financial manager.
Last year Mr. Schundler registered as a Republican and ran unsuccessfully for the State Senate.

HEADLINE: Swinging the G.M. Ax: Which Plants Are Next?

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
For John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., the new chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, the hard part is just beginning. By the end of the year, G.M. has said it will name four more assembly plants to be closed as part of its strategy to cut its excess capacity.
The four plants will be in addition to the G.M. mini-van plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Willow Run in Ypsilanti, Mich., where full-size rear-wheel-drive cars are built. These plants were named earlier in the year when G.M. announced 12 of 21 assembly and parts-making factories it planned to close. These were on top of earlier G.M. closing announcements affecting factories like those in Scarborough, Ontario, and the West plant in Pontiac, Mich. 
 Predicting the new plants likely to be closed has grown increasingly difficult, industry experts said, as the company has shifted production of models in a way that eliminates some options. "One must question how serious G.M. is about closing facilities," said Clifford J. Swenson, manager of production forecasting for Jacobs Automotive, a consulting firm in Little Falls, N.J. "They have not been overly aggressive."
 
Three at Great Risk
 G.M. officials and the United Automobile Workers union declined to comment, but Mr. Swenson pinpointed three plants with the greatest risk of being closed: one of the two plants in Oshawa, Ontario, that build mid-size cars like the Chevrolet Lumina; one of three plants that build full-size pickup trucks in Oshawa, Fort Wayne, Ind., and Pontiac (at the East plant), and a Detroit plant that builds truck and motor-home chassis.
Beyond those three, however, a surprise seems in store, perhaps on the order of the stunning news in February when G.M. abruptly announced it would close its only plant that makes mini-vans and instead build a new version at a plant in Doraville, Ga. The big surprise may be that G.M. will have to drop well-known models.
It labored over consolidating its rear-wheel-drive car production in Arlington, Tex., or Ypsilanti before Arlington won out, but some experts question whether G.M. should continue to build the large sedans at all.
Maryann N. Keller, an analyst at Furman Selz in New York, said the large Chevrolet Caprice and Buick Roadmaster models were not making money for G.M. because many were sold to fleets with little or no profit.
To complicate things, G.M. seems to have eliminated some alternatives. G.M. once had the option of consolidating production of large, front-drive cars from three plants to two.
The ones to stay open under that move, Mr. Swenson had predicted, would be Flint, Mich., and Wentzville, Mo., while the plant in Orion Township, Mich., would be closed. But G.M. has said it will shift Oldsmobile 88 production to Orion, which will also build updated models of the Buick Riviera and Oldsmobile Toronado.
Also, its Linden, N.J., and Moraine, Ohio, assembly plants looked like candidates for the padlock but G.M. has signaled that it will reopen the Linden plant to produce a new small pickup truck. Moraine has been promised a new paint system, a hint that it may stay in business.
The willingness of the U.A.W. to be more flexible may also be an important factor as G.M. considers which plants to close.
A nine-day strike in late August by workers at a G.M. parts plant in Lordstown, Ohio, led to costly shutdowns of nine assembly plants, including the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.
Strikes can wipe out any savings that the company may be able to wring from suppliers as part of its mission to cut costs.
In another possible move, Corvette production might be shifted from a low-volume plant in Bowling Green, Ky. One option might be to move the Corvette to Ste. Therese, Quebec, where G.M. makes other sports cars. But making the Corvette, an American icon, outside the United States is difficult to picture. "But then again," Mr. Swenson said, "a new day may be dawning at G.M."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yield of 3-Year Notes Up Sharply

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Treasury auctioned $15.5 billion of three-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 5.17 percent, almost a half percentage point more than at the auction in August. The sharp rise in yield was another sign of how quickly the mood in the bond market can change.
"Its a very strange time," said Mary Rooney, an economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "People can not get positive. People seem to have given up for the rest of the year." 
 It was slightly more than two months ago that yields on the 30-year bond were at a six-year low of 7.25 percent and the discount rates on three- and six-month bills were below 3 percent, their lowest in about 30 years.
The change in mood has several causes, including the uncertainty surrounding the new economic policies of President-elect Bill Clinton. In comments in Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Clinton once again indicated that he was concerned that financial markets not react negatively to his proposals.
 
Apparent Fed Decision
 In addition, the market was undermined by the apparent decision by the Federal Reserve to stop reducing short-term interest rates. There has also been some recent data showing that the economy might be a little stronger than traders and investors had thought.
Patrick Rothstein, managing director at Merrill Lynch Government Securities, also suggested that the investors and dealers might have just pushed the market too far too fast.
"We had priced-in the end of the world," he said, referring to expectations for incredibly slow economic growth. "Now we are back to levels that make more sense. The market may just have gotten ahead of itself."
The rest of the bond market limped though yesterday as the Treasury began its quarterly auction of 30-year bonds and 10- and 3-year notes. The 10-year note auction is today and the 30-year bond auction is Thursday, after the Veterans Day holiday tomorrow.
 
Note to Be Reopened
 Instead of auctioning a new 10-year note, the Treasury announced last week that it would reopen the current 63/8 percent note due in August 2002 because of a severe shortage of the note in the market. The note will have the same 63/8 percent coupon with 9 3/4 years to maturity.
In late trading in the secondary market, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was trading at 9413/32 , up 9/32to yield 7.73 percent, down from 7.76 percent Friday. In the pre-auction, or when-issued, market, the new 30-year bond was trading at a yield of 7.72 percent, down from 7.74 percent Friday.
The prices of notes fell across the board. The two-year note was down 4/32 point to yield 4.53 percent, up from 4.46 percent Friday. The three-year note auctioned yesterday was yielding 5.15 percent in the when-issued market. And the 9 3/4-year noted to be auctioned today was yielding 6.98 percent, down from 6.99 percent Friday.
The small drop in the yield of the three-year note indicated that there was some demand for it after the auction. And the drop in yields on the other two securities to be auctioned may indicate a little more comfort with the two remaining Treasury sales.
The discount rates on three-month and six-month bills rose sharply at the regular weekly Treasury auction yesterday. For the three-month bill, the average discount rate was 3.10 percent, up from 3.05 percent last week and the highest since the 3.17 percent on Aug. 31. The discount rate for the six-month bill was 3.30 percent, up from 3.27 percent last week and the highest since the 3.31 percent of July 13.
The main reason for the decline in the bill market was the disappointment after the Federal Reserve decided not to cut short-term interest rates further in October. But Darwin L. Beck, the director of the economics department at the First Boston Corporation, said the Fed could still move in the future if the economic data became worrisome again.
"Just as the expectation got too high in October that they would ease, the expectation that they will never ease again has gotten too high," he said.
The auction of three-year notes went well because expectations were low, traders said. Dealers had aggressively sold at the end of last week to bring prices down and yields up ahead of the auction. This is a regular tactic before auctions because it can make new securities cheaper for dealers.
Since the details of the auction were announced last week and trading began in the pre-auction market, the yield on the three-year note moved from 5.04 percent to 5.17 percent just before the deadline for bids at noon yesterday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall in U.S. Following Plunge Overseas

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Copper futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York after prices plunged in London.
Several Comex contracts fell to 10-month lows in morning trading in reaction to the heavy liquidation on the London Exchange Market, according to Bernard Savaiko, an analyst at Paine Webber. The turmoil in London came amid speculation that China was a heavy seller of copper. 
 It was the fourth straight session of declines, as supplies continued to outpace demand as a result of the weak global economy. At the London Metal Exchange, copper stocks totaled 320,475 tons, up 2,675 tons as of Nov. 6.
Steady selling by Japan and China, as well as concerns about Russian sales of copper and other base metals, had already chipped at the foundation of the copper market last week, Mr. Savaiko added.
In New York, the December copper contract closed 1.55 cents lower at 94.80 cents a pound, slightly above the five-year low of 90 cents.
In other commodity markets, cotton closed marginally higher ahead of the Agriculture Department's crop report today, while grains ended lower on expectations for large yields in that same report.
Although cotton analysts also expect total United States cotton production in 1992 to loom large in the Agriculture Department's monthly crop report, December edged higher on commission house buying to close up 0.05 of a cent at 55.73 cents a pound.
"We have had some fairly favorable weather in the Southwest during October and parts of the late cotton crop in West Texas look good," said Carl Anderson, a cotton specialist at Texas A & M University. But he also noted crop deterioration in the Delta and Southeast last month.
Experts expect cotton production to range from 15.94 million to 16.261 million bales, up from the Agriculture Department's October estimates of 15.89 million. This estimate was 10 percent lower than last year's production of 17.6 million bales.
On the other hand, expectations for large corn and soybean crops in the Government's report knocked futures prices lower at the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts expect 1992 corn output of a record 9.2 billion bushels, versus the last Agriculture Department estimate of 8.9 billion, and estimated soybean production at 2.13 billion bushels, up from 2.11 billion.
December corn closed off 1 1/2 cents at $2.06 1/2 a bushel, and November soybeans ended off 2 cents at $5.49 1/4 a bushel. Wheat closed mostly higher on hopes China may buy wheat. December soft red wheat settled up 3 1/2 at $3.62 3/4 a bushel.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Helping Marketers Adjust to Mood Swings of Consumers

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
TO some, bungee-jumping is a stunt. To others, it is a sport. But to a growing number of consumers, it is a metaphor for their attitudes and behavior, according to a new study that urges advertisers to consider the phenomenon when plotting marketing strategies.
The study, prepared by the strategic planning and research department at Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. in New York, is called "The American Consumer's 'Quality of Life:' Perception Versus Reality." It posits that the public has been undergoing a series of "bungee-like" mood shifts that are an overreaction to short-term changes in statistical measures covering important areas like the economy, the environment, health care and crime. 
 Larry Chiagouris, the agency's executive vice president of strategic planning and research, said he had named this "the bungee effect" because, "instead of swings that take place over perhaps a few years, you see more and more volatile swings."
As consumers' self-described perceptions of the overall quality of life swing, he added, between exaggerated levels of optimism and satisfaction on one hand, and pessimism and dissatisfaction on the other, they tend to consistently mismatch whatever the reality might be, either positive or negative.
The study, which analyzed government consumer data from the last 16 years, is the latest in a spate of research reports from large multinational agencies that seek to plumb the mysteries of consumer motivation. The reports stem from a growing realization at agencies that creating campaigns that win the acclaim of the chattering classes is not always sufficient to sell products to the consuming classes.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Chiagouris said the most recent bungee-jumping undertaken by American consumers involved leaping from an overly optimistic view during the 1980's to an overly pessimistic view today.
As a result, he added, the type of advertising so prevalent in the 80's, which emphasized overexuberant, overly materialistic life styles that "consumers might not believe they could realistically achieve," has given way to campaigns meant to woo "more cynical" shoppers by offering product-focused information.
"Think of all the ads you saw in the 80's with someone jogging with a sweatband on his or her head," Mr. Chiagouris said. "If it was advertising for sweatbands, O.K. -- but it wasn't."
Now, he added, "when consumers are more pessimistic than reality should make them feel, they're a little more tough to convince. So when they walk into the store and see your product on the shelf, the brand image had better be associated with something of value to them."
That is why, for instance, advertising that Backer Spielvogel produces for the Miller Brewing Company's Miller Genuine Draft beer is "putting so much emphasis on the cold-filtered process" by which the brand is brewed, he continued, "rather than just relying on pretty faces on a beach."
Mr. Chiagouris said the study was intended as the first in a biannual review comparing consumer perceptions and reality. He offered a preview of what he believed subsequent results might reveal in the wake of Gov. Bill Clinton's defeat of President Bush.
"You'll see even more positive perceptions among consumers," he said, "not just because of the change in Administrations, but because a lot of new people are coming to Washington, and Clinton is saying he'll be tackling the economy first.
"By February or March," he added, "you'll find perceptions much, much more significantly improved over where they are today. Yet reality doesn't change that much, that quickly, because it takes time to move the economy.
"As a result, by the summertime, I think we'll begin to see the first signs that sentiment, already improved, is beginning to ebb."
So Mr. Chiagouris warned marketers to beware of "an eagerness to overreact," by rapidly increasing ad-spending budgets, for instance.
"As much as I, or anyone else, would like to see" those budgets rise, he said, it is important "not to get taken with the euphoria of better times."

HEADLINE: Oilmen Ponder Future Under Clinton

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
More than 1,000 oil executives gathered yesterday in Manhattan at the American Petroleum Institute's annual convention to ponder what the Clinton-Gore Administration holds in store for them.
Bill Clinton's platform included calls for reducing oil imports and improving energy efficiency, ideas the oil industry finds worrisome at best, and replacing oil with natural gas, which most oil companies see as a silver lining in a very large cloud. But many executives see the platform as unlikely to be a threat. 
 Jerry M. Brown, executive vice president of Amoco for domestic oil production, said the oil industry would probably be a large target because of environmental considerations.
 
Emphasis on the Economy
 Still, the environment is probably not the first priority, many people at the convention said with a touch of optimism. The industry has argued for years that new environmental mandates impose costs on the economy and is now arguing that the economy cannot face any additional burdens.
"Clinton has recognized the need for business as an engine to drive this economy and create those jobs he's said so much about," said Ron W. Haddock, president and chief executive of American Petrofina Inc.
While oil executives express anxiety about the Vice President-elect, Al Gore, a prominent advocate of alternative fuels and higher energy efficiency, they are not lamenting the outgoing Administration. President Bush is a former Texas oilman, but the industry believes that it lost most of the battles it faced in Washington during his tenure.
For example, it has yet to achieve its top legislative priority of recent years: access to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. And in a struggle earlier this year with the ethanol industry, a competitor, over providing gasoline to areas with significant air pollution problems, the White House ruled against the oil industry.
That decision may be revisited, said Charles J. DiBona, president of the petroleum institute. "It's hard to see how a candidate who won would necessarily feel obligated to honor all the somewhat politically motivated decisions of the candidate who lost," he said.
Other energy decisions that could be reopened include forcing the auto industry to build more efficient cars, a proposal that the Bush Administration opposed and Congress eventually dropped but that Mr. Gore strongly favored. The idea of a gasoline tax also arose during the campaign, but it belonged to a losing candidate, Ross Perot.
 
Opposition to Import Duties
 A related proposal, also aimed at reducing the trade deficit and dependence on imported oil, is to impose import duties on crude oil, but executives say that policy tool would be as ill advised in a Democratic adminstration as it was in a Republican one, mostly because it invites retaliation by oil exporters. The exporters have complained that the governments of importing countries use taxes to make more profit on oil than the exporting countries do.
On the industry agenda, oil companies want permission to drill in many places on the outer continental shelf and would like new rules on gasoline formulas to be as lenient as possible. The overall argument, as framed by Mr. DiBona, is that "an economic plan that doesn't include the energy industry isn't going to work." The industry has pared 450,000 jobs in the last 10 years, 72,000 of them in the last year, Mr. DiBona said. The figure does not include the 1,500 that Chevron said yesterday that it would cut.
Mr. Haddock, expounding on that theme, said the decision to forgo development of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge was costing the gross national product $5 billion a year.

HEADLINE: Clearing Firm's Worst Nightmare

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Lee B. Stern was on his way to Florida on Oct. 22, far from the action, when Darrell M. Zimmerman strode onto the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade and fired off a barrage of orders for Treasury bond futures and options that confused and jolted bond markets around the world.
Despite not being there at the time, the 65-year-old Mr. Stern has become the focal point of much of the resulting controversy. Stern & Company, his family firm, had agreed earlier this year to process Mr. Zimmerman's trades and guarantee settlement of resulting debts to other traders. But when the call came at the end of the day's trading demanding millions of dollars to cover Mr. Zimmerman's liabilities, Mr. Stern balked. 
 Mr. Stern says he wanted an exact assessment of the losses and he wanted time to get back to Chicago. Most of all, he wanted some of the burden to fall on the independent brokers who had handled the trades, which he says were obviously suspicious and should never have been accepted.
That stand escalated what might have been a bizarre but quickly contained patch of financial turbulence into a major challenge of the Board of Trade's accepted relationships among traders, brokers and the clearing firms that support them. It also tarnished Mr. Stern's standing in the trading community, as the Board promptly banned him, two associates and his firm from doing any further business at the exchange.
To be reinstated, Mr. Stern put up $8.5 million and withdrew from the Board of Trade Clearing Corporation, whose more than 120 members handle trade settlements. In pending arbitration proceedings, he is seeking restitution from Mr. Zimmerman and 11 others, including 9 brokers.
Headlines are nothing new for Mr. Stern, who leveraged the fortune he made in Chicago's agricultural and financial exchanges into local prominence as an investor in the White Sox baseball team and the owner of the Chicago Sting, a money-losing but athletically successful soccer team during the 1970's and 1980's.
But he was unprepared for the first rush of news coverage, which Mr. Stern said made his company look less like a victim than a co-conspirator. "The whole thing defies the imagination," Mr. Stern said recently. Most everyone in the rough, insular world of the trading pits here seems to agree with that assessment, although many also include Mr. Stern's behavior in that indictment.
The confirmed events of Oct. 22 are still hazy as Federal and Board of Trade officials continue investigations that may lead to both civil and criminal charges against Mr. Zimmerman and one or more associates. Those charges may come as early as the end of this month. The Board is also expected to adopt new rules that might, among other things, require independent traders like Mr. Zimmerman to be better capitalized.
Reports to date agree that Mr. Zimmerman sold 12,000 contracts on 30-year Treasury bond futures, each contract obligating him to buy Treasury bonds with a face value of $100,000 at a set price at a specified date. He also bought thousands of related put options, each of which gave him the right but not the obligation to sell options on the bond futures at a specific price on or before the expiration date of the put.
Both types of orders amounted to a bet that bond prices would fall, allowing Mr. Zimmerman to pay less for the contracts that would cancel out his trades and thus profit by pocketing the difference.
To the traders who alerted exchange officials it appeared that Mr. Zimmerman was working in tandem with Anthony Catalfo, a new member who had placed large orders and had just begun trading that week. The unexpected flood of orders temporarily pushed prices down further than traders had expected that morning when a release of unemployment figures had proved only mildly disappointing to the bond market.
 
Forced Off the Floor
 Mr. Zimmerman had never placed such sizable orders before and, in any event, did not have the type of membership authorizing him to trade in the futures pit. Both Mr. Catalfo and Mr. Zimmerman were removed from the floor after 45 minutes by exchange officials, who also removed and turned over to Federal law-enforcement officials two visitors signed in by Mr. Catalfo.
Mr. Zimmerman had a paper profit of $2 million at one point, according to someone familiar with the Stern firm's predicament, but he also had potential liabilities that could have run into tens of millions of dollars.
In Mr. Stern's absence, his son Daniel quickly moved from the soybean trading pits to try to whittle down the exposure by making offsetting trades. Later in the morning, Mr. Stern's eldest son, Jeffrey, began directing from his computer the even more complicated task of unwinding the options positions. By the end of the day Mr. Zimmerman's remaining positions showed a sizable loss, and the Board of Trade Clearing Corporation made its fateful margin call to Mr. Stern's firm.
Mr. Stern says brokers should have realized that Mr. Zimmerman was not authorized to trade futures. He also contends that brokers should have at least checked with the Stern firm upon receiving so many huge orders naming it as clearer. Stern is best known as a grain trading firm and is a small player in the bond pits.
"I think it was a case of sheer greed on the part of the brokers and the perpetrators," Mr. Stern said. No brokers named in the arbitration proceedings could be reached for comment. But other traders and brokers, who insisted on not being identified, said they could recall no precedent for Mr. Stern's suggestions or for a clearer's declining to pay up first and argue later about liability.
 
Covering the Debt
 Mr. Stern was safe in assuming that the clearing corporation would cover the debts. It has more than $100 million in assets and access to credit lines to cover members' obligations.
But exchange officials were clearly in no mood to treat the situation as simply an internal dispute, and their retribution was swift. The next day, the memberships of Mr. Stern and his firm were revoked and held as salable assets, along with those of Daniel Stern and Lester Mouscher, a company vice president.
Mr. Stern says he had already offered to provide the full $8.5 million margin call, but it was not until the following Tuesday, four days later, when he "voluntarily" agreed that Stern & Company would drop out of the clearing business at the Board, that the memberships were restored.
Mr. Zimmerman and Mr. Catalfo dropped from sight immediately. But Mr. Stern's local celebrity and his confrontation with the Board did not give him that option.
"I didn't know the ramifications of not meeting the call," Mr. Stern said.
 
Started at the Bottom
 It was a shattering experience for Mr. Stern, who grew up on Chicago's North Side and came to the Board of Trade as a lowly order runner in 1947. His mother, a millinery buyer for a department store, staked him to the $2,500 he needed to become a member in 1949. He began by brokering orders for Cargill, the grain company, but quickly decided that he preferred trading for his own account. When he fretted to a mentor that he had only $500 to work with, he was told, "Son, if you had more, you'd lose it."
Now, a millionaire many times over, he worries that the Zimmerman affair will bring about his retirement at a pace not entirely of his own choosing. "I have to sort out where to put my resources," he said.
But fears about irreparable harm to his reputation have waned. At a recent Chicago Mercantile Exchange meeting, he received a standing ovation from 700 traders and embraces from officers when he was called to the podium with others to get an award for longtime membership.
"From then on, I felt that things were going to be all right," he said.
Still, he gets indignant remembering the first few days of the incident, especially the Board's flat refusal to consider an interim step to restore Daniel Stern's and Mr. Mouscher's memberships in return for the senior Stern's offer to put up the cash value of their memberships. Mr. Mouscher, who is seriously ill with cancer, had sharply curtailed his activity and had been in the process of transferring the membership to his wife.
"I have yet to hear one word of compassion or understanding from the clearing corporation," Mr. Stern said.
Officials of the clearing corporation, including William Feldman, the chairman, and Roger Rutz, the chief executive, refused to respond to repeated requests to discuss the handling of Mr. Stern's case.
 
Eye on the Regulators
 In the ego-riven world of the Chicago exchanges, there are always suspicions that personal grudges are being settled along with policy decisions. But some traders speculate that such feelings were less important than was a desire to show the regulators at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission that longtime insiders do not get favorable treatment. They note that Mr. Stern was chairman of an important administrative committee and a member of the oversight committee; he has been stripped of both positions.
Some traders also suspect that the exchange wanted to re-emphasize the cardinal rule that clearers must know their customers. Other clearers had turned down Mr. Zimmerman's business and he was known to have debts to a clearer at the Mercantile Exchange when Stern & Company signed him up.
Mr. Stern said Mr. Zimmerman had pledged to trade only in small lots and to pay his debts. "And that's all he did for several months before telling us he was going to Europe on vacation," Mr. Stern said. "There was no indication this guy was an accident waiting to happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The whole thing defies the imagination," said Lee B. Stern, whose clearing firm was exposed to losses when an independent trader made large trades in Treasury bond futures last month on the Chicago Board of Trade. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Declines Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher yesterday in choppy dealings on world currency markets.
Gold prices fell worldwide, with their biggest losses in domestic markets. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery lost $3.10 an ounce to settle at $332.60. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $333.25 an ounce, down $2.55 from Friday. 
 The dollar ended mixed in Europe and initially declined when trading shifted to United States markets. Dealers were intent on taking profits after the currency's rise over the last few weeks.
But the dollar ultimately rose because of developments involving other currencies. First, the British pound came under heavy selling pressure. The pound was hurt by speculation that Britain was considering cutting interest rates, said Mike Malpede, an analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago.
Separately, the Japanese yen came under pressure after a steep decline in stock prices on the leading Tokyo exchange. Traders cited growing pessimism over Japan's political turmoil, widely expected to delay Government measures to help the economy.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing of 123.78 Japanese yen, up from 122.95 yen at Friday's close. Later in London, it rose to 123.96 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.25 yen, up from 123.40 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5170, from $1.5375 late Friday. In New York, it cost $1.5120 to buy one pound, less expensive than Friday's $1.5295.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5995 German marks, up from 1.5973; 1.4350 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.4055 French francs, up from 5.4025; 1,367.50 Italian lire, up from 1,267.28, and 1.2569 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2550.
