HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The President-Elect;
Despite Some Signs of Recovery, Clinton Points to Economic Perils

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 9

 BODY:
Laying groundwork for a pre-Christmas economic conference intended as part shock therapy and part consensus-building, President-elect Bill Clinton today dismissed signs of economic recovery, insisted that the economy remained weak and said the focus must be "on the gravity of the situation."
While acknowledging that the unemployment rate had dipped, Mr. Clinton painted an insistently bleak picture of the overall state of the nation's economic health. 
 "The unemployment rate has held steady, even gone down a little bit, but the underlying reality is that unemployment is up, production is down," Mr. Clinton said in a brief talk with reporters as he left the Statehouse here. "There are a lot of very troubling signs in the economy."
 
Dampening Expectations
 The economic conference, which Mr. Clinton's strategists say will be a two- or three-day meeting of business executives, labor leaders, economists and Congressional figures, is shaping up as the focal point of the transition process.
The tone of the President-elect's statements today reflected a conclusion by his advisers that, after a campaign in which candidate Clinton made many promises of economic betterment, it is essential that President Clinton focus the discussion on what can realistically be achieved in a short time.
The economic conference will be a vehicle for doing that, a three-day cold shower of ill economic tidings. Although the meeting remains largely unplanned -- aides say they expect to hold it before Christmas -- Mr. Clinton's strategists say the essential point will be to focus a heavy burst of national attention on what is wrong with the American economy, a notion that some likened to a "national audit."
The emerging point of the conference seems to be in great measure to frame the discussion of economic revival in such a way that Americans will not expect miracles from Mr. Clinton. His advisers said the state of the economy would be presented in dire terms, suggesting that it is considerably worse than either the voters or Mr. Clinton had previously been aware.
One Clinton transition official, speaking on condition of anonymity, suggested that the conference would also be used to build a case that President Bush's economists underestimated the scope of the nation's economic problems.
"There is some concern among economists that the country's economic condition may be somewhat worse than previously reported," the official said.
In making this case, Mr. Clinton would be resuming an argument that was at the center of the campaign, in which he said the economy was doing worse than Mr. Bush cared to admit and the President said the Democrats were painting a dire picture simply to drive him from office.
Other Clinton transition aides hint at the same thing.
"I don't think the summit will be a time of study in terms of prescriptions," said Dee Dee Myers, a spokeswoman for Mr. Clinton. "The idea in calling it an audit is that it will be an honest description of where the country is."
 
Message: 'I Get It'
 She added, "Governor Clinton wants to have an honest accounting as possible of the country's economic situation, and he feels that the best way to do it is to pull together some of the nation's top economists and business leaders to discuss it."
Ms. Myers suggested an additional, more acutely political reason for the conference.
"One of the reason George Bush was not re-elected is that people felt he was not connected to them, to their problems," she said. "One of the first messages Bill Clinton wants to get across is: 'I get it. I understand your needs and fears. I take this seriously and I am going to work on it seriously from the first day of my Administration.' "
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's director of communications, said the President-elect intended to focus a "tempered" view on the economy that would "keep expectations in check."
 
Gathering His Options
 He added, "The only way you can build a consensus towards solution is to make sure the people understand the scope of the problem and that they feel they are part of the solution from the beginning."
Mr. Clinton, in his brief remarks today, made much the same point. Asked what he hoped to accomplish with the conference, he spoke not of solutions, but of problems.
"I want to bring in some of the brightest people in the country from a broad range of backgrounds to talk to them about the gravity of the situation, deal with what our options are, get as many good ideas as I can," he said. "I just think it would be a very good thing for me and for the country where we have two, three days where we really focus on it, and give some people a chance to have their say to me directly and talk about what out options are."
The planning of the economic conference comes as Mr. Clinton faces two simultaneous transitions, one in which he vacates the office of Governor of Arkansas, and another in which he assumes the Presidency.
 
Working Without Titles
 In the last weeks of his campaign, the candidate said several times that he had not studied anything seriously beyond Election Day, and it now appears that both he and his staff are getting a quick education in how much is involved in a transfer of power.
As the Clinton campaign operation shuts down and the transition effort gears up, lines of authority and information have become blurred.
When Mr. Clinton's transition chiefs, Warren M. Christopher and Vernon E. Jordan, revealed the planning for the economic conference in Sunday television interviews, their disclosures clearly caught Ms. Myers unaware. She is serving without benefit of formal appointment as a press secretary.
Mr. Clinton himself, in a rambling, casual chat with reporters on Sunday, spoke repeatedly of his surprise at how much there was to do.
"There's a slew of things you never think about," he said. "I mean, we've got -- there's an inaugural to organize, there's letters, acknowledgments, record packing."

HEADLINE: Prospects for the Elderly Differ Widely by Sex

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
As life expectancy increases and the time from retirement to old age stretches out, men and women find themselves with markedly different prospects, according to a new report from the Census Bureau.
Men tend to die earlier than women, but if they survive, men are more likely to be healthy, self-sufficient and living with their families rather than alone. 
 The differences are most stark among men and women aged 85 and over. In this group, women are three times as likely as men to be poor. But the pattern starts at retirement.
One reason is that women are more likely to be alone, precisely because men have shorter life expectancies. "A major cause of impoverishment among older women is widowhood," said Richard Suzman, director of the office of the demography of aging at the National Institute on Aging.
In 1990, a quarter of all elderly people living alone were poor, with only their own financial resources, including private pensions and programs like Social Security. But men are far less likely to live alone. About 82 percent of the men aged 65 and over were living with their spouses or other relatives, compared with 58 percent of the women. Only one-third of the men 85 and older were living alone, as against two-thirds of the women.
Another reason for the economic disparity is that men and women reach retirement age with very different work histories, according to the report, which was written by a Census Bureau demographer, Cynthia M. Taeuber, from the 1990 census and a variety of other public and private surveys.
Women over the age of 65, who grew up in an era when it was difficult to work outside the home, are less likely to have access to pension and Social Security income in their own names, the report said.
 
31 Million Over 65
 And although men's life expectancy is 71.8 years, about six and a half years less than women's, those men who live a decade or more into retirement are less likely than women their age to need help -- from a spouse or anyone else -- with basics like eating, dressing, bathing, preparing meals, managing money and getting outside. Of men aged 75 and older, 17.2 percent needed such basic help; 30.2 percent of the women did. "Elderly women are likely to have long-term, chronic disabling diseases," the report said, "while men tend to develop relatively short-term fatal diseases.
"The differences between older men and women include differences in education, differences in occupation, presence in the work force, having pensions in their own name," Ms. Taeuber said. "If their wives should happen to die, they remarry real fast."
According to the 1990 census, about 12.5 percent of the nation's population, or 31.1 million people, were 65 or older. About 18 million were 65 to 74; 10 million were 75 to 84; slightly more than 3 million were 85 or older.
 
Other Trends Found
 The wide-ranging report also highlighted several trends that are causing serious concern to social health and welfare planners, including these:
*By far the fastest growth in the elderly population came among the very old; in 1990, three million people in this country were 85 or older, or 1.2 percent of the population -- twice the proportion of very old people in the population in 1960, and six times as large as in 1900.
*The migration trends of the 1980's left a cluster of Farm Belt and Rust Belt states with higher concentrations of elderly than anywhere except Florida. These are also more likely to be poorer and to be living alone or in a nursing home, although the states involved are some of the least able to afford a high concentration of dependent residents.
*Nine states had more than one million residents aged 65 or over, topped by California, with 3 million, and New York and Florida, with 2.4 million each.
*Men, particularly white men, are retiring earlier; 16.4 percent of men older than 65 were in the work force in 1990, compared to 45.8 percent of men in that age group in 1950.
*The ethnic diversity of the elderly is increasing, a trend that is expected to accelerate in the next three decades. About one elderly person in 10 was nonwhite; that proportion should double in 60 years.
"At the same time as some of the ethnic groups that migrated here from Europe are dying out, you're getting an increased representation of minorities among the elderly," Mr. Suzman said. "These are the group most at risk.
"Looking ahead, you're going to get minority cohorts entering old age with inadequate financial resources in terms of pensions and social security because of a checkered work history. One has to be concerned about what pension wealth and social security wealth they are going to have."
"One of the biggest short-term and long-term demographic currents is the very rapid growth of the oldest old group," he added. "They are the group with the highest needs at the lowest level of physical independence. They are going to grow -- we're getting a forewarning now -- that group's going to grow explosively when the baby boom generation hits very old age."
In 1987, the Health Care Financing Administration estimated that the annual average cost of health care for a person aged 65 to 69 was $3,728, with $2,298 of it coming from public programs, usually Medicare. Private costs, either out-of-pocket or covered by insurance, were $1,430.
For an individual 85 or older, the average annual cost was $9,178, with $5,547 coming from public funds and $3,631 coming from private expenses -- including an average of $2,191 in privately financed nursing home care.
"The increasing size of the oldest old population, and their health situation, which clearly declines with increasing age, suggests that a larger number will seek long-term care as part of the continuum from independent living to assisted living at home to institutional care," the report said.

HEADLINE: From Carter to Clinton, A South in Transition

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLAINS, Ga., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Sixteen years after Jimmy Carter's Presidency came to symbolize a resurgent South, Bill Clinton and Al Gore have gone him one better, becoming the first all-Southern ticket to win election since Andrew Jackson and John C. Calhoun in 1828.
But after the Southern pageant of Billy Beer and boiled peanuts, which played out here in the late 1970's, what is most telling in Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore is how little of the stereotyped image of the South they seem to carry with them. 
 The difference reflects different men, different locales and different generations: Mr. Carter's is the last to grow up with segregation, Mr. Clinton's and Mr. Gore's the first to grow up while Southerners, white and black, were being freed from it.
 
A Blend of Two Souths
 But if Mr. Carter symbolized the passing of the old order in the South, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore reflect the complexities of an evolving one that is neither cartoonish Old South nor neutered New South, but a sometimes-baffling blend of the two that is certain to shape the style and the content of the Clinton-Gore Administration.
"The thing about the South is that it's finally multiple rather than singular in almost every respect," said Hodding Carter, the Southern journalist and the State Department spokesman during the Carter Administration. "You've got to say about eight different things about each subject to say what it is, whereas before you could always say just a couple."
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, two Ivy Leaguers steeped in policies and programs, would never be confused with the denizens of William Faulkner's mythical Yoknapatawpha County. But even they bear out Faulkner's famous observation of the South. "The past is not dead," he said of the place. "It isn't even past."
 
Religiosity and Manners
 From their "yes m'am, no m'am" demeanor and their Southern Baptist upbringing to their centrist, eager-to-please campaign, both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore reflect the degree to which the religiosity and manners of Plains, Ga., Hope, Ark., and Carthage, Tenn., still dominate Atlanta, Little Rock and Nashville.
"I'm very skeptical of the notion that the South is disappearing," said Edward L. Ayers, professor of history at the University of Virginia. "People have been saying that for 100 years."
Even if Southerners want to forget their past, it is not likely that the rest of the nation will let them. When Jay Leno joked about the Democrats' "trying to get the all-important 'Hee-Haw' vote," and reporters referred to the Democratic candidates, who studied at Yale Law School and Harvard, as the "double bubba" ticket, it reflected the degree to which the South remains the nation's most caricatured region.
Tom Smith, a social scientist with the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago, said the center's 1990 survey of ethnic images found that Americans view Southerners almost like a separate ethnic group, and regard them as "a little less intelligent, a little less hard-working" than whites in general.
 
The Southern 'Catch 22'
 Prof. John Shelton Reed of the University of North Carolina said, "A fellow named Jack Kirby at Miami University in Ohio once wrote about the Southern 'Catch 22', which is that if you're not picturesque or grotesque or conspicuously rustic, people stop thinking of you as Southern."
Professor Reed, a sociologist, added: "The Waltons on television were located in the Virginia mountains, but they weren't the Dukes of Hazzard, so as time went by, they lost their accents. I don't believe that non-Southerners' repertoire of stereotypes really has space for middle-class Southern folks."
The toned-down regional imagery surrounding Mr. Clinton, and particularly Mr. Gore, partly reflects the degree to which the Southern stereotypes do not fit them. It also results in part from Arkansas's being less definably Southern than a Deep South state like Georgia.
But beyond that, the transition from Mr. Carter to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore also mirrors the social and economic evolution of the South.
Although it was not precisely true even then, the Plains of 1976 could serve as a stand-in for the enduring, essential small-town South. But today it is clear that this town, with its economy based on cotton, soybeans, peanuts and Carter tourism, is not what the South is, but what it used to be.
Like the dusty Carter Administration souvenirs and painfully out-of-fashion, segregation-era memorabilia at the antique shop owned by the former President's cousin Hugh, Plains is a reminder that the South's economic progress has largely bypassed the places that are most distinctly "Southern."
"Some people are making a living, but no one's making any money," said Governor Wilson, a retired farmer, as he talked with a friend in front of the Phillips 66 gas station that used to be Billy Carter's forum.
Professor Reed noted that from 1980 to 1985, 90 percent of the new jobs in the South were in Texas, Florida and a dozen metropolitan areas elsewhere.
Shelby Foote, the Memphis novelist and Civil War historian, noted with great regret "the withering away of the small cities and towns throughout the South," and added: "They're dying at the core and their young people are leaving. It's the life I grew up with, and I can't begin to tell you how highly I think of it."
 
Changes in Race Relations
 At least as sweeping have been the changes in race relations since Mr. Carter made it to the White House in 1976. Mr. Carter's history as a moderate on racial matters and his ties to the Atlanta civil rights leadership helped define a new era of race relations in the South.
Since then, however, the South has moved from outgrowing the legacy of segregation to becoming the center of black political power in America. In 1976, 3 of the 17 blacks in Congress were from the South. Now, 17 of 40 are.
According to the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization specializing in issues affecting blacks, the states that led the nation in the number of black elected officials in 1991 were Alabama with 706, Mississippi with 690 and Louisiana with 551. Alabama and Mississippi alone had 30 percent of the nation's total.
The Rev. Joseph Lowery, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, said there were still pockets of the South with "the smell of the dark ages," when it comes to racial justice.
But from Los Angeles to Howard Beach, the last 16 years have obliterated whatever was left of the idea that the South was unique in its struggles over race.
"I think the race issue is now, more than it's ever been, a national issue," Mr. Lowery said. "The whole country is South. It's down South, up South, over South and out South."
 
Carter Led the Way
 To some people the biggest political difference between Mr. Carter's South and Mr. Clinton's is simply that Mr. Carter came first.
"On Nov. 2 the South is being readmitted to the Union," ran one Carter campaign advertisement in 1976, which called the election "the most important day in our region's history."
In a historic way, Mr. Carter validated for the first time the post-civil-rights South. And having done so, just as John F. Kennedy neutralized the religious issue for Roman Catholics, Mr. Carter rendered the Southern issue less important for those who came after him.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore come to power from a far more national and less parochial base, in terms of votes as well as contacts, than Mr. Carter did. Even so, said Hodding Carter, the journalist, Jimmy Carter's election as a Southerner will make the transition easier for Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore.
"The people who will come north with Clinton and Gore are not coming with a chip on their shoulder," he said, referring to the sometimes-rocky adjustment of the Georgians who formed the nucleus of the Carter Presidency. "They don't have to prove anything to anybody in Washington."
Instead, they come at a time when the economic progress of the South, like that of most of the United States, has stalled, when the aggressively pro-growth economics of the South match the national mood and when the South's voting this year was as fractured as it has been in this century.
 
Oozing Toward the South
 Like the popular crossover country music of Garth Brooks or Billy Ray Cyrus -- country, but only vaguely Southern -- it all suggests a new milestone in the South's slow rapprochement with the rest of the United States. Even the media images -- the difference between "Designing Women" and "Deliverance" -- may finally be beginning to catch up.
"What's happened is that middle America has kind of oozed toward the South, and it's put the South closer to the mainstream," said James C. Cobb, a professor of history at the University of Tennessee.
In that sense, Mr. Carter may be seen as a bridge between the unmistakably Southern politicians of an earlier era and the more national Southern politicians who have come to dominate the region -- whether they are Democrats like Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore or Republicans like Education Secretary Lamar Alexander, a Tennessean, and Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina
But if it is another step along the road, few expect it to be the end of the enduring imagery of the South.
"I think it demarcates something new," said Mr. Ayers, the University of Virginia history professor, "but if we think it's the end of the "Deliverance"-"Gone With the Wind"-"Dukes of Hazzard" image of the South, I think we're being very optimistic."

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices Examine Limits on Commercial Speech

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Supreme Court heard arguments today in a free-speech case that could help define where advertising fits in the hierarchy of First Amendment protections.
The City of Cincinnati asked the Justices to reinstate a ban on the distribution of advertising brochures from newspaper vending machines that the city licenses for use on public property. 
 Two lower Federal courts ruled that the ban violated the First Amendment rights of the companies that publish the free brochures, one a compilation of local real estate listings and the other a listing of adult education courses and social activities.
Cincinnati's lawyer argued today that the selective ban, which eliminated the brochures from 62 vending machines while permitting newspapers to continue using nearly 2,000 other machines, was justified by an effort to control litter and visual clutter. He said the ban was permissible because the Supreme Court has ruled that speech that does no more than propose a commercial transaction has a lower level of First Amendment protection than noncommercial speech.
 
Justices Join the Fray
 The Court has struggled for years over this question without reaching a clear resolution, and some of the strains were evident during the argument today.
The Court had many questions for the lawyers representing each side, and neither lawyer appeared prepared for some of the Justices' most pertinent queries. As often happens when the Justices find an argument less than satisfactory, they jumped into the case themselves, in the process conducting a lively argument that revealed a great deal of their own inclinations.
"Why do you pick on commercial speech?" Justice Antonin Scalia demanded of Mark S. Yurick, Cincinnati's assistant city solicitor. Without giving the lawyer a chance to respond, Justice Scalia continued, "When I think back to the important decisions in my life, buying a house was one of the most important."
Justice Scalia said that for himself and for other home buyers getting information about the real estate market was "much more important than the war in Bosnia," yet Cincinnati was trying to keep the real estate brochures out of the vending machines. "Why is that speech so unimportant that it can be suppressed?" he asked.
Mr. Yurick replied that the Court itself has indicated that commercial speech is entitled to a "lesser degree of protection."
 
Space as a Limiter
 Justice Scalia was not satisfied. He said the Court had allowed government to suppress commercial speech "only for purposes that had something to do with the distinctive nature of commercial speech," as with advertising that was fraudulent. "But commercial speech doesn't clutter up your sidewalks any more than other speech, does it?" Justice Scalia said.
Marc D. Mezibov, a Cincinnati lawyer for the two advertisers, also encountered skeptical responses to his assertion that the Constitution did not permit the city to treat advertisers any differently than newspapers in the context of vending machine access.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor noted that the Supreme Court itself maintains three vending machines for daily newspapers in a small alcove on the ground floor. Would the Court be violating the First Amendment, Justice O'Connor asked, if it refused a request from the publisher of an advertising brochure to add another machine? "Or can we limit it and say we have a very small space and we have to allocate it somehow," she said.
Mr. Mezibov hesitantly answered that the Court might be able to justify a limitation on the basis of limited space.
"Well, in a sense aren't the city streets a finite resource that can get too cluttered?" Justice O'Connor asked.
The argument underscored one difficulty with the Court's commercial-speech doctrine, that of deciding just what commercial speech is. The Cincinnati ordinances that give newspapers a right of access to vending machines while banning the distribution of "commercial handbills" on the streets do not define the two categories.
Several Justices commented that newspapers often carry large amounts of advertising. The real estate advertising brochure in this case, in turn, occasionally carries articles about mortgage interest rates and related subjects.
"Is there a definition that divides the world into two categories, newspapers and commercial speech?" Justice David H. Souter asked Mr. Yurick, the city's lawyer.
Mr. Yurick replied that the two were different and that " 'newspaper' is not such a vague term that it can't be understood by a reasonable person."
Justice Souter asked, "Isn't your problem that the ordinance is inarticulate?" He added: "We have no idea what the city may decide to do next."
The case, Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, No. 91-1200, is an appeal from a 1991 ruling of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, which has its headquarters in Cincinnati.
In the decision, written by Judge Danny J. Boggs, the appeals court said that commercial speech "has a high value to the society" and should be presumed to enjoy full First Amendment protection except when it is false, deceptive, or proposes a commercial transaction that is itself illegal or would create some distinctive harmful effect. The distribution of advertising brochures from vending machines fell into none of these categories, Judge Boggs said.
There were these other developments at the Court today:
 
Cap on Damages
 The Court, without comment, refused to hear a constitutional challenge to a cap on damage awards against the state, adopted by the Colorado Legislature. The Colorado Governmental Immunity Act provides that the state's financial liability, in an accident in which the state is at fault, will be no more than $150,000 per person or $400,000 per accident.
The limitation was challenged on behalf of the 9 people who were killed and the 19 people who were injured when a 6.7-ton boulder being moved by a state highway crew fell off a Rocky Mountain highway and hit a Grey Line sightseeing bus in August 1987. Claims against the state are in the millions of dollars, but the $400,000 limit provides only $11,000 for each victim of the accident if the pool of money were to be divided equally. The Colorado Supreme Court upheld the cap as a valid economic regulation. The case was DeFoor v. Pacheco, No. 91-1922.
 
Detroit Car Dealers
 The Court refused to hear a challenge by 94 Detroit automobile dealers to a finding by the Federal Trade Commission that a 20-year agreement among them to limit their showroom hours and to remain closed on Saturdays was a violation of Federal antitrust law.
Detroit is the only metropolitan area in the country in which automobile dealerships are closed on Saturdays. The dealers entered into the agreement as a way of limiting their employees' working hours in order to thwart a labor organizing drive by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The Sixth Circuit upheld the trade commission's findings earlier this year, while sending the case back to the commission for further consideration of the hours the dealers should be required to stay open. The case was Detroit Auto Dealers v. F.T.C., No. 92-333.

PUB-DATE: November 10, 1992

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Science Desk; Medical Science Page

LENGTH: 1426 words

HEADLINE: Exhibition Examines Scientists' Complicity In Nazi-Era Atrocities

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is a question that few have been willing to face or to debate for decades. Why were so many doctors and scientists so intimately involved in some of the greatest atrocities of Nazi Germany?
There is a tendency to see these atrocities, from the deliberate extermination of millions of people to barbaric medical experiments on thousands of innocents, as isolated occurrences during a period of madness more than a half century ago. 
 Many people, including some historians, have attributed these acts to the perversions of a few sadists and madmen who, through coercion, forced others to become unwilling participants in these programs.
But that view, particularly as it pertains to doctors, nurses and other health workers in Germany before and during World War II, is being challenged by medical historians and ethicists who say that there was more at work than people being forced into compromise and crime at the barrel of a gun.
 
Devaluation of Human Life
 A disturbing exhibit that opened here last week at the National Museum of Health and Medicine argues that something happened to German science and medicine after World War I as attempts to expand health care and to improve society were turned into a system that devalued human beings and allowed doctors to abandon their ethical responsibilities.
Modern medicine, which faces such ethical questions as rationing of health care, using genetic engineering to identify or treat disease, testing experimental treatments with human subjects, or doctor-assisted suicide for the terminally ill, must never forget what happened in Germany and how easily ethics can be eaten away by expedience, the exhibit's organizers said.
The exhibit, "The Value of The Human Being: Medicine in Germany, 1918-1945," was commissioned by the Berlin Medical Association and was first shown in 1989. The current exhibit is co-sponsored by the American Medical Association.
Dr. Christian Pross and Dr. Gotz Aly, members of a group of young German doctors and historians who began searching archives in the early 1980's to uncover the role of the medical establishment before and during the war, said doctors in their country had developed a "collective amnesia" when the era was over.
"No one wanted to admit to what extent they profited under the system and how none of this could have happened without the direct complicity of the German medical establishment," Dr. Pross said in a telephone interview. "It was more than just a few doctors who were involved," he said. "The medical establishment knew what was happening and lended a credibility to it through its direct and indirect involvement."
 
Agents of the State
 Dr. Marc Micozzi, the physician who directs the museum that is showing the exhibit through Dec. 9, said many people, including doctors, would like to believe that what happened in Nazi Germany can never happen again. However, he said, the exhibit of 45 panels of text and photos illustrates how changes in how doctors view their relationship with patients can lead to disaster. "If we don't understand how it happened in the first place, how can we assure it won't happen again?," Dr. Micozzi asked.
The groundwork for atrocity was paved with good intentions, said Dr. Pross and other experts. After World War I, Germany's Weimar Republic tried to use scientific principles to build a better, more orderly society, including establishing the first true system of universal access to health care. This system emphasized using the best medical technology for treatment and research into the causes of disease, coupled with a strong emphasis on preventive medicine.
 
Seeking Superior Genes
 This new interest in improving Germany's health, which produced substantial decreases in infant mortality, tuberculosis and venereal disease through expanded use of public clinics and hospitals, shifted the emphasis of medicine from helping each individual to improving the health of the community at large, experts said. Many doctors became agents of the state instead of advocates of the patient, they said, and began viewing people as impersonal statistics instead of individuals.
In addition, theories of genetic inequality among races and the idea that some people had greater value than others to society were gaining popularity worldwide and particularly in Germany. Numerous genetic institutes were established to study racial differences and to prove the superiority of "Caucasians of non-Jewish origin."
When Western economies were hit with the Great Depression in 1929, the Weimar Republic had much less money for health care and began cutting back on services. Limited resources were used to help people of greatest value -- nnon-Jewish whites in the workforce. This cost-benefit approach worked against people who were poor or who were considered an expression of genetic inferiority, and those who suffered from mental illness, deformity and inherited diseases or conditions.
Adolf Hitler and his followers embraced the idea that the right to life must be earned and justified, not assumed, and this became an excuse for eliminating the genetically deficient, who consumed valuable resources. Among those considered deficient were Jews, gypsies, people of mixed blood and those with inherited illnesses.
The exhibit suggests that doctors, more than any other professional group in Germany, accepted the new order. More than 38,000 doctors, almost half of Germany's total, joined the Nazi Party. Being part of this system allowed doctors and scientists to get research grants, receive promotions at universities and take over the jobs and practices of thousands of Jews who were no longer allowed to practice medicine.
It was hard for doctors who did not go along with the system to advance their careers, Dr. Pross said, but he added that there was little evidence that physicians who refused to take part were killed or sent to prisonunless they also actively worked against the party or supported the underground.
Fewer than 100 doctors and scientists were found guilty of war crimes in Allied courts after the war, said Dr. Arthur L. Caplan, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. But he said many more had helped to conduct research on prisoners and to organize the death camps by assisting in designing and reviewing the "research" or by offering technical assistance.
Dr. Caplan, who edited the book "When Medicine Went Mad: Bioethics and the Holocaust," (1992, Humana Press), said the role of mainstream medicine and science in the atrocities had been underplayed.
"A relatively small number of doctors and scientists took a direct role in killing and torture," Dr. Caplan said. "But a large number, many in universities and prestigious institutions, provided intellectual and professional support for the policies of the Nazis."
 
'An Awesome Potential'
 Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice-president of the American Medical Association, said there is always a moral hazard when powerful individuals achieve such dominance over ordinary people. Doctors, he said, have a special responsibility because people entrust them with their privacy as well as with with their lives. The museum, which is located on the campus of Walter Reed Army Medical Center at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology.
"The great concern of American physicians is the Government increasingly interfering with the doctor-patient relationship," Dr. Todd said. "One of our biggest challenges today is balancing medicine and health against the resources available. But we have to strive to do this without forgetting about the patients we serve."
The issues that faced German doctors still exist, and modern biomedical science has given people the tools to manipulate human genetics in ways the Nazis could never have dreamed of, Dr. Todd said. "Genetic manipulation gives us an awesome potential to use it for good, to detect and treat disease and deformity," he said. "But we must learn to use it morally and ethically, without stepping over the line."
The exhibit, which shows what can happen when doctors stop following the Hippocratic Oath with its admonitions to "give no deadly medicine to any one if asked" and to "abstain from every voluntary act of mischief and corruption," teaches that human beings cannot be devalued below the sum of their parts.
"These were our brothers and sisters," Dr. Todd said of those depicted in the exhibit, "The ones who suffered so, and the ones who inflicted the suffering upon them."

PUB-DATE: November 10, 1992

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 2927 words

HEADLINE: In Provinces, Artists Learn Self-Sufficiency Is Price of Freedom

SERIES: The Arts in Russia -- Second of three articles: Getting Along Without Moscow

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PERM, Russia

 BODY:
Bouncing along in a used right-hand-drive Toyota on the pothole-ridden streets of this, the capital of the Ural Mountains region, one passes a movie theater playing "Vampires of Beverly Hills" and "Phantom II" as an American rapper boasts from the car radio about how bad he is and warns us not to disrespect his brother.
As in Moscow and St. Petersburg, Russia's outlying capitals sometimes seem dizzy with change and awash in Western trivia. Yet like the provincial cities themselves, more tightly run and less rampantly chaotic than the centers, the arts in Perm, which is on the borderline between European Russia and Asian Russia, Voronezh in southwestern Russia, and Novosibirsk and Irkutsk in Siberia actually appear steadier and more settled than the anarchic volatility of the western Russian metropolises.
 
Points of Interest Indeed
 Many of these cities have fascinating cultural histories. Voronezh, today a shabby but still picturesque city in the midst of the Russian agricultural heartland, was the first stop for Stalinist exiles in the 1930's. They were detained there while evidence of further crimes against the state was sought, and if no greater sins turned up, they were allowed to stay. The result was a disproportionate number of lively Moscow and Leningrad artists and intellectuals, who fostered local culture. 
 Perm, which is particularly rundown despite its spectacular perch above the Kama River, has its own Stalinist ghosts as the site of a dense concentration of prisons, some of them political. The city's cultural horizons were broadened during World War II, when the Kirov Opera and Ballet were sent there for safekeeping during the siege of Leningrad. Today, Perm's ballet conservatory is one of the most famous in Russia.
In Novosibirsk, whose broad boulevards and anonymous architecture epitomize the grimness of Soviet urban planning, the principal cultural ornament is the Novosibirsk Philharmonic. Founded in 1956 by the feisty conductor Arnold Katz and sustained by him ever since, it is now one of the premiere Russian orchestras, playing regular concert series in both Novosibirsk and the university and research center of Akademgorodok, 20 miles to the south.
Certainly a visitor to a recent performance of Glazunov's ballet "Raymonda" at the Perm State Academic Theater of Opera and Ballet would have been hard pressed to discern the aura of crisis and despair that pervades so many artists in Moscow and St. Petersburg. The production, a new one, was traditional but fresh and opulent. The dancing was at a high level, in no way "provincial." And the audience, which filled the theater, was well dressed and sophisticated.
Hard-Liners Memories of Past
Shore Up Present
The relative stability of cultural life in the provinces has something to do with simple inertia. And it owes something to the prevalence in regional parliaments of ex-Communist hard-liners and Russian nationalists (the two are often the same) eager to perpetuate Soviet artistic values and institutions.
With the overthrow of Communism, the West was captivated by pictures of giant statues of Lenin, leveled by blowtorches and cranes, lying helplessly on the ground. Mighty Lenin statues still dominate the provinces. One stands in the square in front of the Voronezh State Opera and Ballet Theater, and the comparable theater in Perm not only has a nearly identical statue, but also boasts Communist Street as its address. Igor M. Nepomnyashchy, the director of the Voronezh theater, greets visitors with a formal Lenin portrait on the wall behind him (Tchaikovsky is on the opposite wall).
The differences between the big western Russian cities and the provinces also stem from President Boris N. Yeltsin's reforms, and especially from a profound change in government financing. This was meant to break down inefficient centralization and to restore autonomy and self-determination to the regions.
 
Central Budgets Slashed
 The budget of the central Russian Ministry of Culture was sharply reduced. Given runaway inflation -- 300 percent over the summer alone -- meaningful dollar figures are almost impossible to adduce. Yevgeny Y. Sidorov, the Russian Minister of Culture, said that under the Soviet system, culture received between 3 and 4 percent of the national budget -- his ultimate goal for his ministry -- but that now the share was below 1 percent. To accomplish anything, he must wheedle for state funds and private support like the manager of the smallest theater. "I have to beg and solicit money," he said.
With its diminished state funds, Moscow still directly supports some institutions of national importance, particularly in Moscow and St. Petersburg. But much of the financing of major institutions elsewhere has been turned over to provincial administrators, who are usually Yeltsin appointees but who may not heed guidelines from the central ministry as to financing levels.
In the Soviet system, local governments and administrators found all sorts of ways to circumvent central authority. In Voronezh, the local Communist Party built an opulent puppet theater without informing Moscow that money was being spent for that purpose. "There were lots of ways of cheating Moscow before perestroika," recalled Yuri Pchelkin, the head of the Voronezh regional Arts Department, with sly pride.
But now, decentralization represents state policy, even if President Yeltsin and his team are still concerned that local authorities sometimes insist on looking to Moscow for handouts rather than developing their own local support systems. "People are still accustomed to central planning," Mr. Sidorov said. "They should do it themselves; things should be handled locally."
In most provincial cities, grumbling aside, they are. And many of them have ample resources on which to draw. Russian regions, or oblasts, correspond to American states, and they can be huge, especially in Siberia. Vladimir M. Lapenkov, the head of culture for the Irkutsk oblast, casually allowed that his region was three times the size of France. They can also contain autonomous ethnic territories, such as the Ust-Ordynsky Buryat National District in the Irkutsk oblast.
 
Rich and Poor
As Money Flows So Go the Arts
 The regions vary widely in economic health, and hence in their ability to support local culture. Voronezh, Perm and Irkutsk, for instance, are all military-industrial centers, but officials in Irkutsk seem more optimistic about the economic health of their industrial base than do arts leaders in Voronezh and Perm. In Voronezh, there is concern that the local politicians slight cultural support in favor of more pressing social concerns, and about what beleaguered officials see as the unfairness of having to underwrite a drama conservatory that provides actors not just for the region, but for the entire country.
Irkutsk officials boast that their region, buoyed by oil and chemical development and forestry, is better off economically than most other Siberian areas. Unlike in Perm, where community performing groups dried up after the fall of Communism, they are thriving in Irkutsk. "There was a decline at first," said Mr. Lapenkov. "The trade unions gave up all support for culture, but we just took it over. The number of amateur groups has actually increased."
 
Optimism in the Hinterlands
 In general, regional cultural administrators seem more optimistic about the present health and future prospects of their cultural activities than officials in Moscow and St. Petersburg. "Culture has the same problems as the country as a whole," said Liana Mekhtardzheva, the manager of the regional cultural administration in Perm. "But much to our advantage, the people -- the local administration, the cultural community and the audiences -- understand these difficulties. It's a great help to us. Together, we're trying to preserve the artistic treasures of Perm."
Optimism is partly inspired by local pride and competitive feeling. The director of the Perm State Art Gallery, Nadezhda Belyayeva, said: "Ours is the main museum in the Urals, and it will continue to be that. Perm has always been the cultural center of this region, and we are not going to give up the lead."
Miss Mekhtardzheva, the head of regional culture in Perm, fiercely defended regional prerogatives against claims from Moscow. "We are not going to give back our Perm theaters to Moscow," she said. "Whoever provides the money can do whatever they want with the theaters." Mr. Katz, the conductor of the Novosibirsk Philharmonic, boasted that he needed no sponsors and still paid his musicians two to three times the going rate in the country as a whole.
 
Neighbors
Pride and Support For Local Culture
 Optimism reflects the close-knit cultural, political and economic forces that run these cities. Although they are not small -- from 600,000 for Irkutsk to 1.8 million for Novosibirsk -- they are less cosmopolitan and more manageable than St. Petersburg (5 million) and Moscow (9 million).
The synergy within provincial life can be seen in various ways. In Irkutsk, local authorities are trying to upgrade the dismal quality of films at commercial movie theaters by subsidizing the showing of quality pictures. In Perm, Miss Mekhtardzheva helped the choreographer Yevgeny Panfilov set up his modern-dance company.
Regional and municipal cultural commissions are eager to act as clearing houses for potential private sponsors. In Voronezh, where former Communists were recently voted into power in the regional parliament, the House of Culture has been refurbished as a "business center" complete with slinky hostesses in mini-dresses, all intended to to lubricate proto-capitalist communication and encourage cultural philanthropy. Such coordination can prove mightily successful: Ninel G. Pidemskaya, the administrative director of the ballet conservatory in Perm, said her budget had actually increased in real terms because of private sponsorship.
Even with decentralization, resentment runs high against the national tax system. "The law doesn't help -- not in any way," complained Ivan P. Chukhnov, the head of the Voronezh municipal Culture Department. "Last Christmas, a company donated 100,000 rubles for the holiday festival, and in three weeks they were taxed 30,000 rubles. That's against logic and common sense."
In the rush to privatization, and given the readiness of former Communist managers to seize ownership of state-run industries, a curious blending of public and private is taking place. A new, supposedly private television station will often list local public officials and former Party leaders as stockholders. While this blurs the line between state ownership and capitalist enterprise, it does facilitate a station's access to public airwaves and financial backing.
Local authorities also help arts institutions evade Moscow guidelines. Ideal budgetary levels are generally set, for instance, in relation to the number of an institution's employees. That number tended to be larger than needed under the Soviet system, which guaranteed employment no matter how useless. Now, institutional leaders are letting their work forces decline through attrition, yet are retaining their old subsidies pegged to the official employee levels. Officially, the Voronezh Theater for Youth has 33 actors, but there are 7 vacancies and no plans to fill them. "The money goes to the other actors," explained Mikhail V. Bychkov, the artistic director of the theater.
 
Preservation
Tradition Over Trends
 Large performing-arts institutions in the Russian provinces generally lag behind the innovative tendencies of such companies as the two St. Petersburg operas, the Kirov and the Maly. In Voronezh, the director of the opera theater explained the limited repertory, with little Wagner or Italian opera or 20th-century opera, on what he called "technical" grounds. In Perm, however, repertory seems livelier -- there was a triple bill of 20th-century operas this spring -- and attendance has held up to near capacity, despite unemployment and inflation.
The emphasis on 19th-century Russian operas, plays and ballets may simply reflect local taste and a desire for reassurance in an unsettling period. But it may also indicate a determination to reinforce Russian values in a "time of troubles" -- a phrase that echoes the turbulent 16th century as captured in such operas as Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" and "Khovanshchina." The emphasis on Russian patriotic and religious values has become a veritable fad, dismissed as such by cynics and progressives.
Even the much feared cultural diaspora, or artistic brain drain, seems to have less impact on the provinces than on Moscow and St. Petersburg. There is a periodic turnover of artists, and in some cases a palpable loss has been felt. Mr. Katz, the Novosibirsk conductor, said he missed three musicians who had departed for higher German wages. Vladimir Verbitsky, the conductor of the Voronezh Philharmonic, has been on leave for two years in the West, and that has indeed disrupted local musical life, said Mr. Nepomnyashchy, the opera director.
 
New Blood for Old
 But mostly the losses have either been welcome or perceived as part of a normal pattern in which ambitious performers move upward within the Russian system itself. "The situation is stable here," said Mr. Lapenkov in Irkutsk. Mr. Katz said the departure of six older players to Israel was no great loss, since they were past their prime. Of course, there have been more vacancies recently in Moscow and St. Petersburg as artists there gravitate west. But often, as with two new actors in Irkutsk, local cultural life has been invigorated by Russian artists fleeing unrest in the former Soviet republics.
Progressive artists, with or without affiliations to the old state-theater system, have a harder time in the provincial capitals, and a sense of detachment from the West can be felt. "Because of the isolation of the Russian provinces, our collections are not known in the world," lamented Miss Belyayeva of the Perm State Art Gallery, which has particularly rich holdings of wooden religious sculptures, many taken from churches destroyed during the Stalin years.
The one modern-dance company in Novosibirsk recently disbanded, and there is no private gallery scene in Perm, largely because of high rents. Yet the museum helps make up the gap by sponsoring a commercial gallery within its walls, exercising a certain selectivity in the artists it allows to display there.
More radical money-making schemes are not confined to the provinces. These can range from museum gift shops, a commonplace in the West, to more bizarre ventures such as the toothpaste for sale at the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, the home of the Kirov Opera and Ballet, or part of the lobby of the Voronezh Theater for Youth's being rented out to a Chinese clothing store. AIST-TV in Irkutsk supplements its income by printing business newspapers and tourist guides.
 
Space Instead of Money
 In Perm, which seems less well off economically than either Voronezh or Irkutsk, Mr. Panfilov is popular with audiences and admired by the local cultural authorities. Although they have been unable to provide him a regular subsidy or to arrange for sponsorship support, they did manage this fall to gain him access every Friday to the Perm Drama Theater for performances, and are working to obtain an unused movie theater as his permanent base.
Mr. Bychkov, the progressive Voronezh theater director in whose state-owned building the Chinese venture flourishes, has been applauded locally and internationally. But he must work within the confines of the old Soviet system, and local officials -- who in this case include proud former Communists -- try to make him devote more of his energies to youth performances.
He dreams of establishing his own, privately supported Chamber Theater, but he cannot find adequate sponsorship and he has no idea where to get a theater to match the one he has now. "I keep my ideal of a Chamber Theater inside," he said. "When it's time, it will come out. In the meantime, I can do something here, and that's why I don't quit."
 
Minorities
Ethnic Differences Are Recognized
 Despite the breakup of the Soviet Union, Russia has many officially recognized ethnic minorities, and their cultural relations with the Russian mainstream remain problematic, especially in Siberia, with its huge ethnic districts and autonomous ethnic republics.
For Mr. Lapenkov of the Irkutsk regional administration, multi-cultural relativity on the Western model is not yet an issue. "High culture," by which he meant European culture, "is international," he said. "We cannot speak of it in terms of Siberian or Russian: it belongs to the whole world." Yet he also said that in the newly decentralized regional cultural scheme, the subsidy of such minority cultures as the Buryats and the Tofalars was actually more generous than before.
In the end, local pride and a tenuous economic self-sufficiency seem to have blunted the pessimism endemic to Moscow and St. Petersburg. "The people of Perm did not get their wages for three months," said Miss Mekhtardzheva. "Yet the theaters were still sold out."
Mr. Nepomnyashchy of the Voronezh State Opera and Ballet Theater agreed. "People have to find time for everything in life, including the theater," he said. "You can't always go to demonstrations."
NEXT: Signs of innovation.

SECTION: Section C; Page 10; Column 4; Science Desk

LENGTH: 858 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
The Case of the Frustrated Shopper

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
A COLLEAGUE went to the local computer store and ordered a Macintosh Powerbook 145. The store took his money and said delivery would be in three to four weeks. Five weeks passed, then six. He complained, and was told the Model 145's were "seriously backordered." He got the same story from a couple of other computer stores.
And it's not just Powerbooks. Shoppers trying to find Compaq Prolinea machines, I.B.M. Valuepoints, Dell Dimensions or any other popular computers often find that they must wait weeks, and sometimes months, for their orders to be filled. Supplies of color monitors, hard disk drives and power supplies are also "constrained," as salesmen like to say when the elves have not been working fast enough. 
 If it is any consolation, the big corporate buyers are waiting right along with somebody who wants a single machine.
"Everybody's got short supplies," said Bobby Orbach, president of Orbach Inc., a computer industry consulting concern in New York City.
For thousands of computer buyers and sellers, frustration over short supplies is growing. And it appears that no relief is imminent, because computer companies are forecasting continued high demand for the next six months.
"Business is hot, and nobody expected it," said Seymour Merrin, president of Merrin Information Services Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif.
Benjamin Rosen, chairman of the Compaq Computer Corporation, said last week that even if his company could obtain all the parts it wanted, it would still not be able to meet demand for Compaq's Prolineas.
The short supplies are the result of several factors, foremost among them the PC price war that started in June. Computer companies grossly underestimated demand for new, lower-cost computers. As a result they did not order enough components to make the machines. Once they realized the magnitude of the demand, factories were put on double or even triple shifts, but the companies that supply the computer makers with key parts could not keep up.
When economic indicators suggest that the country is mired in a stubborn recession, why are so many computer companies overwhelmed with demand?
"It's a phenomenon," Mr. Merrin suggested, and it is fueled by three converging groups of buyers.
Owners of older XT and AT-class computers are discovering that they have to buy newer and more powerful machines to run today's software, especially Microsoft Windows 3.1.
Companies that had planned to add computers anyway are snapping up bargain-priced PC's, especially those built around the i486 microprocessor, at a rapid pace. "What we're getting today in terms of value for the dollar is unbelieveable," said Mr. Merrin, who was one of the country's first personal computer dealers.
Last, Mr. Merrin said, are "the new buyers, who may have been computerphobes." Small businesses are discovering that they cannot afford not to have a PC, since all their competitors and suppliers and accountants are using them. And, after a decade of seeing advertisements and listening to boring cocktail party chatter about bits and bytes, many individuals are finally confident enough to take the plunge, using the "If my idiot brother-in-law can learn to use a PC, then I can too" rationale.
All these shoppers are converging on an industry that is famous for periods of feast and famine. The advice from Mr. Orbach is to keep looking. "The smart retailers have already boosted orders to get larger allocations," he said. "If you really hunt and know where to buy, you may pay a little more but at least you'll find what you want."
"The retailers who are less fortunate can always, if they're good, move people to different brands," Mr. Orbach added. It is not quite bait and switch, but it means persuading a customer that one computer is pretty much like another.
Experienced computer buyers learned long ago that despite all the braying by computer companies, there are really very few important differences among major brands. So, switching to Brand X is less upsetting to them.
But for novice computer users, who often investigate a potential purchase for weeks or months and count each byte being offered, it is discouraging to be told that their first-choice machine will not be available until after the holidays.
Apple Computer Inc. customers are in different straits. Our Powerbook 145 shopper could not switch to Brand X because there are no non-Apple Powerbooks. Industry analysts suggest that Apple has taken orders for 50,000 more Model 145's than it has been able to produce, and that there are even 30,000 back orders for Model 170's, which Apple discontinued in September.
So rather than wait indefinitely, the shopper decided to spend a few hundred dollars more for a Powerbook 160, which the store had in stock. He will be happy with it because it is a better machine, and the dealer is happy to make the sale.
While Mr. Merrin expects the shortages to last several more months, he does see a change ahead. "Our industry has a classic pattern," he said. "Like politicians, we never learn from history. First we underproduce, and then to meet demand we overproduce."

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Now Duva Takes a Risk In Pay-Per-View Ring

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
The $2.75 million loss incurred by TVKO for last June's Evander Holyfield-Larry Holmes heavyweight title fight took more than just a stash of cash out of Time Warner's pay-per-view boxing service. It took the risk out, too.
The risk-free TVKO debuts Friday night with the Holyfield-Riddick Bowe championship bout. This time, TVKO is paid a fee to market, distribute and produce the TV telecast of the fight, unlike other events when it bought the rights to the fight, guaranteed the fighters' purses and took what profits it could, which, unfortunately, were not many. 
 "We've opted for less gain and less glory," said Seth Abraham, the president of Time Warner Sports. "We think it's a terrific fight, but we simply could not agree on a buyout license fee."
Taking the risk usually assumed by TVKO is promoter Dan Duva, who would like to prove Abraham dead wrong. According to Duva, they parted ways on selling the fight to TVKO when he projected it would draw 800,000 to 1 million pay-per-view buyers and Abraham estimated it wouldn't exceed 600,000.
Abraham said his pessimism grew out of the fight vying for attention with basketball, football, hockey and the overriding interest in the Presidential election. Said Duva: "We'll be happy to take all the money. We're very happy to do it."
Duva's financing comes from the usual sources: domestic and foreign pay-per-view and closed-circuit sales, corporate sponsorships, the site fee from the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas and the gate receipts. Duva projects that Holyfield, who has a percentage of the pay-per-view sales, will probably take home between $15 million and $18 million. Bowe is guaranteed $7 million.
Because Duva is in charge, he's altered a few things from the TVKO model. Most notable will be a change in analyst. For this fight, Joe Goossen is, thankfully, out and ESPN's Al Bernstein is out. Host Khambrel Marshall is out and Jim Hill is in. Len Berman remains as the blow-by-blow announcer.
If Duva's gamble succeeds, this financial format may become a regular at TVKO, which doesn't want any more financial debacles like Holyfield-Holmes, which, with about 735,000 buyers, fell short of expectations, or the Mike McCallum-James Toney fight last December that lost nearly $1 million.
Fiscal prudence -- compounded by the recession, the absence of Mike Tyson and the shortage of fights and fighters worth a $40 pay-per-viewing -- reigns at TVKO, which laid off 12 workers in the summer and will stage six fights next year, down from 12 in its first year.
The Holyfield-Bowe pay-per-view performance, of course, will determine how urgently Duva takes on future financial burdens in order to snare upside bonanzas. It may also alter TVKO's structure because both Duva and promoter Bob Arum receive 20 percent of profits from fights they license to TVKO.
"We'll look at deals fight-by-fight," said Abraham. "What Dan brings to us in the future will determine whether we roll the dice. And I've talked to Arum about one or two distribution deals with him."
If TVKO mixes risk-averse distribution deals with equity participation arrangements, the service would look like SET, Showtime's pay-per-view arm. SET is a partner with Don King, who generally raises the money for pay-per-view cards while SET markets, distributes and produces them. SET has no regular schedule, as TVKO originally did, but stages fights as they come.
"Having not done so well in its first year," said Shelly Finkel, Holyfield's manager, "I think TVKO sometimes will do some deals like this one with Dan and some like they usually do."

HEADLINE: National Security, Redefined

 BODY:
High-tech weapons proliferate. Dictators flout international law and opinion. And ethnic strife sunders a galaxy of post-Communist states. The world, Bill Clinton rightly affirms, remains a dangerous place.
But at least for Americans, the danger has greatly diminished. For the first time since Pearl Harbor, a new Administration takes power with no global strategic threat hanging over it. Economic issues like European protectionism, North American free trade and competitiveness with Asia have moved to the center of foreign policy debate. Mr. Clinton would be wise to seize this opportunity to change the national security agenda. 
 Foreign policy involves far more than secret arms deals, late night calls to world leaders and military showdowns. As Bill Clinton and Al Gore well appreciate, America's international influence ultimately depends on the strength of its economy, and how well it adjusts to the demands of the global marketplace.
There's no longer any excuse for allowing America's foreign initiatives and aid programs to be driven by anxieties about what rival military powers might be up to. Absent a compelling military threat, foreign policy ideas will have to compete for public support on the basis of their consistency with American values, like democracy, human rights and environmental protection.
Mr. Clinton pointed the way on the campaign trail, giving priority to his plans for rebuilding U.S. economic strength, repudiating protectionism and urging that American influence be used to promote higher labor and environmental standards abroad.
Still, Pentagon spending could be slashed far more boldly than Mr. Clinton has proposed. That would free resources for such real national security challenges as urban decay and educational neglect. Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton must tend to an inherited agenda of trade negotiations, arms control with former Soviet republics, Middle East peace talks and cease-fire enforcement with Iraq.
Prospects for a Uruguay Round global trade agreement hinge for now on the success of President Bush's threat of retaliatory duties against European white wine. But the North American Free Trade Agreement can be ratified in Mr. Clinton's first month.
Political and financial support for former Communist nations struggling with reform offers the best insurance against renewed confrontation. To maintain the momentum of Middle East peace, Mr. Bush might invite Mr. Clinton to send a representative to the negotiations now. Mr. Clinton must somehow signal sufficient evenhandedness between Israelis and Arabs to keep this genuine triumph of Mr. Bush's from dribbling away.
Iraq needs to be held strictly to the arms control and other provisions of Security Council resolutions. But Mr. Clinton ought to heed the advice of the chief U.N. arms inspector, Rolf Ekeus, and encourage Baghdad's cooperation by pledging that full compliance would bring an end to the international oil embargo.
The new Administration also needs to ease America out of the costly role of world policeman by helping to transform the United Nations and regional groups into credible instruments for enforcing collective security.
Mr. Clinton cannot afford to lapse into national security business as usual, carrying forward cold war spending levels and rhetoric into an era of strategic peace. The nation's real security needs won't allow it.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton And the Mideast

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In the icy days of Polish Communism, an editor in Warsaw slipped past the censors a little drawing that told exactly what Poles felt about their rulers and their Soviet and German neighbors, and the whole hard world.
"The dream of the Polish nation," said the caption. The drawing was just of the moon in space. But on the moon was a tiny map of Poland -- high, away, deliciously alone. 
 During the Presidential campaign, the candidates went along with Americans' own moon dream. They acted as if they really thought the American economic navel could live separate from the rest of the world's body and pains.
But sometimes, almost as a forbidden luxury, they delivered reminders that the world still turned, somewhere down there.
President Bush showed no recovery from the professional distortion of so many American foreign policy bureaucrats. Like them, he suffers from the inability to grasp that dictators are inherently dangerous because no amount of appeasement can remove their survival instinct to solve problems by oppression at home and war abroad.
President-elect Clinton, to my ear and mind, understands that American power and American democratic idealism have to be combined to create American effectiveness, and that without one the other is crippled.
He cannot rid the world of dictatorships. But throughout his comments about the world runs a pledge not to use American knowledge and strength to help them.
That policy, carried out, would be the strongest barrier against war. Mr. Bush did not understand that.
Saddam Hussein showed that appeasing dictators and encouraging or permitting their military buildup creates the powder of war. Mr. Clinton inherits the still-vivid dangers of those policies:
Saddam Hussein in power after military defeat. Syria ruling Lebanon. Expansion of Syrian military strength. Economic and military explosion of Iranian power and the drive toward Iran's nuclear capacity.
Just yesterday some Americans of influence told us the way to deal with Saddam Hussein was to embrace him. Today similar seers warn us not to upset his neighbor dictator, Hafez al-Assad.
Evans and Novak, ever obsessed by Israel, are for the moment hugging the Labor Government, apparently in the hope it will obediently diminish Israeli power. But to show they have not lost their talent for comic journalism, they solemnly deliver a warning. They tell us that Labor is upset that some pro-Israel Democrats are trying to "stigmatize" Hafez al-Assad of Syria as a "missile-toting terrorist."
My word, those boys sure can write. Couldn't think of a better description myself.
Mr. Assad is not only a terrorist against foreigners and his own people but the landlord, paymaster and political pimp for the largest collection of terrorist killers ever gathered in one country: Iranian, Palestinian, Libyan, Lebanese, fundamentalist and of course Syrian. So large in fact that Syria has been officially listed as a terrorist nation by the United States, year after year.
That did not prevent Bushbaker from acceding -- polite word -- to the Syrian takeover of Lebanon, a bit of perfidy Americans barely note.
Missiles? Yes indeed, boys, all he can tote -- from Communist China, North Korea and other suppliers. He bought them with the money the Arabs gave him from sending his troops to watch the gulf war.
Iran: On Oct. 9 I wrote about Iran's military buildup, and its determination to become a nuclear military power. Stout denials flowed from Teheran's embassies. Since then news stories have provided more details about Iran's unrelenting, and increasingly successful, march to make oil, and military technology, the road to fundamentalist supremacy throughout the Middle East.
Mr. Clinton knows what is needed: a tough, single, unified international anti-proliferation mechanism buttressed by punitive national laws and international sanctions against violators.
We've known that for years. But we also knew it might lower profits of arms and technology manufacturers -- perhaps including American.
That will be Mr. Clinton's duty -- to choose. For all American Presidents and all American voters, foreign affairs have a way of becoming very American affairs, and the moon gets closer and closer.

LENGTH: 268 words

HEADLINE: Capitalism Thins the Ranks of China's Rulers;
Radio Redundancy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"An Asian Voice for Democracy" (editorial, Oct. 20) states that a new broadcast service to Asia should be "independent of Voice of America, thus assuring a diversity of voices."
This proposal comes under the heading of expensive redundancy. There are more than 300 hours of foreign broadcasting a week into China by the Americans, British, French, Germans, Russians and others. Millions of Chinese listen to the Voice of America's broadcasts in Mandarin, Cantonese, Tibetan and English. During the terrible days of Tiananmen Square, Voice of America news was broadcast from loudspeakers into the square to the students, who knew that the world was watching. 
 Voice of America broadcasts 10 hours of world news and information each day in Mandarin, with emphasis on developments in China. In April, Voice of America established a news and research office in Hong Kong, and last September began "China Focus," a program dedicated to events inside China. Voice of America plans to target broadcasts throughout East and Southeast Asia under the name V.O.A. Asia.
There's another reason V.O.A. Asia makes sense, and Radio Free Asia, the concept you support, doesn't. Radio Free Asia would cost $69 million to start up and $39 million a year to run. Those estimates are from the special Congressional commission you cite, which many consider unrealistically low. The new system could take years to become fully operational and many more to achieve Voice of America's credibility and listening audience.
 
HENRY E. CATTO
Director, U.S. Information Agency
Washington, Oct. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Black Caucus in Congress Gains in Diversity and Experience

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 9

 BODY:
All but one of the 16 new black members of Congress brings a wealth of political or legislative experience to their jobs, a development that many say will mean a significant qualitative difference in Congress as well as a record number of black voices.
Of the 16 new members, 13 are from largely black districts that were created through reapportionment. Three others are replacing retiring or defeated black incumbents, making the net increase in the number of black members 13, the largest single increase since Reconstruction. 
 For some, the term "freshman" will seem strange indeed, since they will be giving up senior committee posts in their state legislatures when they move to Washington.
 
'They Aren't Newcomers'
 From the youngest, 29-year-old Cleo Fields of Louisiana, who served as chairman of the committee that passes on all major state appointments, to 66-year-old Carrie Meek of Florida, who was chairwoman of a major appropriations subcommittee in her State Senate, the move will mean a big change in the prerogatives of office.
Only 11 of the current 26 black members of Congress entered office with elective experience, said a spokesman for the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation. Representative John Lewis, a Democrat who has been a member from Georgia since 1987, said: "They aren't newcomers to the job like a lot of us were. They have command of issues and will be able to hit the ground running."
There will be a total of 39 blacks in the new House. David Bositis, a senior research associate at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, a political research organization specializing black issues, said that in addition to the political savvy that will characterize the new members, there will also be a greater regional diversity.
"There was a time when you talked about the Congressional Black Caucus that you were talking about a handful of people from half a dozen large cities across the country," said Mr. Bositis. "Now they are from all over the country, and some of their districts are whiter than those of their predecessors. It is too early to tell what impact all of this will have, but you do have people from different places with very different characteristics."
Many from this freshman class will gather in Atlanta on Tuesday for the first Black Congressional Leadership Institute, sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation. Faith Edwards, a spokeswoman for the foundation, said the session would deal with some of the nuts and bolts of Congress, special workshops on ethics and efforts to establish connections between experienced Capitol Hill staff members and the aides that the new members will be hiring.
With the addition of Carol Moseley Braun, the only black member of the Senate and the first black woman to be elected to that body, the Congressional Black Caucus will have 40 members.
Of the group, only Mel Reynolds, who takes over the Chicago Congressional seat that had been held by Gus Savage, has never held elective office. Ten others are or were once members of state legislatures, often holding crucial committee or leadership posts, and three others held municipal or county elective offices. Of the remaining new black House members, Alcee Hastings of Florida was a Federal judge before his impeachment and James E. Clyburn of South Carolina has for the last 17 years been the state's human affairs commissioner, an appointive post.
In all, the group exhibits a confidence perhaps best typified by Earl F. Hilliard, 50, a former state Senator who represents Alabama's mostly agricultural black areas as well as much of its largest city, Birmingham. He said that as an 18-year veteran of the Alabama Senate "it won't take me long to adapt because I won't be wide-eyed and mystified."
Mr. Hilliard said that perhaps the most overriding concern of the new members, both black and white, would be to get something done quickly about things like cuts defense spending and foreign aid -- and therein may lie the chance for conflict with the Congressional leadership carried over from what President Bush described as the "gridlock Congress."
"I think we will all want to see some things done quickly because we don't want to be seen by the people back home as being part of the problems that we were elected to solve," Mr. Hilliard said. "We'll be pushing hard for what the people back home are saying."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 12, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the Congressional Black Caucus referred imprecisely to blacks in the new House of Representatives. There are 38 representatives, not 39. The delegate from the District of Columbia, Eleanor Holmes Norton, is black but does not vote.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);
