HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: How to Lift the Poor;
To Aid Those Most in Need, Clinton Wants to Help the Middle Class First

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The last time a Democrat lived in the White House, 29 million Americans (13 percent of the population) lived in poverty. Now 35 million Americans (14.2 percent) do, and their place on Bill Clinton's list of priorities remains unclear.
Mr. Clinton takes office with a mandate for domestic change. But he created it with incessant talk about the middle class and relative quiet on topics like inner cities, the homeless and the underclass. 
 With a few notable exceptions, the President-elect's domestic proposals are intended to help the poor while helping others, rather than singling them out for special initiatives.
That is certainly the case with the centerpieces of his campaign, his call for a reinvigorated economy and national health care. And it is also true of many other policy initiatives that have won his most enthusiastic support: calls for retraining workers, expanding college aid and strengthening enforcement of child-support laws.
His advisers say this approach is in line with efforts like Social Security and the G.I. Bill, Government programs that have done much to alleviate poverty while offering benefits to all Americans.
"The most successful opportunity programs this society's ever had have all been broad-based," said Bruce Reed, an issues adviser to Mr. Clinton.
But skeptics contend Mr. Clinton's approach will reach only the most fortunate of the poor and do little for Americans locked in the worst circumstances. Perhaps only 10 percent of the country's poor live in areas of concentrated, long-term poverty. But the violence and suffering of such areas has a disproportionate effect on American life, driving people from cities and poisoning the nation's racial atmosphere.
"You have to face it head-on," said Roger Wilkins, a historian at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., who contends that the problems of the people with the biggest disadvantages cannot be solved with programs aimed at the middle class.
Mr. Wilkins went as far as likening Mr. Clinton's approach to the trickle-down economics that the candidate ridiculed. "He says he'll help the middle class and the benefits will trickle down to the poor," the professor said.
By contrast, other prominent blacks who had called the Clinton campaign insensitive to the needs of minorities and the poor have been adopting a more conciliatory tone since the Arkansas Governor's resounding victory. The Rev. Jesse Jackson said Mr. Clinton's proposals could "make a significant impact" on poverty and do so "early on."
Whatever his priorities, Mr. Clinton also faces external constraints. Chief among them is the need to control the Federal deficit, which severely limits his spending options. Mr. Clinton has also tied his success to changing the health-care system and getting the economy growing, which is necessary to help the poor but not enough by itself. The inner cities, which have little political power, will have to settle for whatever time, willpower and money remains.
Mr. Clinton's proposals do include some aimed directly at the poor. He has called for a large expansion in the Head Start pre-school program and in the Women, Infants and Children program that gives food supplements to poor families. After the riots in Los Angeles this spring, he voiced his support for enterprise zones, which give tax breaks in the inner cities, community development banks and escrow accounts to help poor Americans save money without losing public benefits.
Most notably, he has called for what sound like sweeping changes in the welfare system. Mr. Clinton has pledged to quintuple, to $5 billion a year, what the Government spends on job training for welfare mothers. He has said he will make them perform community service after two years, or face reductions in their grants.
But reality will lie in the details, which are yet to be spelled out, and many analysts doubt that his approach will be as sweeping as it sounds. The history of welfare reform is one of bold talk followed by much compromise.
Most of Mr. Clinton's other domestic proposals are aimed at a broader audience than the poor. His pledge to collect more child-support payments from absent fathers, for instance, is certainly of interest to poor mothers living on welfare. But the Government will have problems collecting from jobless fathers who have no money. A bigger payoff may come to single mothers whose former partners are a notch or two up the economic ladder.
An important part of Mr. Clinton's philosophy is revealed in a phrase he has gleaned from David T. Ellwood, a professor of public policy at Harvard University. Pledging to "make work pay," both men have said people with jobs should not be poor.
 
Talking of 'Values'
 Correspondingly, Mr. Clinton has called for a $2 billion expansion in tax credits that provide an annual boost to low-paid workers, aiming to lift them from poverty. Most of the impact is concentrated on workers making $7,500 to $12,000.
Of course, this does not help those without jobs. Similarly, Mr. Clinton's calls for expanded worker training, high school apprenticeship programs and expanded college aid all help those most willing or able to help themselves.
Mr. Reed, the domestic adviser, said this was part of an intent to encourage responsibility. "I wouldn't avoid the word 'values,' " he said, referring to talk about causes and cures to poverty.
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, thinks Mr. Clinton's proposals would make a modest difference in the poorest neighborhoods. "Would they make a drastic difference?" he said. "Probably not."
Mr. Greenstein said more ambitious plans were thwarted by a lack of consensus. Some experts, for instance, call for a big Federal jobs program, which others say would be prohibitively expensive. Some call for intensified social services, while others argue that such programs have made only modest differences.
Last week, Mr. Reed was talking most enthusiastically about helping the working poor, and avoiding the war-on-poverty oratory that once infused hope about the most downtrodden Americans.
"Clearly, these problems have been so long in the making," he said, "that it will take at least a generation to overcome them."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 12, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Tuesday about the antipoverty policies expounded by Gov. Bill Clinton referred incorrectly to a comment by Robert Greenstein, a researcher. He predicted that Mr. Clinton's domestic proposals would probably have a significant effect on the poor generally, but only a modest impact in the most blighted neighborhoods.

HEADLINE: Clinton to Promote High Technology, With Gore in Charge

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
IF the promises of the Clinton campaign for science and technology now come to pass, America is headed for a new era in which the Government's focus on making armaments will shift to fostering a host of new civilian technologies and industries. No financial midget, the civil initiative would spend money twice as fast as the Pentagon's Star Wars anti-missile program, one of the biggest research efforts of all time.
The aim, outlined in campaign documents and by advisers to President-elect Bill Clinton and Vice-President-elect Al Gore, is a new wave of research discoveries and applications that will flood the economy with innovative goods and services, lifting the general level of prosperity and strengthening American industry for the international trade wars of the 1990's and beyond. 
 "This is a watershed," Kent H. Hughes, president of the Council on Competitiveness, a private group based in Washington that advised the Clinton campaign, said in an interview. "We're now going to develop an economic strategy much in the way we developed a national security strategy to fight the cold war."
"It's a paradigm shift in terms of the Government's role in technology," said Erich Bloch, a distinguished fellow of the council who is a former director of the National Science Foundation, the top Federal agency for the support of general research.
At the heart of the Clinton plan is a change of focus in Government research priorities from military to civilian endeavors.
As a peace dividend from the cold war's end, a minimum of $30 billion over four years is to be taken from the Pentagon's research budget and put into advanced work in areas like robotics, smart roads, biotechnology, machine tools, magnetic-levitation trains, fiber-optic communications and national computer networks. Also earmarked are a raft of basic technologies like digital imaging and data storage, which are increasingly seen as the underlying secret of lasting commercial success.
Significantly, the initiative would spend the same amount of money as Star Wars, $30 billion, in half the time.
But skeptics say the initiative is likely to backfire, bloating Congressional pork and creating whole new categories of Federal waste. They argue that Government officials generally lack the knowledge to predict which technologies will succeed in the marketplace and are never frugal with taxpayers' money, unlike entrepreneurs who risk their own. These defects, they say, make industrial policies all too prone to engender white elephants.
But advocates say past failures and painful lessons have increased the odds that the Clinton Administration will avoid such pitfalls to achieve a new kind of success. Most important, they say, business and government in this new era are to be partners, working together in an alliance that takes cognizance of market forces to produce a powerful new engine of technological advance.
The Clinton plan is outlined in an 18-page document, "Technology: The Engine of Economic Growth," issued Sept. 21 by Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters in Little Rock, Ark.
"America cannot continue to rely on trickle-down technology from the military," Mr. Clinton said in the document. "Civilian industry, not the military, is the driving force behind advanced technology today. Only by strengthening our civilian technology base can we solve the twin problems of national security and economic competitiveness."
 
Air of Excitement
 The plan has received little notice in the nation's general news outlets but has been widely read and applauded by the nation's technology experts, many of whom are now giddy with excitement. It is seen as the culmination of a slow shift in Federal priorities that has been grudgingly under way for several years, championed by the Democratic-led Congress but generally resisted by the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
A central question, these experts now say, is whether the Clinton plan can win the major financial backing it seeks.
"It's going to be a real push," said Dr. Roland W. Schmitt, president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in Troy, N.Y., a former head of corporate research for General Electric. "But the signs, I think, are very good that we may be embarked on a fundamental change."
Charles F. Larson, executive director of the Industrial Research Institute, a trade group in Washington, praised the plan but expressed doubt on its chances of being fully carried out.
"It's not going to be as easy to reduce the military budget as they think," he said. "There are going to be military tensions. Warfare is not over. We're looking forward to some positive changes in research funding, but with some skepticism as to whether they can pull off the whole plan."
Other experts said the Pentagon knows it ultimately has no choice but to go along with this type of initiative, since the technological strides needed for new weaponry are increasingly made by industry, and usually when unfettered by red tape and arcane Government regulations.
"It's in everybody's best interest," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, who is chairman of the technology and national security subcommittee of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee and has pushed hard for Federal-industry research alliances.
The fate of the technology plan also will benefit from the fact that the Democrats now control both Congress and the White House, giving them great political leverage -- and accountability. "The Democrats know if there isn't quick movement in the right direction, they're going to get clobbered," said a Senate aide who is working on putting the Clinton-Gore technology plan into effect.
 
Former Official Is Skeptical
 One skeptic is Murray L. Weidenbaum, an economist at Washington University in St. Louis who advocated free-market mechanisms as chairman President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers. In an interview, he said much of the money that did materialize would probably be squandered in pork-barrel projects meant to appease Congressional interests, not those of American industry.
"Judging from past performance," he said, "a lot of it will go for boondoggles."
For more than half a century, the Government's research policy in general has been to finance basic science heavily and trust that this will automatically lead to practical innovations and social betterment. Washington made little effort to translate discoveries about nature and nature's laws into devices and technologies, leaving that job to industry.
The exceptions to this policy mainly had to do with the military and aerospace, which were viewed as critical to fighting the cold war. The Government over the decades put trillions of dollars into building industries and doing research that could aid the development of new kinds of bombs, ships, guns, missiles, radars, aircraft and spy satellites.
A few times Government went further to direct the development of purely civilian technologies. But its record was mixed, with as many failures as successes. Photovoltaic cells, which turn sunlight into electricity, are now entering the big time after decades of modest Government financing. But the $30 billion space shuttle program is still largely a technology in search of a mission. Synthetic fuels and the breeder reactor, which was to have made its own fuel, suffered similar fates.
The Reagan and Bush Administrations, awed by the power of laissez-faire economics and market forces, disdained Federal involvement in industry research, although the Bush Administration has recently softened its ideological opposition. And while economists are highly critical of so-called industrial policy, many policy makers now embrace it.
One reason for the reversal is the example set by Europe and Japan in using Government research to spur industrial innovation, the programs having had mixed success. Another reason is that in the American economy, the seemingly endless stream of military "spinoffs" that long buoyed the civil sector (computer chips, jet engines, communications satellites) are beginning to dry up. Instead, the military increasingly seeks to "spin in" advances from private industry, which in turn is rapidly falling behind foreign competitors.
Beginning in the mid-1980's, Democrats on Capitol Hill, fearing that America was losing its technical edge, began to fight for increased Federal money and attention for industrial renewal. Among the leaders were Senator Bingaman, Senator John Glenn of Ohio, Senator Ernest Hollings of South Carolina and Senator Gore of Tennessee.
For instance, they led a charge to pump billions of dollars into the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, and broadened its mandate to spurring many advanced technologies with both military and civilian uses, such as high-definition television, computer chips and fiber optics.
On another front, Senator Gore for years pushed hard for a national high-speed computer network that could link computers in Government, universities, industry and libraries. Last December his High-Performance Computing Act, which seeks to spend $2.9 billion over five years, was signed into law. Mr. Gore calls the network a "information superhighway" meant to be a catalyst to cultural and industrial progress.
In his September policy statement, Mr. Clinton said he would give Mr. Gore, the Vice-President-elect, "the responsibility and the authority to coordinate the Administration's vision for technology" and to lead all Government agencies and research groups in meeting the new goals. "This is a real job," Mr. Clinton emphasized, rejecting the ceremonial presumption for much Vice-Presidential work.
One of Mr. Gore's first tasks, Mr. Clinton said, will be to "create a forum for systematic private sector input into U.S. government deliberations about technology policy and competitiveness."
The Clinton technology plan itself, among other things, would spearhead research on advanced materials and industrial processes, would create 170 manufacturing extension centers around nation modeled on the highly successful agricultural ones and would redouble the push for information superhighways.
"Such a network," Mr. Clinton said, "could do for the productivity of individuals at their places of work and learning what the interstate highway of the 1950's did for the productivity of the nation's travel and distribution system."
Perhaps most important, the Clinton plan pledges to increase sharply Federal financing of research into the so-called critical technologies. These include ceramics, computer programs, sensors, photonics, electronics, robotics, computer-aided manufacturing, biotechnology, advanced composites, artificial intelligence, waste management and pollution reduction.
The Clinton Administration, the plan says, "will view the support of generic industrial technologies as a priority mission."
 
Shift to Civil Efforts
 To this end, it proposes "at the very least" that 10 percent of the $76 billion that the Government now spends each year on research, or $7.6 billion, should be redirected from the Pentagon's research budget to civil efforts. Over four years this would add up to more than $30 billion.
This shift, the plan notes, would bring the Pentagon's share of the Federal research budget down to 50 percent from 60 percent. "Having achieved this balance," it says, "the Government should examine whether national security considerations and economic conditions warrant further shifts."
The plan would also direct the nation's 726 Federal laboratories, many of which were spawned by the cold war and do military work, to designate 10 to 20 percent of their existing budgets for joint ventures with industry.
The plan also lauds cooperative ventures like Sematech, an industry consortium that uses Federal and private funds to advance computer-chip manufacturing, and calls for similar ventures in other high-technology industries.
Advisers to the Clinton-Gore transition team say many details of the technology plan are only now being worked out, including whether to form new agencies, departments and initiatives or to work within existing Government structures. The leaning of the moment, said a Senate aide, is to create "nothing out of whole cloth." But Mr. Clinton himself, during the campaign, promised that he would create a civilian equivalent of Darpa to help encourage industrial innovation across the nation.
Senator Bingaman, who is helping to refine technology proposals for the new Administration, said a secret to avoiding the pitfalls of the past was to develop a new partnership with industry in which Federal funds would be matched with private ones, so market forces help shape and direct Federal largess and reduce the odds of technological waste.
 
Sharing the Costs
 "We'll sit down and say, 'What do you think is important?' and require them to spend their own money too," he said. "Cost sharing has to be a requirement."
Mr. Bloch of the Council on Competitiveness noted that many of the planned Clinton initiatives were expansions, albeit dramatic ones, of existing programs.
"It's not that the Bush Administration did nothing," he said. "But they did it reluctantly and there were ideological handicaps. The new Administration doesn't have those handicaps. That's a major change."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Bill Clinton's probable policy toward science and technology misstated the time he said it would take to move $7.6 billion in annual Federal spending on scientific research from military to civil projects. He said the move would occur gradually, taking three years to reach $7.6 billion; thus, the total funds shifted over four years would be somewhat less than $30 billion.

HEADLINE: Chip Index Up For October

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Orders for chips in the United States market set a record in October, and the semiconductor industry's leading indicator rose for the first time in four months, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.10 for the three months ended October, up from a revised figure of 1.07 in September and 1.09 in August. The book-to-bill compares orders with shipments. A ratio of 1.10 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $110 was ordered. A ratio above 1.0 indicates rising demand. 
 At $1.77 billion, three-month orders for October were up 5.4 percent from $1.68 billion for the three months ended September, and 41.1 percent higher than the comparable figure a year ago. At $1.53 billion, actual American market shipments for October were down 16.5 percent from the $1.83 billion shipped in September.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Political Memo;
Change of Tone for Clinton: High Energy to Low Profile

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 10

 BODY:
The most striking thing about Gov. Bill Clinton since the election has been the intriguing contrast between Bill Clinton the candidate and Bill Clinton the President-elect.
The Bill Clinton the public saw during the campaign was decisive, vigorous and remarkably open, a candidate who spent up to 18 hours a day talking up his ideas in public. But President-elect Bill Clinton has been seen only rarely. He has been conspicuously deliberate in making decisions and as obsessed with holding information close to the vest as any President. 
 The question is, Which style will characterize his Presidency?
Advisers and friends of the Governor say both: he will try to be an agent of change, but he will go about it slowly, carefully controlling information given to the public and using the cover of committees and economic conferences to make the politically tough choices.
A week after Election Day the Clinton transition operation still consists of Mr. Clinton, his wife, Hillary, Vice President-elect Al Gore Jr., a few intimate friends and advisers from the campaign and a skeletal transiTion board that has met only twice and is still trying to work out a timetable to present to Mr. Clinton for his most important transition decisions.
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's director of communications and one of the very few former campaign officials with any apparent connection to Mr. Clinton these days, presents daily briefings for the public that are portraits in minimalism. Tiny shreds of information about Mr. Clinton's activities and thoughts are padded out and embellished to make the puny sound Presidential.
 
Report of a Phone Call
 Consider today's briefing, where the biggest news was that several members of the transition team had had a telephone conversation. Mr. Stephanopoulos was asked what could be expected from Mr. Clinton's transition board, headed by Vernon E. Jordan and Warren M. Christopher.
"I don't think we will have any staff announcements today," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "I think this is the first time they will meet as a group in a week and they will be going over the progress in the last week and setting the agenda for the next."
Reporters then asked Mr. Stephanopoulos to define what he meant by progress. He chuckled.
"Obviously we have appointed Vernon Jordan as chairman and Warren Christopher as director, and they have started to present Governor Clinton with options and set up a background-check operation," he said. "It is my understanding that they have reached memorandums of understanding with the F.B.I. and the G.S.A. to talk about how this process will proceed. They will be presenting options for the timetable that President Clinton will make appointments, the timetable for the economic summit, and for when they will discuss filling out the transition team."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said Mr. Clinton was making final preparations on new ethics rules that include requiring political appointees to sign a pledge barring lobbying of their Government agencies for five years after they leave office, compared with one year now.
"We hope to have them very soon, hopefully this week," he said.
There seems to be a combination of two things. One is Mr. Clinton's long-standing style of governance, which has always been characterized by a deliberate, committee-driven approach, in contrast to his aggressively open style of campaigning. The other is the natural state of confusion that follows any Presidential campaign: a state of confusion, though, which a number of Clinton aides say is going on just a bit too long.
Mr. Clinton's campaign organization was the envy of his opponents for its speed and efficiency. A high-octane 24-hour-a-day war room insured that no charge by an enemy, or question by a reporter, went unanswered for more than an hour or two.
 
Ambiguity and Awkwardness
 Now, the scene around what is left of Mr. Clinton's campaign headquarters evokes ambiguity and awkwardness. Apart from Mr. Gore, not one of Mr. Clinton's campaign employees appears to know what job he or she will have in the new Administration.
"The reason that it seems like very little is happening is because very little is happening," said one longtime Clinton friend, who spoke only on the condition that he not be identified. "Very few decisions have been made. This is very much Bill's style: being extremely deliberate if not slow. He wants to do things carefully and right."
Mr. Clinton and his aides have said they would like to have at least some of the main economic appointments in place before Christmas, which would not be far off the pace of many of his recent predecessors.
In 1960, John F. Kennedy made his first cabinet appointments on Dec. 1; in 1968, Richard Nixon appointed his entire cabinet on Dec. 11. In 1976 Jimmy Carter made his first appointment on Dec. 3, and in 1980, Ronald Reagan his on Dec. 11.
But Mr. Reagan formed a plethora of transition committees within days of his election, and George Bush chose a Secretary of State almost immediately after Election Day.
The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Institute for International Economics issued a recommendation today urging Mr. Clinton to go slowly in picking his top cabinet, and to wait until he has "made fundamental decisions about priorities and organization."
But the idea that Mr. Clinton has not made such decisions may seem odd for a candidate whose whole campaign was based on the notion that he had a more detailed plan for economic renewal than his opponents.
Although Mr. Clinton ran for office with a 200-page economic plan that he said had been endorsed by 10 Nobel prize-winning economists, promising that he would begin putting that plan into into effect on Day 1, his first policy announcement here was that he was convening an economic conference before Christmas to get the views of the best minds in the country on the economy.
But this too is in keeping with the Clinton style. After Mr. Clinton was defeated at the end of his first term as Governor of Arkansas, a term marked by bold policy initiatives and radical departures from traditional Arkansas politics, he developed a far more cautious style to governing.
In his four subsequent administrations, Mr. Clinton was careful to limit himself to pushing one large reform idea each term and often used appointed committees of outside experts to provide political cover -- both for his agenda and for the more controversial initiatives, like raising taxes to pay for education reform.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: The F.B.I.;
F.B.I. Head Says He'll Keep Job, But Faces Doubt

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
On election night, as Bill Clinton's lead built toward certain victory, William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, sent a teletype message to all F.B.I. employees announcing that he had reached the midpoint of his 10-year term and intended to stay on.
In calmer times his message would have stirred less notice, advising employees, as it did, that reaching the halfway mark "was an occasion for me to reflect on events of the past five years and to focus on my vision of the F.B.I. for the future." But these are not normal times at the bureau.
 
Interpreting the Message
 Some agents perceived the message as a move by the Director, a Republican who was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987, to head off speculation about whether he would depart under the incoming Democratic Administration. 
 The question of whether Mr. Sessions will survive has been under discussion in law-enforcement and political circles for several weeks, with doubts fueled by an ethics investigation against him, criticism over some recent investigations involving prominent Republican officials and complaints that Mr. Sessions has not provided strong direction, allowing the bureau to drift.
Aides to Mr. Sessions insisted his comments were not intended to be delivered at the end of Election Day, nor were they meant as a political statement. But in an interview today Mr. Sessions reaffirmed his message to the bureau's employees, insisting that he was determined to complete his term and did not anticipate being forced by the incoming Administration to step aside. He also said the accusations swirling around him and his management of the F.B.I. in recent weeks had been personally painful.
"It is a difficult time to get through," he said, adding: "Hundreds and hundreds of friends have come forward. It's something that just happened. I just have to live through it and go on."
 
First Response to Inquiry
 Responding for the first time to questions about the Justice Department's inquiry into his travel and administrative practices, Mr. Sessions said: "I am confident those will all be cleared. I feel certain they will be."
Dismissing complaints about the the bureau's role in a politically delicate cases before the election, Mr. Sessions said: "The bureau strives mightily to be sure that the world and the media and the public know we are apolitical. When investigations come in we have to take them where we find them, where a crime may have been committed. But it's painful."
Urged by friends and his wife, Alice, to confront his critics more aggressively, Mr. Sessions rejected complaints about his performance as Director, saying, "A person should be judged by the quality of the product they produce, and the bureau continues to produce an excellent product in every single area."
So far Mr. Clinton has said nothing about Mr. Sessions, nor have the Clinton transition planners appeared to focus on the F.B.I. But some Democrats involved in the process said the question would probably be debated as the President-elect shifted from appointments in economic affairs to domestic agencies.
Associates of Mr. Sessions are hoping that he can keep his job with the backing of Democrats in Congress, who have supported his affirmative action initiatives at the bureau and his mild displays of independence from the Bush and Reagan Administrations on issues involving criminal justice.
But if Mr. Clinton decides he wants a change it could be a politically costly fight. The Director's friends have warned that any move against him runs the risk of appearing to be making the top job at the F.B.I. a political prize to be bestowed on a supporter by the new President.
The Director is a Presidential appointee, but the 10-year term instituted by Congress after the death of J. Edgar Hoover in 1972 was intended to insulate the office from partisan political pressure and impose a time limit after Mr. Hoover's nearly five decades in office created a climate that many lawmakers said led to abuses at the bureau.
The law does not clearly spell out how a President can remove an F.B.I. Director. But the Senate Judiciary Committee, in its debate over the statute, said the President should have reasonable grounds for such a step and explain it to the committee, which would consider it in evaluating the President's next nominee.
The Director's difficulties result from a confluence of events, some coming as recently as last weekend with the arrest of Judge Sol Wachtler, the Chief Judge of New York State's highest court, to complaints dating to the start of his tenure, when Mr. Sessions seemed to some agents to be more attentive to the ceremonial aspects of the job than to the bureau's law-enforcement priorities.
In interviews in which they spoke on condition of anonymity, and in discussions with Justice Department officials and members of Congress, former and current F.B.I. agents have also accused Mr. Sessions of failing to take firm control of the bureau's criminal investigative program. Others say he has shown little interest in defining a post-cold war agenda for the counterintelligence division, whose direction has seemed unfocused since the collapse of the Soviet Union.
 
Gains in Affirmative Action
 Mr. Sessions seems most proud of his efforts to combat the lingering effects of a legacy of racism left from the Hoover era, negotiating ground-breaking agreements with black and Hispanic agents over issues like promotions and training procedures.
The Director's counterparts at the Justice Department have seemed largely unimpressed with his efforts in affirmative action, but those activities have solidified his support in Congress.
Lately, however, it has been the F.B.I.'s investigations that have led to complaints. The most recent was the inquiry involving Judge Wachtler of the New York State Court of Appeals. The case began when Joy A. Silverman, a wealthy Republican fund-raiser who had broken off an affair with Judge Wachtler, brought her complaints in person to Mr. Sessions, who turned her charges over to the bureau's criminal investigative division.
Today some Democrats in Congress said there appeared to be nothing wrong with the Director's actions but expressed uneasiness over the impression that a major Republican donor had used direct access to the nation's top law-enforcement official to start a criminal investigation.
The Wachtler case came after F.B.I. agents conducted searches here and in Atlanta late last month in an inquiry into influence-peddling involving Catalina Vasquez Villalpando, the United States Treasurer. She has not been accused of any wrongdoing, but the searches rankled some Republicans officials, who complained that the inquiry became publicly known so close to Election Day.
The bureau has also been criticized by reports that it responded to Ross Perot's accusations of Republican spying by setting up an undercover operation in which an F.B.I. agent offered to sell an audio tape and documents from Mr. Perot's office to Jim Oberwetter, the chairman of President Bush's Texas campaign.
The tactics outraged Mr. Oberwetter, who rejected the agent's offer but accused the F.B.I. of trying to entrap him in a crime.

Philips Electronics is introducing two revolutionary products and trying to build recognition as a innovator. Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking Tighter U.N. Sanctions on Serbia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
In an effort to tighten sanctions against Serbia, the United States is pressing to ban the shipment of goods through Serbian-controlled territory to other countries, senior Administration officials said today.
A resolution under discussion at the United Nations would also require countries bordering the Danube River, particularly Romania and Bulgaria, to stop and inspect ships suspected of carrying goods to Serbia. 
 The decision to press for a new resolution comes amid increasing evidence that sanctions imposed by the United Nations five months ago have had only a limited effect on the Serbian nationalist Government of President Slobodan Milosevic.
Intelligence reports in recent weeks have concluded that the sanctions are so porous that, for example, Serbia has been able to import about half the oil it did before, allowing it to continue to run major industries and limiting any effect on Serbian policy in Bosnia.
 
The Little People Get Hurt
 In fact, the sanctions' major consequence thus far has been to hurt ordinary Serbs who have suffered from soaring inflation while enriching smugglers who operate with the approval of the Belgrade Government.
Some analysts at the Central Intelligence Agency argued a few months ago that because of the way the sanctions were structured, they were doomed to fail. Even now, intelligence officials at the C.I.A. and the Pentagon do not believe that squeezing the Serbs economically will necessarily change their actions in Bosnia, where it is felt they already have what they need to sustain an indefinite war.
Until now, the sanctions -- which include a ban on most trade -- have allowed exporters to ship their goods overland across Serbia to other destinations in Europe.
This has allowed trucks carrying goods marked "transit" to enter the country, unload and leave without accounting for where the cargo went. Similarly, goods moving up and down the Danube have easily been diverted to Serbia, and countries along the river have done little to stop the illicit trade.
The American plan does not yet have the backing of the British and French in the Security Council. Even if this should change, a tighter regimen of sanctions, as now envisioned, would still be imperfect because it would rely largely on the good will of Serbia's neighbors, rather than the threat of force to assure compliance.
A senior State Department official said, "We are working in the Security Council to secure a resolution that would address a number of issues, including the tightening of sanctions enforcement and a ban on trans-shipments of commodities."
The official added that while the United States favored a total ban on shipments, it would settle for one limited to important commodities like oil, chemicals, tires, vehicles and industrial equipment. "We don't want to promise too much," he said.
Another senior official conceded that the sanctions at most would serve as "a deterrent factor."
"Sanctions worked in Iraq because they were enforced," he said. "They don't work in Yugoslavia because they depend on good will."
The decision to press for a new resolution comes as there is increasing concern within the Bush Administration that the war in the former Yugoslav republics will spread to other Balkan countries.
Senior officials today confirmed United Nations reports that Serbs in Bosnia have repeatedly violated the Security Council ban on military flights there, raising the question of whether the United States will push for a second resolution authorizing United Nations members to use force to prevent such overflights.
President Bush said last month that the United States was ready to use force to impose a ban on combat flights in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but the British and French Governments have resisted such a move.
American intelligence reports indicate that there have been at least two dozen violations of the ban, including the use of MI-8 helicopters to bring in reinforcements and supplies during attacks on towns, and the use of anti-tank Gazelle attack helicopters in combat.

HEADLINE: Cooper Companies and Former Head Are Indicted

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Cooper Companies, once a leading producer of eye-care products, was charged yesterday in a Federal indictment with participating, along with its former chairman, Gary A. Singer, in an extensive criminal scheme to profit from insider tips on junk bond trades.
In announcing the charges in Manhattan, Otto G. Obermaier, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said Mr. Singer was "central to the scheme," which was said to involve bribing a Boston mutual fund analyst to get tips about the fund's proposed junk bond purchases and then trading in advance of the fund, both through the company and through family accounts. 
 The fund analyst, G. Albert Griggs Jr., and an accomplice, John D. Collins 2d, both pleaded guilty on May 21 to related charges and have been cooperating with the investigation.
 
 
'Done Little'
 But Mr. Obermaier said the company, whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, also bore criminal responsibility for the insider trading scheme because it "has done little, if anything to rectify" the actions of its chairman.
Mr. Singer, 37 years old, a resident of Cresskill, N.J., was charged with 24 counts of racketeering, conspiracy, money laundering and fraud. The company was charged with 10 counts of conspiracy and fraud. Potential penalties range from 20-year jail terms for the racketeering charges against Mr. Singer to fines of at least $500,000 for each allegation against the corporation.
In a statement last night, Arthur C. Bass, the acting chairman of Cooper, said he was disappointed that the company had not been able to "avoid these charges or settle them on a reasonable basis." Richard Weinberg, a lawyer for the company, said Cooper "intends vigorously to defend itself" against the allegations.
Charles A. Stillman, Mr. Singer's lawyer, said that his client "denies each and every claim of wrongdoing" and "fully expects to be vindicated."
In tandem with the criminal indictment yesterday, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced a civil complaint against the company, Gary Singer and his brother, Steven G. Singer, the Cooper Companies' chief operating officer, of participating in the junk bond trading scheme. The commission is also seeking to recover trading profits from various Singer relatives who the S.E.C. said benefited from the trades.
In addition, the S.E.C. accused the company and Gary Singer of manipulating the price of a publicly traded Cooper note issue to avoid a required interest-rate increase owed to note holders. And it accused Gary Singer individually of fraudulently shifting the company's junk bond trading profits into family accounts.
William R. McLucas, the director of enforcement at the S.E.C., joined Mr. Obermaier at a news conference yesterday. "The level of deceit and audacity of the defendants in this case was quite remarkable," Mr. McLucas said after detailing the commission's charges. He said that many of the junk bond trades cited in the Federal indictment occurred after the Singers knew the company was already under S.E.C. scrutiny for suspicion of manipulating the price of its notes.
The S.E.C. complaint seeks to permanently bar Gary and Steven Singer from serving as officers or directors of a public company. It also seeks to recover more than $3.6 million in trading profits.
Mr. Singer became co-chairman of Cooper in 1988, when his family and an allied group of investors took control of the company and ousted its founder, Parker G. Montgomery. Mr. Singer remained co-chairman until May 29, when he took a leave of absence in the wake of the guilty pleas by Mr. Griggs and Mr. Collins.
The charges brought yesterday are the latest dismal development for public shareholders of the Cooper Companies, once a booming medical products conglomerate with bright prospects.
The company's stock traded for more than $25 a share in the mid-80's, but has fallen steadily ever since. Yesterday, it closed at $1.125 on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from Monday's level.

GRAPHIC: Photo: At a news conference yesterday, right, William R. McLucas, director of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced the indictment of Gary A. Singer, above. To the right of Mr. McLucas was Otto G. Obermaier, U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York. (Jamie Tanaka; Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Jobs Grow In New York State's Small Factories

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
The number of small factories in New York State outside of New York City grew in the 1980's, creating jobs even as plunging employment at larger companies resulted in an overall drop in manufacturing jobs, according to a study released yesterday.
The gains at establishments with 99 or fewer workers was one of the few encouraging facts to be found in the study of New York State manufacturing by the regional office of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional Commissioner, said it was "an oasis of hope in a desert of despair." 
 "This does have public policy implications," he said. "When you see some are making it, you have to wonder if there is a way to build on these sectors of potential."
The study's good news came from an analysis of manufacturing establishments -- defined as a single physical site with predominantly one type of activity. From 1979 until the end 0f 1991, such businesses declined by 5,239, or 15.9 percent, throughout the state. Much of the decline was in New York City, where the number of establishments fell by 6,195, or 32.1 percent. Jobs in manufacturing dropped by 40.7 percent to 308,000 over the 12 years studied. The number of jobs has since fallen to 291,000.
In the rest of the state, the number of manufacturing establishments rose by 956, or 7 percent. But over all, manufacturing employment fell by 23.1 percent to 750,000 at the end of 1991. The latest total is 715,000.
Of the state's 62 counties, all but 10 lost manufacturing jobs in the 1980's. The exceptions were the downstate counties of Putnam and Suffolk, Ulster in the mid-Hudson region, Saratoga in the Capital District, Clinton and Warren in the Lake George-Lake Champlain region, Franklin in the Black River-St. Lawrence region, Otsego in the East Southern Tier, Cortland in central New York, and Ontario County in the Genesee-Finger Lakes region. Suffolk led in creation of new establishments with a net increase of 565 in the 1980's.
Most of the jobs lost outside New York City were at larger manufacturing establishments. From March 1979 through 1988, the number of people employed by establishments with 1,000 or more workers fell by 103,111, or 26.1 percent, while it fell by 35,709, or 9.7 percent, at those with 100 to as many as 999 workers.
In contrast, employment at smaller establishments, with as many as 99 workers, grew by 6,137, to 213,536, in 1988. While the rise is slight, it is remarkable given the general manufacturing trend. Mr. Ehrenhalt added that these smaller establishments were not concentrated in a handful of industries. "While the overall picture is bleak," he said, "there is a significant part of New York manufacturing that has demonstrated substantial staying power."
While the overall number of manufacturing jobs in New Jersey and Connecticut plunged in the last 12 years, as they did in New York State, Mr. Ehrenhalt said he did not know of a similar pattern of growth in the number of smaller factories and their job levels in those two states.
With an employed work force of 7.8 million in September, New York now has slightly more than one million manufacturing jobs, which include nonproduction jobs at companies classified as manufacturers.
From 1979 until the end of 1991, New York lost 444,000 manufacturing jobs, an unexpectedly sharp decline. If employment in New York's 18 industries had followed the national pattern for those groups, the state would have lost only 165,000 manufacturing jobs, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
In the last 12 years, rubber and plastic products was the only state industry in which employment rose, by 9.9 percent. But the industry is tiny so this amounted to just 3,200 jobs. In the state's biggest industries, jobs in electrical and electronic equipment and instruments fell by 82,600, printing and publishing by 11,700, nonelectrical machinery by 60,100, and apparel and textiles by 67,100.
In the booming 1980's, when New York had its highest job growth since World War II, jobs in nonmanufacturing sectors, led by services, grew by 1.4 million. That more than offset the 312,000 lost in manufacturing.
But since payroll employment in New York peaked in June 1989 at 8.3 million, the state has lost about 550,000 jobs, with manufacturing accounting for the most -- 174,000.
Other than stating the obvious -- that "New York has clearly become a less attractive place globally for the conduct of manufacturing activities" -- Mr. Ehrenhalt offered no specific reasons for the decline, saying it was not something he had studied or could derive from the bureau's data.
Other economists and business executives have speculated that the reasons include high taxes, fiscal problems, inadequate infrastructure like transportation and high-cost labor.
Alan C. Sullivan, executive deputy commissioner at the State Economic Development Department, tried to take comfort in the findings of the Federal study. "Manufacturing is alive and well" outside of New York City, he proclaimed.
Many executives complain that the state has not done enough to create a friendly environment for manufacturers. But Mr. Sullivan said the Cuomo administration has put in place a variety of programs to help small and medium-sized manufacturers.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senators Fight Over '94 Races

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
In a shaky first volley of his expected 1996 Presidential campaign, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas was re-elected today by one vote to lead the effort to elect more Republicans to the Senate.
Mr. Gramm put the best face on his narrow re-election as chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, saying the race "was very close because my opponent worked hard for two years." 
 But some Republican Senators said the 20-to-19 vote showed that some had reservations about the Texas Republican, and that some feared supporters of other Presidential candidates would hold back campaign contributions to the organization.
His opponent, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, argued for weeks that Mr. Gramm was using the post solely to advance his bid for the Presidential nomination in 1996, and that he would give more attention to raising money for his own campaign than for the campaigns of others.
"The principal issue of the race was whether running for President and being chairman of the Senatorial committee are compatible activities," Mr. McConnell said in an interview after the vote. "I argued they were not."
 
Year of Opportunity
 Republican strategists view 1994 as a year of opportunity for Republicans to improve on their current Senate membership of 42 or 43, depending on the outcome of a runoff in Georgia.
Of the 33 Senate races that November, the Democrats will have to defend 20 or 21 seats, depending on the results of a special election in North Dakota to complete the term of the late Senator Quentin N. Burdick. And with a Democrat, Bill Clinton, in the White House in 1994, the opposition party can expect to follow a historical trend and do well in the off-year elections.
Mr. Gramm is widely regarded for his knowledge of economic affairs, but his propensity to drive a hard bargain and to mix his debating points with cutting remarks have sometimes upset Republican as well as Democratic colleagues.
This year he also came under criticism from some Republican Senate campaign aides, who felt uncomfortable by requests from the National Republican Senatorial Committee to share their individual contributor lists. Critics of Mr. Gramm said they suspected the lists would be used to further his Presidential aspirations. A spokeswoman for the committee said the lists had been compiled strictly for party purposes.
 
D'Amato a Supporter
 But several Republican committee members said Mr. Gramm had generally been highly successful in raising money for Republican candidates. They said the recent comeback victories of Republicans like Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania helped Mr. Gramm's cause.
Mr. D'Amato and Senator Connie Mack of Florida, who is running for re-election in 1994, gave the nominating speeches for Mr. Gramm at the caucus in which he was re-elected by secret ballot to head the Senatorial committee.
Mr. D'Amato offered what his colleagues described as a spirited speech for Mr. Gramm, during which he noted that the Texas Republican had come to New York three times to campaign for him. Trying to introduce a dash of levity, one Senator bellowed, "And you still won?"
Mr. Gramm will travel around the country in the next two years recruiting Republican challengers, promoting the re-election of Republicans and raising money. Asked at a news conference after the vote if his job could be helpful to a Presidential candidate, he responded, "Any post is a good post to have if you're interested in promoting ideas."
Mr. Gramm has said he will not make a decision to run until after the 1994 elections.
Republican Senators said that in the committee balloting that gave him his narrow re-election victory, Mr. Gramm had assembled his majority from conservative loyalists and the four freshmen Senators who wanted to show their gratitude for his help in electing them last week. Senators Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, Hank Brown of Colorado and William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware were absent and did not vote.
Two years ago, Mr. Gramm defeated Mr. McConnell for the same job by a vote of 26 to 17.
"Those who supported Gramm felt he had funded their campaigns in an excellent fashion and worked hard for them regardless of their ideological orientation," said Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island. "Those who opposed him felt that Phil has Presidential ambitions. One view expressed was that this job is extremely time consuming and could produce conflicts over time and money solicitations."
Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, said several lawmakers did not vote for Mr. Gramm because they did not want to break the precedent that chairmen do not keep the job for more than two years.
 
Other Contests
 At the meeting, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming also withstood a challenge for his position as Republican whip by Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, winning a comfortable 25 to 14 majority. In the race for secretary of the Republican Conference, the official record keeper of floor votes, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, defeated Senator Christopher S. Bond of Missouri and Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska in a three-way race, 20 to 14 to 5. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas was re-elected as minority leader without a contest.
The Democrats also elected their leaders today, but no positions were contested. Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana succeeded Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois as chief deputy majority whip. Mr. Dixon lost his bid for re-election in a primary to Senator-elect Carol Moseley Braun.

HEADLINE: Borough President Declares War on Rats in Downtown Brooklyn

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Progress inevitably has its downside. In downtown Brooklyn these days, it comes in the form of rats.
Driven out of their homes by the recent rush of redevelopment, the rodents have moved unchecked into the courthouses, the busy Fulton Mall, the brownstone streets of Brooklyn Heights, and even the Metrotech office complex. 
 Not to worry, says the Borough President, Howard Golden. Backed by a veritable Who's Who of downtown Brooklyn, Mr. Golden yesterday announced "a concerted, one-week rat-cleanup campaign" to begin on Monday, with follow-up scourges over the next few months.
Rat problems are nothing new in New York City, which is said to be home to as many rodents as residents. Nor are highly publicized efforts to get rid of them.
Mr. Golden is clearly following in a grand tradition.
 
'Rat Extermination Kickoff'
 In a statement titled "Golden Announces Rat Extermination Kickoff in Downtown Brooklyn," the Borough President refers to an increase in rodent sightings, and says, "The redevelopment of downtown Brooklyn, however beneficial, does not preclude certain quality of life concerns." Then he adds: "The rat-extermination campaign represents an example of our commitment on behalf of all the people of Brooklyn to respond to their concerns as quickly and efficiently as possible."
The Borough President's rat "task force," which has already met twice, is made up of representatives from the city's Departments of Health, Sanitation, Parks and Recreation, General Services, Transportation as well as representatives from the Transit Authority, Federal and state courts, Metrotech, the Joshua Muss Development Corporation, the Fulton Mall and the Brooklyn Heights Association.
The one-week cleanup will include an extensive web of poison traps to be set in and around Cadman Park Plaza, Columbus Park, the Walt Whitman Park and the Brooklyn War Memorial, as well as near shops and buildings where the bands of rats have been sighted. The poisons -- put around garbage sites or inserted into the ground near rat tunnels -- will not seriously harm dogs or cats, said Julius Spiegel, Brooklyn's Parks Commissioner, who is participating in the campaign. "With more businesses opening downtown," he said, "there is just more opportunity for rats. More people. More garbage. So more rats."
Signs will also be posted at the poison sites. Officials are asking parents with young children to be particularly mindful of the notices.
Residents and workers in downtown Brooklyn, who talk of sighting rats running up and down the steps of the State Supreme Court and through Cadman Park Plaza, say the effort comes none too soon.
 
'Big as Cats'
 "You see those two bushes over there?" asked Edward Joseph Webb, a senior court clerk who pointed to Columbus Park as he stood outside the Supreme Court yesterday, "the rats run regular paths in between there, and they are big as cats."
Fifty yards away, William J. Kahaly, a 43-year-old senior court officer stood guard over one of several new parking lots, whose construction left dozens of rats homeless. Though he has spotted only a few rats in recent weeks, he has seen them in full force outside the courthouse.
"Last year, it was ridiculous," he said. "They were jumping in and out of garbage cans, running in and out of the ground cover, and up on the courthouse steps at night, two or three would be running back and forth."
He lowered his voice. "I killed one," he said. "He'd been poisoned and was walking kind of funny, so I hit him with my nightstick."
He paused, and said, "Actually, I killed two."

HEADLINE: London Cheers Yeltsin After His Vow to Use Power to Thwart Foes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia told the BritishParliament today that he was willing to assume emergency powers, if necessary, to thwart a cabal of militant nationalists and former Communist officials he says are plotting to oust him.
Ending a high-profile, two-day state visit to Britain intended to demonstrate Western support for his beleaguered Government, Mr. Yeltsin won a standing ovation after his speech before members of both the House of Commons and the House of Lords. 
 "We must directly recognize: there are in our country forces interested in a revanchist coup," declared Mr. Yeltsin, loosely describing his opponents as remnants of the former Communist Party, nationalists and "political adventurers."
At the same time that he warned he was ready to use "the power granted me by the people" to block any attempt at overthrowing his Government, he derided the threat posed by his political opposition. He described it as "nothing but a theater of shadows, in which the ghosts of the past are giving their farewell performance."
 
Lunch With the Queen
 In his final day in London, Mr. Yeltsin plunged into a crowd to shake hands with office workers in London's financial district, and traveled to Buckingham Palace to have lunch with Queen Elizabeth II, whom he invited to visit him in Moscow. A spokeswoman at Buckingham Palace said the Queen accepted the invitation "in principle," but no decision has yet been when, or if, she would be traveling to Russia.
Mr. Yeltsin's 36-hour swing through London, the first state visit by a freely elected Russian leader, produced a flurry of political and economic agreements between the two countries, nearly all of them more symbolic than substantive, as well as ringing declarations affirming the two countries as democratic allies.
Senior British officials regarded the visit as an opportunity to affirm, at least symbolically, Western support for the Russian President, who is facing mounting economic and political challenges at home.
 
'Will Not Turn Back'
 But in an editorial today, The Daily Telegraph, a newspaper that often reflects Conservative Party thinking, was sharply critical of the Government's high-profile program for the Yeltsin visit, arguing it was "inappropriate."
"It was as if the Government wanted to believe that he has already become what, in fact, he has yet to prove himself to be -- a man capable of turning his country into a capitalist democracy," the newspaper wrote.
For his part, Mr. Yeltsin reiterated his commitment to economic and democratic change. "Despite the hysterics of the opponents of reforms, Russia will not stop and will not turn back," he told Parliament today.
But he also reminded the West that he needs more help, particularly in deferring payment of Moscow's huge debts to the West, and appealed for sympathy and support for the civil and human rights of ethnic Russians who are residents of former Soviet republics.
Without naming the Governments, Mr. Yeltsin was apparently referring to Estonia and Lativa, which he has described in the past as relegating Russians into a second-class citizenship.
He also strongly defended his decision to use Russian troops to deal with ethnic rebellion in southern Russia. "Timidity and delay in taking decisions lead to chaos and turns against the peaceful population," Mr. Yeltsin said.

HEADLINE: France's Choice on Trade

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 10

 BODY:
With pressure on him growing to conclude a world trade agreement, President Francois Mitterrand of France is confronted by a tough choice: incur the anger of France's most important ally, Germany, by continuing to resist a deal, or enrage the powerful and vociferous French farmers' lobby by signing an accord.
The current signs are that President Mitterrand is leaning toward concessions that would once again cement the German alliance, avoid the imposition by the United States of punitive tariffs on white wine and other European products next month and help conclude a trade agreement to revive the world's sagging economy. 
 "I want to reach an agreement," he said this week in a television address. "I want it even more so because the isolation of a country like France, if it were to occur, would be very dangerous for France. We must not get to this point."
 
Pressure From Germany
 It was the first time that the President had referred to the possibility of France's being isolated, and his tone appeared to reflect growing German pressure.
German irritation with France over the stalled General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks has risen markedly this month. Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann chided France for delaying an agreement for domestic reasons, and Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said today that "compromises will be needed and France will, in the end, have to join in." German industrialists have accused Jacques Delors, the French President of the European Community Commission, of chauvinism and selfishness.
This open German criticism amounts to a startling departure. The French-German alliance lies at the heart of Europe's ambitious plans for unity, and the countries tend to paper over any differences quickly. When Germany angered France last year by recognizing Croatia without consulting its European partners, the French Government decided reluctantly to go along with the Germans, effectively sacrificing its old ally Serbia.
"In the end, the overriding need to safeguard our friendship with Germany was stronger than our profound irritation at the Croatian decision," said one senior official, who insisted on anonymity.
President Mitterrand must again decide whether to give in to German impatience, which in this case is shared by several other European Community members, especially Britain. He knows that France is increasingly isolated in the six-year-old GATT talks, whose successful outcome could eventually add $100 billion to world output. On the other hand, there are big temptations in a course of continued obstruction.
In March, it is almost inevitable that centrist and right-wing opposition parties will triumph over President Mitterrand's Socialists in parliamentary elections. If the GATT issue is still unresolved, it will fall to a center-right government to make the uncomfortable concessions, which, in turn, could dent the popularity of the right with farmers before the 1995 presidential election.
The farmers are already angry over this year's reform of the European Community's agricultural policy, which will lead to cuts in the $40 billion annually that the community now pays farmers and the removal of some land from cultivation. France has Europe's largest agricultural sector.
Still, Mr. Mitterrand has not been alone in moderating his tone. The top French official in Brussels, Mr. Delors, has up to now been notably apathetic on GATT questions, to avoid being blamed by French farmers for what they are sure to regard as a bad deal. This would damage Mr. Delors's thinly disguised French presidential ambitions.
But today, Mr. Delors said he hoped that an agreement could be reached before the European Community summit meeting beginning on Dec. 11. The Secretary General of GATT, Arthur Dunkel, was formally mandated by trade negotiators today to travel to Brussels and Washington to seek to revive talks.
Some of these signals appear to have reached Washington. One United States official said that he suddenly perceived a new European willingness to negotiate. Apparently reflecting such a mood, Ray MacSharry, the European Community's Agriculture Commissioner, has tentatively agreed to rejoin the GATT talks with the United States, The Associated Press and the British Broadcasting Corporation reported tonight from Brussels. Mr. MacSharry stepped down from his role as farm negotiator last week, charging that Mr. Delors had interfered in oilseed talks with the United States.
 
Waiting for a Sign
 The community's executive commission will confirm Mr. MacSharry's return on Wednesday, the BBC said. Community officials had no comment tonight. American officials have been waiting for his return as a sign that the Europeans may be willing to strike a compromise.
Still, big problems remain. United States officials described the latest European offer on cutting the community's oilseed production and subsidies -- the immediate cause of the threatened imposition of punitive tariffs -- as inadequate.
The community has said it will hold oilseed production to about 9.5 million tons from an annual average of 13 million, but has offered no guarantees and no means of compliance.
"It's not an enforceable offer and we don't believe that production will fall that low," said one United States official.

HEADLINE: House Democrats Proclaiming Unity

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 10

 BODY:
House Democratic leaders said today that they were sure the freshmen in their party would join them in working with the Clinton Administration on jobs, health care and deficit reduction.
"All of us saw very strong support for the principal objectives of the Clinton campaign and the Clinton Administration," House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said. He spoke after a third meeting with the newcomers here, following sessions in Los Angeles and Chicago. 
 Mr. Foley said he had found little interest in procedural issues like term limits or House rules. There was "more unanimity on that than I expected," he said.
Cynthia McKinney, a newcomer from Georgia, offered similar optimism after today's meeting. "We have a unique opportunity to be a part of the reshaping of our national priorities and our national values," she said, "hand-in-hand and arm-in-arm with the Democratic leadership and with President Clinton."
The 18 freshmen who met here with party leaders defined themselves as agents of change because of their support for those goals, which they said had been ignored by Republican Administrations. But there were occasional voices, including those of Tom Barlow of Kentucky and Sanford Bishop of Georgia, urging greater attention to the goal of a balanced budget.
 
'I'm a Tugboat'
 As their colleagues urged in different accents and cadences in the earlier meetings, the lawmakers-to-be here insisted that they were interested in accomplishments, not fame.
"I'm a tugboat, not a showboat," said Corinne Brown of Florida. "I'm here to work and get it on."
Although the 63 Democratic freshmen in the House will amount to the biggest group of newcomers in many years and to almost one-fourth of the 258 Democrats in the House, they showed little enthusiasm at these meetings for making themselves a distinct entity.
That idea came up in Chicago on Monday, when Louis Gutierrez of Chicago urged his newly elected colleagues to convene a meeting soon where they could assess the leadership and its policy plans.
But other freshmen at the meeting, including fellow Chicagoan Bobby Rush, roundly ridiculed his idea, telling him that legislative success was their only real interest. Later, at a news conference, Mr. Rush said, "We don't anticipate organizing a separate agenda." And Mr. Gutierrez acknowledged that a consensus did not want to divide the freshmen from other Democrats.
Bobby Scott of Virginia was blunt about the subject here today, saying: "I think people are not interested in who the leader is. They want to know when we're going to get some health care and jobs."
Before meeting with 18 newcomers today, the Democratic leaders told reporters that they thought more senior Democrats would show the same spirit of cooperation with the incoming Administration. Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a chief deputy whip, said, "The rank and file are convinced that Bill Clinton is the leader of our party and we must produce."
Mr. Foley said, "I can't quite recall -- except the enthusiasm of the early Johnson and Kennedy years -- anything that matches the sense that this group and the Congress now has."
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader who led battles against President Bush, said of the Congress: "It is not set up to lead. It is set up to follow. What we're hearing from our members is let's get it done."
 
Possible G.O.P. Support
 Mr. Gephardt even offered the hope that support for Mr. Clinton could be found among the 47 Republican freshmen. "Bill Clinton is a moderate Democrat," he said. "He will offer proposals that may well attract the support of some moderate Republicans."
In the course of the three days of meetings, with 55 of the 63 newcomers, there were different embellishments to the basic texts of jobs, deficit and health care in different places. The environment came up more often in Los Angeles, although Marjorie Margolies Mezvinsky of Pennsylvania said here today that there was agreement that people must "stop using the earth as if we have another one to go to."
The need for public-works spending was the additional chapter at the Chicago meeting. Representative Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan said. "We have to start putting our brains our technology and our money into infrastructure."
Here, if there were few new topics, there was a more constant sense and use of the word urgency. The new lawmakers here who included 11 blacks in newly created districts, represent some of the poorest districts in the country.
 
No Worry About Wine
 Asked about the group's views of the trade dispute with Europe that has led to increased duties on white wine from Europe, Carrie Meek of Florida noted that many of her constituents were still suffering after Hurricane Andrew. "I have difficulty worrying about French wine at this time," she snapped.
There were also efforts by the leaders to influence the Clinton agenda they were promising to support. In Chicago, for example, Mr. Foley said, "I do believe that there will be more emphasis on deficit reduction than has been noted by the press or perhaps the Clinton Administration."
And Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, suggested that tax increases greater than Mr. Clinton has proposed would become necessary. But when asked what his committee would do, he said, "It all depends on what the President suggests."
Here, Melvin Watt of North Carolina said "for the first 100 days, or six months, I sensed an amazing willingness to put aside our individual agendas and get on with a common agenda and break the gridlock."
