HEADLINE: Community Colleges Forced To Restrict Access, and Goals

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
With tuition at four-year colleges climbing and a sluggish economy forcing workers back to school to retrain for new jobs, students of all ages have been flocking to the relatively inexpensive classrooms of the nation's community colleges. But they do not always get in.
For the first time since the start of their explosive growth in the 1960's, community colleges -- which now enroll 36 percent of all students in higher education, and more than 50 percent of all freshmen -- are being forced to narrow their open-access policies and deal with fiscal constraints that will determine, to a large extent, whether they offer legitimate opportunity or just second-rate schooling.
 
More Harm for Some
 The colleges have been criticized for failing to keep their promise to America's most economically and academically disadvantaged students. Intellectual rigor can be flabby, classroom discipline loose, academic standards abstract. An associate's degree can be of little help in finding a good job. 
 And yet, for many who are willing to work, these colleges are a genie's lamp that can transform the unlucky, and it is they who are most likely to get hurt by the current squeeze.
In California, for example, the nation's largest community college system is turning away students because the state, for the first time, has refused to provide the financial support for everyone who wants to get in. Until now the state paid the 107 colleges, with an enrollment of over 1.5 million students, a set fee for each student no matter how many enrolled.
The California colleges also have raised their fees and for the first time are charging students who already have a degree $50 a credit more than other students, presumably to discourage them from taking up classroom space.
In Pennsylvania, officials have alerted community college presidents that the state will run short of money and not fully finance the colleges this year for all the students they admit. One of the largest community colleges in the nation, Miami-Dade Community College, capped enrollment earlier this year but was able to lift it two months ago only because voters in that hurricane-damaged region approved a special tax increase to support the school.
Officials of the American Association of Community Colleges say the picture is grim in most states and getting worse. Even where colleges have not limited enrollments they have been unable to schedule enough classes for new students, thus, in effect limiting their access to an education.
"This is a crucial period," said David R. Pierce, president of the association. He said financial imbalances have placed open access, the "centerpiece of our institutions, in very real jeopardy."
Although maligned as "high schools with ashtrays" or safe havens for students who cannot get into real colleges, the nation's 1,158 publicly financed community colleges, private junior colleges, and technical colleges have grown so much that they now enroll about 6.4 million students. For more than half of all entering freshman in higher education, going to college means going to the local community college.
 Without community colleges, many of the 6.4 million would not go to college at all. But half of them are casual students who never earn more than 12 credits, and of the rest, only about a quarter go on to a senior college, down from more than 45 percent in the 1950's.
 
Still Providing Some Opportunity
 The colleges are as unorthodox as their students, and administrators point out that, for many, the goal may not include a traditional academic course leading toward a degree. The students' average age is 29. Almost 65 percent attend part time, going to class at night or on the weekends. On average they take three years to get an associate's degree that used to take two years. Many, however, stretch the schooling to four or five years.
The degree itself is no lock on success. Someone holding an associate's degree can expect to make 29 percent more than a high school graduate, but far less money and social progress than someone with a bachelor's degree. Although occupational training programs can lead to attractive careers in computer science, many students end up in low-paying jobs in a field like cosmetology.
Nonetheless, community colleges in recent years have served as crucial portals for minority students, and the recent cutbacks threaten hard-won advances in that area. While community colleges enroll 37 percent of all white students in higher education, they enroll 38 percent of Asians, 42 percent of blacks and 54 percent of Hispanic students.
Community colleges have long been seen as salvage operations, giving the least advantaged students -- people like Nilda Ortiz of Homestead, Fla., -- a chance to grab the American Dream.
"Andrew didn't stop me and nothing is going to keep me away," said Ms. Ortiz. It was her first day of class at Miami-Dade Community College's battered Homestead campus, and though her home had been badly damaged by Hurricane Andrew, she was determined to begin her college career. "I've been waiting for this for a long, long time," she said.
But for every teary-eyed story of students overcoming adversity, there is a corresponding story of failure, like the student who was finally thrown out of Essex County Community College in Newark in 1980 after officials discovered he had taken 70 credits without getting more than a zero grade in any course.
College officials themselves agree that too few of their students complete their courses, too few get their associate's degrees and too few transfer to four-year colleges and earn the bachelor's degrees that can change their lives.
Critics go further and say community colleges routinely water down academics and allow perennial students to live off financial aid. They also sometimes accuse the colleges of channeling their minority students -- who often need to take remedial courses that cannot be counted for credit at four-year colleges -- into occupational training programs that dampen aspirations and lead to low-paying jobs.
"The rhetoric is terrific, but the reality is in transferring people, and that record is not good," said L. Steven Zwerling, an expert on community colleges with the Ford Foundation, which has been trying for years to improve the colleges. "What's going on in general is that people are coming in and they're getting washed out or directed to low-skill, low-wage kinds of jobs."
 
Original Mission Is Diverted
 The first junior colleges date back to the turn of the century, and even then they were seen as transitions, helping to give less-prepared students a boost toward a four-year college. In the 1970's, when new community colleges were opening at the rate of one a week, they expanded their mission, offering occupational training that led to jobs as a medical technicians or beauticians.
In the 1980's, they expanded again, offering job retraining for older workers who needed new skills.
But with the new focus on jobs, many of the colleges seemed to have lost sight of their original academic mission. Now, just 24 percent of community college students transfer to four-year colleges according to the Center for the Study of Community Colleges at the University of California, Los Angeles.
Even that figure can be misleading because it refers to only those students who accumulate 12 or more credits (about four courses). Nationally, half of all entering community college students never even get that far.
"These colleges are not necessarily transforming anybody," said Valerie E. Lee, an associate professor of education at the University of Michigan who has studied community college education. "The best students tend to transfer, and the weaker students do not."
Community college administrators are wary of making too much of transfer rates because they say it is not fair to expect that every student who enrolls intends to, or should, go on to a four-year college.
But they generally do concede that they have got away from their original purpose and need to move back toward academic preparation, even though the current financial squeeze will make that more difficult.
The colleges' support generally comes from three sources: the state, the local community and tuition. At a college like the Community College of Philadelphia, the financially strapped city has not fully financed the college for six years. Last year, the president, Ronald J. Temple, led students on a march to City Hall to demand greater support.
The city has shorted the college again this year. The state said it would probably not fully finance the college for every student it enrolls. And tuition, now at $61 a credit, is as high as the law allows it to be.
As a result, the library's book acquisition budget has not increased for 10 years, even as book prices have soared. Class size has jumped to 26 from 23 over the last two years. The college cannot offer enough courses to meet the needs of all students.
So Janice St. Clair, who has multiple sclerosis and uses a wheelchair, has to take a math course at the main campus, which is an hour's drive from her home, because the Northeast regional campus, which is two minutes away, canceled the course.
Hung Vong, who came from Vietnam six years ago, is not sure when he can take the literature course he needs to transfer next fall to Temple University, where he will pursue a bachelor's degree in education. Next semester the course is only available in the morning, when he is at work.
"It's going to slow me down a little bit," said Mr. Hung with the frontier spirit typical of many community college students.
 
Good and Bad In Diversity
 At Lucy Aghazarian's Humanities 102 class, the 21-year-old Mr. Vong struggles in his new English to explain a stanza from Thomas Hood's 19th-century poem "The Song of the Shirt." A few seats away, Joseph Leone aces it. Mr. Leone, a 20-year-old honors student, had planned to go to Drexel University but could not afford it. He enrolled at the community college three years ago. Next year he will transfer to Temple University and pursue a double degree in pharmacy and medicine.
"I have no regrets," he said of his decision to save money by living at home and attending the community college, where tuition is less than half as much as at Temple. He said he enjoyed the community school's cultural diversity, small class size and the attention of the faculty. "I'm perfectly happy here," he said.
The diversity of community colleges is their strength and their weakness. When open admissions rose out of the idealism of the 1960's, poorly trained students were welcomed; they represented pedagogical challenges just begging to be overcome.
As the number of those students increased, and their academic preparation plummeted, the colleges were overwhelmed. At some, more than 90 percent of students take remedial courses and reading skills can hover around the fifth-grade level.
This is generally attributed to a lack of preparation in high school, not a lack of commitment by the community college faculty. Surveys show they love teaching, do little research and do not rely on graduate assistants.
But surveys also show they often feel dispirited and sometimes they deliberately lower their academic standards to match the skills of their students.
Under current financial conditions, the colleges have been hiring more part-time faculty members. Now more than 65 percent of all community college faculty are part-timers, who cannot devote as much attention to student needs as full-time faculty. Some colleges are experimenting with televised courses or videotape class lecture libraries to fill the need, but teachers' contracts limit the use of such innovations.
Community colleges show other signs of stress. In California, David Mertes, chancellor of the state system, said the colleges have had to clamp down on registration and often are not able to offer students the courses they need.
The president of Miami-Dade Community College, Robert H. McCabe, says he would have been in serious trouble had not voters approved the tax increase that will establish a $100-million endowment for the college.
He said that community colleges are often misunderstood because they do so many different things. But the surprising results of the September vote, he said, testify to the strength of a college that is truly part of its community.
"People decided," he said, "that despite anti-tax sentiments, despite the devastation of the hurricane, that this is an institution that believes in giving everybody an opportunity."

HEADLINE: Gift of Concern Over California Colleges

 BODY:
Voicing concern about the future of higher education in California, a foundation yesterday announced it would put up $6 million -- its largest gift ever for a single project -- to start an independent policy research center to study the issue.
The James Irvine Foundation, a 55-year-old organization devoted to improving the quality of life in California, said the gift would establish the California Higher Education Policy Center in San Jose. The goal of the center will be to develop strategies for higher education based on the suggestions of educators, government leaders and ordinary citizens in the state. 
 Asserting that California's much-praised system of public colleges and universities had been damaged by recent budget crises, the president of the foundation, Dennis A. Collins, said the center seeks to have a voice in the shaping of the future of higher education. The foundation, Mr. Collins said, "believes the future of California's colleges and universities is too crucial to be decided by default or by budget trimming alone."
"The Center will look beyond the current financial crisis," he said at a news conference in San Francisco. "It will consider core issues, such as who should benefit from higher education and how our institutions can be more accountable to the public."
He said the center would be the first of its kind in the nation, and would be influential because it would be independent of government and the university system. Its director will be Patrick Callan, a former vice president of the Education Commission of the States, a policy and research group.
The foundation, established by James Irvine, a California businessman and farmer, distributes about $30 million in grants a year.

HEADLINE: Companies Cut Research Budgets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
American industry is pulling back on scientific research and development as it plans its budgets for next year, keeping that critical activity mired in a recession at least through the end of 1993, according to a survey released yesterday.
The survey on expected trends in research expenditures was conducted by Industrial Research Institute, a trade group based in Washington that represents the research centers of major corporations. 
 The results of its annual survey, which this year brought responses from 141 companies, were "more pessimistic" than last year, Dr. Gary E. McGraw, chairman of the institute's research committee, told a Washington symposium yesterday.
 
Few See Larger Staffs
 About 28 percent of the companies responding to the survey expect to cut their total research and development spending, he said, while only 24 percent expect to increase it. Moreover, the proportion of the budgets devoted to "directed basic research" is expected to decrease at 31 percent of the companies, while increasing at 11 percent.
Many more companies expect to cut capital spending on research and development (36 percent) than increase it (20 percent), Dr. McGraw said. And more plan to decrease hiring of new graduates (40 percent) than increase it (10 percent).
Overall, 84 percent of the companies expect their research staffs to remain unchanged or to shrink next year.
The general budgets of the surveyed companies for research and development, when calculated as a percent of sales, are expected to drop next year from 3.4 percent to 3.3 percent, Dr. McGraw said.
In addition to being chairman of the institute's research committee, Dr. McGraw is vice president of development for the Eastman Chemical Company in Kingsport, Tenn., a division of Eastman Kodak.
Private experts have worried that a steady erosion of America's industrial edge is undercutting the nation's ability to compete in world markets, and for some time they have recommended tough steps to strengthen industry against foreign rivals.
During the Presidential campaign, Gov. Bill Clinton promised such help, saying he would redirect billions of dollars in Federal research funds from military to civilian endeavors.

HEADLINE: STUDY SEES EXCESS IN X-RAYS OF HEART

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
About half of all special X-ray procedures to examine the heart performed in this country are unnecessary or could be safely put off for long periods, say authors of a study reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
The conclusion about the procedures, called coronary angiograms, was immediately disputed by the head of the leading group of heart specialists in the United States. 
 But, while cautioning against generalizing from one study to the entire population, Dr. Claude J. Lenfant, the head of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md., said the findings "need to be looked at very carefully, and additional studies are needed to confirm the findings."
The authors said theirs was the first systematic study of second opinions on whether the X-ray procedure is necessary. About a million coronary angiograms will be performed in the United States this year, at a cost of about $5,000 each.
 
Outlining the Arteries
 In the procedure, dyes are injected into the coronary arteries that supply blood directly to the heart and X-rays are taken. The dyes outline the contour of the arteries and define the degree of blockage in them. When these arteries become clogged with fatty deposits from arteriosclerosis, they can lead to angina and to heart attacks. The coronary angiograms thus help doctors determine whether patients will benefit from additional procedures like angioplasty and coronary bypass surgery.
Because the study involved patients who were motivated on their own or by an insurance company to seek a second opinion about the procedures, Dr. Thomas B. Graboys of the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, the senior author of the study, cautioned about extrapolating from the study's results to all patients with coronary heart disease.
Nevertheless, in the article, in a news release from the American Medical Association in Chicago and in an interview, Dr. Graboys said his team believed that about half of the coronary angiograms performed in the United States every year were not needed. He said he hoped the new findings would "chip away" at the soaring number of angiograms, which he described as "the funnel into" other procedures and heart surgery.
 
New York Study Cited
 A rigorously controlled study to address the problem of overuse of coronary angiograms more specifically would have to involve thousands of patients and cost millions of dollars, Dr. Graboys said, and would not provide an answer until the year 2000.
A study of angiograms and other heart procedures in New York hospitals conducted by researchers from the Rand Corporation is being reviewed by a medical journal, said Fran Tarlton, a spokeswoman for the New York State Health Department, which helped sponsor the study.
Dr. Adolf Hutter, president of the American College of Cardiology, said in an interview that he disputed the conclusions of Dr. Graboys's study.
The criteria used in the study "are too restrictive based on everything we have learned" from other rigorously controlled studies, and the findings "cannot be extrapolated to a larger population," said Dr. Hutter, a staff member of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
 
'Danger of Overextrapolating'
 The cardiology college "is against the inappropriate use of medical procedures," Dr. Hutter said, "but is also against the underuse of appropriate procedures, and that is the danger of overextrapolating from this type of study."
The study's findings emerge from a series of studies of second opinions in the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease that Dr. Graybos's team has been working on since the mid-1970's. The latest was aimed at determining the long-term outcome of patients who were advised in a second opinion not to have a coronary angiogram.
The study involved 171 consecutive patients referred to Dr. Graboys's team from 1981 to 1988. Their average age was 60 years, and ranged from 36 to 88. Of the total number of patients, 144 were men.
One hundred and thirty-four patients, or 80 percent, were judged not to require angiography. The decision was deferred pending further studies in 28 patients, or 16 percent of the cases, and recommended in six. The doctors evaluated the patients through questionnaires, telephone calls and examinations after a follow-up period that averaged 46 1/2 months.
Eleven patients died, seven from heart problems, for an annual cardiac death rate of 1.1 percent. Nineteen patients suffered a new heart attack, an annual rate of 2.7 percent annual rate, and 27 patients, or 4.3 percent, developed a worsening of their angina.
"There is much disquiet that if coronary angiography is not undertaken, one gambles on the unpredictabilities of outcome," the report said. But Dr. Graboys said the findings were reassuring on that point.
"It is not in the hospital's or the cardiologist's best interest to reduce the numbers of people coming in" for such studies, he said, "because the fiscal survival of many hospitals is dependent on the high rate of reimbursement procedures."
Dr. Graboys said it was difficult for doctors to spend the time exploring the options with patients. He added, "It is easier to say we will do the angiogram and other invasive studies, and we will get paid five times as much."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up Only 0.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Prices received by American producers edged up only one-tenth of 1 percent in October from the month before, as the weak economic recovery continued to keep inflation at bay, Labor Department figures showed today.
Smaller than usual increases for passenger car prices helped offset higher prices for gasoline and other energy components of the Producer Price Index for finished goods, which are products ready for sale to final business and individual users. The index had risen three-tenths of 1 percent in September. 
 The small October increase was cited as an important factor in a solid rally in the bond market today. Long-term Treasury issues were especially strong, with the price of the 30-year bond gaining $7.81 for each $1,000 in face value. [Page D13.]
 
Warning on Stimulus
 Analysts who studied the first price report published since Election Day said there was no immediate threat of revived inflation. But they warned that the interests of President-elect Bill Clinton and the new Democratic Congress in giving the economy a lift with a stimulus program could pose such a risk. The President-elect's economic team has signaled that any stimulus would be short term.
Some also said today's report indicated that the Federal Reserve, which has a policy meeting next Tuesday, has leeway to cut interest rates further. The dominant view, however, was that the Fed would refrain amid some recent signs of a pickup in the economy, the repeated monetary infusions already in the pipeline, and the uncertainty of a new Administration.
Today's report showed even weaker prices at the intermediate and crude stages of production, which both posted one-tenth of 1 percent declines. This means that in the production of, say, a loaf of bread, millers receive lower prices for sacks of flour and farmers get less for bushels of wheat.
When the volatile food and energy components are excluded, finished goods prices themselves eased one-tenth of 1 percent, the third small decline in the last five months.
There has been "a major break in the core rate" of inflation this year, said Joel Popkin, a Washington consultant who specializes in studying prices, likening the current inflation picture to the one inherited by President John F. Kennedy in 1961.
He added that inflation would almost inevitably move higher when the economy picked up speed, but he thought it would be contained by a "cushion" of improved corporate profitability and fiscal inhibitions related to the Government's huge budget deficit.
Mr. Popkin also pointed to the fact that wages and salaries, up 2.7 percent over the 12 months through September, trailed the 3 percent rate of consumer inflation for the same period.
Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, cautioned today that as Mr. Clinton put his policies into effect, prices would "bear careful watching to determine what effect stimulative actions he may take to 'get the economy moving again' will have on inflation."
But Mr. Schreibman added that slack in the economy meant that renewed upward pressure on prices would probably not appear for several months.
Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly consensus of about 50 economic forecasters, reported today that its latest survey projected 1993 consumer inflation at 3.2 percent, unchanged from the projection of last month. The low projection of the survey was 1.8 percent and the high was 3.9 percent.
In October, finished consumer foods edged up one-tenth of 1 percent as a 27 percent jump for fresh and dry vegetables was partly offset by declines for fish, dairy products, eggs, pork, soft drinks and coffee.
Energy climbed 1.4 percent, nearly twice the September increase, because of increases in natural gas and residential electricity that combined with a 3.3 percent jump for gasoline.
New environmental regulations requiring oxygenated gasoline took effect Nov. 1, but analysts said some of this more costly fuel may have been introduced earlier in some areas.
Passenger car prices spurted up 7.1 percent, but after the seasonal adjustment factor was applied, prices fell 2.3 percent, the report showed. Of the $526.47, or 13.7 percent, yearly increase in what auto makers received for cars, the department calculated that $74.70 represented quality improvements.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 15.40, but Smaller Stocks Gain

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday, but smaller stocks continued to gain ground.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials lost 15.40 points to close at 3,225.47. A late round of computer-related program selling insured that the key index closed at its session lows. 
 But advancing issues actually outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 223.2 million shares as of 4 P.M., up from 197.6 million in the previous session.
The market got an initial boost from a Government report showing wholesale prices edged up a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in October -- the best performance since August and an indication inflation is well under control.
But equities then wavered, with blue-chip issues giving ground as secondary stocks continued their upward move.
Small-capitalization stocks have been in the spotlight in recent weeks. Analysts said part of the reason was technical -- they had been hit harder than blue chips earlier in the year. But there is also the belief that small businesses may benefit more than their large counterparts under President-elect Bill Clinton.
Analysts said large multinational corporations had suffered in part because of the Clinton factor as well as from the recent run-up in the value of the dollar. As the dollar rises, the value of a company's profits that are earned in a foreign currency declines.
"This is a better-looking market than the Dow itself would suggest," said Dick Hoey, chief economist at Dreyfus Corporation. "The underlying pattern is that strength has been very intense in mid-capitalization and technology growth stocks even in a market that's kind of flat."
Some of the session's best performers were technology-oriented issues, including Motorola, which jumped 4, to 101 3/8, a high for the last year. In addition, the biotechnology leader Genentech added 3/4, to 37 7/8; the pacemaker manufacturer Medtronic jumped 1 1/8, to 108, and Scientific-Atlanta was up 1 at 31 3/4.
Among technology-related over-the-counter issues, Cisco Systems jumped 3 1/2, to 69 7/8; Intel rose 7/8, to 70 1/8; Novel Inc. added 1 1/8, to 33, and MTC Electronic Techology rose 1 3/4, to 16.
Mortgage-oriented stocks also posted strong gains in reaction to a rally in the bond market. Several hit 52-week highs, including North American Mortgage, which rose 1, to 16 3/4; Federal Home Loan, which added 5/8, to 47; First USA, up 1 1/2, to 17 3/8, and Federal National Mortgage, or Fannie Mae, up 3/8, to 72 7/8.
On the downside, gold stocks plunged as the metal's price hit a seven-year low. Among them, Newmont Mining plummeted 2 3/4, to 40 1/2; Homestake Mining lost 7/8, to 10 1/2.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
General Motors Files to Issue $1 Billion in Stock

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Saddled with large capital expenditures at the same time it has racked up losses from operations, the General Motors Corporation registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission today to raise up to $1 billion from a new issue of preference stock.
Added to G.M.'s seven other equity offerings since June 1991, the issue increases to nearly $8 billion the amount raised in equity markets in less than two years. The company said it expected to offer the first shares of the new issue within a few weeks. 
 "I wouldn't want to bet this is the last time" that G.M. raises equity, said David Healy, automotive analyst for S. G. Warburg & Company. The auto maker lost $4.45 billion in 1991 and another $970.7 million through the first nine months of 1992.
 
Heavy Spending
 While G.M. has been absorbing these losses, it has been forced to spend about $7 billion to develop new models and retool its factories. Moreover, the company continues to pay dividends on its common stock that total about $500 million annually.
Because of the tight finances, G.M. said this week that it was canceling the redesign of two of its aging midsize cars: the Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera and the Buick Century. The two models, first introduced in 1982, are built at a factory in Oklahoma City, whose future is not clear after 1996. As recently as August, G.M. had said that new versions of the cars would be built.
G.M. also postponed for a year, until 1996, the redesign of another midsize car line consisting of the Chevrolet Lumina, Buick Regal, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme and Pontiac Grand Prix, according to Automotive News, a weekly industry publication. A G.M. spokeman declined to confirm the report.
The company could face even more expenses as a result of talks its labor negotiators are having with the United Automobile Workers about buyouts of some employees. "Buyouts and retirements are also going to eat up cash," Mr. Healy said.
Preference stock, which pays a fixed dividend, outranks common stock but is behind preferred stock in the order of dividend payments. By selling preference stock, which is accounted for as equity, G.M. avoids borrowing, which would weaken its balance sheet and threaten its already shaky credit rating. A reduced credit rating would, among other things, make it more difficult for the company's financing subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, to continue borrowing in credit markets at favorable interest rates.
 
A Note of Caution
 The preference-stock issue was termed a "short-term positive" by Scott Sprinzen, director of corporate finance for the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency. But he cautioned that "one way or another the company can't continue to tap the equity market to make up for poor performance."
Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service have both said they are monitoring G.M. for a possible downgrading of its credit rating.
G.M. said Lehman Brothers would serve as lead manager for the initial offering. The shares will be issued from time to time, according to market conditions, G.M. said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Declines to $330.10; Lowest in Nearly 7 Years

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices approached a seven-year low yesterday as expectations for a surge in inflation continued to fade.
Other precious metals also posted losses as traders reassessed the potential economic impact of the Clinton Administration. 
 Gold for December delivery fell $3 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $330.10 an ounce, the lowest settlement for a near-term gold contract since Jan. 3, 1986.
 
Sixth Consecutive Decline
 The price dipped below $330 during the session, which ended with gold's sixth straight daily decline.
December silver fell 5.7 cents, to $3.645 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum for January delivery plunged $11.90, to $345.90 an ounce.
This week's weakness in precious metal prices largely reflects a change in perceptions about how President-elect Bill Clinton will try to stimulate the sluggish economy when he takes office in January.
In the weeks before the election, the betting was that his plans would include an immediate tax cut for the middle class and tax incentives to industry that could ignite a sharp rise in wholesale and consumer prices along with increased economic activity.
Higher inflation typically means higher gold prices, because investors view gold as a hedge against rising prices.
But Mr. Clinton and his advisers have said they want to hear from all sides on how to help the economy, indicating that they will take a more deliberate approach.
"The reality is that it's going to be a long-term thing, so a lot of investors are getting out of precious metals," said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metal trading for the New York branch of the large Swiss bank Credit Suisse.
Inflation has been held nearly in check this year. Yesterday, the Government reported that inflation at the wholesale level had inched up a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in October, making for a 1.9 percent annual rate so far this year.
In other markets, natural gas futures rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid predictions for record cold temperatures this weekend in the Midwest. Oil futures weakened as traders took profits after a strong rally on Monday.
December natural gas deliveries rose 6.3 cents, to $2.417 for 1,000 cubic feet; December light sweet crude oil fell 15 cents, to $20.47 a barrel; December heating oil fell 0.26 cent, to 58.10 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline fell 1.03 cents, to 55.20 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: ON THE SET WITH: Bryant Gumbel;
Steady in Storm or Calm

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
IN recent years, the ride on NBC's "Today" show has been like an adventure on the high seas -- down, then up, then down, now up again. But the guy at the wheel still shows no signs of losing his equilibrium.
After 11 years as host of the program, the longest tenure in the history of "Today," Bryant Gumbel, now 44 years old, remains secure, self-assured, and just a bit inscrutable. 
 Mr. Gumbel is the most visible African-American in the world of network news. And starting Friday, he will accomplish a goal he freely admits has been "an obsession" for the last five years: bringing "Today" to sub-Sahara Africa for a week of special broadcasts.
But to Mr. Gumbel a connection between these two facts, while perhaps logical, is much too facile, and thus inaccurate.
"Frankly, there are a lot of reasons for making the trip," Mr. Gumbel said, enumerating them quickly and articulately, exactly the way he does just about everything on television:
Africa is a continent too long ignored by Western news media; it is full of arresting, entertaining and important stories, as well as spectacular pictures for television; and besides, it is the only continent, other than Antarctica, that "Today" has never visited.
Those are the true reasons, Mr. Gumbel said, that he pressed a penurious NBC management repeatedly -- submitting proposal after proposal and budget after budget -- to broadcast "Today" from Africa. Those are the reasons he met time and again with African diplomats, corresponded with various embassies, and made courtesy calls on important African officials as well as members of the United States State Department.
"I was already taken to task by someone who seemed upset that I don't say, well, I wanted to go to Africa because I'm an African-American," Mr. Gumbel said. "While I think that played a part, to suggest that played a major part is to suggest I've been derelict for 10 years because we didn't go to Africa."
Mr. Gumbel doesn't make this point in anger. He just wants it to be clear. "I have strived mightily to make sure this week is not 'Bryant Goes to Africa,' " he added. "Because that's not what it is."
Anger is hardly what Bryant Gumbel said he is feeling these days anyway. A week and half before the Africa shows, Mr. Gumbel relaxed on the "Today" set in NBC's studio 3B on his hourlong break between the end of the program at 9 A.M. Eastern time and the new opening he and his co-host, Katie Couric, would do for the West Coast edition.
Mr. Gumbel has not changed much physically in recent years, though he wears his glasses more often on the air. He is still squarely built but surprisingly light on his feet. He still golfs avidly, and commutes to Manhattan daily (well before rush hour; his day begins around 4 A.M.) from the Westchester home he shares with his wife, June, son, Bradley, and daughter, Jillian.
Moving across the set to the main "Today" interview area, Mr. Gumbel talked comfortably about the trip, the program, his years as host, the two years remaining on his contract, and even the marathon he faced beginning the next morning, when he would serve as co-anchor for the "Today" show, do six hours of election-night coverage, and another "Today" show, all in 26 sleepless hours.
It could not have been easy to be comfortable, not sitting on the "Today" couch. Designed as it is to discourage relaxation -- and thus slouching -- the "Today" couch could double as a bench in a bus depot.
And after all, the show itself hasn't exactly been the most cushy place to recline. Upheaval, discord, convulsion and change have swept through "Today," with Mr. Gumbel in the middle of most of the action.
But now the program has rebounded, using its strength in hard-news coverage to charge back up in the last two months to the top of the Nielsen ratings for network morning shows.
"It's very satisfying that the Africa trip is coming at a time when we've got our house back in order," Mr. Gumbel said.
The days of disorder began three years ago in the wake of a much-publicized memo by Mr. Gumbel in which he evaluated, often harshly, many of the "Today" staff members. A serial drama involving Mr. Gumbel's co-hosts ensued, starting with the perils of Jane Pauley, followed by the short, unhappy morning life of Deborah Norville, and culminating in the glory days of Katie Couric.
The comeback for "Today" has been so convincing that a new storm with potential for further Drang -- a book, "Inside Today," by Judy Kessler, an ex-staff member, filled with aspersions on Mr. Gumbel's character, especially his alleged abuse of women -- blew over quickly last month. TV Guide splashed the book's charges over two issues, but it received little attention after that.
"I never even took the time to say anything about the people who were part of that story," Mr. Gumbel said. "I think most people recognized it for what it was: rantings that didn't have an awful lot of substance and not a bit of merit."
The charge that he is insensitive to women is an old one, and indeed some women formerly on the "Today" staff have been critical of him in the past. Ms. Pauley once called him a Neanderthal when it came to women, but she and other women who have worked on "Today" wrote responses to TV Guide supporting Mr. Gumbel. For the record, he said, his relations with the women on "Today" are fine.
He has his own ideas about why "Today" has rebounded lately, starting with his belief that it was never "that terribly broken anyway." The fix came, Mr. Gumbel said, in defining what the program does best -- news -- and having the discipline to stay within a news definition.
Of course, he acknowledged that it has helped to have an aggressive young executive producer in Jeff Zucker and a co-host who is spending a lot of her free time on magazine covers and being identified as one of "the intriguing people of the year."
"I kind of sit back amused by it all," Mr. Gumbel said of the frenzy of attention that has greeted Katie Couric. "It doesn't bother me. A few years ago I was one of the intriguing people. I've told Katie to go ahead and enjoy it because it isn't going to last. Pretty soon somebody else will be the flavor of the month."
On the set, he and Ms. Couric have the kind of respectful working relationship and camaraderie Mr. Gumbel clearly likes.
"We have a great time together," Mr. Gumbel said. "We yell at each other sometimes. We commiserate with each other a lot. We have a lot of the same interests and we have the same sense of humor."
A sports fan to his core, Mr. Gumbel sees the two of them in baseball terms, with him playing Goose Gossage to Ms. Couric's Ron Davis.
Those two men were pitchers with the New York Yankees more than a decade ago, with Gossage the star as a ferocious "closer," the man who finished off a game, while Davis was the "set-up" man, the guy who took care of the late innings so the closer could get the save.
"I had become a closer without a set-up man," Mr. Gumbel said, referring to the need for him to conduct every big interview on the program. "Instead of pitching one inning I had to pitch three. Does that take a toll and limit your effectiveness? I think it does."
But Ms. Couric's contribution can't be summed up completely by a reference to a few solid innings of work. "It's a fun place to come to work now," Mr. Gumbel said.
He had an unusual amount of fun last July while Ms. Couric was off doing the Olympics. Mr. Gumbel traveled -- accompanied by NBC News crews as well as 13-year-old Bradley -- to Africa to tape stories for the coverage that begins Friday.
It was the culmination of an enormous personal effort to research the continent and find stories that would be both informative enough and entertaining enough to make the week exciting for American viewers, and worth the cost for NBC.
The pieces range from news-oriented reports on economics and government to social-trend pieces, a study of the tourist industry and a lot about African wildlife. The programs will be broadcast from three locations in Zimbabwe, using the spectacular Victoria Falls as a backdrop twice.
Mr. Gumbel said he hoped the week would counter the "terrible images" most Americans have of Africa as mostly jungle with wild animals roaming around. "Africa is a land of 2,000 languages and great religious diversity," Mr. Gumbel said. "You'll find Africans who say they've never seen an animal outside a cage. Americans view Africa as this monolithic land, as if it were France."
The anachronistic images are a product mainly of ignorance, Mr. Gumbel said. "If you dismiss reports on either famine or apartheid, you'd be hard pressed to come up with an hour's worth of coverage on Africa in the past two years."
But he also admitted that he went to Africa with his insensitivities intact. "We were going to do a piece about the vanishing tribes of Africa," he said. "A young African asked me why we can talk about the struggle in Yugoslavia between ethnic cultures, and when we come to Africa we call them tribes."
Though Mr. Gumbel agreed that racism may be at the root of why American television viewers have not demanded more coverage of Africa, he added that African-Americans have not pushed the issue strongly themselves, a fact he tied to differences in accessibility to heritage.
"However strained someone of European background's lines of heritage may be, they at least have the possibility of straightening them out," he said. "By contrast, most African-Americans are descended from the blood of slaves. So even if I was of a mind to spend millions to trace my heritage, I probably couldn't. And until African-Americans are in a position that their own fate here is comfortable enough that it allows them to be concerned with people outside themselves, they're not going to be concerned with Africa."
Mr. Gumbel said he was not sure how much difference one week of television programs can make. "I don't want to say we're shining a light here," he said. "That would sound presumptuous. But I do hope we can at least build a small constituency."
Having accomplished his goal of helping "Today" re-establish its claim to the top of the morning in television, and finally seeing his desire to bring the program to Africa fulfilled, Mr. Gumbel may temporarily be out of goals. When he reflected on that, his face clouded over a bit.
"Are there great challenges for me?" he said. "Maybe when I'm done in Africa I'll stop and think about that, and maybe the answers I'll come up with aren't real terrific. When I used to do sports, I'd say I didn't envision myself saying 'Dodgers 3, Giants 2' my whole life. Now I don't know what to say about the future."
Then he brightened again. "But I'm not the least bit unhappy doing this job. Matter of fact, I'm really happy doing it."

HEADLINE: Russia's New Culture Begins to Emerge From Soviet Rubble

SERIES: The Arts in Russia -- Last of three articles: Up From the Underground

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IRKUTSK, Russia

 BODY:
It was still morning at the cramped studios of AIST-TV in Irkutsk, a park-filled city on the Angara River best known as a stop on the Trans-Siberian Railway and for its proximity to mighty Lake Baikal. The television station wouldn't even go on the air until 9 that night. Yet already producers and technicians were swarming about, tending to the shiny Japanese equipment and preparing programs for future broadcast.
AIST -- the call letters stand for Alternative Irkutsk Studio Television -- is one of hundreds of new, private television stations in Russia, and a leader among them: during the Russian coup of August 1991, AIST, which happened to have a crew in Moscow, was the only station in the country to telecast fresh images of the drama in the capital. Station officials almost arrested for their pains, an action halted by the local authorities and ultimately made moot by the failure of the coup. But that scoop helped make AIST-TV the most popular station by far in a region that spans vast tracts of south central Siberia. 
 Like most such stations, AIST broadcasts its share of third-rate American films obtained on the cheap from Moscow distributors who are often indifferent to quality and the niceties of international copyright conventions. And like most such stations, it does not yet own its own transmitter, having instead to buy time on a state channel.
 
Some Signs of Change
 But AIST is also a good example of the innovative tendrils pushing their way up through the debris of the collapsed Soviet system. It and other innovators, full of lively new ideas or attuned to survival in the new Russian world of faltering government support and erratic private sponsorship, offer hope for a renewal of Russian cultural life. And in the chaos and confusion of their efforts, they lend the Russian cultural scene an aura of unpredictable excitement that recalls Europe and the United States between the world wars.
There are many other examples of such innovation, ranging from big, long-established institutions like the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg to feisty provincial dreamers like the theater director Mikhail V. Bychkov in Voronezh and the modern dancer Yevgeny Panfilov in Perm to hustling vanguard entrepreneurs like the gallery director Oleg Kulik in Moscow.
The Avant-Garde Bunny Costumes
And Doomed Hogs
In late October in Moscow at the Shkola Gallery, which is normally devoted to photography, grown men in bunny costumes, complete with fluffy white ears and tails, led earnest art lovers through a garden environment, evoked by video monitors and gauzy drapes, all meant to suggest a "universal space of action."
Mr. Kulik and the Regina Gallery, seem particularly emblematic of the new Russian arts, not least because Mr. Kulik, who is Ukrainian-born, speaks so fervently about the need for a renewal rooted in Russian traditions. Of course, the renewal he actually represents is far from the stolid traditionalism of self-styled Russian conservatives.
"The Regina Gallery has set itself the task of forming new standards of reality," Mr. Kulik proclaimed. "Peter the Great, Rasputin, Stalin, they transformed reality. But the Soviets alienated the Soviet artist from reality, and Russian artists must reinvent it."
 
A Talent for Promotion
 Although he is himself a painter, Mr. Kulik's real talent would seem to lie in the organizing of exhibitions, and especially of the trendy openings, really performance art, that bring out Moscow's nouveau-riche beau monde. So boldly does he squeeze fellow artists' paintings and sculptures into his concepts that some have angrily withdrawn their work.
Examples of his openings include a ceremonial slaughtering of live pigs. "We wanted pain, screaming, blood," he explained cheerfully. That the slaughterers were licensed butchers did not assuage the animal-rights protesters out front, whose presence, to be sure, pleased Mr. Kulik enormously and insured live television coverage of the occasion.
In June, there was the opening in which 50 paintings were held for display by 100 bare arms reaching through holes in plasterboard walls. Or one with paintings swinging back and forth on ropes, threatening constantly to decapitate unwary art watchers. However much some of these ideas may recall Western happenings of the 1960's, they have served to make the Regina Gallery into a Moscow symbol of the very latest in artistic derring-do. This fall Regina activity is on hold while its fancy new downtown quarters are being renovated.
Some vanguard artistic activity in Russia today floats defiantly free of patronage both public and private. In Moscow, a performance artist and social organizer who calls himself Petlyura has holed up in an abandoned building with some 20 fellow anarchists. He has named his community Independent Territory, claims to rehabilitate outcasts through art and resists all efforts to oust him from his headquarters. A three-day Independent Territory party in late September attracted a wide range of the Moscow artistic underground.
 
Echoes of Warhol
 But the majority of the country's small-scale artistic innovators have more conventional forms of artistic communication in mind. Most speak to a new social class in Russia, one buoyed by the profits of nascent capitalism and eager to emulate a flamboyant Western life style they have until now only been able to view from afar. Videotapes of Regina openings look like historical film clips from Andy Warhol's Factory in Manhattan, minus some of the more extreme 60's fashion and makeup: a young, attractive social set with seemingly ample resources and a determination to make a splash in attire, conversation and sexual display.
Alla Sigalova, who has her own Moscow company in which actors untrained in dance perform modern-dance dramas, cuts a dashingly fashionable figure, the clothes stylish and impeccable in a way that looks French yet is enlivened by an inescapably Russian intensity. She calls her public "an elite audience."
 
The Bankrollers
Monied Gangsters And Other Angels
 The ostentation with which Russia's newly successful have flaunted their good fortune has aroused resentment. After 70 years of inculcation in the evils of capitalism, the average Russian, let alone the convinced Communist, finds it difficult to accept sudden new wealth as anything but criminal. Even when -- or especially when -- the wealth has been won by former Communists. Businesses, usually vaguely defined "stock companies" or "commodities exchanges" often partly owned by former Communists, are routinely called "mafia" whether or not they actually involve organized crime. Employees rationalize theft from store owners by their belief that the owners must somehow be stealing from the public.
Even if the term mafia is too loosely and broadly applied in Russia today, criminal behavior would scarcely seem an innovation born of capitalism. "Gangster money is hardly new in Russia," argued John Cripton of Satra Arts International, a Connecticut-based arts management firm that imports Russian companies to North America. "There was always money being paid under the table."
If artistic innovators speak to a new social class, they also survive by it. With national, regional and municipal governments struggling to sustain traditional institutions, the innovators must fall back on private sponsorship. Unless, of course, they resist it on principle and have the wherewithal to support that stance. AIST in Irkutsk has refused sponsorship since its first backer went bankrupt, surviving on commercials and side ventures.
 
The Importance of Sponsors
 The Regina Gallery is named for the wife of Vladimir Ovcharenko, a Moscow businessman and scene-maker who bankrolled the gallery with Michel Litvak, who is based in Paris but keeps an apartment in Moscow. Mr. Kulik said he liked Mr. Ovcharenko -- "the man has taste" -- and would dread trying to find a new sponsor. "When your wife walks out on you, you can ultimately find a new one, but it wouldn't be the same," he explained.
Miss Sigalova owes her company's existence to her sole sponsor, Anis Investment Inc., a stock company. She said hers was "a miraculous situation, not typical at all." When a sponsor suddenly reneges, as happened to Mr. Panfilov, local authorities may be sympathetic and offer short-term aid, but often the only solution is to suspend activities and regroup when money becomes available.
It is possible to come very close to actual commercial success in the arts. While many of the older state drama theaters seem locked in stale repertory, leaden acting and a financial miasma that forces them to rent out their buildings, newer directors have scored popular successes on the model of Broadway and the West End. Roman Viktyuk, for instance, has had hits at several Moscow theaters, and last spring took his version of "Two for the Seesaw," starring the former ballerina Natalia Makarova, to her hometown, St. Petersburg.
Mr. Viktyuk's seasonal opening in late October at the Mossovet Theater in downtown Moscow was an event. The production was his biggest hit from last season, David Henry Hwang's "M. Butterfly." The staging is full of flashy disco dancing, doubles for the title figure and riveting performances by the two central characters (the Butterfly, Erik Kurmangaliyev from Tadzhikistan, even manages a very creditable falsetto rendition of Puccini's "Un bel di").
 
A Russian Hit-Maker
 Mr. Viktyuk said that although his tickets cost 10 to 20 times the Moscow norm (but less than $1.50 at the current exchange rate), he needed sponsorship to break even. Still, his lavish productions of modern and classic Russian plays and Western hits almost always seem to sell out, and he is seeking his own permanent theater.
His actors, he said, are paid eight times the going rate at the state theaters, which naturally assures him his pick of the lot. He stages eight productions a year, four in Moscow and four in the West, and is negotiating with Circle in the Square to take Miss Makarova to New York in the spring in Turgenev's "Month in the Country."
Even this aggressive and successful theatrical innovator has his problems, however. Russia's refusal to adhere to international copyright conventions means that affordable rights to Western shows -- like Edward Albee's "Lolita," which Mr. Viktyuk opened on Nov. 1 -- are not easily available. His solution is to go ahead and produce the shows without permission and then to hope that their success will persuade Western authors to sell him the rights inexpensively and retroactively. The director said Mr. Hwang -- "a generous, kind man" -- did just that.
"Nothing has changed," Mr. Viktyuk intoned theatrically. "The same trenches, the same forests, the same guerrillas. The previous Government banned all foreign plays. Today's ruling powers are trickier. They don't pay and so nobody can stage them."
 
The Popular Arts
Western Influence, Russian Tradition
 In the overtly popular arts, while most of the old dissident rock bands like Brigada S complain about an onslaught of trivial pop music, clubs are opening and records are being sold. "It's still a small scene," said Garik Sukachev, the lead singer of Brigada S. "We all know one another, and there is lots of overlap with theater and film." Mr. Sukachev has acted in six films.
Even in the film industry, which seems particularly depressed, the odd film does get made, and not just in Moscow: a detective thriller and a comedy were produced and shot in Perm last year, and international film festivals still show the occasional Russian film, even if those films may not be widely distributed at home.
The new wave of Russian films is no longer obsessed with gloom and angst: showing in Moscow right now is a film by Vladimir Khotinenko called "Patriotic Comedy." It stars Sergei Makovyetsky, the other principal in Mr. Viktyuk's "M. Butterfly," and it has been called "optimistic and life-affirming."
Some artists manage to do innovative work within the old state system. Mr. Bychkov, who runs the Theater for Youth in Voronezh, has devised a style that blends painterly references (he often designs his own sets) and modernist music to enlivening effect. His adaptation of a Chekhov short story, "Rotshield's Violin," which he brought to Moscow this fall, aptly recalls Chagall's art and such folk fables of Igor Stravinsky as "Les Noces" or "Renard."
 
Innovations Become Dogma
 Much Russian performing art seems still indebted to the Russian tradition -- shaped by pioneers like Stanislavsky and Meyerhold and then hammered into Soviet dogma -- of psychological verisimilitude and broadly emotional expressionism. Mr. Panfilov, who leads the modern-dance company in Perm, has made contact with Western dancers, above all at the summer American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. He concedes openly that he is still finding his way, stylistically. Yet his work has a theatricality and an intensity that makes it very much part of the Russian tradition, for all its originality.
Russian tradition seems to fuel everyone from gallery owners to novelists to film makers to rock bands, which almost by definition ape Western models yet also struggle to retain some Russian identity in their lyrics and arrangements. It certainly fuels Russian folk groups, which Elvira Kunina, the director of the Russian Scientific and Methodical Folk Art Center, said were now being supported more generously than before, since Moscow no longer had to give equal time to the many ethnic cultures in the former Soviet republics.
 
Isolation's Amber
Soviet System Preserved a Past
 An inadvertent advantage of the political and economic isolation of the Soviet era was the artificial preservation of older forms of artistic organization and tradition. While critics in the West complain about a bland internationalization of film, ballet, concert life and operatic production styles, in Russia those arts have been maintained in sometimes splendid estate. What often looks dowdy can also seem preserved in a kind of innocent purity lost in the bustle of the modern Western world.
That is one reason even some of the grandest old state theaters can adapt successfully, as with the Kirov Opera, which toured to the Metropolitan Opera House this summer, along with the rather less well-received Kirov Ballet. Under the artistic direction of the conductor Valery Gergiyev, the Kirov Opera has infused historically important old productions with life, begun a needed revitalization of production styles and repertory and retained the loyalty of important singers and orchestral musicians. But its main value for the West is as an enlightened guardian of Russian operatic tradition.
 
A Penny Earned Is a Penny Kept
 Once a company like the Kirov catches on with the international press and public, it has little difficulty attracting Western sponsorship and recording and video contracts. Once it has those, it actually finds itself in a far better position than before, since hard currency earned abroad no longer has to be remitted to the central authorities.
Some arts leaders even suggest that the skimming off of top Russian artists by Western impresarios makes room for a talented younger generation that otherwise would either stagnate or be forced to emigrate. Given the depredations on Russian cultural life by the absence of so many great Russian artists, that seems close to wishful thinking.
In nearly every case, artistic distinction in Russia today -- or indeed accomplishment in any field -- can be traced to the talents and perseverance of one strong person. "You see that mess over there," said Mr. Gergiyev, pointing to a collapsed and abandoned construction site near the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg. "It's been there for years. All it would take would be one call from the head of the post office across the street -- if he were strong -- and that would be cleaned up in three days."
What remains palpable, right alongside the despair of so many Russian artists and arts administrators and the placid pride of the provinces, is an undercurrent of innovation and excitement, an excitement that, said Mr. Viktyuk, has not yet been dampened by the AIDS epidemic.
 
An Unfortunate Precedent
 As in the country itself, rapid change has brought displacement and despair, but also the possibility of heretofore undreamed achievement. To the extent that such ferment recalls Berlin and the Weimar Republic between the wars, it can be a cause for concern, given how that renaissance came to its end in 1933.
But optimism persists, certainly as an official tenet among President Boris N. Yeltsin's appointees, but also among those who prize the novelties all around them.
"I have no choice," said Mr. Sidorov, the Minister of Culture, who in perhaps typically Russian fashion managed to introduce the gloom of mortality into a credo of hope. "Culture is optimism itself. It is always the last to die; it will die only with human beings. So one cannot possibly be pessimistic."

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Cuomo Remains Bench Jockey of New York Racing

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
Officials of the New York Racing Association testified yesterday before the Governor's Commission on Racing in the 21st Century and made three proposals: Reduce the state tax on bets, cut six weeks off the winter racing season and allow the race tracks to take over off-track betting.
The proposals came in response to a call from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who created the commission in an attempt to recast the structure of racing in the state. The Governor's chief target was the association, the private nonprofit organization that is empowered to run racing at Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga until the year 2000. 
 The Governor, during a news conference in Albany later in the day that was unrelated to the commission hearings, indicated that his earlier confrontations with N.Y.R.A. had not ended. He did not respond to the proposals, but in a sharp attack on executives of the association he said that data from his commission showed that combined annual salaries and bonuses on the N.Y.R.A. were way too high, with the highest being the $261,000 for Gerard J. McKeon, the president of the association.
"These are not salaries we can afford to pay," he said. "This is an absurdity, and it's going to change. A lot of us are in the wrong line of work."
 
Speaking of Salaries
 The governor himself draws a $130,000 salary, $30,000 of which he returns to the state. Hazel Dukes, president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, is paid $104,500 in salary.
Earlier this year, Cuomo demanded that the N.Y.R.A. come up with $50 million through a sale of land to help balance the state budget. Under threat of an investigation and special legislation, the racing board relented and produced the money.
McKeon and Allan R. Dragone, the chairman of the association's board of trustees, attended the hearing, which was held in the Manhattan office of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. They appeared before Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development, and other members of Cuomo's commission.
"The state must rearrange its priorities," McKeon said. "It must put racing first. Since 1941, when parimutuel betting was made legal in New York State, you have overtaxed us. You have viewed us as a tax source."
McKeon outlined "three categories where we think the industry is in trouble."
"The first," he said, "is the institutional competition that is stifling the growth of racing: the six Offtrack Betting Corporations in the state that are marketing easy wagering. We think racing is a lot more than that. We propose to put OTB under the auspices of the race tracks, namely the N.Y.R.A."
The association's second proposal was to reduce the state's 17 percent "takeout" on bets.
"OTB even imposes a surcharge on bets," McKeon said. "Our takeout is the highest in the country. So we have difficulty attracting and retaining customers. New York will have to reduce its taxes on bets and give it to the players, the horsemen for purses and the tracks for capital improvement."
In the third major proposal, N.Y.R.A. called for an end to year-round racing.
"We operate perpetually," McKeon said. "The customer never gets a rest, and the quality of racing goes down in the winter. We suggest no racing from the beginning of January to the middle of February."

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 771 words

HEADLINE: Priorities, Priorities

 BODY:
Take a look at the list below. It includes only some of the promises President-elect Clinton made in his 13-month campaign. Many are sparklingly good and could, if carried out, make America a better, more productive country. But like politicians generally, he's offered something to everyone -- welfare mothers, high-tech entrepreneurs, chronically ill retirees -- and created frighteningly expensive expectations.
Mr. Clinton says he can institute his program while gradually cutting the deficit in half. It's a dubious proposition. Even if he could do that, he'd be reckless to try. By pushing too fast on too many fronts, Mr. Clinton would risk repeating Jimmy Carter's mortal error, drowning Congress in a sea of policies and insuring that he brings none to shore. 
 President-elect Clinton now needs to embrace priorities every bit as urgently as Candidate Clinton was quick to make promises. The task is to concentrate Congress's attention on the highest priorities and leave the rest for later.
Jobs and Investment. In the Presidential debate in St. Louis, Mr. Clinton said: ". . . my first priority would be to pass a jobs program, to introduce it on the first day I was inaugurated." He was right, then and now. The best way to jump-start the economy would be to accelerate his plan to invest $80 billion in infrastructure. Another way would be to pass a temporary tax credit for businesses willing to increase investment in plant and equipment. Accelerated spending and temporary tax cuts would be self-liquidating; Wall Street need not fear increasing long-term deficits.
Health Care. Responding to voter anxiety, Mr. Clinton put health care reform at the center of his campaign. His proposed answer -- managed competition -- is the best solution known for the dual challenge of too few people covered and too many billions spent.
Education and Training. What distinguished the Clinton program was its forward-looking emphasis on educating and training workers -- the surest ticket to vigorous growth. To fulfill this pledge, the President-elect could take the first steps toward apprenticeship training for non-college-bound students and on-the-job training for low-skilled workers.
Campaign Finance Reform. Mr. Clinton owes voters an overhaul of the political process, awash in corrupting campaign contributions, no matter what some wary advisers warn. The risks of disgusting the public outweigh the risks of irritating party leaders.
For all his promises, promises, if Mr. Clinton can advance these priorities he could rightly claim success, success.
 
PROMISES, PROMISES: BUT WHICH ONES?
Here are some Clinton campaign proposals that would have significant impact on the Federal budget.
 
Training and Education
 Impose a 1.5 percent payroll tax on large employers to finance training and education for low-skilled workers.
Increase Federal spending on education and training generally by $10 billion a year starting in 1993 and $20 billion a year by 1996.
Create a national service trust fund to give every American the right to borrow money for college
Guaranteed apprenticeships for half of all students not going to college.
 
Health Care
Create a new system of universal health care for all.
Extend Medicare to cover long-term care.
 
Infrastructure and Technology
 Inject $20 billion a year in transportation, communications and environment, to stimulate growth and to revitalize essential systems.
Create a civilian advanced technology agency.
Establish 170 manufacturing extension centers to help smaller businesses choose equipment and learn cutting-edge techniques.
 
Urban Development
Create 100 commnity development banks and 1000 micro-enterprise programs to help small businesses and revitalize communities.
Establish from 75 to 125 urban enterprise zones.
Increase community devlopment block grants.
 
Tax Cuts
Create a targeted investment tax credit.
Reduce personal income taxes for some number of middle Americans, costing $22 billion over four years.
Raise the earned income tax credit for the working poor.
Create tax incentives and credits for recycling and pollution reduction.
 
Crime
 Establish a Police Corps to train 10,000 new officers a year for ten years.
Help states create and operate boot camp prisons.
 
Social Policy
 Boost poor children by fully funding Head Start and the WIC health program
Make permanent the low-income housing tax credit.
 
International
Increase contributions to the World Bank.
Increase assistance to Russia.
Pay overdue U.S. dues to the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Why Increased Gasoline Prices Mean Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Unfair Shots at a Fair Tax," your Oct. 13 endorsement of Ross Perot's proposed gasoline tax of 50 cents a gallon only proves once again that some of the American people, and you with them, have a 10-minute memory. 
 Your back issues for 1978 and 1979, when the country was faced with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gas crisis, will show you that gasoline soared from 79 cents to $1.40 a gallon and thereby caused the greatest period of inflation in the 20th century. It took the failed Presidency of Jimmy Carter, the Presidency of Ronald Reagan and also the Presidency of George Bush to bring inflation and interest rates down.
If you look at some of the prices of the 70's you will understand that the $10,000 Cadillac of 1978 now costs $35,000. Better yet, the 39-cent can of tuna fish now costs $1.39, and that translates into a 356 percent increase over 14 years.
Nothing in this country moves without transportation of some kind, and it is all dependent upon gasoline or other fossil fuels. Raising gasoline prices is the biggest cause of inflation because every product large or small contains 20 percent or more of built-in transportation costs.
Figure it out for yourself. Wouldn't you have to raise the price of your newspaper 20 percent to account for it in the final tally? Wouldn't that be inflationary?
 
PAUL L. SHERMAN
East Brunswick, N.J., Oct. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Why Increased Gasoline Prices Mean Inflation;
Urban Aid and Yachts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "An Urban Aid Bill That Doesn't" (editorial, Oct. 26): While I don't disagree that as a response to the events of last April in Los Angeles, H.R. 11, the "urban aid bill," falls short of what our urban areas need, I must take exception to your condemnation of "tax breaks for yacht buyers" in the bill. 
 Unfortunately, any tax bill introduced in Congress is subject to having many items added to the original intent of the bill. This is the way the system is set up.
I have worked in the boating industry for 14 years. The 10 percent excise (luxury) tax on pleasure boats priced above $100,000 has all but wiped out more than 30,000 direct manufacturing jobs and countless more indirect industry jobs, while adding to the Federal budget deficit. The excise or luxury tax on boats has been costing every taxpayer money for almost two years because it costs more to collect than it brings in.
Several times in our history it has been proved that luxury taxes do not hit their intended target, yet Congress made the mistake of trying them again during the drawn-out budget process in the fall of 1990.
The boating industry has been crippled by the luxury tax, with sales of boats in the affected price range down about 80 percent. Why anyone would want to do anything to interrupt or alter the economic process that takes place when a person buys a large boat is beyond me. Boating may be one of the best methods to distribute wealth ever devised. Jobs are created, and money passes from those that have it to spend to those that need it. Even after purchase, the process continues for as long as the person owns the boat.
The boating industry has put forth in H.R. 11 a method for the Government to collect the revenue that was supposed to come from the luxury tax: diesel fuel sold to the boating public would be subject to a 20.1 cent a gallon tax effective next Jan. 1.
In defense of Senator George Mitchell, if there are subsidies to shipbuilders in Maine contained in H.R. 11, they are not going to those who build boats affected by the luxury tax.
 
RICHARD C. LOH
Old Greenwich, Conn., Oct. 26, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 6; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Why Increased Gasoline Prices Mean Inflation;
Fairness to Donors

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to "An Urban Aid Bill That Doesn't" (editorial, Oct. 26), the President should approve, not veto, the tax law Congress has passed. You overlook many positive features. 
 The new law would reverse the harmful measure in the 1986 tax law that denies charitable donors their full deduction on gifts of appreciated property. Such gifts transfer private assets to public benefit and represent a true loss for the donor. When universities, museums, hospitals and other not-for-profit organizations serving the public interest depend on increased private gifts to balance their budgets, this sensible reform should be approved.
The bill would also restore the access, lost in 1986, of independent universities to tax-exempt bond financing. Public universities continue to enjoy this help; private institutions should too. The new facilities and renovations it makes possible represent a fruitful and cost-effective investment for the public.
Further, if the bill is not signed into law, beneficiaries under expired provisions of the current law would suffer tax increases. For example, employees who receive tuition benefits would have to pay taxes on them. What could be more counterproductive than asking an employee who goes to school after work to pay more taxes solely because his or her employer is paying the tuition for that instruction?
While we too would like to see larger and more focused efforts on urban enterprise zones in the bill, we see no reason not to start with the first wave of overdue relief. This legislation is not a "budget buster," as you suggest, but revenue neutral: provisions decreasing Federal revenues by $27 billion over the next five years are paid for by compensating measures to replace the forgone revenues.
The need for the new law in its present form is urgent. It should be signed now.
 
JONATHAN F. FANTON, L. JAY OLIVA, FRANK H. T. RHODES,
MICHAEL I. SOVERN
New York, Oct. 29, 1992
 
The writers are the presidents of, respectively, the New School for Social Research, and New York, Cornell and Columbia Universities.
